title: Energy Harvesting in Solar-Powered UAV Communication With Rate Splitting Multiple Access
authors: Hosein Zarini, Maryam Farajzadeh Dehkordi, Mehdi Sookhak, Dusit Niyato, Ali Ghrayeb, Hussein Mouftah
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Future wireless networks are anticipated to evolve by aerial communication platforms. Nonetheless, the operational lifespan and efficacy of transceivers such as unmanned aerial vehicle (UAVs) and Internet of Things (IoT) devices are strictly prohibited by their constrained onboard power sources. This paper focuses on an aerial network configuration where a UAV harvests solar power to serve energy-limited IoT devices through simultaneous wireless information and power transfer. In this setup, the UAV and the IoT devices, each are equipped with energy and data buffers. This system also benefits from rate splitting multiple access for efficient interference management. Upon optimizing the system efficacy, we formulate a long-term resource allocation problem to maximize the time-averaged energy efficiency. To address this stochastic and non-convex optimization problem, we propose a multi-stage solution strategy. Firstly, by leveraging Lyapunov optimization theory, we transform the long-term stochastic problem into an equivalent deterministic short-term form. Next, by recasting this equivalent problem into Markov decision process, we propose a resource allocation mechanism based on actor-critic hindsight experience replay (AC-HER), tailored to capture the problem dynamics and optimize its variables. Moreover, given the UAV high mobility and the system reconfigurations, we fortify the trained AC-HER model with meta-learning strategy, enhancing its adaptability to system variations. Simulations verified that the proposed resource allocation strategy considerably outperforms its counterparts.

title: Your Model Is Unfair, Are You Even Aware? Inverse Relationship between Comprehension and Trust in Explainability Visualizations of Biased ML Models
authors: Zhanna Kaufman, Madeline Endres, Cindy Xiong Bearfield, Yuriy Brun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Systems relying on ML have become ubiquitous, but so has biased behavior within them. Research shows that bias significantly affects stakeholders' trust in systems and how they use them. Further, stakeholders of different backgrounds view and trust the same systems differently. Thus, how ML models' behavior is explained plays a key role in comprehension and trust. We survey explainability visualizations, creating a taxonomy of design characteristics. We conduct user studies to evaluate five state-of the-art visualization tools (LIME, SHAP, CP, Anchors, and ELI5) for model explainability, measuring how taxonomy characteristics affect comprehension, bias perception, and trust for non-expert ML users. Surprisingly, we find an inverse relationship between comprehension and trust: the better users understand the models, the less they trust them. We investigate the cause and find that this relationship is strongly mediated by bias perception: more comprehensible visualizations increase people's perception of bias, and increased bias perception reduces trust. We confirm this relationship is causal: Manipulating explainability visualizations to control comprehension, bias perception, and trust, we show that visualization design can significantly (p < 0.001) increase comprehension, increase perceived bias, and reduce trust. Conversely, reducing perceived model bias, either by improving model fairness or by adjusting visualization design, significantly increases trust even when comprehension remains high. Our work advances understanding of how comprehension affects trust and systematically investigates visualization's role in facilitating responsible ML applications.

title: Spectral-Guided Multiscale Feature-Aware Transformer for Hyperspectral Image Classification_supp1-3630239.pdf
authors: Songze Tang
publish: N/A
abstract: Transformer-based methods have recently shown remarkable success in hyperspectral image classification (HSIC). However, their applications, in practice, still face two significant challenges. First, although the multihead mechanism in self-attention improves model robustness during training, it may overlook the continuity of spectral bands. Second, existing methods often struggle to effectively balance global and local information during multiscale feature extraction, limiting further improvements in classification performance. To address these issues, we propose a novel spectral-guided multiscale feature-aware Transformer (SMFAT) framework for HSIC. Specifically, a global low-rank spectral learning (GLSL) module is introduced to project hyperspectral image patches into a low-rank subspace, reducing spectral redundancy and capturing global spectral correlations. Furthermore, we introduce the multiscale feature-aware self-attention (MFASA) mechanism, which dynamically integrates fine- and coarse-grained features to enhance multiscale feature modeling. Finally, a spectral-guided fusion (SGF) module leverages the global spectral information extracted by the GLSL module to guide MFASA in more effectively capturing interspectral correlations and spectral continuity. This approach facilitates a more effective integration of spectral and spatial features in HSIs. Experiments on three well-known HSI datasets verify that the proposed SMFAT method significantly outperforms several state-of-the-art approaches in real-world HSIC tasks. The source code for this work is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/stellaZ77/SMFAT</uri>

title: Cluster Head-Based Cooperative Communication System for Efficient Energy Consumption in Swarm UAVs
authors: Donghyeon Kim, Yoseb Lee, Sangoh Park
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Demand for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has surged across diverse domains. Because UAV systems are battery-powered, their available energy is limited, which in turn constrains transmit power and thus communication range. To mitigate these constraints, swarm UAVs—in which multiple UAVs cooperate to accomplish a mission—have attracted significant attention. In a swarm, multiple UAVs fly concurrently and perform tasks cooperatively; the operational area of each UAV is partitioned to minimize overlap. Consequently, swarms can systematically cover a wider area than a single UAV and increase mission throughput. However, in decentralized flying ad hoc network (FANET) environments, the large volume of UAV-to-UAV communications induces congestion, and mobility leads to high topological volatility, rendering links unstable. As a result, latency and packet loss may occur, making it difficult to guarantee quality of service (QoS). In centralized models proposed to address this issue, a cluster head manages communications. Because the cluster head consumes more energy than other UAVs, it has a shorter flight time. When the cluster head is replaced, the ensuing topology change degrades the overall network stability. To remedy the instability caused by rapid energy depletion of the cluster head, we propose a Cluster-Head-Based Cooperative Communications System (C3S) that leverages cooperative communications. C3S shares data with cooperative nodes and performs cooperative transmissions to reduce the energy consumption of the transmitting node, thereby balancing energy expenditure across cluster-head nodes and extending network lifetime. Moreover, C3S exploits temporal and spatial diversity gains to provide reliable communications at low transmit power.

title: Model-Based Design and Robust Control of a V-Shaped Tilt Bi-Rotor (Homma): From Modeling to Flight Validation
authors: Arshia Rezaei, Amin Talaeizadeh, Aria Alasty, Ali Moaveni, Alireza Bahmanyar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Multi-rotors have garnered significant attention in aerial robotics due to advances in versatile configurations and tilt mechanisms that enhance endurance, payload capacity, velocity, and agility. While these innovations improve energy efficiency and operational flexibility, they also introduce complex dynamics that challenge control design. Notable progress, such as the Gemini tilt bi-rotor, has refined bi-rotor architectures through extensive simulations and experimental validation. However, optimal configuration, accurate modeling, robust control frameworks, and practical implementation of tilt bi-rotors remain open research problems. This study proposes a model-based methodology for the design, modeling, and simulation of the Homma tilt bi-rotor, incorporating two distinct control strategies. A comprehensive dynamic and subsystem model is developed, accompanied by a trajectory-tracking control scheme, with Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) and Sliding Mode (SM) controllers carefully designed and optimized to match the system's inherent dynamics. Simulation results demonstrate that both controllers achieve high tracking accuracy, with SM exhibiting superior robustness in handling the complex dynamics of tilt bi-rotors. This research underscores the potential of tilt birotor configurations and establishes a resilient control framework for their performance optimization. By integrating Model-in-the- Loop (MIL) and Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) simulations with advanced flight control techniques, the study iteratively improves tilt bi-rotor performance through systematic controller development and rigorous flight testing.

title: Radio Channel Measurements and Modeling: Incorporating Reconfigurable Antennas Into Wireless Propagation Channels
authors: Cheng-Xiang Wang, Chenxuan Gu, Junling Li, Jie Huang, Ying Liu, Yunfei Chen
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: Reconfigurable antennas (RAs) have been a pivotal technology due to their ability to dynamically adjust parameters. This paper underscores the critical need for the radio channel modeling—defined as an integrated framework that captures the full signal transmission chain, encompassing wireless propagation channel characteristics, transmitter antenna parameters, and receiver antenna responses, while quantifying their intrinsic coupling. This stands in contrast to traditional channel models, which treat antennas as ideal transducers and focus solely on the propagation medium, often overlooking the impact of antenna parameters. A measurement framework, featuring a custom-designed 28/5.3 GHz RA with reconfigurable cross-polarization ratio, isolation level, and voltage standing wave ratio, is established. Results from outdoor and indoor measurement scenarios are presented. Experimental analyses reveal that the influence of isolation levels varies significantly, with indoor environments at 28 GHz showing stronger sensitivity to isolation levels compared to outdoor settings. The paper further discusses radio channel modeling methods, including circuit-based, field-based, and unified field-circuit approaches, emphasizing their roles in bridging information theory and electromagnetic physics. Finally, the study identifies the distinctions between traditional and general antenna designs.

title: Identification of Lightning Strikes to Towers Using Their Electric Field Signatures and a Machine Learning Approach
authors: Ziqin Ding, Si Chen, Hanbo Yang, Kang Yang, Vladimir A. Rakov, Joel B. Harley, Yanan Zhu, Istvan Kereszy
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Lightning often strikes tall (≥200 m) objects and poses significant threat to the infrastructure. Using the characteristic electric field signatures of the tower-terminated lightning, we developed a machine learning approach to identify strikes to towers in large lightning datasets. The ground-truth data were acquired at the Lightning Observatory in Gainesville (LOG), Florida. The classification model used in this study is based on supervised multi-layer perceptron model, aiming to capture complex pulse patterns with the neural network architecture. The results show that tower-terminated lightning and non-tower-terminated lightning can be accurately identified. We found that the model performance depends on the configuration of the training dataset. Using the Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME), we found that our machine learning model is capable of capturing the key features of electric field signatures produced by lightning strikes to tall towers.

title: Seismic denoising via multi-round SCU-Net
authors: Yuli Qi, Guoxin Chen, Jinxin Chen, Jun Li, Rongsen Du, Haiyang Lu, Naijian Wang, Xingguo Huang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: As oil and gas explorations progressively advance towards deeper and more complex geological formations, the imperative for precise characterization of subsurface structures has become increasingly prominent. The efficacy of noise suppression is a critical determinant for the quality of subsequent inversion and imaging processes. In recent years, deep learning methodologies have garnered significant attention and widespread application in seismic denoising, primarily due to their inherent data-driven advantages. While conventional deep learning implementations have achieved notable denoising performance, they are confronted with inherent limitations, including incomplete noise reduction and potential signal degradation. To address these challenges, this study proposes an innovative multi-round SCU-Net (MR-SCU) denoising approach. The MR-SCU methodology based on SCU-Net employs noise as labeled data to generate an initial denoised outcome in the first round. Denoising results are used as input while utilizing the residuals between the labeled and predicted data as labels for subsequent denoising round. Multiple rounds are iteratively repeated to achieve more thorough denoising effect while preserving effective signals from being compromised. The incorporation of SSIM (Structural Similarity Index Measure) as the loss function further enhances the method’s precision in detail-oriented denoising tasks. Numerical experiments conducted on synthetic data and field data acquired from a specific region in western China substantiate the efficacy of the MR-SCU, demonstrating its capability to deliver superior denoising performance while optimally preserve valuable seismic information.

title: Towards Power System Data Standardization: An Integrated Framework for Renewable Energy Generation Data Analytics
authors: Cengceng Wang, Peihua Jin, Longjun Zhang, Xiaoyu Wang, Yuelin Zou, Lirong Xie
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Addressing the challenges of multi-energy systems in data collection and integration — such as heterogeneity, spatial disparities, and temporal scale mismatches—this paper investigates the characterization and modeling of renewable energy generation data. First, by modeling the principles and output characteristics of wind and photovoltaic power generation, we analyze their nonlinearity, non-smoothness, and multi-scale properties. To address the difficulty of extracting actionable insights directly from raw data, we introduce signal decomposition techniques and propose a refined analytical method for wind power daily profiles based on K-means clustering and variational mode decomposition (VMD). The K-means algorithm clusters wind power data into typical daily profiles, while VMD decomposes the signals, with the modal number K optimized via average sample entropy to precisely extract structural features. Experimental results demonstrate that this method improves data interpretability and enhances prediction accuracy. This study not only advances standardized processing methods for renewable energy data but also contributes to the development of a holistic "source-grid-load" energy data framework.

title: A Threat Intelligence Enhanced Approach for Real-time Detection of Malicious Tor Traffic
authors: Wenxun Jiang, Yanqing Yang, Cengceng Wang, Lirong Xie
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Tor network malware detection faces critical challenges as 30.3% of active samples constitute grayware and 8.7% represent ransomware operations. Existing methods suffer from semantic disconnect between encrypted payloads and threat behaviors, computational bottlenecks preventing real-time deployment, and inability to adapt to zero-day attacks. This paper introduces a unified framework integrating four complementary technologies: (1) LLM-inspired behavioral tokenization for encrypted payload analysis, (2) TCN-based temporal modeling with multi-scale dilated convolutions, (3) few-shot learning for rapid threat adaptation, and (4) high-throughput stream processing architecture. Our semantic-temporal hybrid approach achieves 96.1% detection accuracy with sub-10ms response latency, while the prototypical learning framework demonstrates 89.7% accuracy on zero-day attacks using only 10 labeled examples per category. Comprehensive evaluation across six datasets including UNSW-NB15 and CIC-IoT23 validates consistent improvements: 95.3% average accuracy and 60% latency reduction compared to LSTM-based approaches. This research bridges theoretical deep learning advances with practical encrypted traffic analysis requirements.

title: FlameRAG-SHO: A Hybrid RAG and Bio-Inspired Optimisation Framework for Intelligent Wildfire Prediction Using Multi-Source Satellite Data
authors: Uma Maheswari V, Mallisetty Praveen Kumar, Anitha Patil, Vemula Venkata Sunil Kumar, Mallellu Sai Prashanth, Dhruba Jyoti Bora
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: In order to detect wildfires, environmental data must be monitored for early warning signals like temperature spikes, smoke, or gas emissions. To improve precision and reaction time, modern methods use AI algorithms, sensor networks, and satellite imagery. Reducing harm, preserving ecosystems, and guaranteeing public safety all depend on early detection. This study presents Flame RAG-SHO, an AI-powered architecture that integrates Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) with multi-source satellite data and the Spider-Tailed Horned Viper Optimisation (SHO) algorithm. It aims to tackle the pressing need for dependable early detection. In order for the model to learn complicated spatiotemporal wildfire patterns, it incorporates crucial features like Land Surface Temperature (LST), Normalised Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), humidity, wind speed, and soil moisture. To improve the model's contextual understanding, RAG retrieves pertinent historical and geographical data, and SHO optimises the model's hyper parameters for efficient and robust training. A full suite of performance metrics is used to assess the model. The results show that the model performs exceptionally well in terms of prediction, with metrics such as Accuracy-93.40%, Precision-91.78%, Recall-88.96%, F1 Score-90.35%, AUC-ROC-96.04%, and IoU-81.71%. Visualisation outputs such as area under the curve (AUC-ROC), principal component analysis (PR) curves, loss trend plots, and feature importance plots offer explanations and useful information. Early warning systems, environmental monitoring, and disaster response planning have great potential for the proposed Flame RAGSHO architecture, which provides a robust and interpretable solution for real-time wildfire risk prediction.

title: Optimizing Symbiotic Performance of the Cooperative NOMA-SR using Particle Swarm Optimization
authors: Hong Nguyen Thi, Tran Trung Duy, Trung Doan Van, Anh Le Thi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper investigates a novel green communication model by optimizing the symbiotic performance of the cooperative NOMA (Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access) communication model, integrating Symbiotic Radio technology with the support of an Energy Harvesting - Backscatter Device (EH-BD). In the proposed model, a Base Station (BS) transmits signals to NOMA users through a cluster of cooperative relays and EH-BD devices. EH-BD not only reflects signals to serve users but also harvests energy from the transmitted signals to maintain its operation. Furthermore, to enhance the system’s symbiotic performance, we apply the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm based on power allocation for each user. Simulation results reveal that the energy efficiency and data transmission rate are improved considerably under various channel conditions. Finally, such a model has great potential for green communication systems due to its utilization of energy harvesting and symbiotic performance optimization, reducing dependence on traditional energy sources while maintaining high data transmission rates.

title: No-Code Application Programming Interface Testing Platform – Atlas
authors: Emre Torun, Talha Eroğlu, Rıdvan Gülcü, Cihan Güler, Berat Çetin, Ceren Ulus, Nazlı Yusufoğlu, M. Fatih Akay
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: In today's software-driven world, Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) play a central role in enabling communication between different systems and services. To verify the functionality, reliability, and performance of these interfaces, testing procedures are carried out. Ensuring that API development and testing processes are conducted quickly, efficiently, and accurately is critical for delivering high-quality software services. The complex structure and limited features offered by existing API testing tools often reduces user experience and lead to time loss during the testing process. Moreover, these tools typically store test data on their own servers, posing a potential security risk by exposing sensitive and confidential company data. In this context, a need for a more comprehensive solution for API testing and management processes has emerged. No-code is an innovative approach that requires very little programming experience from the creator of an application, providing great convenience and time savings for developers. The aim of this study is to develop an API testing platform that addresses these needs while maximizing both security and functionality. To achieve this, a no-code API test platform called "Atlas" has been developed. The platform has been designed as a desktop solution using Electron, with the user interface builted in React. The back end utilized Node.js for automatic updates and version control, and Couchbase has been selected as the database. The platform provided a customizable framework that aligned with corporate requirements and demonstrated the effectiveness of creating codeless API testing. With the developed platform, it has reduced both cost and security-related risks.

title: Water Quality Assessment Model Based on Projection Pursuit and Multi-source Data Fusion
authors: Tingting Wang, Hongzhi Wang, Xuehui Lu, Zhenkun Gu, Tianhao Zhou, Cong Wang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To address the challenges posed by the nonlinearity and high dimensionality of sample data in water quality assessment in arid regions of Northwest China, this study proposes a comprehensive water quality evaluation framework based on Projection Pursuit (PP) theory. The framework incorporates a Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm to determine the optimal projection direction, thereby establishing a PSO-based projection pursuit model for integrated water quality assessment. Taking representative cross-sections of river basins in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region as the study area, a water quality evaluation system comprising nine key indicators was developed. This system enables effective dimensionality reduction and comprehensive analysis of multidimensional water quality data. When analyzing both comprehensive and individual evaluation indicators, the proposed model effectively distinguishes water quality conditions across different sections and quantifies the influence of each indicator on overall water quality. The case study demonstrates that the PSO-based projection pursuit model effectively addresses the issues of nonlinearity and high dimensionality in water quality assessment, showing strong applicability and potential for broader implementation in water quality evaluation across arid river basins in Northwest China.

title: Reliability Assessment of DC Solid-State Circuit Breaker with Snubber Circuit Based on Part Stress Analysis Using LSTM
authors: Jae-Hun Cha, Yun-Sik Jang, Sang-Hyeok Lee, Feel-soon Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This paper presents a reliability evaluation of a dc Solid-State Circuit Breaker (dc-SSCB) equipped with a snubber circuit, based on the FIDES 2022 failure library and the Parts Stress Analysis (PSA) methodology, utilizing a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network. To validate the performance, actual temperature data from Seoul, South Korea, was used. The system failure rates and reliability were analyzed using both the conventional failure rate method and LSTM-based predictions of operating temperature. Furthermore, the predicted temperatures were compared with actual measured values to assess the accuracy of the prediction model. The analysis results show that the LSTM-based approach predicts the system reliability to reach 0.5 after approximately 14 years of operation, which is about 12.5% lower than the result obtained using the conventional static method based on average failure rates. Moreover, when compared with the reliability evaluated using actual measured temperature data, the prediction error of the LSTM-based approach was found to be less than 1%, demonstrating high accuracy. These findings indicate that incorporating time-varying thermal stress information enables more precise and realistic reliability assessments that closely reflect actual operating conditions.

title: Efficient Phase Noise Compensation Technique for FMCW LiDAR Sensors with Simplified Complexity

title: Attention-based multimodal feature fusion visual question answering
authors: Qi Zou, Shixuan Zhang, Hongyan Yang, Huisheng Ma
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA), an emerging interdisciplinary field bridging computer vision and natural language processing, has garnered substantial attention for its challenges in multimodal reasoning. Central to advancing VQA systems is the seamless alignment of cross-modal representations derived from visual inputs and linguistic queries. We demonstrate that integrating structured visual relationship modeling with adaptive attention mechanisms enables hierarchical fusion of cross-modal features. To this end, we propose a lightweight architecture that captures multi-order dependencies among visual entities through sparse graph computations. We develop a dynamically parameterized bilinear attention mechanism that performs language-conditioned feature recalibration, enhancing semantic specificity in visual representations. Our framework jointly processes visual and textual inputs through parallel relational reasoning and attention pathways, enabling cross-modal feature integration for precise answer inference.

title: Quantum-Enhanced Zero-Knowledge Proofs for zk Rollup Security in Web3 Ecosystem
authors: Niketa Yadav, Gaurav Indra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: With the emergence of quantum computing, traditional cryptographic methods used in blockchain systems face increasing risk. One such area of concern is the Layer-2 protocols zk-Rollups designed to improve scalability and privacy in platforms like Ethereum, which are heavily dependent on classical zero-knowledge proofs such as zk-SNARKs and zk-STARKs. These systems may be compromised by quantum algorithms. To address this, we propose a quantum-secure zk-Rollup model using Quantum Zero-Knowledge Proofs (QZKPs), implemented with IBM’s Qiskit simulator. The protocol uses quantum features like superposition and random basis selection to verify transactions without leaking private data. Simulation results confirm key properties: valid proofs are reliably accepted, while invalid ones are rejected. This demonstrates both the feasibility and future relevance of integrating QZKPs into blockchain systems for post-quantum security.

title: A Practical Identification of Parameters for a DC Motor by Recurrent Neural Networks
authors: Rodrigo Sánchez-Zavala, Dulce Martinez-Peon, Enrique Alvaro-Mendoza, Mariela Flores-Martínez, Rene Sanjuan Galindo, Gerardo Maximiliano Mendez
publish: 2025 Latin American Robotics Symposium (LARS)
abstract: Direct current motors are used in robotics, industrial process automation, and electric traction systems, among other applications, due to their high starting torque and dynamic response. However, although the second-order mathematical model is well known, parameter identification is required for each motor, both because the physical characteristics vary among motors and because these parameters change over time. Once the parameters are obtained, a control can be applied. This work presents the identification of six parameters for a DC motor using recurrent neural networks. The implemented mathematical model uses measurable system data, including current, input voltage, and angular velocity, to estimate electrical resistance, inductance, electromagnetic torque, viscous friction, and inertia. These estimations were validated through simulations and comparison with measured data. The results showed that the parameters were estimated with 99% accuracy.

title: Robust Adaptive Kalman Filtering with Dynamic Learning for UAV Altitude Estimation
authors: Longxin Wei, Jin Shi, Kit Guan Lim, Min Keng Tan, Hou Pin Yoong, Kenneth Tze Kin Teo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This paper presents a ground altitude estimation algorithm for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) based on the fusion of low-cost Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) and barometric sensors. A robust adaptive filtering algorithm based on prediction residuals is proposed. By constructing a state vector containing altitude and velocity, the algorithm adaptively adjusts the noise covariance matrices according to the prediction residuals. An adaptive learning factor is then introduced to regulate the weighting between predicted and observed values, improving estimation accuracy. Compared to the Kalman Filter (KF) method, the proposed algorithm does not require precise prior covariance information and achieves faster responsiveness with lower estimation latency. The proposed algorithm was evaluated against complementary filtering (CF), Kalman filtering (KF), and unscented Kalman filtering (UKF) methods using experimental UAV flight data. Under identical initialization parameters, it achieved a 9.2%-13.2% reduction in altitude estimation RMSE compared to these classical algorithms.

title: Two Port Dual Band Half Mode Substrate Integrated Waveguide (HMSIW) MIMO Antenna for Sub-6GHz and WLAN Applications
authors: V Shiva Prasad Nayak, Manjunathachari K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: A compact 2-port (1 × 2) Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) antenna for sub-6 GHz 5G applications is described in this paper. The proposed antenna has components in a Half-Mode Substrate Integrated Waveguide (HMSIW) configuration and is based on Substrate Integrated Waveguide (SIW) technology. The antenna, with dimensions 28.4 × 52 × 1.67 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and is constructed on a FR-4 substrate, operates in 2 distinct frequency ranges: 3.51–3.59 GHz and 4.37–4.5 GHz. CST Studio Suite was applied to assess metrics for performance. With matching -10 dB bandwidths of 80 MHz and 130 MHz, the antenna achieves its resonance frequencies of 3.55 GHz and 4.44 GHz. Throughout its operating bands, it achieves port isolation of less than -15 dB and keeps the Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR) below 2:1. The suggested antenna is an appropriate choice for deployment in modern 5G communication systems, based on the simulation findings, which display an attractive radiation pattern and gain.

title: Digital Twins Beyond C-Band Using GNPy
authors: Andrea D'Amico
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: GNPy advancements enable accurate and efficient modeling of multiband optical networks for digital twin applications. The developed solvers for Kerr nonlinearity and SRS have been validated through simulation and experimentally in C+L transmission, supporting real-world network planning, design, and performance optimization across disaggregated optical infrastructures.

title: FPVcar: An Affordable Robotic Platform to Support Computer Vision Education, from Hardware Design to User-Friendly Programming
authors: Julia G. Matos, Dener V. Ribeiro, Celso O. Barcelos, Raieni R. Da Cunha, Pablo M. Paula, Vitor O. Koch, Osney N. Matos, Michel M. Silva
publish: 2025 Latin American Robotics Symposium (LARS)
abstract: Computer Vision focuses on techniques to enable computers to extract and interpret information from the environment based on data from sensors, primarily through cameras. Currently, there is an abundant application of this field in autonomous or assistive mobile robotics. With a great practical appeal, robotics presents potential to aid in educational fields, including Computer Vision, by providing engaging hands-on learning. However, the use of robotics as a didactic tool is hindered by the price of robotic kits and the need of using proprietary software that requires a long learning curve. Additionally, it is necessary to have knowledge of low-level concepts such as motor control techniques, hardware assembly, and low-level coding. Therefore, this study aims to present a robotic system intended to serve as a tool that allows teachers and students to apply concepts in a practical, engaging and, most importantly, cost-effective manner. The solution features a camera-based robot platform and a high-level library, which encapsulates the communication with the robot and provides the user with the ability to control it through simple commands. The data, 3D models, and codes are publicly available at: https: //github.com/MaVILab-UFV/FPVCar_LARS-2025.

title: Two incipient fault detection methods: comparison and further analysis
authors: Hongquan Ji
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Statistical process monitoring has made great progress in the past several decades, with a wide application to process industries. Recently, two novel methods were proposed to achieve incipient fault detection for industrial systems with stationary observations. In the present work, these two methods are first briefly revisited. They are compared with each other in theory, revealing a fact that the two methods accomplish incipient fault detection from different perspectives. Furthermore, two mechanisms involved respectively within these two methods are integrated systematically, leading to a novel algorithm, which possesses further enhanced detectability for incipient faults. Besides, the fault isolation aspect for these methods is discussed. Finally, simulations on a numerical example are carried out to demonstrate the monitoring performance intuitively.

title: A Study on Non-invasive Blood Glucose Monitoring using Terahertz Spectroscopy
authors: Kirankumar Manivannan, Sandra Saji, Dedeepya Penumaka
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Diabetes mellitus is a high-risk metabolic disorder which occurs due to high glucose levels in blood. IDF Diabetes Atlas stated that 10.5% of the adult population around the world suffers with Diabetes, Type 1 and Type 2. Some long-term complications namely cardiovascular diseases, neuropathy and retinopathy etc. can be controlled with the help of continuous blood glucose monitoring. Currently, followed methods like finger-stick blood sampling are invasive and uncomfortable. They might lead to infections too. This leads to the need for non-invasive method. The aim of this study is to explore a particular non-invasive method, Terahertz Time-Domain Spectroscopy (THz-TDS).

title: Optimal Symbol Rate for Discrete Nonlinear Frequency Division Multiplexing Transmissions
authors: Chuang Xu, Jingchuan Wang, Alan Pak Tao Lau
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: By analyzing the noise power dependence on symbol rate in the discrete eigenvalue transmission, the optimal symbol rate the minimizes the noise power is analytically found to be low, and the possible gain of advanced equalization algorithm is characterized.

title: Nonlinear Mitigation for Coherent Optical DAC Transmitter
authors: Tong Ye, Ke Zhang, Xiaofei Su, Jingnan Li, Shinsuke Tanaka, Yohei Sobu, Motoyuki Nishizawa, Hisao Nakashima, Takeshi Hoshida, Zhenning Tao
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a behaviour model to characterize nonlinearity in coherent optical DAC transmitters. Bit-segment mapping mitigates nonlinearity using model-predicted SNRs. Experiments show interactions among mapping criteria, segment imbalance, and receiver DSP, achieving >1 d B Q improvement via interaction-aware mitigation compared to interaction-anonymous one. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Efficient Uncooled High-Power $1.31 \ \mu\text{m}$ DFB Laser Diode for Co-Packaged Optics
authors: M.S. Buyalo, S.V. Poltavtsev, V.V. Belykh, V.S. Mikhrin, A.V. Zhabotinskii, S.S. Mikhrin, A.E. Gubenko, A. R. Kovsh
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We report on O-band InAs/GaAs QD DFB laser with integrated SOA section, able to deliver more than 400 mW optical power with efficiency beyond 20% in 25-85 °C temperature range. This laser is perfectly suited for uncooled operation in ELS for CPO.

title: Remaining Useful Life Prediction of Rolling Bearings Based on Full-Band Feature Feedback Adaptive Fusion
authors: Lei Jiang, Jianfei Zheng, Xinyi Cheng, Lihao Yang, Xi Chen, Qihui Han
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Rolling bearings are critical components in mechanical systems, and accurately estimating their Remaining Useful Life (RUL) is essential for ensuring reliability and minimizing maintenance costs. However, current prediction approaches make limited use of frequency-domain features and often overlook the integration of prediction outcomes in feature fusion. To overcome these limitations, this study introduces an RUL prediction framework that leverages full-frequency-band degradation feature extraction combined with adaptive feedback-based fusion. First, a 1/3 binary tree filtering strategy is used to perform multi-scale decomposition of the vibration signals, and the Wasserstein distance (WD) is employed to extract full-frequency-band degradation features. Next, a dynamic feedback mechanism is introduced to adaptively adjust Health Indicators (HI). Experimental results on the XJTU-SY dataset confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Why Dark Nuns Split Audiences: A Sentiment Analysis of Hype vs Disappoinment Using BERT NLP
authors: Bryan Yang, Kevin Gunawan, Christian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This paper analyzes shifts in audience sentiment regarding the Indonesian horror film Dark Nuns by studying user comments on TikTok before and after the film's release. A sentiment classifier based on Indonesian RoBERTa was employed to process and track shifts in 2,700 user comments. The sentiment analysis showed that premature marketing and star-centric promotions fostered predominantly positive and neutral sentiments, suggesting cautious optimism and anticipated hype. In contrast, release period comments showed a significant spike in negative sentiment, demonstrating pervasive disenchantment due to a disconnect between expectations and the film's narrative style execution. The research highlights the marketing enigma where promotional activities disconnect with reception, revealing the friction between content strategies tailored to audience expectations within the starkly horror genre, famous for its suspenseful pacing. This study develops a sentiment analysis film framework while providing admonition to filmmakers and marketers concerned with perception management given technological acceleration and paradigm shifts.

title: Diagnosis-Aware Active Learning Based on Uncertainty Metrics
authors: Guoao Ning, Zhixing Wei, Xin Wang, Huai Li, Qin Zhao, Yu Ding
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The healthy operation of electromechanical system products is closely related to the safety of aircraft, and accurate fault diagnosis is one of the key core technologies in order to ensure their high availability, high mission safety and reliability. However, the low and unbalanced failure rate of aircraft electromechanical products leads to the challenges of scarce samples and the high cost of data annotation for fault diagnosis. To address this question, this study proposes a diagnosis-aware active learning (DAAL) method based on uncertainty metrics, introduces an active learning strategy, trains the ranker to capture the diagnostic uncertainty of unlabelled samples by designing the ranking loss and embedding it in a hidden code, and perceives the diagnostic information by using a task-independent active learning model, so as to filter out the unlabelled data that are both informative and high-impact in terms of diagnostic uncertainty metrics, finally achieving efficient data labelling.

title: Proactive Sensing of Environmental Events Through Optical Data Networks: a Path to Intelligent Resilience
authors: Cecilia Clivati, Simone Donadello, Filippo Levi, Davide Calonico, Renato Ambrosone, Rossella Centonze, Federico Notarstefano, Emanuele Virgillito, Aladino Govoni, Lucia Margheriti, Maurizio Vassallo, Andrè Herrero, Sergio Bontempi, Daniele Loiacono, Stefano Straullu, Antonino Nespola, Marianna Hovsepyan, Francesco Carpentieri, Vittorio Curri
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Fiber sensing holds potential for global environmental monitoring and cable supervision, provided that compatibility with conventional network architectures and ability to localize and interpret events autonomously are demonstrated. We show our progress on these aspects, based on years-long fiber sensing data analysis in real environments. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Data Lake Validation Strategies: Ensuring Quality in Data Warehousing Pipelines
authors: Savya Sachi, Ravi Kiran Pagidi, Shilesh Karunakaran, Sarvesh Kumar Gupta, Suraj Dharmapuram, Om Goel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The most recent trend is storing vast quantities of raw and unstructured data. Nonetheless, this still places enormous challenges on the quality and reliability of the data in these lakes to support data warehousing pipelines. Any inaccurate, incomplete, or outdated data used in business analytics can produce incorrect insights and decisions, resulting in potential losses for organizations. So, it is essential to enforce data quality and make sure data warehousing pipelines are operating to their best by introducing data lake validation best practices. A critical approach that is often used is data profiling, where we analyze the data to detect patterns, relationships, and anomalies. This is the main reason why it is always a good practice to review the data first since this enables data engineers to gather information about the nature of the data and see its quality. Moreover, data can be cleaned by using techniques to find and correct errors in data, such as missing data or inconsistencies. The reason is that this step allows for the cleansing of data and ultimately ensures that downstream data processing can be done accurately.

title: Enhanced SOH Estimation for Electric Vehicle Power Batteries Considering Climate Variations and Driving Habits
authors: Mengfei Wen, Shilong Zhuo, Yu Jiang, Yun Zhou, Heng Li
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Accurate and efficient state of health (SOH) estimation for electric vehicle power batteries is crucial for timely maintenance and facilitating battery reuse. This study proposes a precise and computationally efficient SOH estimation method based on four years of operational data from nine electric vehicles. First, battery interval capacity is estimated from charging segments in the raw dataset to generate SOH labels. Then, 15 candidate features encompassing battery characteristics, driving habits, and climate conditions are extracted, with 12 selected for SOH estimation. Finally, seven machine learning models are evaluated, with LightGBM chosen as the optimal model for mapping features to SOH. Cross-validation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an MAE of 2% in SOH estimation.

title: Attention Enhancement and Multi-Norm Constraints Based Adversarial Attack for Motor Fault Diagnosis Model
authors: Chao Yang, Liang Huang, Tao Peng, Kefan Yao, Chunhua Yang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a adversarial attack method for traction motor fault diagnosis model - Attention Enhancement and Multi-Norm Constrained Adversarial Sample Generation Network (AEMNC-ASGN). AEMNC-ASGN focuses on solving the problem of low attack success rate under perturbation concealment constraints in time series data attacks. Firstly, the SE attention mechanism is embedded in the generator to learn the key perturbation regions. Secondly, dual-discriminator co-architecture of SEResNet and ResNeXt50 is constructed in the discriminator, and the generator is guided to mine the cross-model common blind spots to enhance the adversarial sample aggressiveness. Thirdly, the composite loss function of the proposed L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>−L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>−L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> norms is integrated into the loss function to constrain the perturbation strength to enhance the concealment of the adversarial sample. Comparative simulations on a traction motor fault diagnosis model show that the adversarial samples generated by AEMNC-ASGN significantly enhance the attack efficacy under the perturbation amplitude constraints compared to the existing methods.

title: QoT Impairments Induced by Statistical Filtering Variations with a Realistic Equalizer
authors: Enrico Miotto, Andrea Rosso, Emanuele Virgillito, Stefano Straullu, Andrea Castoldi, Andrea Bovio, Francisco Martinez Rodriguez, Vittorio Curri
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We analyze filtering penalty in ASE-impaired optical links, including transceiver noise effects. A mathematical model for FSE equalization is validated via time-domain simulation and exploited to perform Monte Carlo analyses, incorporating stochastic variations in optical filters' bandwidth and central frequency.

title: Grade Prediction Using Transfer Learning Methods on Meningioma Brain Tumor Images
authors: Kaan Gümele, Talha Karahan, Mustafa Umut Etli, Gonca Gül Öndüç, Muhammet Sinan Başarslan
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Meningiomas are a significant subgroup of central nervous system tumors, so accurate grading is essential for clinical decision-making. This study developed a deep learning–based artificial intelligence (AI) model that can predict the grade level of meningiomas non-invasively using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data. The model was trained on the Google Colab platform and various convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures, such as Xception, ResNet50, InceptionV3, DenseNet121, MobileNet and EfficientNetB0, were compared using an 80:20 training:testing split. Regularization techniques were employed during the training process to prevent overfitting. The Xception architecture achieved the highest accuracy (Acc) (98.83%) and F1 (98.82%). The developed model is integrated with a web-based user interface that enables physicians to upload MRI images and quickly obtain predictions in a user-friendly manner. This study contributes to improving patient comfort and enhancing the efficiency of healthcare services by supporting diagnostic processes with non-invasive AI solutions.

title: A Comprehensive Review of COVID-19 Detection Methods: Cough Sounds, Clinical Symptoms, Chest X-Rays, and CT Imaging
authors: Kolluru Venkata Nagendra, Revanth Madamala, C. Madhusudhana Rao, Naga Lalitha Sree Thatavarthi, Avinash Bhetalam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic required the fast creation of accurate and scalable tools that can regulate the transmission of the virus and enhance patient outcomes. The paper is a thorough comparison of four common methods of detection which include a cough sound analysis, clinical evaluation of symptoms, a chest X-ray, and a computed tomography (CT) scan. The modalities are compared based on the diagnostic accuracy, their availability, and deployability to the resource limited settings. The improvement in artificial intelligence and machine learning allowed a meaningful extraction of acoustics and visually based biomarkers, particularly in cough and CT-based diagnostics. The widespread use of symptom checkers and imaging methods still faces problems in obtaining an accurate diagnosis, standardizing data and data collection ethically. The review also notes the recent advances in deep learning architecture such as COVID-CTNet and COVNet and recommends a way forward to combine multi-modal diagnostic approach. This chapter sums up limitations that need to be overcome at the moment along with the most important directions of the future studies related to COVID-19 detection.

title: Predictive Modelling of Type 2 Diabetes via Glucose-Insulin Interactions Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Nor Azlan Othman, Mohd Hussaini Abbas, Sarah Addyani Shamsuddin, Nor Salwa Damanhuri, Mastura Mohd Sopian, Belinda Chong Chiew Meng, Samsul Setumin, Nur Sa’adah Muhamad Sauki, J. Geoffrey Chase
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: A metabolic disorder, Type 2 Diabetes (T2D), where the human body unable to utilize and store glucose properly, results from chronically increased blood glucose (BG) levels. In particular, human body has a limited ability to generate enough insulin in order to control the BG levels and ensure homeostasis due to increased insulin resistance and/or reduced pancreatic secretion. Insulin Sensitivity (SI) is a glycaemic control biomarker indicating increased insulin resistance via lower values. This study uses a machine learning (ML) classification technique to generate insight in linking a SI with BG performance in T2D individuals. The main objective is to develop a machine learning program to make an early prediction for T2D by linking SI with BG level. An artificial neural network (ANN) is employed with a Levenberg-Marquardt (LM) training model and data from a series of Dynamics Insulin Sensitivity and Secretion Test (DISST) results. The correlation of SI as well as BG results achieved 88.89% accuracy in predicting a T2D patient compared to a non-diagnosed individual. The SI value calculated from DISST model is comparable with the HOMA model. This method and resulting ANN model can be used to help predict patient condition more accurately.

title: Vision-Guided Radar System for Wireless Reading and Identification of 3D-Printed Microfluidic Sensors
authors: Ali Hadj Djilani, Dominique Henry, Patrick Pons, Hervé Aubert
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents a passive depolarizing and microfluidic sensor which was fully 3D printed from selective laser fusion additive manufacturing technology. The sensor includes a microfluidic channel filled with liquid metal (Galinstan) to measure the temperature. Experimental validation was performed by using a vision-guided radar system. The monolithic sensor demonstrated a maximum sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.6 ~\text{dB}/\text{mm}$</tex> and a full-scale dynamic range of 15.1 dB in cross-polarization, showing significant improvement over previously reported version of the sensor based on multiple pieces. Additionally, interrogation of multiple sensors was achieved using color-coded labels for sensors identification.

title: An On-Chip Dual-Tone Source for Photonic-Based Terahertz Transmitters
authors: Shima Rajabali, Xinrui Zhu, Hana K. Warner, Yunxiang Song, Leticia Magalhaes, Amirhassan Shams Ansari, Marko Lončar
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We report a dual-tone source on thin-film lithium niobate for generating a tunable carrier frequency in the terahertz domain. The system achieves a stable carrier above 100 GHz, with sub-KHz linewidth and tunability over 5 GHz, offering a compact solution for integrated terahertz photonic systems.

title: Performance Analysis of Different Classification Algorithms in Land Use and Land Cover using Landsat-8 Satellite Imagery
authors: Nancy Hoodaa, Sartajvir Singh, Paurav Goel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: It is the comparative study of three algorithms based on machine learning approaches RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Classification and Regression Tree (CART)) in Landsat 8 satellite imagery to classify Land Use and Land Cover (LULC) in a chosen area. All the classifiers were assessed using overall accuracy, Kappa coefficient, and the class-level evaluation measuressuch as precision, recall, and the F1-score. The outcome shows that the Random Forest algorithm has the highest accuracy (87.5%) and good Kappa (0.777), and the results indicate that the algorithm has excellent classification results in all the classes of land cover and especially the Urban and Water classes. SVM showed competitive performance with more agreement (Kappa: 0.787) and unmatched accuracy exhibited in Urban regions whereas CART performed poorly with less accuracy (70.8%) and a major error of misclassification between Water and Vegetation classes. The results validate that Random Forest istruly the best and dependable classifier of LULC mapping in dissimilar landscapes

title: Smart Cane for the Visually Impaired: Enhancing Navigation, Safety, and Emergency Response
authors: Leong Kah Meng, Irene Kong Cheh Lin, Ng Khai Le, Chan Bun Seng, Tan Tian Swee, Matthias Tiong Foh Thye, Jahanzeb Sheikh, Makun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: In Malaysia, blindness and visual impairment are still severe problems, with 180,000 blind persons and more than half a million are suffering from moderate to severe visual impairments. In response to these challenges, an innovative smart cane has been proposed, developed, and tested. The cane has built-in obstacle detection, and a fall detection system with auto-emergency notification alert and GPS for navigational assistance. A user-friendly mobile application is designed and it is connected to the cane via Bluetooth. The mobile application is created with Kodular and it allows simple interaction using swipe and tap gestures and includes text-to-speech option. It also supports customizable fonts and high contrast visual themes. Users can locate facilities such as toilets or bus stops through the app, improving independence, equality, and sense of security. The cane consists of a fall detector that employs Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) sensors, which trigger GPS navigation and WhatsApp based emergency notifications through Bluetooth to emergency contacts. The emergency button on the cane can be manually pressed and it produces an alarming sound and grabs attention of the surrounding people to the users. Therefore, the proposed cane and app can gain independency, support security, and achieve SDG Goal 3 to enhance good health, well-being and SDG Goal 10 to reduce inequalities.

title: Optical Access Networks - An Operator View from Past to Future System-Technologies and Applications
authors: Dezhi Zhang, Ming Jiang, Dekun Liu, Derek Nesset, LuYao Huang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: This paper systematically reviews the evolution, standard development, application scenario expansion, and system capability improvement of GPON, 10G-PON, and 50G-PON from the perspective of carriers, and looks forward to the future development trend.

title: Compact Slotted Cavity-Back Antenna with Wideband Circular Polarization for UHF RFID Readers
authors: Juan Huerta-Ruescas, Miguel Ferrando-Rocher, Miguel Ferrando-Bataller, Toni Barberá-Pastor, Denislav Popov, Manolo Reguart
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This communication presents the design and comprehensive evaluation of an RFID reader antenna tailored for UHF applications (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$868-915 \text{MHz}$</tex>). The proposed design incorporates a metallic rectangular cavity, two arc-shaped planar feeding elements, and an annular slot extruded on the upper surface of the cavity. By combining these elements, the antenna achieves an operational bandwidth of 11.4 % and directivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8. 1 3 ~ d B i}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 6 8 ~ M H z}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8. 4 9 ~ d B i}$</tex> at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1 5 ~ M H z}$</tex>. Moreover, the antenna consistently maintains an axial ratio below 1.6 dB at both frequencies, ensuring excellent circular polarization performance. The radiation pattern's -3 dB beamwidth exceeds 71°, which provides a wide coverage area suitable for complex communication environments. These performance characteristics demonstrate that the proposed antenna design is highly effective for enhancing the reliability and efficiency of RFID systems in various industrial and logistics applications.

title: LLMs for Embodied Robotics: A comparative analysis on augmentation methods between an embedded AI computer and consumer-grade hardware for Autonomous Navigation
authors: Andrés Sarellano Acevedo, Ivan Eric Diaz Arenas, Valeria Enriquez Limón, Guillermo Montemayor Marroquín, Abraham de Jesus Maldonado Mata, Luis Alberto Muñoz Ubando
publish: 2025 Latin American Robotics Symposium (LARS)
abstract: Large Language Model (LLM) Augmentation methods have introduced the capability of employing Agentic AI systems in Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) for autonomous navigation purposes. Such systems typically are implemented using cloud-based computing and are not exposed to the hardware limitations that embodied robotics suffers from. For this reason, we present a comparative analysis on augmentation methods for a real-time Agentic AI systems for AVs. In particular we: (1) evaluated the real-time feasibility of employing a single-board AI embedded computer for LLMs against consumer-graded hardware and (2) compared the accuracy of multiple LLM responses on spatial queries following two different augmentation methods, i.e., Retrieval-Augmented Memory for Embodied Robots (ReMEmbR) and Cache Augmented Generation (CAG). Our tests indicated that the Jetson Orin AGX embedded computer was incapable of generating real-time performance for position related queries, and the consumer-graded hardware demonstrated that models with a higher number of parameters seemed to improve precision when using CAG as the augmentation method.

title: A Hybrid Genetic Algorithm for Multi-Satellite Mission Planning Problem
authors: Yaowei Bian, Yajie Ma, Bin Jiang, Xuan Lyu, Wenbo Li, Chengrui Liu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The traditional genetic algorithm tends to fall into local optimality when solving large scale satellite mission planning problem, which makes it difficult to attain better planning results. The improvement of the algorithm's optimization search capability for higher gains in satellite observation missions is of great research interest. In this paper, a new hybrid genetic algorithm is proposed for the comprehensive optimization of the multi-objective satellite mission planning problem to maximize the satellite observation gain while minimizing the energy consumption of the satellites. An integer coding method is designed in the algorithm for the characteristics of satellite mission planning. The algorithm adopts a hybrid initialization method to improve the quality of the initial population while maintaining the diversity of the initial population. The adaptive genetic variation method and simulated annealing elite selection strategy are used in the evolutionary process of the algorithm. The combination of the global optimality-seeking ability of the genetic algorithm and the local optimality-seeking ability of the simulated annealing algorithm improves the optimality-seeking ability; the possibility of the algorithm falling into a local optimum is reduced by the adaptive mutation strategy. Finally, the effectiveness and superiority of the hybrid genetic algorithm is verified through experiments.
