title: Three-Dimensional Coordinate Positioning Approach Based on Hypersonic Vehicle-Borne SAR with Spiral Trajectory
authors: Zixuan He, Chenghao Jiang, Shiyang Tang, Zhanye Chen, Ping Guo, Xintian Zhang, Yifan Wang, Wangwang Du, Jiahao Han, Yuchen Luan, Linrang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Compared with conventional synthetic aperture radar (SAR) systems, hypersonic vehicle-borne (HSV) SAR with a spiral trajectory offers unique advantages, including high maneuverability, large detection range, and diverse observation views, enabling precise three-dimensional (3-D) SAR coordinate positioning. However, the high maneuverability of the spiral trajectory poses significant challenges, such as model mismatch, image defocusing, and positioning algorithm failures. To address these challenges, a geometric vector model of HSV SAR with a spiral trajectory is established, and the corresponding signal and trajectory characteristics are analyzed. Subsequently, the 3-D coordinate positioning approach based on HSV SAR with spiral trajectory is proposed. The proposed method achieves target positioning via two-dimensional (2-D) multi-view imaging, SAR target matching, and 3-D coordinate calculation. This method is relatively novel and provides superior imaging and positioning performance. Simulation, real data, and semi-real data experiments are given to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Active Circulator GaN Front-Ends With Integrated Tunable Cancellers for Multifunction Phased Arrays
authors: Kenneth E. Kolodziej, Laila Marzall, Zoya Popović
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Multifunction phased array radar can add in-band full-duplex (IBFD) technology to eliminate the blind range that prevents it from detecting nearby objects. These advanced systems require unique front-end circuits to suppress the resulting self-interference (SI) and provide transmit-to-receive isolation. This article presents two active circulator monolithic microwave integrated circuits (MMICs) that contain integrated tunable cancellers with one and two canceller sections. The chips were fabricated in gallium nitride (GaN) and operate between 2.5 and 3.2 GHz. In addition to enabling an antenna to be shared between transmit and receive, they uniquely provide transmit and receive gains greater than 10 up to 20 dBm of transmit power output and roughly a 7-dB noise figure, as well as tunable transmit-to-receive isolation of more than 50 dB. The active circulator is also evaluated with a radar chirp waveform and, when combined with a subsequent digital cancellation filter, suppresses the SI by a total of 70 dB, within 1 dB of the receiver noise floor.

title: A Stable Locality-Aware Task Scheduling Mechanism for Mobile Edge Computing With Workflow Task Offloading
authors: Yuee Zhou, Lianbo Ma, Ying Qian, Min Huang, Fei Hao, Xingwei Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Services Computing
abstract: Offloading a plethora of end workflows to edge servers in mobile edge computing (MEC) systems involves a series of coupled decision-making steps, including how much edge resources will be allocated for each workflow, which subtasks will be offloaded, and how to determine edge-end transaction prices to ensure system stability. Particularly, these decisions must jointly account for workflow characteristics, the resources available at each edge server, as well as local constraints (e.g., communication distance, task latency, and bandwidth conditions), which again increases the difficulty of optimizing the problem. However, no existing study addresses such joint optimization problems for these tightly coupled decisions. To fill this gap, a minimum-delay workflow partitioning algorithm is first designed to determine the optimal task offloading solution under various resource conditions. Based on this algorithm, two locality-based social welfare maximization models (basic and dynamic) are constructed. Specifically, for basic model, a multi-stage task matching game with the second lowest cost strategy is developed to determine the resource selection and pricing. For the dynamic model with uncertain requests, an online learning algorithm is introduced to track the dynamic valuations of mobile devices and to ensure that the resulting task allocation solution achieves an upper-bounded regret. Strict theoretical analysis demonstrates that our mechanism guarantees individual rationality, Nash Equilibrium, and stable approximation ratio. Simulation results verify the effectiveness and efficiency of our mechanism, and show that the proposed mechanisms obtain at most 18% higher social welfare than existing studies.

title: Reliable Federated Multi-View Learning for Heterogeneous Information Fusion in Mobile Edge Computing
authors: Daoyuan Li, Zuyuan Yang, Jiawen Kang, Zehui Xiong, Dusit Niyato, Shengli Xie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The rising data demands of generative AI models, such as large language models (LLMs), underscore the value of utilizing edge device data in mobile computing, where federated learning (FL) provides a privacy-preserving approach via decentralized model training. To address data heterogeneity across edge devices, federated multi-view learning (FedMVL) has been proposed to improve global model performance by capturing consistency and complementarity among diverse data views. However, existing methods often assume ideal conditions and neglect data uncertainty in mobile edge devices environments. To overcome these challenges, we propose Federated Reliable Multi-view Classification (FedRMVL), a vertical FedMVL framework incorporates Subjective Logic for lightweight uncertainty quantification at local edge devices and applies the Dempster-Shafer combination rule for adaptive and reliable multi-view opinion fusion at the server. Additionally, a partial parameter-sharing strategy is introduced to address feature dimension heterogeneity during federated optimization. The effectiveness and robustness of FedRMVL are validated through theoretical analysis and extensive experiments on real-world datasets.

title: Non-contact Sleep Apnea-Hypopnea Syndrome Detection Using Variational Mode Decomposition-based Respiratory Signals and Deep Neural Networks
authors: Saman Faridsoltani, Zahra Rahmani, Somayyeh Chamaani, Fatemeh Kashaninasab, Mahboobeh Khoozan, Mir Farhad Ghalebandi, Mansour Vali
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Sleep Apnea-Hypopnea Syndrome (SAHS) is a common sleep disorder that impacts quality of life and often goes undiagnosed. The gold-standard for SAHS detection, polysomnography (PSG), is expensive and inconvenient for long-term monitoring. As a result, research has increasingly shifted toward alternative approaches, such as radar sensors. Feature extraction is crucial for SAHS detection using radar-based respiratory signals. It relies not only on the expertise of specialists and their prior knowledge of respiratory patterns, but also on the methodologies used to extract respiration from the radar. This study presents an automated feature extraction method that utilizes radar respiratory signals processed through variational mode decomposition (VMD) to better preserve the morphological structure of breathing patterns, followed by a hybrid convolutional neural network (CNN)-Transformer for classifying SAHS events from normal segments. Then, the apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) is applied to discriminate SAHS subjects from healthy ones. Our study involved 20 PSG recordings and IR-UWB radar data across all sleeping positions. The proposed method achieved per-segment classification accuracy of 93.85% (88.28%), sensitivity of 87.86% (75.52%), specificity of 93.97% (95.74%), F1-score of 90.6% (82.62%), and Cohen’s kappa of 0.763 (0.724) using leave-one-out cross-validation for two (thee)-class classifications. AHI estimation analysis showed a strong correlation between the estimated and reference AHI, with a Pearson’s correlation coefficient of 0.996. In addition, SAHS diagnosis achieved an average accuracy of 98.33% and a Cohen’s kappa of 0.96 for AHI thresholds of ≥5, 15, and 30 events/h.

title: TVG-SLAM: Robust Gaussian Splatting SLAM with Tri-view Geometric Constraints
authors: Zhen Tan, Xieyuanli Chen, Lei Feng, Yangbing Ge, Shuaifeng Zhi, Jiaxiong Liu, Dewen Hu
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Recent advances in 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) have enabled RGB-only SLAM systems to achieve high-fidelity scene representation. However, the heavy reliance of existing systems on photometric rendering loss for camera tracking undermines their robustness, especially in unbounded outdoor environments with severe viewpoint and illumination changes. To address these challenges, we propose TVG-SLAM, a robust RGB-only 3DGS SLAM system that leverages a novel tri-view geometry paradigm to ensure consistent tracking and high-quality mapping. We establish temporally consistent tri-view correspondences to enable three core contributions. First, Hybrid Geometric Constraints combine geometric cues (trifocal and 3D alignment) with photometric supervision, ensuring stable pose estimation when illumination shifts cause rendering inconsistencies. Second, TUGI estimates uncertainty from multi-view 3D geometric consistency-capturing cross-view stability rather than pairwise 2D matching confidence-to guide principled Gaussian initialization. Third, DART adaptively attenuates photometric trust when rendering degrades, allowing geometric priors to govern optimization. Experiments on multiple public outdoor datasets show that TVG-SLAM outperforms prior RGB-only 3DGS-based SLAM systems. Notably, in the most challenging dataset, our method reduces the average ATE by 69.0% while achieving state-of-the-art rendering quality.

title: COMET: A Dual Swashplate Autonomous Coaxial Bi-copter AAV with High-Maneuverability and Long-Endurance
authors: Shuai Wang, Xiaoming Tang, Junning Liang, Haowen Zheng, Biyu Ye, Zhaofeng Liu, Fei Gao, Ximin Lyu
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Coaxial bi-copter autonomous aerial vehicles (AAVs) have garnered attention due to their potential for improved rotor system efficiency and compact form factor. However, balancing efficiency, maneuverability, and compactness in coaxial bi-copter systems remains a key design challenge, limiting their practical deployment. This letter introduces COMET, a coaxial bi-copter AAV platform featuring a dual swashplate mechanism. The coaxial bi-copter system's efficiency and compactness are optimized through bench tests, and the whole prototype's efficiency and robustness under varying payload conditions are verified through flight endurance experiments. The maneuverability performance of the system is evaluated in comprehensive trajectory tracking tests. The results indicate that the dual swashplate configuration enhances tracking performance and improves flight efficiency compared to the single swashplate alternative. Successful autonomous flight trials across various scenarios verify COMET's potential for real-world applications.

title: Higher-Order Dynamic Modeling and Robust Optimization of Fully Decoupled MEMS Gyroscope with Fabrication Errors
authors: Zeyuan Dong, Jian Zhao, Baolin Zhao, Pengbo Liu, Guofen Xie, Hao Zhou
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: The fully decoupled configuration integrating high-aspect-ratio flexible beams and proof masses is a widely adopted design in Microelectromechanical System (MEMS) vibratory gyroscopes. However, such structures are extremely sensitive to microfabrication errors, particularly beam width deviations. To address this issue, this paper proposes a high-order nonlinear dynamic modeling method and a robust optimization strategy for fully decoupled MEMS gyroscopes, explicitly accounting for microfabrication errors. Nonlinear stiffness expressions are derived for double-folded beams, V-shaped coupling beams, and composite beams, and a high-order dynamic model is established incorporating both geometric and electrostatic nonlinearities. Theoretical natural frequencies agree well with finite element simulations, with deviations below 3.3%. Assuming all beam width deviations are normally distributed, the direct probability integration method (DPIM) is used to quantify gyroscope performance uncertainties in mechanical sensitivity and quadrature output. Robust optimization is conducted using beam structural parameters and drive voltage as design variables, aiming to improve sensitivity while minimizing deviations in sensitivity and quadrature output. The optimized gyroscope structure demonstrates strong robustness against beam width deviations, achieving a 3.75 times improvement in sensitivity and a 31% reduction in quadrature output. The 1σ standard deviation of sensitivity and quadrature output is significantly reduced by 78.1% and 40.2%, respectively, effectively suppressing the impact of fabrication errors on device performance.

title: Establishing Reality-Virtuality Interconnections in Urban Digital Twins for Superior Intelligent Road Inspection and Simulation
authors: Yikang Zhang, Chuang-Wei Liu, Jiahang Li, Yingbing Chen, Jie Cheng, Rui Fan
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Road inspection is crucial for maintaining road serviceability and ensuring traffic safety, as road defects gradually develop and compromise functionality. Traditional inspection methods, which rely on manual evaluations, are labor-intensive, costly, and time-consuming. While data-driven approaches are gaining traction, the scarcity and spatial sparsity of real-world road defects present significant challenges in acquiring high-quality datasets. Existing simulators designed to generate detailed synthetic driving scenes, however, lack models for road defects. Moreover, advanced driving tasks that involve interactions with road surfaces, such as planning and control in defective areas, remain underexplored. To address these limitations, we propose a multi-modal sensor platform integrated with an urban digital twin (UDT) system for intelligent road inspection. First, hierarchical road models are constructed from real-world driving data collected using vehicle-mounted sensors, resulting in highly detailed representations of road defect structures and surface elevations. Next, digital road twins are generated to create simulation environments for comprehensive analysis and evaluation of algorithm performance. These scenarios are then imported into a simulator to facilitate both data acquisition and physical simulation. Experimental results demonstrate that driving tasks, including perception and decision-making, benefit significantly from the high-fidelity road defect scenes generated by our system.

title: Fixed-Time Active Fault-Tolerant Tracking Control of an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle with Sensor Faults and Stochastic Disturbances
authors: Chanyuan Ma, Yujiang Zhong, Ping Li, Zhizhong Liu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper investigates a fixed-time active fault-tolerant tracking issue for unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). Firstly, a nonsingular fixed-time fuzzy tracking control algorithm is proposed, enabling robust tracking performance. Building upon this algorithm, an adaptive controller is designed for the UAV system subject to stochastic disturbances, which are modeled as a standard Wiener processes. Unlike traditional control strategies, the proposed controller can effectively avoid the singularity of the control input. In addition, a Radial Basis Function Neural Network (RBFNN) is employed to approximate unknown nonlinearities. Meanwhile, the controller can guarantee the boundness of all system states in probability within afixed-time, independent of initial conditions. Futhermore, To address sensor faults, a robust three-step unscented Kalman filter (RTS-UKF) is utilized for fault detection and estimation. The estimated fault signals are structurally embedded into the control law, forming a closed-loop fault compensation mechanism. Finally, simulation is conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Bidirectional transfer-based fault diagnosis network for planetary gearboxes
authors: Haifeng Li, Ke Zhang, Shijie Wei, Delin Wang, Rui Huang, Jiaxi Zhang, Weilong Qin, Xinyu Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In industrial intelligent fault diagnosis, the method based on unsupervised domain adaptation can effectively reduce domain differences and transfer transferable knowledge to the target domain. However, the current adaptive methods in the field still face the problems of overfitting and underfitting. Aiming at the above challenges, this paper proposes a domain adaptive method for two-domain cooperative confrontation. In this method, two domain discriminators are introduced, and the feature extractor can be forced to extract features that deceive both discriminators at the same time through adversarial game, and the network can be induced to extract higher-quality domain invariant features.

title: A Topology-Driven CNN Framework for Stock Price Prediction Using News Sentiment and Market Dynamics
authors: Abdul Kadar Muhammad Masum, Md. Fokrul Islam Khan, Faisal Md Rahman, Chanda Rani Debi, Regina Connolly, Md. Abul Kalam Azad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Stock price prediction remains a challenging task due to the volatile and non-linear behavior of financial markets, especially in emerging economies like Bangladesh. Existing models often fail to integrate both temporal patterns and structural features, limiting their predictive power. This study proposes a hybrid deep learning framework called TDACNN, which combines Topological Data Analysis (TDA) with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to enhance prediction accuracy. The model utilizes rolling window inputs from stock price sequences, daily sentiment scores derived from financial news, and macroeconomic indicators including DSEX and DS30 indices from the Dhaka Stock Exchange (DSE). TDA features capture statistical trends across sliding windows, while CNN layers extract short-term local patterns. Optuna-based hyperparameter tuning is employed to optimize model configuration. The model is evaluated using data from five DSE-listed companies and compared with traditional and deep learning baselines such as BiLSTM, BiGRU, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machines. The experimental results show that TDACNN achieves better performance with lower MAE and MSE values and a higher R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score. This work demonstrates the advantage of combining topological and temporal features for improved stock prediction in emerging market environments.

title: Multiplicative Watermarking for Replay Attack Detection in Distributed DC Microgrids
authors: Jun Shi, Yuchen Jiang, Xinmin Zhang, Hao Wang, Hao Luo
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In distributed energy systems and networked control systems, the integration of communication layers increases vulnerability to cyber-attacks, which can lead to severe operational consequences. Watermarking has emerged as a prominent solution for detecting cyber-attacks. This paper investigates a multiplicative watermarking scheme based on sensor output to address replay attacks in distributed DC microgrids. The proposed scheme employs a pair of finite impulse response (FIR) filters to encrypt and decrypt the sensor output, integrated with unknown-input observers (UIO) for attack detection. Theoretical analysis demonstrates how the multiplicative watermarking enhances the observer’s ability to detect attacks by amplifying residual signals. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through simulations on a four-area DC microgrid system.

title: Broadband Athermal Silicon Nitride Microring Resonators with Improved Stability
authors: Wenbo Zhu, Xinyu Zhou, Jingyuan Ji, Xiaoyan Zhou, Lin Zhang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We report a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Si}_{3} \mathrm{N}_{4}-\text{TiO}_{2}$</tex> hybrid microring resonator with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SiO}_{2}$</tex> cladding, achieving athermal performance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<0.6 \text{pm} / \mathrm{K}$</tex> over 1510-1590 nm and an intrinsic quality factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.6 \times 10^{5}$</tex>. The proposed devices maintain their athermal feature, while noticeable performance degradation is found for uncoated devices after three weeks.

title: OCR AND NER Based Generic Medicine Recommendation System
authors: Kaustubh Gaikwad, Shubhangi Kharche, Rupali More, Sheetal Kadam, Supriya Bobade, Paurnima Patil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Access to healthcare in developing regions is often hindered by the high cost of branded medications and a lack of awareness regarding affordable generic alternatives. Our research presents a pioneering solution utilizing deep learning and natural language processing to transform prescription analysis. Through a custom-trained Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and four state-of-the-art OCR engines (TrOCR, EasyOCR, Tesseract, PaddleOCR), we achieved over 98% accuracy in interpreting handwritten prescriptions. Post extraction, the text is processed using named entity recognition and fuzzy string matching to identify medication names from a dataset of over 21,700 brand-generic mappings. Preprocessing through adaptive thresholding and noise reduction enhances precision. Our approach minimizes manual effort and errors, promoting increased awareness of generics and improving digital healthcare accessibility. By merging digital healthcare innovation with medication affordability, our scalable framework offers significant improvements in healthcare inclusivity and cost-effectiveness, benefiting patients and providers globally.

title: Logical Numerical Modeling of Battery Energy Storage Systems for Modern Power Grid Integrations
authors: Bappaditta Saha Chowdhury, Md Shahin Alam
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: In this era of growing dependence on renewable energy sources (RESs), such as photovoltaic (PV) and wind turbines, ensuring power grid stability has become a critical challenge. RESs are beneficial as a clean and affordable energy option, but they are uncertain in terms of constant power. Solar panels may be less effective at dusk, wind turbines may be slow on one day with no wind, but the electricity demand always persists. Battery energy storage systems (BESSs) come here in as silent but efficient balance keepers between generation and load. BESS stores extra energy when supply is high, especially when renewables are available, and releases it when demand goes up, which helps reduce energy prices and makes renewable integration more stable. This paper presents a logical-numerical model of BESS developed using MATLAB/Simulink, which provides a simple yet effective framework for BESS modeling charge-discharge activities. This model is built of modular parts, including a charge-discharge controller, power conversion system, and battery unit, all of which are designed for uncomplicated analysis and adjustment. Using simulated scenarios such as peak shaving, load shifting, and load leveling, this model proves that it can be used to smooth energy bills and improve productivity. By establishing a low-barrier system for feasibility analysis, this approach helps planners and academics to integrate clean energy sources and handle modern grid demands more efficiently.

title: DMT vs PAM: An Experimental Comparison Over VCSEL-MMF Links for Intra-Datacenter Connections
authors: A. M. Rosa Brusin, F. Aquilino, D. Pilori, A. Nespola, F. Forghieri, A. Carena
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: DMT and PAM4 formats are experimentally compared over VCSEL-MMF links targeting rates >100 Gbps. The tight adaptability of DMT to the frequency-selective channel supports its adoption in the next-generation high-speed intra-datcenter connections.

title: A Web-Based Image Segmentation Tool for Educational Purposes Using Java
authors: Vladimir Hristov, Martin Doichev, Aykut Ismailov, Dimitar Pepedzhiev
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This paper presents the development and evaluation of a Java-based web application designed to facilitate image segmentation education. The application provides a user-friendly web interface, allowing students to upload images and explore various segmentation algorithms, including K-means clustering and GrabCut. The system is built using Spring Boot for the backend, Thymeleaf for dynamic HTML rendering, and OpenCV (accessed through JavaCPP) for efficient image processing. Functional testing demonstrates the stability and reliability of the application and offers a comprehensive platform, accessible through a modern web browser, supporting a broad spectrum of computer vision concepts. Quantitative evaluations were conducted to measure the accuracy, performance, and stability of the segmentation algorithms, providing valuable insight into the tool's efficacy in an educational context. The results suggest that the tool achieves a reasonable balance between segmentation accuracy, computational resources and ease of use, representing a valuable starting point for students who seek an effective introduction to image processing techniques.

title: The Impact of Digitalization on Operational Efficiency in Ports: A Case Study of Borusan Port
authors: Altan Konuk, Ibrahim Çil, K. Alper Konuk
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study highlights the contributions of digital transformation to operational processes and sectoral development in port operations. Digitalization has been found to yield significant outcomes in terms of accelerating processes, strengthening occupational safety, improving operational efficiency, and enhancing coordination among stakeholders. The case analysis conducted at Borusan Port, supported by field data and literature, demonstrates that digitalization not only improves operational efficiency but also provides strategic advantages. In conclusion, digital transformation offers ports not only operational benefits but also competitive advantages. This study contributes to the engineering management and logistics literature and serves as a reference for future smart port applications.

title: AI-Driven Computational Materials Science for Advanced Energy Materials Development
authors: Paula Marielle Ababao, Ian Benitez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into computational materials science (CMS) has introduced powerful approaches for accelerating the discovery and optimization of advanced energy materials. As energy demands shift toward renewable systems, the development of efficient materials for batteries, fuel cells, and electrocatalysts becomes increasingly critical. This paper systematically reviews recent AI methodologies applied within CMS, particularly those leveraging density functional theory (DFT), molecular dynamics (MD), and kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) simulations. Emphasis is placed on the use of machine learning (ML) models, including supervised learning, deep learning, and hybrid strategies for property prediction, structure optimization, and inverse design. The review categorizes current applications across key energy technologies and discusses how AI is reshaping material screening and development pipelines. It concludes with an outlook on future directions, highlighting the need for standardized datasets, interpretable models, and physics-informed frameworks to improve predictive accuracy and facilitate AI adoption in practical materials research.

title: In-Field Demonstration of Multi-Tech Sensing on Terrestrial Optical Data Network using State Of Polarization and Phase Monitoring
authors: Emanuele Viroillito, Federico Notarstefano, Rossella Centonze, Rudi Bratovich, Raffaele Corsin, Andre Herrero, Aladino Govoni, Marianna Hovsepvan, Francesco Carpentieri, Simone Donadello, Cecilia Clivati, Vittorio Curri
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We implement a multi-tecnnique seismic observatory on a live optical link in central Italy, using phase and state-of-polarization sensing coexisting with data traffic. Combining diverse fiber sensing and traditional tools enables turning telecom infrastructure into a resilient smart grid for interpreting complex and heterogeneous events. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Fault warning model of wind turbine pitch system based on BiGRU and multi-attention mechanism
authors: Kai Sun, Bingpeng Gao, Xin Cai, Huabin Han
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Aiming at the issue of difficulty in effectively warning of faults in the pitch system of wind turbines, which affects the operational efficiency and reliability of wind power equipment under complex weather conditions, this study proposes a fault warning model combining Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BiGRU) and multi-head attention mechanism. By extracting key feature variables and utilizing BiGRU to learn the characteristics of SCADA data from wind turbines, the proposed model’s ability to capture feature information is enhanced. Additionally, the introduction of Cycle Network (CycleNet) and Crown Porcupine Optimization (CPO) algorithm optimizes the model’s prediction capabilities. The research results indicate that this model can effectively improve the accuracy of fault prediction in wind turbines, achieve fault warning, reduce downtime, and lower maintenance costs.

title: Yellowfin Tuna Meat Grading Using Computer Vision and k-Nearest Neighbors Algorithm
authors: May S. Demabildo, Jamie Eduardo C. Rosal, Archangelo D. Alegado, Daryl Ivan E. Hisola, Alan B. Alejandrino, Rommel V. Recla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This study presents a computer vision system for grading yellowfin tuna meat using the k-nearest neighbors (k-NN) algorithm. The system utilizes a studio-type light box and a high-definition camera connected to a computer, capturing images under consistent lighting conditions. Image processing techniques were applied to extract color and texture features, which were then used to train the k-NN classifier. The system was evaluated using classification metrics derived from the confusion matrix, achieving an overall accuracy of 80.77%. The developed setup demonstrates effective classification performance while maintaining low computational resource usage, making it suitable for real-time deployment in resource-constrained environments.

title: End-to-End AI for Distributed Fiber Optics Sensing: Eliminating Intermediate Processing via Raw Data Learning
authors: Zhuocheng Jiang, Yue Tian, Yuheng Chen, Yangmin Ding, Sarper Ozharar, Ting Wang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: For the first time, we present an end-to-end AI framework for data analysis in distributed fiber optic sensing. The proposed model eliminates the need for optical phase computation and outperforms traditional data processing pipelines, achieving over 96% recognition accuracy on a diverse acoustic dataset.

title: Real-World Anomaly Detection in Surveillance Videos A Review
authors: Ishika Singhal, Komal Saxena, Navita Mahajan, Anshul Srivastava, Anupam Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: There are many ways to identify abnormal activity in surveillance materials, but there are no comparative studies on the learning approaches being monitored. In this article, we will explore a variety of deep learning strategies. Their effectiveness is assessed using metrics such as accuracy, recall, accuracy, AUC (area under the curve), and F1 score. A critical data record was used with 1900 real surveillance video with 13 different anomalies, including combat, street accidents, robbery and robbery. These videos are long and unprocessed, giving them the complexity of anomaly recognition. The deep mill approach, where data was marked weakly by ranking-based methods, surpassed other methods of recall, F1 scores, and AUC. Future research can focus on developing new, weakly monitored learning methods, improve feature extraction techniques, and improve data labeling strategies for superior outcomes.

title: Application of Genetic Algorithm Optimized Feature Mode Decomposition in Brake Disc Dynamic Balance Vibration Detection
authors: Xinglin Qu, Shaosong Li, Siyang Gao, Changyi Liu, Xueshuo Liu, Xiang Li, Shichao Wang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To address the vibrational disturbances induced by brake disc imbalance, this paper presents an advanced vibration detection methodology based on Genetic Algorithm-optimized Feature Mode Decomposition (GA-FMD) integrated with wavelet soft-threshold denoising. Initially, vibration signals from the brake disc are acquired via accelerometric sensing and subsequently preprocessed. The GA-FMD algorithm is then employed to adaptively decompose the signal into multiple Intrinsic Mode Functions (IMFs), with fault-related modes identified utilizing correlation kurtosis criteria. Subsequently, wavelet soft-threshold denoising is implemented to mitigate high-frequency noise interference. Finally, optimal modal components are selected through Pearson correlation coefficient analysis, and characteristic features are systematically extracted and comprehensively analyzed. Comprehensive simulation studies demonstrate that the proposed methodology efficaciously decomposes periodic impact components, precisely identifies fault frequencies, and substantially improves the signal-to-noise ratio, thereby establishing a superior and more robust framework for brake disc dynamic balance detection.

title: Multi-Agent Adversarial Training for Text-to-Image GANs
authors: Jiabao Shi
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The Multi-Agent Text-Conditioned Generative Adversarial Network (MTC-GAN) is a novel method that utilizes multi-agent text-conditioned generative adversarial networks to enhance text-related image generation, thereby improving its diversity and semantic coherence. The new framework unites many generators that work together with a unified discriminator, resolving the main GAN weaknesses regarding mode collapse and weak semantic understanding. The text-conditioning and classification label information provide each generator with the ability to grasp different fundamental components of the data, resulting in a comprehensive understanding of the distribution. Each generator receives direction from a unified discriminator that assesses the disposition of both semantic content and class Certification and authenticity of produced outputs. Experimental testing is conducted on an artificial, synthetic dataset constructed from a multi-modal Gaussian Mixture Model with five distribution modes. The experiment setup yields thorough evaluations of the model's reliability, along with its ability to generate various accurate visual outputs from textual inputs. The MTC-GAN algorithm shows effective mode collapse prevention while it enhances both image quality and text-related image content, resulting in promising prospects for better controllable generative models.

title: MIMO for Joint Compensation of Mode Coupling, Frequency Offset and Carrier Phase Noise for Optical Carrier-Asynchronous SDM System via Frequency-Domain Pilot Tones
authors: Linsheng Fan, Zhongliang Sun, Xuquan Cui, Shunfeng Wang, Gao Ye, Linguo Cao, Qun Zhang, Zhaopeng Xu, Junpeng Liang, Tonghui Ji, Weisheng Hu, Jinlong Wei
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a novel frequency-domain pilot assisted MIMO scheme enabling joint compensation of mode coupling, frequency offset and carrier phase noise, addressing the MIMO failure in carrier-asynchronous SDM systems. Experimental validation confirms OSNR penalty of < 0.5 dB under asynchronous carrier, offering a scalable solution for high-capacity SDM systems. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Metaheuristic-Based Unknown Interference Suppression for Advanced Antenna Systems
authors: Le Thi Trang, Nguyen Van Cuong, Hoang Thi Phuong Thao, Tong Van Luyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper proposes an interference suppression scheme for advanced antenna systems (AAS), targeting unknown interference without relying on prior knowledge of its characteristics. The approach is applied to uniform rectangular arrays (URAs) with half-wavelength dipole elements and is designed to optimize radiation patterns through amplitude control. A fitness function is formulated based on total output power minimization, incorporating a static penalty technique to enforce constraints and steer nulls in interference directions while preserving the main-lobe gain. To solve the binary optimization problem, two metaheuristic algorithms, Binary Bat Algorithm (BBA) and Binary Grey Wolf Optimizer (BGWO), are employed, with BGWO selected as the primary optimizer for its balance between exploration and exploitation. The effectiveness of the proposed scheme is validated through simulations across three scenarios: convergence analysis, adaptive null-steering, and evaluation of amplitude quantization resolution. Results show that the method achieves high interference suppression capability, efficient beam shaping, and reduced computational cost, making it suitable for next-generation wireless systems such as 5G and 6G operating in dynamic and interference-prone environments.

title: Charging Pile Fault Detection Based on WOA-Optimized Bidirectional LSTM
authors: Yishan Feng, Ergang Zhao, Hongtao Li, Yongliang Zhao, Yuanhang Niu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Existing methods for EV-charger fault detection rely on prior knowledge for feature extraction, struggle to capture long-term dependencies with unidirectional LSTM, and are prone to local optima with traditional optimizers. This paper proposes a WOA-Bi-LSTM framework: a bidirectional LSTM learns both forward and backward temporal features, reinforced by an attention mechanism, while the Whale Optimization Algorithm globally tunes hyper-parameters such as hidden units and dropout rate. Six months of 380 V/16 A/11 kW AC charger data show that WOA-Bi-LSTM outperforms vanilla Bi-LSTM in RMSE and MAPE, yields smoother voltage, current and power curves with smaller residuals, and raises diagnostic accuracy from 87.8 % to 95.6 %, demonstrating its effectiveness and robustness.

title: A Topology-Loss Aware Framework for Addressing Oversegmentation in Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: Sanjeet Kumar, Urmila Pilania
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The problem of oversegmentation in brain tumor segmentation in Magnetic Resonance Images (MRI) poses significant challenges, particularly when finding complex anatomical structures where conventional segmentation models often fail to preserve topological integrity. This study integrates persistent homology into the training of a Multi-Modal Modified Residual U-net (MMResUnet) to introduce a topology-aware loss framework, focusing on enhancing the topological correctness of segmentation outputs. By integrating topological loss functions, the proposed method penalizes discrepancies in topological features between ground truth and predicted segmentations, which in turn lessens oversegmentation errors. The framework is evaluated on the BraTS2021 benchmark brain tumor dataset, demonstrating improved performance in maintaining structural continuity and reducing topological inaccuracies compared to traditional loss functions like Categorical Cross Entropy or Dice Loss. The results of this model highlight the ability of topological considerations in refining models for complex medical image segmentation tasks like brain tumor segmentation. The framework achieves 99.62% Accuracy, 96.18% Precision, 97.73% Recall, 98.20% Specificity, 85.72% Intersection over Union (IoU), 92.03% Dice Score for Edema (ED), 1.3 Betti Number Error (BNE) and 0.039 Wasserstein Distance.

title: A Decision Tree Based System for Real Time Fall Detection in Geriatric Population
authors: Hem Dutt Dabral
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper presents a Decision Tree based system for detecting “falls” in geriatric population. Falls in elderly people are leading cause of physical injury, mental trauma and death. It can also put huge economic burden on society and can adversely affect FQOL (Future Quality of Life) of elderly. This paper proposes an AIoT (Artificial Intelligence of Things) system for detecting falls in elderly people. In the unfortunate event of “Elderly Fall”, an AIoT based system can be used to request caregiver’s attention in an automated manner and help mitigate the harmful consequences of such falls. We used SensorTile.Box Pro IoT kit to create a TinyML system for detecting fall events. Proposed system can discriminate between different causes of fall (forward, backward, lateral, slip, trip, faint etc.). This system can use BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) based connectivity for connecting to an Edge Gateway device, for triggering cloud and/or smartphone-based applications to alert caregivers and medical professionals and request their prompt response.

title: Integrated Multi-Band Photonic Filter Based on MRR–SSG for Tunable Frequency Hopping
authors: Simeng Zhu, Tao Wu, Yizhe Fan, Xiao Sun, Bo Liu, John H. Marsh, Lianping Hou
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose and experimentally demonstrate a multi-channel photonic filter based on a cascaded microring resonator-superstructure grating structure, optimized using a SaDE-SQP algorithm. Featuring thermally tunable passbands and supporting frequency hopping above 300 GHz, it provides a novel integrated solution for reconfigurable, high-security terahertz communication systems.

title: Impact of Non-Uniform Fibre's Zero-Dispersion Wavelength on Four-Wave Mixing in 10-Km IMDD LWDM Systems
authors: Martí Sales-Llopis, Ping Liao, Huijian Zhang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: ZDW measured along multiple fibres revealed highly-linear profiles with slopes between 0.04 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.12 \text{nm} / \text{km}$</tex>, which increase the critical FWM action range by up to 3.8 times in 800G-LR4 systems.

title: Blockchain and Federated Learning(BFL) for Robust IoT Security: NONU
authors: Shekhar, Vikash Bhardwaj, Isra’a M. Essa, Hasanain A. J. Gharban, Ramendra Singh, Vinish Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper offers an extensive examination and introduces novel approaches for improving security in blockchain and related systems. It provides a substantial contribution to the domain of cyber security, with practical ramifications for the advancement of more secure digital infrastructures in an increasingly linked environment. An essential element of the research is the innovative application of federated learning within device contexts. This methodology facilitates decentralized, privacy-preserving data analysis, which is vital in the sensitive domain of security. The study investigates the efficacy of federated learning models in realtime anomaly detection, presenting a technique called NONU a novel solution for safeguarding blockchain-enabled devices. The research findings indicate that the amalgamation of machine learning and federated learning can substantially improve the identification and mitigation of security threats in both blockchain systems and devices. This paper provides significant insights into the advancement of more resilient and intelligent security strategies, thereby promoting the secure adoption of these rapidly evolving technologies. The experimental outcome demonstrates that the honeypot has a success rate of 98.7 %. The Dynamic Weighted Updating Federated Averaging model can be provided for device security when integrated with blockchain and cloud settings, achieving an accuracy of 99%.

title: RFID-Based Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) Enabled by Laser-Induced Graphene (LIG)
authors: Francesca M. C. Nanni, Gaetano Marrocco
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: The growing adoption of the Internet of Things (IoT) has intensified the demand for secure and scalable solutions against counterfeiting and duplication. Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) represent a promising security primitive, leveraging intrinsic manufacturing variability for tamper-resistant authentication. This work investigates the use of Laser-Induced Graphene (LIG) as a material platform to realize PUFs integrated into the electromagnetic response of passive RFID tags. A set of ten LIG-based dipole antennas was fabricated and characterized through backscatter measurements. The extracted fingerprints were digitized and evaluated using standard PUF metrics. The analysis revealed approximately 88 degrees of freedom, indicating a significant level of entropy and inter-device distinctiveness. The proposed approach requires no additional cryptographic hardware and remains fully compatible with standard RFID protocols. These findings support the feasibility of a hardwareefficient, scalable, and environmentally sustainable solution for secure identification in IoT and supply chain applications.

title: Functional Reliability Analysis of Self-Healing Passive UHF RFID Tag Under Mechanical Damage: Cutting and Stretching Effects
authors: Isra Yaqoob, Nikta Pournoori, Jarkko Tolvanen, Toni Björninen, Jari Juuti, Leena Ukkonen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Self-healing (SH) functional polymers, composites, and blends offer innovative solutions for developing fully soft, elastic electronics, antennas, and sensors with the ability to heal themselves. In this paper, we demonstrate, for the first time, the stretching performance and SH functionality of passive UHF RFID tags fabricated of SH elastomer blends. We analyzed the functionality of the passive UHF RFID tag based on a dipole antenna with different conductor thicknesses after being bisected and stretched. After completely bisected, 82.6% of the tag's read range was regained within 24 hours, and it could be uniaxially stretched up to 75%. Our results provide important proof of concept for the development of stretchable and SH antennas, and wireless sensors. One of the most important aspects for future work is enhancing the performance of RFID tags under stretching by improving the bonding of the IC to the radiator with structural design that can also enable waterproofing, thereby making the tags suitable for wearable applications requiring washability.

title: Neural Adaptive Observer Design For Takagi-Sugeno Fuzzy System
authors: Xulang Gao, Juntao Pan, Bin Liu, Xiangyuan Bian, Xueyuan Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In current research practices, researchers often assume the omission of certain unknown factors during system modeling to ensure computational tractability. However, these neglected factors may critically impact experimental results. To address this, we propose leveraging the nonlinear mapping capability of neuronal activation functions to estimate potential unmodeled dynamics in nonlinear systems.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> Concurrently, the sector nonlinearity approach is employed to formulate a Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy representation, achieving enhanced computational efficiency. Finally, the feasibility is validated through a nonlinear system case. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves accurate estimation of both system states and nonlinear dynamics, confirming its effectiveness.

title: Analysis of the thermal runaway propagation and dynamic threshold of lithium-ion batteries under different cooling conditions
authors: Lin Cheng, Ergang Zhao, Qihui Zhang, Min Sun, Zhan Shu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper focuses on the issue of thermal runaway and propagation in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), with the aim of providing a theoretical basis for the design of thermal runaway isolation schemes and warning systems. First, the dangers of thermal runaway and propagation in lithium-ion batteries are explained, and the limitations of existing fixed threshold warnings are highlighted, as well as the characteristics and limitations of dynamic threshold models and the two types of safety strategy. The experiment uses 18650 cylindrical lithium iron phosphate batteries, and a 5x5 diamond-shaped thermal management system is built, filled with a composite phase change material (paraffin + 10% expanding graphite) and, through the experimental platform, set the 33rd battery as the hot spot to trigger the hot spot, simulating the hot spot spreading under different cooling conditions and establishing the relevant simulation model. After grid independence, battery modelling, phase change cooling and hot spot temperature threshold verification, the model was found to be highly reliable. The study found that the composite phase change material cooling could significantly delay the occurrence and spread of the hot spot, with the 33rd battery taking 2.7 s and the time for all batteries to reach thermal runaway increased by almost twofold. This study has verified the reliability of the model, clarified the impact of different cooling methods, and provided a reference for optimising battery thermal management systems.

title: Optimizing Hyperparameters in Machine Learning for Enhanced Fake News Detection on Social Media
authors: Rayner Alfred, Anis Aqilah Binti Zazali, Florence Sia Fui Sze, Lai Po Hung, Rayner Pailus, Khalifa Chekima, Ashraf Osman Ibrahim, Yuto Lim, Haviluddin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: The widespread dissemination of fake news through digital media platforms presents a critical threat to public trust, democratic institutions, and social stability. While machine learning has shown great promise in automating fake news detection, a significant research gap remains in understanding how hyperparameter tuning affects the performance of these models. Many existing studies overlook this aspect, treating model configurations as fixed and underexploring their optimization potential. This study aims to fill that gap by systematically evaluating the impact of hyperparameter optimization on three widely used machine learning classifiers, Support Vector Machine (SVM), k-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), and Naïve Bayes, in the context of fake news classification. Using a publicly available dataset from Kaggle, textual features were extracted using TF-IDF vectorization, and each model was trained under optimized settings: k=5 for KNN, C=1.0 with a linear kernel for SVM, and alpha=1.0 for Naïve Bayes. Performance was assessed using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, supported by statistical t-tests to validate significance. The results reveal that SVM outperforms KNN and Naïve Bayes across all metrics, achieving the highest accuracy (74.1%), recall (87.1%), and F1-score (80.4%), with statistically significant differences (p < 0.001). While Naïve Bayes achieved perfect recall (100%), it suffered from poor precision (61.6%), making it unsuitable for precision-sensitive applications. The findings highlight that hyperparameter tuning significantly influences model effectiveness and overlooking it may lead to misleading conclusions or suboptimal system performance. This paper contributes a replicable experimental framework and provides evidence-based guidance for selecting and configuring machine learning models in fake news detection. By addressing an underexplored but essential aspect of model development, this work strengthens the foundation for building more accurate, scalable, and robust AI-driven misinformation detection systems.

title: $150-\text{GHz}$ Bandwidth, −30 dB CMRR Balanced Photodetector for High-Baud Rate PSK Signal Detection
authors: Toshimasa Umezawa, Shinya Nakajima, Atsushi Matsumoto, Kouichi Akahane, Naokatsu Yamamoto
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We designed and fabricated a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150-\text{GHz}$</tex> wide bandwidth balanced photodetector with low CMRR less than −30 dB using UTC-PD structure. The great potential for high-baud-rate PSK detection is discussed through the demonstration.

title: Application of Optimization Algorithms for Various Scenarios in Gasoline and Diesel Engines
authors: Ebubekir Yaşar, Serhat Bílgín, Mithat Şímşek, Nurullah Gültekín
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Internal combustion engines (ICEs) remain the most widespread power source in the world, particularly within the automotive and transportation sectors. Owing to their high energy density, rapid response capability, and relatively low production costs, they have long been preferred for various applications. Even today, they continue to serve as the primary power units for automobiles, trucks, ships, and certain types of generators. However, the growing concerns over fuel consumption, increasing emission levels, and global environmental regulations have made it necessary to reconsider the balance between performance, efficiency, and emissions in these engines. Consequently, optimization has become an indispensable engineering approach in modern engine development processes. Studies in the literature indicate that multi-objective optimization techniques provide effective solutions for enhancing engine performance parameters. In spark-ignition engines, ignition timing and air–fuel ratio is the main focus of optimization studies, while in diesel engines, injection pressure and injection strategies play a crucial role. Evolutionary multi-objective optimization algorithms such as genetic algorithms, particle swarm optimization, differential evolution methods, and NSGA-II/NSGA-III enable engineers to obtain Pareto-optimal solutions that balance fuel consumption and emissions, offering diverse alternatives suitable for different design conditions. In conclusion, optimization-oriented research on gasoline and diesel engines not only enhances fuel economy and performance but also establishes a significant scientific foundation for supporting environmental sustainability.

title: New Tools for Tracking Small Invertebrates Using Harmonic Radar
authors: Graeme Woodward, Rifat Afroz, Greg Storz, Andrei Mogilnikov, Anastasia Lavrenko, Stephen Pawson
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: We introduce two novel radar systems for tracking small invertebrates, such as insects, using a harmonic radar operating around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9 \text{GHz} / 18 \text{GHz}$</tex>. The first is a scanning radar that continuously measures the range and angle of tagged targets to study their movement patterns. The second is a handheld radar designed for fieldworkers to periodically re-locate tagged targets with visual and audio prompts. Preliminary field results show promising capabilities, with the scanning radar detecting tags up to 130 m, and sub- 1 m localisation accuracy (at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-30 ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> range). The handheld radar could function effectively within 60 m under ideal conditions. However, challenges remain, such as the dependence on the tag orientation, occlusion by vegetation/leaf litter, affixing tags, and the influence of nearby objects (including the target body). Future work will address these issues, in addition to expanding system capabilities using mobile platforms and remote monitoring using cloud processing.

title: A Fault Diagnosis Method for Multi-UAVs Based on Belief Rule Base with Wavelet Transformation
authors: Ruohan Yang, Xiao Gong, Zhichao Feng
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Fault diagnosis is a crucial problem for multi-unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) under complex conditions. To address this critical issue, this study proposes a new diagnostic approach that utilizes belief rule base integrated with wavelet transformation (BRB-WT). Furthermore, a gradient descent optimization method is employed for the refinement of the hyperparameters within the proposed BRB-WT framework. The key merits of our approach are twofold: First, the proposed BRB-WT method can effectively capture characteristics, such as high-frequency components and rapid signal changes, from time-domain signals of UAVs. Second, the formulated gradient descent optimization algorithm exhibits greater interpretability than existing BRB models that utilize the projection covariance matrix adaptation evolution strategy (P-CMA-ES). Collectively, these improvements result in a substantial boost to the overall efficacy of the BRB-WT diagnostic approach. Case studies and comparative analyses reveal that our BRB-WT approach surpasses conventional fault diagnosis methods with respect to diagnostic accuracy.

title: Review of Artificial Intelligence Applications in Performance Prediction of Advanced Energy Materials
authors: Paula Marielle Ababao, Ian Benitez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming the prediction and optimization of advanced energy materials by enabling accurate, scalable modeling beyond traditional methods. This review evaluates recent AI applications—including Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), Convolutional and Recurrent Neural Networks (CNNs, RNNs), tree-based ensembles, and Gaussian Process Regression (GPR)—for forecasting performance metrics such as overpotential, conductivity, capacity, and degradation. GNNs achieved R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> > 0.90 in structure-sensitive tasks; LSTM models predicted battery degradation with <10% error; and tree-based models balanced accuracy (MAE < 0.15 V) with interpretability. GPR excelled in low-data regimes via uncertainty quantification. Hybrid and physics-informed models improved generalizability and data efficiency. While challenges remain in data quality and integration with experiments, emerging strategies like autonomous labs and generative design offer promising advances. This review provides comparative benchmarks and highlights pathways for robust AI-driven materials discovery.

title: Submarine Optical Fibers: A Window Into Climate Change
authors: Sonia Martin-Lopez, Miguel Gonzalez-Herraez, Maria R. Fernández-Ruiz
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate that submarine optical fibers can provide novel and valuable insights into various physical and biological processes in the ocean, such as surface waves, ocean currents, the mechanisms driving water mixing, marine-mammal migration and other indicators that play a crucial role in climate observation. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Impact of Inter-Core Crosstalk on Coherent Optical Time-Domain Reflectometry in Repeatered Multicore Fibre Systems
authors: Kosuke Komatsu, Kodai Ishida, Shohei Beppu, Daiki Soma, Seiya Sumita, Taiki Fukushima, Kazuyoshi Inoue, Hidenori Takahashi, Yuta Wakayama, Takehiro Tsuritani
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate coherent optical time-domain reflectometry (C-OTDR) measurements in unidirectional and bidirectional repeatered multicore fibre systems for the submarine application. We show that inter-core crosstalk can be measured in the bidirectional system, along with a longitudinal loss profile and fibre end location in both systems.

title: System Identification for Resonant Converters Through Correlation Analysis Scheme
authors: Yongyi Liao, Lei Ma, Zheyang Huang, Yanwei Ding
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To achieve closed-loop control and improve dynamic performance, it is crucial to establish an accurate model. Traditional modeling approaches of LLC resonant converters (RC) involve complex derivation procedures and require some theoretical assumptions. This article proposes a system identification method based on sampled-data for LLC RC. A pseudo random binary sequence (PRBS) is selected as the excitation signal to acquire the output voltage. The frequency response model of the resonant converter is obtained through correlation analysis from the input and output signals, which can reduce the impact of noise. Then, the eigen-system realization algorithm is used to derive the parametric model of the system. The proposed identification method can generate an accurate mathematical model while featuring low complexity and ease of implementation. Finally, a PI controller is designed based on the identified model to validate the effectiveness of the presented approach.

title: Next-Generation E-Voting Security using Blockchain Technology
authors: Esha Tyagi, Arun Ahirwar, Deepak Khandelwal, Ashika Goyal, Rupa Rani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: E-voting systems are gaining ground in international space, considering the versatility embedded in them in terms of making voting far more accessible and less expensive in logistics. Such systems, however, pose much higher security issues regarding privacy, especially while using biometric details, such as facial recognition, to verify the voter. The paper describes an e-voting system based on the blockchain architecture coupled with advanced privacy-preserving techniques like Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) and end-to-end encryption. Voters have shied away from adopting this voting system as it is ensured by decentralization, transparency, and tamper-proofness, all at the cost of their identity and biometric data. In addition to this, this blockchain-based system also ensures that no one control is there for the voting process by any particular entity; hence, it guarantees impartiality. Because of ZKPs, it is ensured that voter verification can take place without exposing sensitive personal data in nature. Unlike the traditional e-voting-on-a-blockchain models, ours includes a dynamic key rotation mechanism for further anonymity of votes, with a multi-layer encryption to protect voter credentials even against potential quantum computing threats. Further, this blocking-based system makes sure that not a single entity is controlling the entire process of voting, thus guaranteeing impartiality. Voter verification takes place through the means of ZKP without any sensitive personal information being revealed. As a result, end-to-end encryption keeps intact the integrity of a vote from the moment it is cast until it is finally counted, further building confidence in the election process. It turns out to be a safe and scalable solution for future worldwide adoption of evoting.

title: Temporal Deep Learning for Disease Onset Forecasting from Longitudinal Health Data
authors: Magesh Kumar S, S.Ashokkumar, Shakila M, Anitha Govindaram, Karpagam V, Nelson Kennedy Babu C
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: In order to accurately anticipate the beginning of disease utilising consecutive Electronic Health Records (EHRs), this study suggests a unique deep learning architecture based on Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCNs). The capacity of TCNs to simulate long-range temporal dependencies is greater than that of classic recurrent models like RNNs and LSTMs, allowing for more precise and timely predictions. The framework is extremely resistant to the anomalies commonly present in real-world EHR datasets because it integrates attention mechanisms, adaptive sampling strategies, and robust handling of missing data. This method outperforms traditional deep learning models, such as Transformers, in terms of prediction accuracy and computational efficiency, according to experimental assessment on extensive health data including both acute and chronic diseases. Additionally, its compact and lightweight form allows for deployment in clinical settings with limited resources, enabling quick, in-the-moment analysis and decision-making. Together, these developments show how TCN-based architectures have the ability to revolutionise predictive medicine by facilitating early interventions, enhancing treatment planning tailored to individual patients, and bolstering proactive public health initiatives.

title: Edge Authentication Using a Cryptographic Accumulator
authors: İsmet Kaan Çekiş, Armağan Toros, Volkan Yiğit, İlker Özçelik
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Traditional authentication protocols, which rely on centralized identity providers, face significant challenges with latency and bandwidth consumption as modern information systems scale to a large number of users and real-time processing. Edge authentication offers a promising solution by shifting user verification to local devices, thereby reducing dependency on a central server. However, this approach requires a secure and efficient method for distributing authentication data to edge devices and ensuring a efficient verification process. This paper proposes a novel edge authentication protocol designed for efficiency and security, particularly for resource-constrained Internet of Things (IoT) devices. The protocol addresses the key challenges by leveraging a cryptographic accumulator. This data structure provides a compact and verifiable representation of the authentication database that can be securely distributed to edge devices. The core advantage is its ability to perform verification with an O(1) time complexity, which not only accelerates the process but also enables the system to operate effectively in low-bandwidth environments with a high number of users. The operational mechanism of this theoretical protocol is detailed, with future work planned for implementation and practical performance testing.

title: Understanding and Reducing the Risk of Extreme Photovoltaic Degradation_supp1-3627676.docx
authors: Fiacre Emile Rougieux
publish: N/A
abstract: A small number of photovoltaic modules degrade far more rapidly than average, creating a “long tail” in degradation rate distribution that poses a critical challenge to the reliability and financial viability of solar projects. This study investigates the factors contributing to this phenomenon by analyzing a large global dataset from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory. Our analysis reveals that the long tail is an intrinsic and composite feature of module degradation, not merely a statistical consequence of combining different climates. We identify at least three distinct pathways that could contribute to its formation. The first is accelerated degradation driven by strong statistical associations between different degradation modes, where the interplay of mechanisms appears to be a primary contributor of the most severely degraded modules. The second is rapid early-life failure (infant mortality), which populates the tail with modules likely containing initial manufacturing or material defects. The third is failure of individual latent defects, such as solder fatigue or cell cracks, which can cause sudden severe performance loss at random points in a module's life. Based on our results, we suggest that efforts should be made to understand and mitigate the interaction between associated degradation modes. For instance, the careful selection of key components, such as backsheet, is crucial as it could initiate multiple pathways of degradation.

title: Joint Preamble and DSP Design for Burst-Mode Coherent PONs with Enhanced Wavelength Drift Tolerance
authors: Yiyang Feng, Zhengxuan Li, Siyu Luo, Acai Tan, Lilin Yi, Yingxiong Song
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: The continued surge in data traffic is driving the need for high-capacity solutions in future optical access networks. Coherent passive optical networks are emerging as a promising candidate to meet this demand. However, one specific challenge is integrating low-cost lasers while overcoming severe wavelength drift. Here, we propose a joint adaptive polarization and frequency tracking equalizer designed for wavelength drift tracking, polarization demultiplexing, and linear impairment compensation. This equalizer is embedded within a low complexity digital signal processing and paired with an optimized preamble structure. The preamble is carefully designed to perform multiple functions using a shared training sequence: frame synchronization, frequency offset estimation, and state-of polarization tracking, thereby reducing overhead. We validate our approach through proof-of-concept experiments, transmitting a 200 Gb/s dual-polarization 16-ary quadrature amplitude modulated signal using three tested lasers. The proposed scheme achieves a 3 dB improvement in receiver sensitivity, along with fast convergence, strong tolerance to laser wavelength drift, and low implementation complexity. These results demonstrate the scheme's suitability for next-generation coherent passive optical network systems.

title: Field Trial of High-Sensitivity Forward-Transmission Sensing for Real-World Event Detection over Live Urban Fiber Networks
authors: Jian Fang, Ming-Fang Huang, Scott Kotrla, Tiejun J. Xia, Glenn A. Wellbrock, Jeffery A. Mundt, Ting Wang, Yoshiaki Aono
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Vibration sensing based on forward transmission is an emerging topic for network protection and environmental monitoring, especially in long-haul submarine cables and urban fiber networks. However, previous field trials of this approach have mainly focused on localizing strong events under controlled or relatively quiet conditions. In this work, we investigate the capability of forward-transmission vibration sensing to detect weak signals in noisy environments. We demonstrate a highsensitivity vibration sensing system operating over an 80-km deployed live urban fiber loop without optical amplifiers. The system is enhanced by adaptive time-frequency masking and inband laser phase noise suppression techniques to improve sensitivity and noise robustness. It has successfully identified and localized weak real-world vibration events with peak-to-peak amplitude lower than 20 rad, such as construction activity near a manhole and even footsteps on handhole lids. Field trial results confirm its robust performance under dynamic environments, including road traffic-induced ground vibrations and aerial cable disturbances. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of weak vibration event detection using forward transmission in urban fiber networks. It remarks a significant step towards practical distributed vibration sensing in smart city applications.

title: The interaction of market power and dynamic capabilities in shaping digital transformations success
authors: Jacques Bughin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: This study examines how dynamic capabilities interact with imperfect competition to shape the performance outcomes of corporate digital transformation. Building on an oligopoly model that integrates automation and digital innovation choices, we show analytically that market power and dynamic capabilities act as strategic complements, jointly amplifying the returns on digital investments. Using a global sample of 545 incumbent firms across seven industries, we find strong empirical support for this prediction: transformational capabilities and asymmetric market positions significantly increase the return on digital technologies, especially for early adopters and firms with an innovation-biased strategy. The study demonstrates research rigour by combining a micro-founded structural model with extensive econometric validation, including instrumental-variable estimation, multiple robustness checks, and industry- and geography-adjusted controls. Our results offer new insight into why digital returns are highly skewed across firms and explain why many incumbents experience limited performance gains despite large investments in digital technologies.

title: Speeding up the Iron Losses Calculation using Clustering Technics
authors: J. Korecki, T. Henneron, S. Clénet
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics
abstract: The Finite Element method is widely used to study and design electromagnetic devices. This method is very accurate but often requires huge computational time even during the post processing step where quantities of interest are calculated. In this article, we propose to apply and to compare clustering methods, i.e. the K-Means and Gaussian Mixture methods, in order to reduce the computational time of the iron loss distribution in a postprocessing stage. Indeed, the iron loss distribution calculation relies only on the calculation on only a few elements of mesh and not on all elements like in the case of the standard method. The proposed methods are tested on a nonlinear magnetic example based on an axial flux machine showing a good agreement between the iron losses distribution obtained by the standard and the proposed methods.

title: Magnetic Properties and Magnetocaloric Performance in a Dy-Pt-In Multiphase Alloy
authors: Jéssica Kamilly Pereira França, Aline Alves De Freitas, Hellen Barros Lopes Silva, Maurício Silva Lopes, Hudson Antonio Dias Teixeira, Walajhone Oliveira Pereira, Alan Silva De Menezes, Adenilson Oliveira Dos Santos, Luzeli Moreira Da Silva
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics
abstract: Multiphase alloys with sequential long-range magnetic order represent an intriguing approach to overcoming an intrinsic limitation of single-phase magnetocaloric materials by broadening the operational temperature window and enhancing thermal coupling between phases. In this study, we investigate a Dy–Pt–In alloy with a nominal composition of 35 wt% Dy, 41 wt% Pt, and 24 wt% In, synthesized by arc melting and characterized in terms of its structural, microstructural, magnetic, and magnetocaloric properties. Rietveld refinement of X-ray diffraction data, combined with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analyses, revealed a multiphase alloy composed of a DyPtIn, DyPt₂In, and DyPt intermetallic phases. The alloy exhibit three magnetic transitions: two successive ferromagnetic transitions at 32.5 K and 23.0 K, and a field-dependent antiferromagnetic-like transition at 7.5 K, which together sustain an nearly constant adiabatic temperature change of ~2.1 K across a broad temperature range (2.5–57 K) and a maximum magnetic entropy change of ~6.3 J/kg·K for a field variation of 50 kOe. The results demonstrate the potential of Dy–Pt–In multiphase systems to extend the working temperature span and enhance the performance of cryogenic magnetic refrigeration applications.

title: TFZ: Topology-Preserving Compression of 2D Symmetric and Asymmetric Second-Order Tensor Fields
authors: Nathaniel Gorski, Xin Liang, Hanqi Guo, Bei Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: In this paper, we present a novel compression framework, TFZ, that preserves the topology of 2D symmetric and asymmetric second-order tensor fields defined on flat triangular meshes. A tensor field assigns a tensor—a multi-dimensional array of numbers—to each point in space. Tensor fields, such as the stress and strain tensors, and the Riemann curvature tensor, are essential to both science and engineering. The topology of tensor fields captures the core structure of data, and is useful in various disciplines, such as graphics (for manipulating shapes and textures) and neuroscience (for analyzing brain structures from diffusion MRI). Lossy data compression may distort the topology of tensor fields, thus hindering downstream analysis and visualization tasks. TFZ ensures that certain topological features are preserved during lossy compression. Specifically, TFZ preserves degenerate points essential to the topology of symmetric tensor fields and retains eigenvector and eigenvalue graphs that represent the topology of asymmetric tensor fields. TFZ scans through each cell, preserving the local topology of each cell, and thereby ensuring certain global topological guarantees. We showcase the effectiveness of our framework in enhancing the lossy scientific data compressors SZ3 and SPERR.

title: Lean Healthcare 4.0: Integrating AI, Lean Principles, and Simulation for Laboratory Process Improvement
authors: Ignacio Franco-Alucano, Guilherme Tortorella, Julian Aguilar-Duque, Dora-Luz Flores, Jorge Limon-Romero, Yolanda Baez-Lopez, Diego Tlapa
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The pre-analytical phase in clinical laboratories is vulnerable to inefficiencies and human error, directly affecting diagnostic quality and patient safety.
