This study presents an integrated framework, Lean Healthcare 4.0, that combines Lean Healthcare (LH), discrete-event simulation, and deep learning (DL) to address inefficiencies and errors in clinical laboratories. LH was applied to identify non-value-adding activities and streamline patient and sample flows, while simulation modeled operational dynamics and validated potential improvements. Two DL-based models (v11 and v12) were developed to support real-time visual inspection of blood sample tubes. In parallel, a prompt DL system automated phlebotomist-patient signaling. Results indicate a 25% reduction in patient waiting time at registration and a 20% decrease prior to sampling, alongside improved turnaround time and turnover time. The YOLO models achieved up to 94.0% precision, 92.7% recall, and 97.2% mAP, performing comparably to phlebotomists, validating their suitability in assisting phlebotomists through real-time, smarter inspection. This work demonstrates the synergistic role of Lean Healthcare, simulation, and deep learning to improve patient flow and the quality of care of laboratory operations. The findings offer a scalable, data-driven framework for deploying Industry 4.0 principles within resource-constrained healthcare environments.

title: Position Leakage by Charging Power: Privacy Attacks and Efficient Protection in WRSNs
authors: Chi Lin, Lingbo Huang, Hengyi Li, Wei Yang, Michael Segal, Guowei Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Wireless rechargeable sensor networks (WRSNs) have overcome the energy limitation bottleneck through wireless power transfer (WPT) technology. Traditional research has primarily focused on enhancing charging efficiency, while the critical issue of location privacy security arising from wireless charging has received scant attention. Additionally, sensors are vulnerable to detection and harm by malicious attackers, posing a significant threat to network integrity. In this paper, we propose two attack schemes, termed Least Squares Method (LSM) attack model and Centroid Method (CM) attack model for compromising sensor location privacy by exploiting charging power information and mobile charger behaviors. To counter such threats, we develop a scheme aimed at maximizing the node location privacy protection capabilities of the network. We propose a theoretical analysis to exploit the features of the proposed scheme. Finally, extensive test-bed experiments and simulations have been conducted to validate the effectiveness of our algorithms. The results demonstrate that our algorithms can protect at least 78% of the nodes without significantly compromising their survival rate.

title: Distributed Leaderless Attitude Consensus of Multi-Spacecraft Systems With Full-State Constraints Under Switching Directed Graphs
authors: Yue Sun, Youmin Gong, Jie Mei, Yanning Guo, Weiren Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper investigates distributed leaderless attitude consensus for multi-spacecraft systems with full-state constraints under switching directed graphs. The coexistence of attitude and angular velocity constraints poses significant challenges for the control design of multi-spacecraft systems. To tackle this issue, a transformation method is first introduced to convert the constrained attitude dynamics into an unconstrained form. A linear reference model is designed to guide consensus in the transformed space under switching directed graphs. Then, a virtual controller is designed via a backstepping approach with an auxiliary system ensuring that the states remain within prescribed bounds. Through error transformation, the virtual controller and the spacecraft attitude angular velocity are mapped to the free variables and a tracking controller is designed. Furthermore, an adaptive mechanism is integrated to estimate and compensate for unknown disturbances and parametric uncertainties. Finally, the stability of the system is analyzed using the Lyapunov method, which ensures the achievement of attitude consensus. Numerical simulations are presented to validate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed control strategy.

title: LPATR-Net: Learnable Piecewise Affine Transformation Regression Assisted Data-Driven Dehazing Framework
authors: Yuelong Li, Fei Chen, Zhenwei Liu, Tianyu Zang, Jianming Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Nowadays, data-driven learning based deep neural network (DNN) is the most dominant SOTA image dehazing framework. Here, learning to perfectly simulate the underlying mapping rules (from hazy to clear) told by massive paired training data is its core driving force. However, under genuine scenarios, it is extremely hard to guarantee the 100% qualification of all collected ground truth (GT) haze-free data. That’s because natural weather is hardly controlled, and many weathers are actually in a chaotic status existing between foggy and fog-free. Thus, unlike most supervised learning issues, the image dehazing society is born with the torture of part of faulty ground truth no-haze samples. Therefore, totally trusting training data and solely pursuing more fitting powerful data-driven model may not be a wise solution. To cope with this thorny challenge, in this paper, instead of faithfully pursuing for fitting capacity promotion, we on the contrary choose to intentionally cut down the fitting flexibility to achieve higher-level robustness. That is the LPATR-Net, a novel dehazing framework specially armed with fitting power suppression mechanism to resist intrinsic annoying faulty GT. This solution does not involve any extra manually labeling. Specifically, the LPATR-Net architecture is created completely around elaborately designed fitting-restrained learnable piecewise affine transformation regression. Since such low-order linear regression structure genetically can only fit for majority of data, the interference of minority of unqualified GT samples is expected to be effectively suppressed. Through further coupled with a highly customized multi-concerns high-accuracy dehazing fitting companion component, All-Mattering, proposed LPATR-Net elegantly achieves the seamless integration of traditional majority determining fixed-form regression and modern all freedom data-driven deep learning. Extensive experiments have been conducted on five commonly utilized public datasets to verify its effectiveness. In addition, the wide-range transplantability of the proposed core regression structure has also been experimentally confirmed. Source code is available at https://github.com/****/.

title: Multilevel Plug-and-Play Image Restoration
authors: Nils Laurent, Julián Tachella, Elisa Riccietti, Nelly Pustelnik
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Imaging
abstract: Plug-and-play (PnP) image reconstruction methods leverage pretrained deep neural network denoisers as image priors to solve general inverse problems, and can obtain a competitive performance without having to train a network on a specific problem. Despite their flexibility, PnP methods often require several iterations to converge and their performance can be highly sensitive to the choice of the initialization and of the hyperparameters. In this paper, we propose a new multilevel PnP framework to accelerate the convergence of PnP methods in the context of large-scale images. The proposed scheme, following a coarse-to-fine strategy, is initialized at the coarsest scale and the resolution of the starting point is progressively improved to reach the fine level with the highest resolution. The scheme then combines classical PnP iterations with cheaper iterations, involv ing representations of the images at coarser scales. As a result of the combination of these two ingredients, the multilevel PnP scheme accelerates the convergence and improves the robustness to the choice of initialization and hyperparameters. In a series of experiments, including image inpainting, demosaicing, and deblurring, we show that the proposed multilevel PnP method outperforms other PnP methods in both speed and reconstruction performance.

title: Photonic Reservoir-Based Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Mobile Robots Using Subcarrier Intermodulation Distortion
authors: Hideaki Tanaka, Yusuke Chikamoto, Takashi Kan, Hidenori Takahashi, Yuichi Katori, Takehiro Tsuritani
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate that online reinforcement learning for autonomous mobile robots can be achieved using randomly mapped input signals to a photonic reservoir that employs intermodulation distortion of equally spaced subcarrier signals generated by a Mach-Zehnder modulator. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Bit Error Rate (BER) Performance of BPSK, QPSK, and 16-QAM in a PMCW Radar Environment
authors: Erim Fıçıcı, Yusuf İslam Demir, Tuncay Eren, Mustafa Serdar Osmanca
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: In this paper, Binary Phase Shift Keying (BPSK), Quadrature Phase Shift Keying (QPSK), and 16-QAM are compared in a Phase Modulated Continuous Wave (PMCW) radar operating at 24 GHz. The bit error rate (BER) performance of the three modulation schemes is analyzed at different Signal-to-Noise Ratios (SNR) in a Rician fading channel (K = 10 dB) with additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN). Through simulation, it is shown that BPSK has the lowest BER performance for any SNR value, indicating better immunity to noise and more reliable detection performance, while QPSK and 16-QAM have better spectral efficiency but higher BER due to noise sensitivity. This paper fills a gap in the existing literature by quantitatively addressing the trade-off between data rate and sensing reliability for PMCW-based Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) systems and can guide the design of modulation schemes for 6G network applications.

title: IoT Based Deep Learning Framework for Continuous Healthcare Monitoring of Vital Signs
authors: Arvind Kumar Chaudhary, Ronish Balvantbhai Patel, Divyaraj Singh Jatav, Akshar Patel, Venkata Babu Mogili
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Continuous monitoring of vital signs plays a critical role in early detection and management of health conditions, especially for patients with chronic diseases and the elderly. The integration of Internet of Things (IoT) devices with intelligent data analytics enables real-time, non-invasive, and remote health monitoring which reduces the burden on healthcare systems while improving patient outcomes through timely interventions. Existing methods lack accuracy in processing high-dimensional sensor data, making them ineffective for continuous and personalized monitoring of vital signs. An IoT-driven health monitoring architecture was developed using eight body-worn sensors deployed on 303 patients to collect vital sign data, including pulse rate, blood pressure, temperature, respiratory patterns, and cardiovascular activity. Feature extraction was carried out using a ResNet deep learning model to capture discriminative patterns in the sensor data. To reduce dimensionality and improve classification performance, feature optimization was conducted using an enhanced artificial flora optimization (EAFO) algorithm. The optimized features were then fed into a deep artificial neural network (DANN) for continuous monitoring of health status. Experimental results indicate that the proposed EAFO-DANN model achieves superior performance in detecting anomalies in vital sign data compared to conventional models. This framework represents a step forward in personalized and preventive medicine, enabling timely medical intervention and improving quality of life for patients through remote monitoring.

title: SMF-Coupled Compact Ground Terminal with Advanced Filtering Towards Daylight C-Band Satellite QKD
authors: Argiris Ntanos, Aristeidis Stathis, Panagiotis Kourelias, Evridiki Kyriazi, Panagiotis Toumasis, Nikolaos K. Lyras, Nikolaos Makris, Sotirios Tsavdaridis, E.M. Xilouris, Athanasios Marousis, Ilias Papastamatiou, Athanasios D. Panagopoulos, Konstantinos Vyrsokinos, Kleomenis Tsiganis, George T. Kanellos, Hercules Avramopoulos, Giannis Giannoulis
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate a compact, high-isolation C-band optical ground terminal for satellite-QKD, achieving more than 120 dB daylight background suppression and 135 dB crosstalk noise isolation. Successful QKD over an outdoor 100 m FSO validate its feasibility for integration of satellite QKD with urban fiber segments. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Outage Analysis of IRS-Assisted Friendly Jamming for Physical Layer Security
authors: Naveen Gupta, Ravi Kadlimatti
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: Intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRSs) have emerged as a disruptive technology for sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks. By enabling near-passive control of the propagation environment, IRSs provide a flexible and energy-efficient means to improve link reliability and secrecy. In this work, we investigate the role of IRS-aided friendly jamming in secure two-way full-duplex communications. We formulate closed-form outage probability expressions for the legitimate user while accounting for destructive IRS combining at an eavesdropper. Monte Carlo simulations validate the analytical expressions. Results demonstrate that careful IRS phase and amplitude tuning significantly boosts secrecy rate while maintaining reliable legitimate performance. Beyond analysis, the paper contextualizes IRS for physical-layer security (PLS) in emerging 6G scenarios including IoT, UAV communications, and mmWave/THz bands.

title: A Multi-Die Solution for Recovering from Double-Event Upsets in FPGA-Based Space Applications
authors: Hassanein H. Amer, Yosof Maklad, Hassan M. Hassan, Gehad I. Alkady, Dina G. Mahmoud
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Signals and Systems (ICSigSys)
abstract: Digital signal processing applications are very common in satellites. These applications are often implemented on Static Random-Access Memory (SRAM)-based Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs). If these applications are safety critical and operate in orbits with very harsh environments, traditional fault-tolerant architectures will not be able to detect/correct Double Event Upsets (DEUs). This paper proposes a multi-die Five Modular Redundancy (5MR) architecture with five replicas of the same module distributed on two dies. Continuous Time Markov Chains (CTMCs) are used to calculate the architecture reliability to find the best module distribution strategy in order to maximize lifetime, taking into account available FPGA resources. A case study is presented, and it shows that splitting the modules between two dies of different technologies/failure rates produces a higher reliability than a traditional Triple Modular Redundancy (TMR) architecture (which cannot detect DEUs) or a 5MR architecture with all 5 modules housed on the newer technology die.

title: Performance Analysis of Solar Panels: Effects of Panel Tilt, Surface Cleanliness, and Weather Conditions
authors: Bilge Sıla Çevik, Ceyda Aksoy Tırmıkçı
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This work examined various factors that influence energy that solar panels can produce such as the angle at which panel is tilted, the cleanliness of the panels and the weather conditions. The collected photovoltaic system hourly data between May 1, 2025, and May 27, 2025, installed on the roof of the M6 building of the Faculty of Engineering, Sakarya University, was processed with the Python computer language, and it was subjected to multi-scenario indices. It was found that the horizontal positioning of panels, with a clean surface and favorable weather conditions contributed to maximal energy output. The results of the research would seek to facilitate the formulation of efficiency and maintenance measures that can be taken into account during the planning of the establishment and maintenance of the solar energy systems.

title: Apple Leaf Disease Recognition Using Intelligent Techniques
authors: Vikky, Satendra Kumar, Neha Mittal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Plant leaf diseases must be identified early and with certainty in order to maintain a healthy agricultural sector and produce an abundance of food. This study covers an in-depth analysis of deep learning models used to identify different apple leaf diseases. The given research analyses how well the models based on deep learning perform when recognizing diseases in leaves of apple trees with reference to the dataset consisting of 11,657 images with attributes (labelled as Apple Scab, Black Rot, Cedar Apple Rust, and Healthy). Convolutional neural network (CNN) models were trained, and criteria of accuracy, loss, confusion matrices and receiver operating characteristic (ROC) plots were used to estimate their accuracy. Such methods as data augmentation, regularization, early stopping were used to improve the generalization of the model. The CNN model with the best performance obtained an test accuracy of 99.64% and the other models were equally well performing. These results are supported by accuracy-loss graphs, multi-class ROC curves. The findings demonstrate the promise of CNN-based methods in diagnosing diseases of crops in farming environments via reliable and fast diagnosis.

title: SVM-LSTM Model for Real-Time Detection of Punching Errors and Classification Using Kinectv2 and BNO055 Sensor
authors: Joseph Bryan G. Ibarra, Keenan Kyle Y. Malonzo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time boxer form analysis system that detects errors, classifies punches, and provides feedback to users on how to correct their errors and how these errors affect the punches. This system utilized a combination of visual and wearable technologies to perform its function, using the Kinect v2 and its joint tracking for form analysis and error detection, as well as two glove-mounted BNO055 9-DOF sensors for punch classification. This system also utilized a hybrid SVM-LSTM model, leveraging the strengths of each algorithm to address the weaknesses of the other, thereby creating a robust real-time form analysis system. The system achieved an accuracy of 0.86 for beginners and 0.73 for amateur/professional fighters in error detection. Additionally, it achieved an average accuracy of 0.93 for beginners and 0.87 for amateur/professionals in punch classification.

title: Research on Bearing Condition Monitoring of Offshore Wind Turbine Units
authors: Haolin Huang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Monitoring the quality of bearings, which are essential parts of offshore wind turbines, is crucial to maintaining operational safety. The paper comprehensively reviews recent advancements in bearing monitoring technologies, categorizing existing approaches into three primary groups based on feature extraction methodologies: signal processing-based techniques, mathematical-statistical models, and data-driven models. We examine the evolutionary progress of these approaches, analyzing their respective strengths, limitations, and operational contexts. Particular attention is given to deep learning-based models, where we elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of temporal sequence models (LSTM variants) and data reconstruction models (AE variants). These advanced models demonstrate enhanced detection capabilities for subtle faults through automated feature learning, overcoming the sensitivity limitations of conventional methods. Future research should prioritize the integration of physical mechanisms with data-driven approaches, while developing adaptable network architectures capable of real-time updates. This dual focus will enable more robust and computationally efficient monitoring systems.

title: Smart UHF-RFID Collar Enhances Sustainability in Precision Livestock Management
authors: Alice Buffi, Gianluca Caposciutti, Luca Turini, Mirko Marracci, Bernardo Tellini, Marcello Mele
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents a smart UHF-RFID collar to monitor sheep behaviour so improving the livestock management. Thanks to a multi-modal sensing approach, several animal parameters are gathered to determine the animal's conditions and to investigate its habits. A UHF-RFID passive tag is integrated in the smart collar to guarantee sheep detection even at large distance, thus creating a monitoring system within stable.

title: C-Band 350Gb/s 8.52-km Optical Interconnect Enabled by Anti-Resonant Hollow-Core Fiber and PS-PAM16
authors: Shouchuan Ma, Qibing Wang, Hui Chen, Lei Zhang, Chao Li, Xu Zhang, Jie Luo, Lei Wang, Zhixue He, Jian Song
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate a C-band 350-Gb/s transmission experiment over 8.52-km anti-resonant hollow-core fiber (AR-HCF) benefiting from the lower chromatic dispersion of AR-HCF and high-order modulation format. Using 92-GBaud PS-PAM16, the measured BER is below the 19% SO-FEC threshold with FFE only, achieving 294-Gb/s net data rate.

title: LoRA-MAEJSCC: Masked Autoencoders for Semantic Communications using Low-Rank Adaptation
authors: Thuy An Nguyen, Tran Ngoc Thinh, Toan van Nguyen, Phuong Luu Vo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of IoT applications has led to spectrum resource constraints, increased power consumption, higher bandwidth usage, and transmission delays. To address these challenges, recent research has focused on semantic communication (SemCom), an emerging 6G network paradigm that prioritizes transmitting only the most important and distinctive information. As part of this effort, we propose MAEJSCC, a SemCom framework based on Vision Transformers, which leverages Masked Autoencoder to achieve robust and efficient transmission in noisy environments. Additionally, we further develop LoRA-MAEJSCC, a lightweight and efficient variant of MAEJSCC by integrating Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) into the linear layers. Experimental results show that LoRA-MAEJSCC achieves competitive classification performance while drastically reducing the number of trainable parameters and adaptation costs compared to the proposed MAEJSCC.

title: Performance-Based Selection Methodology for Web Communication Protocols
authors: Roberto Albeiro Pava Díaz, Dario Alejandro Segura Torres, Bryan Steven Perez Salas
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This paper proposes a practical methodology for evaluating communication protocols through experimental testing under realistic conditions. The approach measures latency, CPU usage, and memory consumption across multiple input scenarios, enabling fast and reliable comparisons without requiring deep theoretical knowledge. A five-step process is applied in a real-world use case involving the cloud migration of an e-commerce system. REST, WebSocket, and gRPC were evaluated, with REST emerging as the most efficient under the system’s constraints. The methodology proves useful in resource-constrained environments and can be extended to other communication paradigms in future work.

title: Ultra-Compact Leaky ReLU Nonlinear Function on IMOS
authors: Antonio Lechiara, Andrea Marchisio, Bin Shi, Yi Wang, Andrea Carena, Yuqing Jiao, Ripalta Stabile
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate the first compact MRR-nested-MZI nonlinear function on the IMOS platform, replicating a Leaky ReLU function. Exploiting ultra-compact phase shifters, the device achieves sub-5dBm triggering power and a footprint of 0.22 mm2, without requiring transfer function optimization.

title: Detecting Impersonation in Social Media: An NLP and Machine Learning Perspective
authors: Ihab A. Agha, Nancy K. Bou Ghannam, Mahmoud El Samad, Kamil Badereldine
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: As we begin to rely more on the Internet and social media, impersonation has taken off as a common and dangerous problem, for causes like seeking out attention to pulling off scams, and impersonating celebrities or other famous people. This is violating the basic rights to keep our data safe and, in essence, is highly dangerous not only for people but also for companies. In this context, we are interested in developing efficient algorithms for real-time detection and prevention of fake accounts for the privacy of users (e.g., celebrities) and to reduce impersonation risks. As a first contribution, we collected an accurate dataset of public figures from different data sources. Each record has been labeled and tagged with the appropriate attributes to ensure that the algorithm can accurately distinguish between real and fake data. This initial step allowed us to create a comprehensive dataset to train algorithms to recognize and find such data online is either not feasible or unavailable in open-source formats due to the inclusion of personal information. Our data set comprises 1,400 carefully selected personal data records, mainly from celebrities, with 80% allocated for training and 20% for testing. The second contribution is an algorithm that leverages a Natural Language Processing (NLP) framework to analyze data entered during account creation, determining whether the information is legitimate or not. Our study evaluates and compares five main algorithms: Decision Tree (DT), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Naive Bayes (NB), K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), and Random Forest (RF). The experimental results showed that KNN and RF outperformed other algorithms in precision, recall, and F1-score. DT exhibited a precision-recall trade-off, while SVM performed poorly.

title: Spam Message Classification Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning Approaches
authors: Anuj Mangal, Yash Jain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Spam has grown significantly with the global increase in social media use, which has also led to a massive increase in unwanted emails. Spammers use loopholes to share malicious content and capture private details, such as contacts and files, and pose a severe threat to companies and individuals. Unsolicited emails, such as spam and phishing, have a significant negative impact and cost a huge amount each year. Several models and methods have been introduced to automatically classify spam, and none have succeeded in predicting spam with a success rate of 100%. Since spam continues to evolve, traditional systems have not been able to keep up, and therefore there is a strong focus on more reliable alternatives. Potential directions for improving spam detection come from recent developments in deep learning and word embedding methods. Word embeddings, or text-to-machine-readable forms, have proved to be critical in improving model performance. Natural language processing (NLP) further improves detection performance. In this field, machine learning and deep learning algorithms have performed better. With these new techniques, our goal is to create more effective and reliable filtering systems that address unwanted email challenges and protect consumers from related risks.

title: Modeling and Simulation of Photovoltaic Maximum Power Point Tracking Based on Improved Salp Swarm Algorithm Coupled with PEMEC
authors: Bing Hu, Lijun Xu, Chenglong He, Mengke Liao, Songlin Fan, Xiaochao Fan, Yue Liu, Shujuan Zhao
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To improve the overall energy efficiency and to address the co-optimization challenges of photovoltaic power generation, this paper proposes a co-optimization control strategy based on the Improved Salp Swarm Algorithm (ISSA). First, models of the photovoltaic array's output characteristics under varying environmental conditions and the Proton Exchange Membrane Electrolyzer Cell(PEMEC) electrochemical efficiency are established to reveal the dynamic coupling between power input and hydrogen production. To overcome the limitations of conventional maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms — such as susceptibility to local optima and slow dynamic response—an improved SSA algorithm integrating Tent chaotic mapping and adaptive control mechanisms is proposed. Chaotic initialization enhances population diversity, while leader chaotic perturbation and follower adaptive weighting strategies are incorporated to strengthen the algorithm's global search capability. Simulation results show that, under 25°C and 800 W/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> irradiance, the proposed algorithm achieves an MPPT tracking accuracy of 99.1%, increases steady-state output power by 388.3 W, and reduces response time to 0.17 s, significantly outperforming the traditional SSA algorithm. Moreover, the improved algorithm effectively suppresses power fluctuations, resulting in faster dynamic response and more stable hydrogen production. Consequently, the system's overall energy utilization efficiency is substantially enhanced. The study demonstrates that the proposed ISSA-based co-optimization strategy enables efficient coordination between photovoltaic power generation and the PEM electrolyzer.

title: AI-Assisted Professional Development for English Teachers: Improving Pedagogical Strategies in Adult Education
authors: Jingyi Han
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study emphasizes AI-facilitated tools, notably ChatGPT, in helping English teachers enhance their professional development in adult education. At the moment, in response to high demands for new teaching approaches, AI technologies hold great promise in helping overcome various pedagogical limitations. By focusing on English teachers in China, especially in Shanghai, the study aims to analyze ways in which AI can be utilized to support professional development in improving teaching strategies and in engendering adaptability for adult education settings. This study employs a qualitative methodology of conducting semi-structured interviews among English teachers to determine their experiences, perceptions, and challenges regarding using AI tools. Thematic analysis was made to identify the key patterns and insights from the interviews, which indicate that using ChatGPT improves lesson planning, content creation, and engages learners with it to support teachers in addressing diverse student needs. In addition, the findings indicate some barriers that involve less technical and sufficient resources availability. Targeted training programs with the support of institutions are thus crucial for implementing these changes. This paper contributes to the increasing body of work on AI in education by focusing on the potential of ChatGPT in professional development for teachers in China. The study concludes with practical recommendations for integrating AI tools into adult education to empower educators and improve learning outcomes effectively.

title: Optimal scheduling of hybrid wind-photovoltaic-electricity-hydrogen energy storage microgrid considering safety and health management of energy storage devices
authors: Weishan Song, Ning Zhang, Lirong Xie, Cengceng Wang, Yifan Bian, Jie Hou
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Driven by the goal of " dual-carbon " , wind-photovoltaic- electricity- hydrogen hybrid energy storage microgrids have become an important carrier to enhance the capacity of new energy consumption. Aiming at the problem of renewable energy fluctuation and uncertainty affecting the safety and health of energy storage equipment, a wind-power-hydrogen hybrid energy storage microgrid optimal scheduling model considering the health management of energy storage equipment is proposed. Firstly, a typical scenario of wind-electricity-equivalent uncertainty is established by using the Latin Hypercube algorithm and the K-means clustering algorithm. Secondly, the operating characteristics of battery, electrolyzer and fuel cell are analyzed, and the optimal scheduling model considering the health management of energy storage equipment is established by taking minimizing the operating cost, equipment health loss cost and penalty cost as the objective function, and finally, the Cplex solver is invoked to solve the model based on Matlab. The example results show that the method can effectively balance the economy with equipment safety and health, extend the service life of the energy storage equipment, and improve the operation efficiency of the microgrid.

title: Forging Keystrokes: Practical GAN-based Presentation Attacks on Typing Biometrics
authors: Indrani Roy, Sarker Tanveer Ahmed Rumee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Signals and Systems (ICSigSys)
abstract: In the digital age, biometric authentication has be-come a vital security measure, and keystroke dynamics provides an affordable and intuitive behavioral biometric solution. The introduction of generative models based on deep learning, how-ever, raises questions about how resistant they are to spoofing. In this paper, the viability of using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) to perform presentation attacks on keystroke dynamics is investigated. In order to produce artificial typing patterns that resemble real users without the need for explicit conditioning, we design and test three GAN variants: CNN-GAN, LSTM-GAN, and Vanilla-GAN. Three datasets were used for the experiments: a multi-sentence paragraph with rephrased content, an arbitrary sentence, and a fixed-length password string. A Siamese Neural Network (SNN) authenticator that had already been trained was used to evaluate the produced samples. In every dataset, GANs were able to replicate user-specific typing rhythms and fool the SNN. When it came to accuracy, the LSTMGAN consistently performed the best (95–96%), followed closely by CNN-GAN (92–94%), and Vanilla-GAN (80–87%). Crucially, synthetic keystrokes were indistinguishable from real patterns, even in intricate free-text and paragraph scenarios. These results underline a serious flaw in keystroke-based authentication and the pressing need for strong defences against presentation attack powered by GANs.

title: An open-circuit fault localization method for MMC based on the noise-corrected 3σ criterion
authors: Shixin Huang, Tianzhen Wang, Fan Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The modular multilevel converter (MMC) has gained widespread adoption in high voltage direct current (HVDC) systems due to its superior output waveform quality, modular configuration, and excellent scalability. There are a large number of power switches in MMCs, meaning that each one can be a potential point of failure. This abnormality can distort the MMC output voltage and current and may even damage the MMC. Therefore, diagnosing open-circuit faults in MMCs is very important for the stable, safe, and reliable operation of the system. In practical applications, the actual characteristics of the sensor (such as drift, stability, etc.) will introduce sensor noise. Due to noise interference in MMCs, the submodule capacitor voltage easily exceeds the threshold, resulting to false alarms. An noise-corrected 3σ criterion-based open-circuit fault localization method is proposed. The threshold is corrected in this method, taking into account the characteristics of the faulty submodule capacitor voltage and the influence of sensor noise. By comparing the submodule capacitor voltage with the corrected threshold, the faulty submodule can be quickly located. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves fast and accurate localization of faulty SMs with strong robustness against noise interference.

title: A Retrieval-Augmented Generation Model for Faith-Aligned QA in Bhagvat Gita
authors: Namit Khanduja, Dr. Nishnat Kumar, Dr. Arun Chauhan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) techniques are now absolutely essential for raising the accuracy of specialized domain large language models. This work presents GitaGPT, a novel Question Answering system developed to combine generative artificial intelligence with advanced retrieval methods to offer authoritative interpretations of the Bhagavad Gita. Unlike traditional methods depending just on quick engineering or model fine-tuning, our technique uses a complex two-stage process. First, the most pertinent scripture texts are found via a custom-built retrieval module using cosine similarity and specialized text embedding. Second, these parts give the LLaMA-3.2 language model contextual anchors to generate doctrinally correct responses. Our comprehensive study reveals clear benefits over current methods, with a 40% drop in factual errors comparing to typical implementations. Constructed using open-source tools such as ChromaDB and LlamaIndex, the system architecture offers best performance with 512-token chunks, therefore balancing response latency under 1.5 seconds with retrieval accuracy (0.85 MRR). Theological experts confirmed the output quality; 94% of the responses fit accepted scriptural readings. This approach not only improves conversational artificial intelligence for religious literature but also provides a general structure for other knowledge-intensive disciplines demanding factual accuracy.

title: AI-Powered Moodle Modules for Advanced E-Learning
authors: Radka Nacheva
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The rapid development of artificial intelligence (AI) provides new opportunities for improving e-learning environments. AI-powered Moodle modules can transform traditional learning management systems into adaptive, personalized platforms that deliver the necessary digital content tailored to the needs of learners. These modules can focus on automated test generation, intelligent learning, predictive analytics, and learning content creation, which can reduce the workload of educators and improve student engagement. They also enable real-time feedback, provide adaptive learning paths, and use inclusive tools that support diverse learning styles and accessibility requirements. The purpose of this paper is to explore the possibilities of integrating AI-powered Moodle modules into digital education to improve collaboration in learning environments. Our pilot experiments show that integrating AI into Moodle can increase efficiency, learning outcomes, and overall satisfaction for both learners and educators.

title: Auto Power Supply Control from 4 Different Sources using Microcontroller
authors: Sumit Saini, Manoj Saini, Abhay Shukla, Abhishek Kumar Mishra, Devansh Choudhary, Abhay Yadav
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper develops a multi-source auto power supply system that ensures continuous efficient power delivery. The system enables automatic selection between solar panels, batteries, and fuel cells when each source becomes available and the load needs adjustment. The system operates through a central microcontroller, which manages the source usage based on defined operation criteria and system limitations. Load requirements get met through output stabilization achieved by DC-DC converters, which harmonize fluctuating voltage sources. The control strategies implemented in the system enable distribution of the load efficiently while guaranteeing system reliability during a wide range of operating scenarios. Experimental results together with simulation data demonstrate the system effectiveness, thus making it suitable for renewable energy management and off-grid systems and industrial automation applications. This system design provides energy-efficient capabilities together with cost reduction and reliability improvements, which advance autonomous sustainable power supply risk mitigation implementations through microcontroller and relay device implementation. The system moves to the subsequent priority generator from the original power source if the first generator stops operating. The LEDs used in that source allow users to monitor when that power supply becomes operational.

title: Life prediction of sodium-ion battery based on a double exponential equation
authors: Jiaze Liu, Yvqiang Chen, Bowei Zhang, Changhua Hu, Chuanyang Li, Zhaoqiang Wang, Mingzhe Leng
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Against the backdrop of continuously growing global energy demand and the limited availability of lithium resources, sodium-ion batteries have emerged as a promising alternative for energy storage and have gradually become a focal point of research and industrial application. This paper presents a life prediction method for sodium-ion batteries based on a double-exponential equation model. By analyzing the capacity retention rate data of sodium-ion batteries and applying the double-exponential equation for curve fitting and predictive modeling, the service life of these batteries is successfully estimated. The results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively characterizes the capacity retention decay behavior over charge-discharge cycles and enables reasonably accurate life prediction. Although the model has certain limitations, it offers a rapid and straightforward approach for battery life assessment, providing valuable support for battery manufacturers. This approach holds significant potential in the field of battery lifespan prediction and serves as a reliable basis for quantitative life evaluation.

title: Deep Learning for Suspicious Activity Detection in Surveillance Videos
authors: Chinnavel Siva Kumar, B. Prasad, Ramavath Rahul Naik, Yadiki Venkata Puneeth Setty, Somannagari Prashanthi, Mahesh Marathi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: With the increasing usage of surveillance systems and the malicious practicing of activities, modern security objectives have warranted the use of sophisticated techniques to detect such behavior. Typically, with conventional systems, signals are controlled by operator intervention, making it sensitive to fatigue, and it is based on subjective decision. To improve the processing of real time stream of videos to identify suspicious patterns this project applies deep learning methodologies. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) that derive spatial representations from unique video frames and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks that perceive time dependence in sequences of frames are the central components of the system. Therefore, it is important to combine to identify the complex tasks increasing with time. In case of some abnormal activity the system displays red colored rectangles with rest of the region being black around such persons, and also raises the alarm. Since it is trained on labeled normal and suspicious activities, this makes the model trained capable of any form of a practical application. There are multiple strategies, which are used to enhance the results: This work deals with data augmentation, transfer learning, and hyperparameter tuning. It is confirmed by evaluation measures such as precision, recall rate, F1-score, and accuracy that the proposed system is effective. The mass and cost effectiveness of this project provides a solution to reducing the need for manual monitoring and increasing the amount of time spent addressing threats. Deep learning proved its power to innovate surveillance and improve security with widespread usage throughout public security, crime fighting, and protecting critical infrastructure.

title: Co-Existence of Quantum-Key Distribution and Classical Transmission in Space-Division Multiplexed Fiber-Optic Systems: Modelling and Validation Over Field-Deployed Multi-Core Fibers
authors: Qi Wu, D. Ribezzo, G. Di Sciullo, S. Cocchi, D. A. Shaji, L. A. Zischler, R. Luis, P. Serena, C. Lasagni, A. Bononi, T. Hayashi, A. Gagliano, P. Martelli, A. Gatto, P. Parolari, P. Boffi, D. Bacco, A. Zavatta, Y. Zhu, W. Hu, Z. Xu, M. Shtaif, A. Marotta, F. Graziosi, A. Mecozzi, C. Antonelli
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose an analytical model for inter-core spontaneous Raman scattering noise in multi-core fiber systems with co-existing quantum-key distribution and classical transmission in the C-band. The model is experimentally validated over field-deployed multi-core fibers.

title: RFID Coupler Design for Encoding RFID Tags Without Retraction Inside Printers
authors: Kailash Kashyap, Pankaj Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Rigorous study on various RFID coupler designs had been conducted to solve problems such as RFID Tag retraction for encoding, small pitch Tag detection, necessity of dedicated real estate for coupler inside RFID-enabled printers. A novel low-cost UHF RFID coupler design operating from 860960 MHz was proposed in this paper that can encode/decode RFID Tags having pitch size <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geq 0.6$</tex> inch with high reliability. This design proposal has the capability to address the abovementioned problems. Furthermore, this design approach can work as a combo solution along with print head thus achieving both RFID encoding & label Printing simultaneously without retracting Tag, in-turn increasing the throughput of printer.

title: Qiskit-Enabled Simulation of Quantum Key Distribution over Starlink Satellite Networks
authors: Yudai Takihara, Hoang D. Le, Cuong T. Nguyen, Anh T. Pham
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper investigates the performance of free-space optics (FSO)-based satellite-assisted quantum key distribution (QKD). Specifically, we develop a simulation framework using the IBM Quantum Experience (IQX) simulator with Qiskit that closely emulates real-world QKD implementations. The low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite quantum channels, incorporating the atmospheric loss, atmospheric turbulence, and pointing misalignment, are taken into account. Using the developed framework, we investigate QKD performance, including quantum bit error rate (QBER) and secret key rate (SKR), by simulating the key generation rate by IQX, considering the impact of satellite quantum channels over SpaceX’s Starlink networks. The obtained results provide insights into the QKD performance under various quantum channel conditions in satellite-based FSO/QKD systems.

title: Early Detection of Heart Disease Risk Factors Using Machine Learning: A Predictive Approach
authors: Prince, Anupam Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Heart disease is one of the most frequent observed because of fatalities globally. Detecting risk factors early on Plays an important role in reducing disease prevalence and improving patient outcomes. This study investigates the application of ML approaches for detecting early cardiovascular disease risk indicators. Many machine learning models such as vector machine, random forest and decision-making wood were used to evaluate information. This includes the patient's demographic and clinical behavioral properties. The most relevant risk factor for a heart attack was found in the choice of functions for functions. Memory, performance indicators, such as F1 scores, were used. Our findings indicate Machine can be a learning model accurate predict the presence of cardiovascular risk factors. This is a valuable tool for early intervention. The investigation indicates that ML can be used to assist doctors in identifying clients who are at risk before exhibiting clinical signs. As a result, preventive measures can be taken promptly. The research highlights the importance of integrating predictive analytics into routine health assessments. Promote the design of sophisticated medical systems for making decisions.

title: Long-Haul 2000-Km Single-Mode Fibre Transmission with Net Bitrate of 105.6 Tb/S in S+C+L Band Using Low-Noise Forward-Pumped Distributed Raman Amplification
authors: Fukutaro Hamaoka, Hiroto Kawakami, Kosuke Kimura, Masanori Nakamura, Shimpei Shimizu, Takayuki Kobayashi, Yutaka Miyamoto, Etsushi Yamazaki
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We have successfully demonstrated that our proposed forward-pumped distributed Raman amplification (DRA), which reduces noise transfer by using pump light with polarisation-interleaved narrow longitudinal modes, can dramatically extend transmission distance in conjunction with backwardpumped DRA, achieving net 105.6 Tb/s over 2000-km transmission in S+C+L band.

title: Anti-Reflection Coated SSMF to Hollow-Core Fiber Splicing with Low-Loss and Low Back-Reflection
authors: Cong Zhang, Jiajie Chen, Di Lin, Jianping Li, Yuwen Qin, Radan Slavík, Songnian Fu
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a new configuration where splicing occurs 1 mm away from the AR coating, reducing heating of the coating and thus completely eliminating its degradation due to splicing. We achieved splicing loss below 0.3dB with no degradation to the back-reflection that was below -33dB.

title: Efficient Dynamic Range Optimization for Coherent PONs via Burst-Mode Digital Signal Processing with Adaptive Power Rebalancing, and Guard Band Management
authors: Haipeng Zhang, Zhensheng Jia, Curtis Knittle
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We evaluate the dynamic range and receiver sensitivity of 100G/200G coherent PON burst receiver under significant ONU power disparities. A cost-effective solution leveraging burst-mode DSP, Tx power rebalancing, and guard band optimization is proposed, demonstrating substantial improve-ments in dynamic range and receiver sensitivity experimentally. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Failure prediction of water quality parameters in wastewater treatment processes
authors: Qian Qiang, Yao Yanping, Xue Xin
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To address abnormal fluctuations in key wastewater treatment parameters that may reduce treatment efficiency, this study predicts failures by real-time monitoring of effluent COD. Given the process's multi-parameter, highly coupled, and nonlinear nature, correlation analysis selects high-contribution, strongly correlated parameters as auxiliary variables to simplify model inputs. To overcome the SGA algorithm's tendency for local optima due to random initialization, improvements are made in initialization methods, weight factors, and running trajectory to enhance optimization. Additionally, to reduce randomness in WNN model training caused by random initialization of translation/expansion factors, an ISGA algorithm optimizes WNN parameters, improving accuracy and stability. Results demonstrate high prediction accuracy for effluent COD failures.

title: Optical Chiplet with 0.75-pJ/bit Transmitter Using Membrane III-V Electro-Absorption Modulators on Si and Differential CMOS Driver
authors: Tatsurou Hiraki, Tadashi Minotani, Yohei Saito, Takuma Aihara, Yoshiho Maeda, Toru Miura, Takuro Fujii, Tomonari Sato, Norio Sato, Shinji Matsuo
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: An optical chiplet is constructed with membrane electro-absorption modulators (EAMs) where a CMOS driver is embedded in substrates. By combining a low-capacitance membrane InGaAlAs EAM with a differential CMOS driver, the chiplet exhibits an energy cost of 0.75 pJ/bit with 64-Gbps PAM4 signals. ©2025 The Authors

title: Demonstration of a Mid-IR FSO Link Achieving Complex Data Modulation and a Tuneable Wavelength Covering ∼4-5 μm Based on a 1.55-μm-Pumped OPO
authors: Yue Zuo, Huibin Zhou, Zile Jiang, Abdulrahman Alhaddad, Wing Ko, Yingning Wang, Zixun Zhao, Andrew Ross, Adam T. Heiniger, Jacob Scheuer, Moshe Tur, Alan E. Willner
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate a mid-IR FSO link with complex modulation and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 4-5 \mu m$</tex> wavelength tunability, using a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1550-\text{nm}$</tex>-pumped OPO with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 60-400 ~\text{mW}$</tex> transmitted power. We show transmission of various modulation formats (OOK, QPSK, and 16 QAM), achieving a 4-Gbit/s single-channel and a 20 Gbit/s multi-subcarrier-multiplexed link.

title: Indonesian Folklore Storytelling in Japanese Language with Text-to-Speech
authors: Michael Brian Pratama Tjoa, Bagus Tris Atmaja, Sakriani Sakti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Signals and Systems (ICSigSys)
abstract: Indonesia possesses a rich cultural heritage, including traditional folklore. This study proposes an integrated framework for cross-lingual folklore preservation by automating the conversion of Indonesian folk narratives into Japanese speech to encourage these narratives internationally. Japanese speech was selected based on the research context being conducted in Japan, providing a relevant case study for future cross-lingual applications. The system combines machine translation and text-to-speech (TTS) synthesis: Google Translate converts Indonesian text into Japanese, and a fine-tuned Style-Bert-VITS2 model generates high-quality, expressive speech. The findings demonstrate that the model successfully produces natural and intelligible Japanese narration, highlighting the potential of this method for cultural preservation through dissemination.

title: Bridging Perception and Communication with Intelligence: An Overview of AI in 6G ISAC Systems
authors: Mücahit Altıntaş, Sedat Çimen, Sümeye Nur Karahan, İbrahim Yazıcı, İsmail Duru
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communications (ISAC) brings together communication and environmental sensing on a shared spectrum and hardware, and is a promising component of next-generation wireless network architecture. The utilization of artificial intelligence (AI) within ISAC systems engenders substantial enhancements in terms of contextual awareness, real-time decision-making capabilities, and adaptability within dynamic environments. This paper presents a review of AI-enabled ISAC system architecture, covering key components such as waveform design, signal processing, resource management, and edge intelligence. It demonstrates the implications of the combination of ISAC and AI in various application domains. Furthermore, contemporary challenges such as joint optimization complexity, data scarcity, hardware-intelligence co-design, and security/privacy are discussed. Finally, the paper lays out a number of future research directions, including self-supervised learning (SSL) for unlabeled data, collaborative AI for distributed situational awareness, and neuromorphic and quantum AI possibilities for scalable ISAC. Hence, the paper offers a visionary perspective on the transformative potential of AI-enhanced ISAC systems in shaping the future of wireless communications infrastructure.

title: A Novel Technique for Privacy Preservation of Vehicle users using Blockchain during accessing Smart Applications
authors: Amit Kumar Tyagi, Khushboo Tripathi, Yogesh Singh Rathore, Shrikant Tiwari, Shabnam Kumari, Bhavesh Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: With the progress of smart transport and vehicular networks, protecting data privacy and the security of user communication has become increasingly important. This paper presents a fresh approach to a blockchain-based architecture which maintains the privacy of vehicle users when interacting with smart applications. Current vehicular networks have serious limitations around centralized data and management approaches: they are prone to data tampering and unauthorized access. The method presented in this study combines decentralized records and cryptographic tools to store sensitive user data so that the data is protected while enabling access control and authentication. Smart contracts are used to automate transaction validation against intended privacy policies without Transactional intermediaries. The system architecture facilitates anonymized vehicular data access to only authorized users, which will help mitigate the opportunities for identity exposure and abuse of data. The verification method proposed is shown here to have low latency, to be scalable, and trustworthy; regardless of a reasonably common threat through a network attack. The experimental analysis shows the method presented can be trustworthy, achieve data integrity, data privacy, and access that can be trusted in real time. This method is a potential step towards building smart transport systems that open up the potential of multi-hop vehicular networks through blockchain technology.

title: FIFO-less Bidirectional Core-Pumped 4-core MC-EDFA Featuring with Multicore Isolator / Pump Combiner Hybrids
authors: Hitoshi Takeshita, Yusuke Shimomura, Wakako Maeda
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: A bidirectional multicore EDFA featuring with bidirectional multicore isolator without fan-in fan-out devices was demonstrated, and its amplification operation was successfully demonstrated. In the performance evaluation, −5B.5-dB inter-core crosstalk, 1B.2-dB gain, 22.5-dBm optical output, and 25-% PCE with 5.2-dB NF were obtained when 4-dBm/core input. © 2025 The Author(s)

title: Designing an AI Assisted Telemedicine Portal for Rural India
authors: Bindu Swetha P, Harathi Nimmala, Argha Sarkar, Mayuri Kundu, Sushma K S N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper covers the conceptual development of an AI-powered telemedicine portal designed to cater to the specific healthcare needs of rural India, where access is limited to traditional medical facilities. Founded on digital technologies, the envisioned portal simplifies the healthcare process through real-time video consultations, smart appointment scheduling, and AI-powered chatbot assistance for general health advice. It enables effective healthcare delivery by providing secure video connectivity, automated health screening, and immediate treatment suggestions. In the future, the system will support further enhancement of more features such as increased access to networks of specialists, wearable health monitoring device interface support, multilingual interface support, AI-based diagnostic tools, and telehealth training modules. All these will increase the quality and availability of healthcare services further and support equal provision of healthcare among even the most isolated rural communities.

title: Effective Fault Diagnosis Method for Induction Motors via Knowledge-Enhanced Graph Convolution Networks
authors: Haocheng Wang, Ying Yang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Graph Convolution Network (GCN) has been widely applied in industrial fault diagnosis due to the advantages in small-sample learning and interoperability. However, most existing GCN-based methods are trained using measured data, with limited integration of prior knowledge. Moreover, prior knowledge-based methods are often trained under a single operating condition, limiting their applicability in highly dynamic industrial environments such as metallurgical and rolling mills. In such cases, a single prior knowledge approach struggles to cover all operating conditions. These challenges hinder the application of GCN in industrial settings. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel method for induction motor fault diagnosis based on an improved GCN. Specifically, the method first utilizes prior knowledge to perform a preliminary fault diagnosis and construct an association graph based on the diagnostic results. Then, two subnetworks are trained using fault data under two representative motor load conditions (high and low). A dynamic observer is designed to estimate the real-time operating load of the motor. Finally, the two subnetworks are integrated to form a complete GCN model that covers the full load range. This diagnostic framework effectively integrates prior knowledge and GCN, achieving superior performance compared to existing fault diagnosis methods in experiments. In particular, under varying operating conditions, the proposed method demonstrates better diagnostic performance than other deep learning approaches and unmodified GCN models.

title: 13.56 MHz NFC HF Full Passive and Analog Tag with a Chaotic Duffing Resonator to Achieve Secured Authentication
authors: Adrien Gaffet, Qinyu Liu, Martial Defoort, Nicolas Barbot
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Identification and authentication are major challenges in our society. Radio-Frequency IDentification (RFID) has been in use for more than twenty years. However, authentication usually requires complex digital systems, such as crypto-processors, which significantly increase the cost of the end device. These techniques remain incompatible with many applications where cost is critical. This paper presents preliminary work describing how a transponder at 13.56 MHz can be designed to enable authentication between a fixed reader and a full passive and analogue tag. The antenna is based on an inductive loop, similar to any Near-Field Communication (NFC) tag. The incoming Amplitude Modulated (AM) wave is rectified to provide power to a chaotic system based on a Duffing resonator. The produced chaotic signal is then used to modulate the load connected to the loop antenna to produce a chaotic but deterministic back-scattered signal that can be authenticated by the fixed reader.

title: Intrusion Detection in the Modern Threat Landscape: A Review of Evolving Techniques
authors: Pooja Rani, Parvinder Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: It is very difficult to recognize computer network attacks properly. A s cybercriminals keep on altering packet data to hide from the intrusion detection system (IDS). In addition, several new gadgets are being introduced to computer networks each hour. These new gadgets are making computer networks less secure. The elements of IDSs, the methods and technologies employed, the types of assaults, and the instruments employed must all be carefully studied in order to regulate computer network flows efficiently and provide protection beforehand. In addition to examining novel attack kinds, defense mechanisms, and recent scientific research in this field, this study examines intrusion detection technologies, methodology, and tactics. Furthermore, well-known IDS technologies, available datasets, and the benefits and drawbacks of specific IDSs are thoroughly addressed.

title: Long-Haul SDM Transmission over 12-Coupled-Core Fiber with Semi-Real-Time $24\times 24$ MIMO Processing on FPGA
authors: Manabu Arikawa, Kohei Hosokawa, Takahiro Odaqawa, Hironori Nakanishi, Takaya Maeda, Hiroshi Mukai, Kohki Shlbahara, Taiji Sakamoto, Ryota Imada, Kazuhide Nakajima, Yutaka Miyamoto
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrated transoceanic-class SDM transmission over 12-coupled-core fiber with semi-real-time 24×24 MIMO processing implemented on FPGAs. 1-Gbaud PDM-QPSK signals were transmitted over 8240 km. The mode-dependent loss of 0.26 dB per span and channel variation around 1 ms were monitored using semi-real-time adaptive filter coefficients.

title: Recent Advances in Machine Learning for Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces: Methods, Applications, and Open Challenges
authors: Yasin Emre Tok
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) are planar, programmable metasurfaces that reshape radio propagation to enhance coverage, suppress interference, and enable environment-aware MIMO operation. This survey synthesizes recent machine-learning advances for RIS-aided communications, focusing on: (i) channel estimation and CSI compression with deep and physics-informed models; (ii) RIS configuration and joint active–passive beamforming via reinforcement learning and discrete/combinatorial optimization; and (iii) sensing, localization, and ISAC that exploit RIS-induced spatial diversity. After a concise system-model primer (passive vs. hybrid-active RIS, near- vs. far-field, wideband OFDM, discrete phase quantization), we organize methods by task and compare them under unified metrics—accuracy, sample complexity, inference latency, and robustness to mobility, blockage, and hardware impairments. We also review prototypes and case studies, emphasizing controller architectures, compute budgets, and real-time constraints. The paper concludes with open challenges and a research agenda, highlighting gaps in sim-to-real transfer, safe and uncertainty-aware control, handling non-stationarity, near-field/wideband coupling, and standardized interfaces (e.g., O-RAN) for deployment. By mapping tasks to techniques and practical constraints, the survey offers a compact guide to what works, where, and why—aimed at accelerating robust, reproducible RIS-enabled 6G systems.

title: Lightweight Deep Learning Model for Low-Light Human Activity Recognition: ARID v1.5 Dataset
authors: Manjot Rani, Munish Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Recognizing human activity means it is a process of classifying and recognizing human activities using information collected from different sources it may be camera or non-visual sensors. Human Activity Recognition plays an important role in various domains such as surveillance, sports, security, and healthcare. Still, existing human activity recognition systems often face difficulties in real-world, low-light environments, which are essential in real-world surveillance scenarios. This study addressed and solved this obstacle by using the lightweight, low-light-condition-suited MobileNet model on the ARID v1.5 dataset. ARID v1.5 is a challenging video dataset that contains a total 3,784 video clips from 11 activity categories, specially designed for low-light conditions, in contrast to University of Central Floriad101 dataset, which is a popular benchmark for Human Activity Recognition and focuses on well-lit and controlled environments. MobileNet, is a lightweight model which is optimized for mobile and edge devices, offered an effective balance between classification accuracy and computational efficiency. After being improved with more layers to improve performance, the model is then customized. So, basically, based on experimental results, MobileNet using UCF101 dataset achieved 98.47% accuracy and MobileNet's 76.35% accuracy on the ARID v1.5 dataset showed that it is appropriate for detecting persons in dim lit or in dark environments and also created a benchmark because no prior experiments have been done before on this dataset.

title: High-gain Suspended Silicon Nitride Waveguide Amplifiers En-abled by Double-sided $\text{Er}^{3+}:\mathrm{A}1_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ Coating
authors: Chen Zhou, Yihang Pan, Hao Zhang, Shengyun Zhu, Xiaoyan Zhou, Lin Zhang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate a suspended <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}i_{3}N_{4}$</tex> erbium-doped waveguide amplifier (EDWA), achieving 22.29-dB net gain and 12.51-dBm on-chip output power. This is enabled by double-sided atomic layer deposition (ALD) of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}i_{3}N_{4}$</tex> core with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Er^{3+}: Al/_2\mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> films, which sets a new benchmark for ALD-based EDWAs. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Performance of PM Holmium Doped Fiber Amplifiers with Hybrid Pumping at 1150nm and 1860nm
authors: Jean-Marc Delavaux, Hakim Tahi, Aydin Yeniay, Alexandre Amavigan
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We investigate the performance of a PM holmium doped fibre amplifier (HDFA) at 2050nm with a hybrid pumping consisting of an out-of-band co-pumping at 1150nm and in-band counter-pumping at 1860nm. We show that such amplifier achieves a 3dB noise figure while delivering multi-watt output power.

title: Big Data Analytics for Optimizing Film Distribution and Social Media Promotion
authors: Bianyi Liang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The study presented a multi-faceted big data analytics model, which employs the Random Forest prediction model to forecast the levels of audience engagement to assist in making specific film distribution choices. The framework examines trends by bringing together various datasets, such as box office data, streaming data, demographics, and social media to determine the most viable geographic locations and platforms to release. Random Forest model is used to assign interest level of a user and predict the possible viewership based on the past performance indicators and sentiment information. At the same time, social media posts, including tweets, posts, hashtags, and interactions with influencers, will be processed with Natural Language Processing (NLP) methods to retrieve the sentiment polarity, the frequency of engagement, and thematic alignments. These learnings are applied in real-time to optimise the promotional creative, timing and platform targeting to achieve the greatest reach and optimise the budget. The system also uses the techniques of clustering the audience groups and establishing the alignment of the content according to the behavioural and psychographic attributes. The framework enables data-based decision-making regarding both the conventional and digital distribution channel by combining predictive modelling with social feedback analysis. The modular design provides scalability in independent film campaigns and large-scale movie campaigns and can provide actionable intelligence to movie producers, distributors, and marketers. Finally, this method allows showing how machine learning and big data can transform promotional and distribution approaches in the entertainment business, resulting in better economic returns and viewer satisfaction.

title: Systems Diagnostics Using AI-Enhanced Imaging Techniques for Smart Grid Applications
authors: Gurnoor Singh Dang, Majid Rodgar, Michael Snyder
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Signals and Systems (ICSigSys)
abstract: We present a novel cross-domain application of AI-enhanced medical imaging techniques for intelligent fault diagnostics in smart grid infrastructure. We introduce FusionScan-AI, an image processing pipeline originally developed for enhancing Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Computed Tomography (CT) scans, and adapt it for visual analysis of electrical components such as transformers, switchgear, and power distribution units. The pipeline consists of three core stages: deep learning–based denoising, adaptive contrast enhancement, and edge sharpening via convolutional filters. These stages collectively improve the clarity of noisy, low-contrast thermal and visual sensor data. By simulating these enhancements on infrared thermographic images of substation and high-voltage equipment, we show that latent faults such as insulation degradation, connector overheating, and structural anomalies become more detectable. Drawing on proven success in detecting tumors and microlesions in medical contexts, we demonstrate the transferability of these techniques to autonomous fault detection in the smart grid. Our results support the feasibility of using AI-based medical imaging pipelines for condition monitoring in distributed energy systems, paving the way for safer, more efficient, and predictive maintenance strategies in next-generation power networks.

title: Source Data Free Abnormal Sound Detection of Industrial Equipment Based on Teacher-student Structure
authors: Wenhao Yang, Kunpeng Wang, Wenbo Li, Yi Chai, Yuan Ke, Juan Yao
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In industrial equipment maintenance, acoustic monitoring offers an effective non-contact approach for anomaly detection. However, deep learning-based methods typically require large quantities of high-quality labeled data, which are difficult to obtain in real-world industrial environments due to equipment heterogeneity, data sensitivity, and the high cost of manual annotation. To address the challenges posed by the increasing diversity of equipment types and the growing volume of unlabeled data, this paper proposes an anomaly sound detection method based on a teacher–student framework that operates without access to source data. Pre-trained teacher models are used to perform inference on unlabeled acoustic data, and a statistical filtering mechanism based on anomaly scores is employed to generate high-confidence pseudo-labels. These pseudo-labels guide the student model to learn the predictive distribution of the teacher models. Experiments conducted on the MIMII dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves strong detection performance without relying on source data or labeled samples, reaching an average AUC of 87.79% and pAUC of 81.58%.

title: Leveraging AI for Governance: Navigating Ethical Challenges and Enhancing Democratic Values in Public Services
authors: Vani Kataria, Shaharyar Asaf Khan, Seema Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This study examines the role of artificial intelligence (AI) in governance, democracy, and public service delivery, highlighting the global decline in trust in political institutions and the erosion of democratic norms. It highlights the importance of integrating ethical, transparent, and accountable AI to restore public confidence while addressing critical concerns, such as bias, privacy, and algorithmic transparency. The research examines the evolution of secular governance, with a particular focus on India’s multicultural and pluralistic model, illustrating how diverse political frameworks influence the adoption of AI and public trust in it. It argues that the effective utilisation of AI requires reassessing public sector practices, developing robust governance frameworks, and prioritising citizen participation, digital literacy, and capacity-building to ensure equitable access to AI. Interdisciplinary collaboration and international cooperation are identified as essential for creating resilient AI governance models. Looking ahead to 2050, the study calls for a balanced strategy that aligns AI’s transformative potential with democratic principles and citizens’ rights, ensuring that technological innovation contributes to the common good and effectively addresses societal challenges. (Abstract)

title: Optimized Signal Processing for High-Resolution FBG Strain Sensing Using a Dual-Comb Interrogator
authors: Alejandro Rosado, Malhar A. Nagar, Minghao Wei, Conor McArdle, Aleksandra Kaszubowska-Anandarajah, Davide Janner, Prince M. Anandarajah
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: A high-resolution sensing system based on a DOFC interrogating a fs-inscribed FBG is presented. Optimized signal processing was employed to obtain sub-<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu \varepsilon$</tex> strain resolution (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.32 \mu \varepsilon$</tex>) with a dynamic range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$422 \mu \varepsilon$</tex>, highlighting the potential for precise and real-time sensing applications.

title: An Improved BRB Fault Diagnosis Method Considering Laplace Score and Sigmoid Weight Assignment
authors: Kun Wang, Zhijie Zhou, Zhichao Ming, Fuqiao Zhang, Wenbo Li
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Aiming at the limitations of the traditional Belief Rule Base model in facing high-dimensional fault features due to the increase of model complexity by redundant features and the reliance on experts’ experience or equal allocation of attribute weights, this paper introduces an improved BRB fault diagnosis method considering Laplace score and Sigmoid weight assignment. First, the Laplace fractional value method is used to screen the original feature set to obtain a subset of features with higher contribution; following that, the sigmoid function is innovatively introduced to transform the feature scores into attribute weights, which effectively improves the performance of the diagnostic model while retaining the interpretability advantage of BRB. Experimental validation is carried out through motor bearings, which confirms the accuracy and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Seq-Dssm: A Sequence-Processing-Based Deep State Space Model for Soft Sensing
authors: Shuo Li, Yi Chai, Yun Jiang, Liping Guo, Xiaoxiao Ma, Zhiyuan Lv
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
