abstract: This paper introduces a novel sequence-processing-based deep state space model (Seq-Dssm) designed for soft sensing modeling of air preheaters in thermal power plants. In contrast to conventional deep state space models, our approach employs sequential processing to circumvent matrix inversion operations, thereby enhancing computational efficiency and numerical stability, making it particularly well-suited for modeling multi-input multi-output (MIMO) systems. Tests conducted on real-world operational data from a thermal power plant demonstrate that the proposed model significantly improves the prediction accuracy of air preheater outlet monitoring variables. Furthermore, by providing predictive uncertainty estimates, it offers more reliable guidance for power plant operations. Experimental results confirm the method’s high prediction accuracy and its promising potential for engineering applications.

title: Generative AI-Based Digital Narrative Content Generation for Ideological and Political Education and Ethical Risk Prevention
authors: Xiuying Lu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This research is initiated by the challenge to reconcile the impact of learning with cautious AI use in politically and culturally sensitive environments. This work is a study of a Generative AI-based framework for the creation of dynamic, individualized digital narratives geared toward improving ideological and political education while dealing with ethical risks. The proposed methodology is Deep Q Network (DQN)-driven reinforcement learning technique that modifies the narrative elements depending on user engagement metrics, cognitive load, and how they align with core educational values. By using large scale pre-trained language models and training them within pedagogical setting the system does not only achieve contextual relevance but also ideological fidelity. The hybrid rubric used to assess digital narratives integrates semantic coherence, value conformity, and emotional resonance. A multi-armed experimental set up across university level political education courses is used to measure efficacy. Results indicate that the AI-created content greatly enhances student understanding, retention, critical thought as compared to traditional passive materials. Furthermore, the integrated ethical risk assessment successfully filters biased or inappropriate outputs through the rule-based and probabilistic verification layers. The adaptive capacity of the model even provides live narrative tweaks based on changing student reaction and curriculum movements.

title: Research on the integration of Internet of Things and artificial intelligence in the construction of green transportation infrastructure: Aiming at optimizing transportation economic and environmental benefits
authors: Ye Zhu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT) is transforming transportation infrastructure by enhancing efficiency, economic viability, and environmental sustainability. This Systematic Literature Review (SLR) examines how AI and IoT contribute to green transportation systems, focusing on their role in traffic management, energy efficiency, and cost reduction. The findings highlight that AI-driven predictive analytics and IoT-based real-time monitoring significantly reduce congestion, fuel consumption, and emissions. Additionally, these technologies optimize resource allocation, minimize operational expenses, and improve system reliability, making transportation networks smarter and more adaptive. The study identifies two key themes: (1) the role of AI and IoT in improving transportation efficiency, and (2) their economic benefits in reducing costs and enhancing sustainability. However, limited research explores their combined impact, presenting a gap in understanding real-world implementation challenges. Future research should address policy implications, infrastructure constraints, and integration barriers to maximize their potential. By leveraging AI and IoT, transportation systems can transition toward a more intelligent, cost-effective, and eco-friendly future.

title: Computational Characterization of Ion Beam Uniformity of Planar Pinched-Beam Ion Diodes
authors: A. K. Tichy, J. C. Foster, S. B. Swanekamp, P. F. Ottinger
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: This work presents a particle-in-cell (PIC) simulation-based analysis of ion-beam uniformity from planar diodes. Diode configurations with variations in anode geometry, thickness, and material were explored, including round, tapered, and monolithic polyethylene and Mylar designs. The ion fluence and current enclosed profiles were extracted to assess the quality of the beam across the anode surface. The results show that dual-anode planar geometries produce promising ion beam uniformities, with the most uniform case yielding a coefficient of variation of 10.62%. Round-edge designs mitigate magnetic field losses at anode tips, while thinner anodes enhance ion production through increased electron reflexing. These findings support the use of planar diodes in high-uniformity ion beam environments for materials testing applications.

title: Harnessing Lightweight Transformer With Contextual Synergic Enhancement for Efficient 3D Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Xinyu Liu, Zhen Chen, Wuyang Li, Chenxin Li, Yixuan Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Transformers have shown remarkable performance in 3D medical image segmentation, but their high computational requirements and need for large amounts of labeled data limit their applicability. To address these challenges, we consider two crucial aspects: model efficiency and data efficiency. Specifically, we propose Light-UNETR, a lightweight transformer designed to achieve model efficiency. Light-UNETR features a Lightweight Dimension Reductive Attention (LIDR) module, which reduces spatial and channel dimensions while capturing both global and local features via multi-branch attention. Additionally, we introduce a Compact Gated Linear Unit (CGLU) to selectively control channel interaction with minimal parameters. Furthermore, we introduce a Contextual Synergic Enhancement (CSE) learning strategy, which aims to boost the data efficiency of Transformers. It first leverages the extrinsic contextual information to support the learning of unlabeled data with Attention-Guided Replacement, then applies Spatial Masking Consistency that utilizes intrinsic contextual information to enhance the spatial context reasoning for unlabeled data. Extensive experiments on various benchmarks demonstrate the superiority of our approach in both performance and efficiency. For example, with only 10% labeled data on the Left Atrial Segmentation dataset, our method surpasses BCP by 1.43% Jaccard while drastically reducing the FLOPs by 90.8% and parameters by 85.8%. Code is released at https://github.com/CUHK-AIM-Group/Light-UNETR.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Using a Low-Divergence Pin-Like Beam in a 2-Gbit/s FSO Link with Limited Receiver Aperture Sizes and Variable Link Lengths under Turbulence Effects
authors: Zile Jiang, Xinzhou Su, Huibin Zhou, Yue Zuo, Yuxiang Duan, Murale Ramakrishnan, Abdulrahman Alhaddad, Hongkun Lian, Yingning Wang, Ruoyu Zeng, Zixun Zhao, Jan Tepper, Francesco Nardo, Moshe Tur, Volker Ziegler, Alan E. Willner
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: In FSO communication links employing conventional Gaussian beams, power loss can become an issue due to the divergence nature of a Gaussian beam. This issue becomes more severe when the Rx aperture is relatively small and/or the link length varies. Additionally, atmospheric turbulence can further degrade the link performance by causing beam wandering and scintillation. In this paper, we use a “pin-like” beam to mitigate the adverse effects of limited aperture, variable link length, and turbulence in an FSO communication link. The beam rapidly contracts upon transmission and keeps a small size over a relatively long distance. Experimental results show the pin-like beam's diameter converges from 7 mm to < 1 mm upon 0.6-m propagation, resulting in average power loss reduction of > 3.6 dB compared to a Gaussian beam at different distances (0.6 m and 0.9 m) and with different Rx aperture diameters (1 mm and 3 mm), in the presence of turbulence effects emulated by a phase plate of r<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> = 1 mm. This improvement translates to reduced BER and outage probability in a 2-Gbit/s OOK link. As an example, under a 3-mm-diameter Rx aperture, using the pin-like beam achieves error-free transmission in 40000 symbols for 100 random turbulence realizations, while the Gaussian beam has a 3% outage probability (BER > 3.8e-3). We further simulate a 1.5-km FSO link to compare the pin-like beam with the regular Gaussian beam and focused Gaussian beams with different focal lengths. Results reveal that, while a focused Gaussian beam may have low turbulence-induced power loss at its focal point, the pin-like beam delivers consistent performance across the link.

title: PIDiff: Integrating a High-Performance Transformer into Diffusion Models for Robust and Efficient Imitation Learning
authors: Yunzhi Huang, Peng Jin, Liang Han, Yingzhao Li, Xudong Hou
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Imitation learning is a critical approach for robots to acquire skills by mimicking human behavior. However, traditional imitation learning frameworks often exhibit poor action prediction accuracy and low robustness when handling complex tasks. To tackle these limitations, we propose the PIDiff policy that integrates an enhanced linear-complexity Transformer with a diffusion model and introduces a PointNet-based encoder to efficiently extract visual features, thereby enhancing the policy's understanding of the environment and improving learning efficiency and robustness. Specifically, we introduce the designed SubLink Block and CrossLink Block, enabling the improved Transformer to serve as the noise predictor in the diffusion strategy while retaining the diffusion model's ability to capture multi-modal distributions. To comprehensively evaluate the effectiveness of our method, we conducted systematic experiments across multiple tasks on three robotic manipulation benchmark platforms in simulation environments and performed evaluations in various real-world scenarios. The experimental results demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms baseline methods, achieving higher success rates, faster inference speeds, reduced GPU memory usage, and enhanced robustness.

title: Fingertip-Powered Interactive Gaming: A Sustainable Approach to Human-Machine Interaction
authors: Xin Li, Yuxing Zhong, Xinyuan Chuai, Yaoyi Li, Weifeng Huang, Jiaming Chen, Xinming Zhang, Daxing Zhang, Congsi Wang, Guobiao Hu, Junrui Liang, Wei-Hsin Liao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Human-motion energy harvesting is emerging as a promising solution for wearable electronics and devices, offering a sustainable power source that extends operational longevity and enhances durability. However, current techniques and prototypes have yet to achieve fully interactive, battery-free functionality. This paper presents a battery-free interactive gaming system powered by energy harvested from transient fingertip motion. To ensure the reactivity, interactivity, and stability of the fingertip motion harvester (FMH), we employ a multistable structure. The FMH unit provides a reliable energy solution by utilizing precharged potential energy within dynamically varying potential wells. Additionally, the integration of a bistable screen design facilitates seamless gaming experiences, decouples game logic from user interface mechanics, and ensures rapid system recovery after power interruptions. Beyond advancing fundamental research, this work pioneers a practical battery-free interaction paradigm based on fingertip motion, with potential for broader battery-free user interfaces and low-power interactive systems.

title: Fault-Tolerant Control of a Coaxial Tilt-Rotor eVTOL Aircraft via a Precise Faulty Factor Observer
authors: Zheng Hou, Zongyang Lv, Yuhu Wu, Kai Liu, Hao Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper proposes a fault-tolerant control strategy based on a precise faulty factor observer for a coaxial tilt-rotor (CTR) eVTOL aircraft to counteract a rotor's loss-of-effectiveness (LOE) fault. A force/torque-calculation-based (FCB) observer is designed to estimate the rotor faulty factor. Combining the estimated information, an attitude controller and a velocity controller are developed to address the LOE fault. These controllers are designed to theoretically ensure that the CTR-eVTOL maintains stable flight and achieves fault-tolerant control even when confronted with a 100% LOE fault in one rotor. To further illustrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed control strategy, ground bench tests involving comparative controllers and a real-time flight experiment are conducted. The experimental results demonstrate that the designed fault-tolerant control strategy can effectively address the LOE fault, enhancing the safety of the CTR-eVTOL during flight.

title: Multi-Modal Last-Mile Delivery Optimization With Smart Micro-Hubs: A Branch-and-Price Approach With Valid Inequalities
authors: Kassem Danach, Ali Raad, Abbass Nasser
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The rapid growth of e-commerce and urban logistics has intensified the challenges associated with last-mile delivery, necessitating the integration of autonomous delivery vehicles (ADVs), drones, and smart micro-hubs for cost-effective and sustainable operations. This study introduces a novel Multi-Depot Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem with Time Windows and Multi-Modal Transportation (MD-CVRPTW-MM), where deliveries are dynamically assigned to either ADVs or drones while optimizing hub locations and vehicle routing. The objective is to minimize total operational costs, including transportation, hub activation, and delivery mode selection, while ensuring service-level constraints such as time windows and capacity limits. To efficiently solve this complex combinatorial problem, we propose a mathematical formulation enhanced with valid inequalities for computational efficiency. Furthermore, a Branch-and-Price algorithm is developed, where column generation is employed to iteratively refine delivery routes while enforcing depot assignments and mode selection constraints. The solution approach integrates dual stabilization techniques and path-based heuristics to accelerate convergence. Experimental evaluations on benchmark datasets and real-world logistics scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in reducing last-mile delivery costs, optimizing fleet utilization, and enhancing service reliability. The results highlight the significance of multi-modal last-mile delivery optimization in improving urban logistics and sustainability. This research contributes a new mathematical model, efficient optimization techniques, and practical insights for intelligent last-mile delivery planning in smart cities.

title: Smart Home Security System with IOT and Voice Notifications
authors: Sanjay Kumar Aggarwal, Jagvinder Singh, Arvinder Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The development of the Internet of Things (IoT) has changed the landscape of intelligent security systems that offer remote monitoring, automation, and real-time surveillance. The article describes the development and deployment of an Internet of Things (IoT)-based security system that uses voice messaging to provide more convenient and prompt alerts for intrusions or suspicious activity. Motion sensors, wireless transceivers, and a microprocessor are used in the suggested system to identify intruders and sound speech alerts using speakers and GSM modules. Text-to-speech technology-processed voice alerts provide enhanced situational awareness and human-quality engagement while alerting residents or security personnel. The system is deployable in secure locations, homes, and offices, and it is reasonably priced and expandable. The maximum message passing rate and minimum intrusion detection time provided by the experimental findings have an impact on the solution's usefulness and usability. The extension is a continuation of ongoing research into developing benign and intelligent IoT security infrastructures.

title: User Clustering and UAV Positioning in Hybrid NOMA-Aided Space-Air-Ground Integrated Network
authors: Soham Guha Mazumder, Saumya Chaturvedi, Vivek Ashok Bohara
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: Space-air-ground integrated networks (SAGINs), along with spectrally-efficient access schemes such as non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA), possess enormous potential for the sixth-generation (6G) wireless networks. This paper presents a weighted multi-objective optimization (MOO) problem in a hybrid-NOMA assisted SAGIN. We aim to optimize user clusters, unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) position, and the power splitting factor, for maximizing the network sum rate (NSR) and the UAV cluster serving efficiency (CSE). We include non-linear energy harvesting (EH) for UAV’s power constraints, and we model the UAV-user link using the fluctuating two-ray (FTR) fading model. Owing to the intractability of the problem, we decompose it into two parts- the user clustering subproblem and the joint UAV positioning and power splitting factor subproblem. A novel and modified preference relation algorithm (PRA) is presented to solve the first subproblem. The particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is adopted for the second subproblem. Our algorithms result in a 43% increase in the NSR and a 90% increase in the objective function. Finally, we implement an alternative optimization (AO) that runs the algorithms iteratively to further double the achieved NSR. Our solutions are tested via Monte-Carlo simulations and the applicability and scalability are quantified.

title: Blockchain-Based Security Frameworks for IoT-Enabled Smart Communication Networks
authors: Amit Kumar Goyal, Venkata Ramanaiah Chintha, Pankaj Kumar, Sandeep Shenoy Karanchery Sundaresan, Anorgul Ashirova, Arpit Jain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has emerged in communication networks as a response to its increasing integration and proliferation, shaping new ways of communication where more intelligent systems and processes become interconnected and automated. The dissemination of IoT gadgets in communication networks, however, is associated with major security issues, such as unauthorized access, leaked data, and damaging attacks affecting the integrity of essential infrastructure. The conventional security solutions are not generally sufficient for the requirements of IoT as the resource constrained, dynamic topology, and decentralised operation make the deployment of the normal security measures inappropriate in IoT environments. This paper presents a blockchain-based security architecture designed for IoT and 5G enabled smart communication networks. It uses the decentralized and tamper-proof characteristic of blockchain to solve the main security problems in IoT, including secure authentication, data integrity, privacy, and secure communication. With blockchain technology, the RF devices in the network can securely verify each other, guarantee that the data transmitted is correct by checking for authenticity, and eliminate the possibility of communications tampering, although some nodes can be potentially compromised. There is no central authority holding blockchain, and it minimizes the points of failure, and it is resilient. Moreover, smart contracts can automate the security mechanisms, which increase the efficiency of the operations and reduce information dependency. Also swept in the introduced framework are lightweight consensus mechanisms of resource-constraint IoT device, in order that security solutions are unlikely to affect the performance of the network. Moreover, the blockchain is traceable and it is easy to know what occurred and when and can be used to hold accountability and assist in the rapid detection of violations. This article presents a single solution to the secure-IoT-enabled intelligent wireless communication networks by examining the benefits of the blockchain technology and IoT security requirements, which enhance efficiently the reliability, privacy, and scalability of IoT platforms in real life.

title: Research on Safety Hazard Target Detection Method for Open-pit Mines Based on RTDETR
authors: Penghao Wang, Lirong Xie, Yifan Bian, Yi An, Zhiyong Yang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In the intelligentization process of open-pit mines, the detection of safety hazard targets is confronted with technical challenges, including blurred features of small targets, extreme multi-scale distribution of targets, and severe background interference under complex working conditions. An improved lightweight safety hazard target detection algorithm for open-pit mines is proposed based on RT-DETR. Firstly, the lightweight PConv-Block module is incorporated into the backbone feature extraction network, which precisely captures the features of every safety hazard while notably lowering the model’s computational complexity. Secondly, by combining multi-scale feature fusion with the Slimneck structure, the Slimneck-SSFF cross-scale feature fusion framework is proposed; this framework not only enhances adaptability to safety hazards of different scales but also reduces the network computational load. Finally, the GIoU loss function is adopted, and detection accuracy is significantly improved through dynamic adjustment of weight allocation for hard-to-detect safety hazard samples. Test findings show that, compared with the original RT-DETR model, the enhanced version sees a 30% drop in parameter quantity, while its mAP50 metric hits 91.7%. These outcomes fully validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in detecting safety hazards in open-pit mines.

title: Li-Fi: The Future of Wi-Fi
authors: Rajeev Ranjan, Dedakiya Ghanshyam, Aryan Karthik, Deepanshu Verma, Mahesh Kr. Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This research work provides a comprehensive analysis of Light Fidelity (Li-Fi) and Wireless Fidelity (Wi-Fi) technologies. This research also explores their performance metrics, data security and privacy considerations, economic impact, deployment cost, and integration into existing urban infrastructure. The study also considers the recent literature review to evaluate the potential of Li-Fi, a wireless visible light communication technology, as a complement or alternative to dominant Wi-Fi technology. Key findings highlight the Li-Fi’s advantages in data transmission and security due to its use of light to limited areas i.e., the area where the light is illuminated. The paper concludes by discussing the future directions of Li-Fi also exploring its potential role in various applications such as including secure environments and smart cities.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning Scheduling Strategy for UAV Swarms
authors: Renshu Wang, Wenbin Wu, Weihao Zhang, Zhuolei Chen, Manshu Liang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarms offer significant efficiency gains for power infrastructure inspection but face challenges in dynamic task allocation and real-time scheduling. This study proposes a hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework integrating graph neural networks and a hybrid reward mechanism. Key innovations include global-local decision balance, efficient state encoding via graph topology, and a reward function combining short-term inspection efficiency with long-term maintenance forecasting. Experiments demonstrate a 35% improvement in inspection coverage and a 28% reduction in emergency response times compared to traditional methods.

title: 568.8 Tbls C+L-8and Transmission Over 5,166 km in a Standard-Cladding Diameter 19-Core Randomly-Coupled Multicore Fiber
authors: Besma Kalla, Ruben S. Luís, Menno van den Hout, Stefano Gaiani, Daniele Orsuti, Yuta Goto, Georg Rademacher, Benjamin J. Puttnam, Ayumi Inoue, Takuji Nagashima, Tetsuya Hayashi, Pierpaolo Boffi, Thomas Bradley, Chigo Okonkwo, Hideaki Furukawa

abstract: We demonstrate C+L band recirculating transmission over 5166 km of 19-core randomly-coupled multicore fiber with standard cladding diameter. We achieve a total throughput of 568.8 Tb/s and report the highest capacity-distance product measured in any fiber of 2.93 Eb/s-km. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Quantum Entanglement Distribution Coexisting with Classical Communication Over 18-Km Hollow-Core Fibre Links
authors: Sheng Liu, Yue Luo, Dawei Ge, Yun-Ru Fan, Hao Li, Li-Xing You, Dong Wang, De-Chao Zhang, Han Li, Guang-Can Guo, Qiang Zhou
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a scheme that enables the coexistence of quantum entanglement and bidirectional classical signals with a received power of −15 dBm over an 18-km HCF link, which also supports BBM92-based QKD, achieving a theoretical secret key rate of 612 bps.

title: Rise and Future of Smart Wearable Technology for Real-Time Health Monitoring
authors: Sumeet Prashar, Pooja Kataria
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This study focuses on the advancement & growth in the field of smart wearable devices. In recent times, smartwatches have grown into getting more effective health monitoring widgets. These wearable widgets integrate portability and slice-edge technology to let people to fluently cover multitudinous aspects of their health and good. A lot of smartwatches use optic heart rate detectors that track a stoner's heart rate regularly. This capability offers real-time information on heart rate oscillations, which is useful for diagnosing anomalies and assessing general cardiovascular health. There are multitudinous benefits to heart rate monitoring. Wearable technology has the implicit to revise the provision of medical care. In recent times, wearable technology has progressed from being impracticable to being adequately useful. An early look at the newest developments propelling wearable technology forward. Wearable technology is transforming tailored healthcare by ensuring patient safety. Cases and healthcare professionals can profit from ongoing health perceptivity thanks to wearable technology.

title: ExplainNet: A Hybrid Visual-Linguistic Model for Human-Centered Autism Diagnosis
authors: S.M. Sefat, Muhamad Hariz Bin Muhamad Adnan, Md Mahmudul Hasan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder is a complex neurodevelopmental condition that requires early diagnosis for effective treatment. Deep learning-based facial image classification models have demonstrated significant potential for automated autism diagnosis. Nevertheless, the black box nature of the model limits its application for clinical adoption. This paper presents a novel approach to a hybrid model framework that enhances the interpretability of deep learning models by combining visual interpretability with natural language processing. The model utilizes Grad-Cam-based heatmaps with facial landmarks-based region segmentation to indicate salient areas such as the eyes, nose, and mouth that influence classification. In this pilot study, the identified regions are mapped to predefined linguistic templates using a rule-based explanation module, while the full framework proposes a transformer-based natural language generation model for future implementation. This heatmap-to-text pipeline bridges the gap between AI decision-making and clinical reasoning, achieving 80 percent accuracy on a small dataset. Interpreting heatmaps requires technical expertise, and a human-readable explanation improves clinical decision-making. The proposed approach enhances user understanding, clinician trust, and early autism screening accessibility in real-world healthcare environments.

title: Stock Price Forecasting with Temporal-Feature Attention and Graph SAGE on Multimodal Financial Data
authors: Md. Abul Kalam Azad, Md. Fokrul Islam Khan, Mohammad Zahir Raihan, Chanda Rani Debi, Md. Khaliluzzaman, Abdul Kadar Muhammad Masum
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Forecasting stock price movements is a complex task due to the dynamic behavior of financial markets and the interdependencies among various economic and behavioral factors. Existing models often fail to jointly capture temporal dependencies, feature relevance, and structural relationships among multiple stocks, particularly when integrating multimodal data such as sentiment and market indicators. To address this gap, we propose a novel architecture TDAGNN-SAGE that combines a dual attention mechanism with a topology aware Graph SAGE framework to enhance predictive performance. Our approach leverages multimodal financial data including time series stock indicators, market index features and sentiment scores extracted using FinBERT from daily news headlines. The dual attention module captures both temporal and feature-level relevance, while the graph component models inter stock correlations using a static correlation based adjacency matrix. We further employed SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations) to analyze feature importance and enhance model interpretability. We evaluated our model using data from five publicly traded companies listed on the Dhaka Stock Exchange (DSE). The result shows that our approach consistently performs better than traditional methods such as CNN, BiLSTM, BiGRU, Random Forest, and Linear Regression. TDAGNN-SAGE achieved a mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.1353 and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.9665. Our findings highlight the effectiveness of graph augmented attention frameworks for more accurate financial time series forecasting using multimodal data.

title: Effects of Virtual and Mixed Reality Environments on Heart Rate Dynamics During High-Intensity Gaming
authors: Penio Lebamovski, Evgeniya Gospodinova, Galya Georgieva-Tsaneva
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study investigates the impact of virtual reality (VR) and mixed reality (MR) interfaces, equipped with sensors for voice commands, eye tracking, and hand and body movement, on heart rate variability (HRV) during a high-intensity gaming task. The game used in the study was previously developed and validated. Twenty-two healthy participants were tested under VR and MR conditions, and HRV parameters were analyzed in both time and frequency domains, as well as using nonlinear methods, including Poincaré plots, entropy measures, and detrended fluctuation analysis (DFA). Results indicate that VR exposure elicits a stronger sympathetic response, characterized by reduced MeanRR, SDNN, RMSSD, pNN50%, decreased HF power, increased LF power and LF/HF ratio, and reduced nonlinear complexity (SD1, SD2, ApEn, SampEn, α<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>, α<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) compared to MR. MR conditions showed relatively preserved parasympathetic activity and higher autonomic adaptability. These findings suggest that the type of virtual reality and mixed reality interface modulates autonomic responses during immersive gaming, providing valuable insights for the design of interactive applications, training programs, and therapeutic interventions in VR and MR environments.

title: Thermally Accessible Low-Repetition-Rate Single Soliton Combs in Mode-Coupling-Engineered Microresonators
authors: Yi Zheng, Andreas Jacobsen, Yanjing Zhao, Yang Liu, Haoyang Tan, Kresten Yvind, Minhao Pu
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We designed a silicon nitride racetrack microresonator that introduces a proper mode coupling for generating single soliton microcomb through manual tuning. With the proposed design, high quality factor is sustained and we demonstrate thermally accessible 30-GHz soliton microcomb.

title: Online Monitoring Driven Analysis of Multi-physics Failure Interactions in High-Temperature Thermal Energy Storage Units
authors: Gang Wang, Peng Chou, Xiaolong Ren, Zhijun Wang, Chengyue Zhang, Xu Liu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The on-line monitoring and driving analysis of multi-physical field failure interaction in high temperature thermal energy storage unit is studied. As a promising energy storage solution, thermal energy storage technology mainly relies on temperature changes and phase transition processes to store and release energy. However, in actual operation, the thermal energy storage equipment will inevitably have operational failures. In this paper, we study these faults deeply and summarize their failure mechanism to provide technical support for further optimization of the equipment.

title: Pushing the Limits of Core Density in Multi-Core Fibres for Data Centre Applications
authors: Hiroki Takehana, Shota Kajikawa, Katsuhiro Takenaga, Takuya Oda, Kentaro Ichii
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose ultra-high-density 8-core and 12-core MCFs for O-band IM-DD transmission. These fibres achieved the highest core density reported to date, while maintaining comparable optical performance and mechanical reliability to those of conventional fibres.

title: Multi-modal Recommendation with Joint Content and Interaction Augmentation

title: Semi-Active RIS Optimization Using Reinforcement Learning Across Frequencies
authors: Yasin Emre Tok
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) are widely viewed as a key enabler for 6G thanks to their ability to reshape propagation for higher spectral efficiency, extended coverage, and improved reliability. Conventional passive RIS deployments, however, typically depend on a dedicated control or backhaul link to the base station (BS), which constrains placement flexibility and adds integration cost. This paper studies an autonomous, semi-active RIS that dispenses with an explicit BS–RIS control link: the RIS locally senses uplink/downlink pilots, updates its phases on-device, and closes the loop via reinforcement learning. We design an observation-driven Double-Dqn controller that uses a DFT-based action set and a reward computed directly from RIS observations, requiring no explicit downlink CSI. To obtain compact state features, pilot snapshots are compressed with an OMP-based angular dictionary; downlink performance is evaluated with MMSE precoding. Using a common training recipe (replay, target network, advantage rewards), we compare two bands representative of current and near-term systems 3 GHz (sub-6 GHz, 5G) and 7.8 GHz (upper mid-band, 6G). Across both bands, the observation-reward agent consistently converges and tracks an reference agent trained with perfect-CSI rewards, while markedly outperforming random baselines. Results indicate that future RIS setups can be self-optimizing and frequency-robust without a dedicated BS–RIS control link.

title: Tool Wear Prediction Using an Ensemble Hybrid Model Based on LSTM and Transformer
authors: Wenbin Pan, Cunsong Wang, Quanling Zhang, Dengfeng Zhang, Moshu Qian
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Tool wear prediction is crucial in manufacturing, as tool degradation affects production efficiency, product quality, and operational costs. Traditional methods, relying on empirical or physics-based analyses, often fail to address complex non-linearities and varying operational conditions. An ensemble LSTM–Transformer encoder (ELSTM-TE) hybrid architecture is proposed for tool wear prediction. LSTM captures temporal dependencies, while Transformer enhances global feature extraction through multi-head attention. Additionally, an ensemble learning approach is integrated to reduce noise and improve robustness. Experiments on the PHM2010 milling benchmark indicate that ELSTM-TE achieves lower prediction error than several recurrent and convolutional baselines. These results show that the proposed model can reliably estimate tool wear under complex and noisy operating conditions, and thus has good potential for integration into tool-health monitoring systems.

title: Knowledge Fusion Graph Neural Network for Industrial Process Fault Diagnosis
authors: Longying Mao, Zeyu Yang, Peiliang Wang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Fault diagnosis is one of the important means to ensure industrial production safety. The data-driven fault diagnosis methods are becoming increasingly mature, yet they often overlook the role of prior knowledge from industrial flow chart in guiding the coupling relationships among industrial process variables. We propose a fault diagnosis model called knowledge fusion graph neural network (KFGNN) for this purpose. When constructing dynamic graphs, the model incorporates prior knowledge that conforms to the operation mode between equipment in actual industrial processes. At the same time, the Kolmogorov-Arnold network (KAN) constructed using the Kolmogorov-Arnold representation theorem is used to diagnose possible faults. Finally, the effectiveness of KFGNN was validated on the Tennessee Eastman Process (TEP) dataset, and it exhibited more satisfactory performance compared to other baseline models.

title: A Review on Explainable Artificial Intelligence in Colorectal Cancer Biomarker Analysis using Microbiome Data
authors: Anand Kumar, Savleen Kaur
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: In recent years, the potential to enhance colon cancer detection, prediction, and overall patient care has generated significant interest in integrating artificial intelligence (AI) into healthcare. The use of AI can improve the decision-making process in the field of medical illnesses such as colon cancer. Explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) has improved the interpretability and transparency of in-depth analyses of diseases. This study helps us to understand the deep concern related to colon cancer by utilizing explainable AI for detection and prediction. The major areas of conclusion are early detection after the screening, finding the associated risk, and final decision-making. This review highlights the advantages and disadvantages of the earlier proposed literature reviews by employing XAI for prognosis and Diagnosis. Furthermore, it discusses the challenges associated with and future research that can be made out of it. The ethical and legal consideration of colon cancer is also examined in the article. So, the proposed review of the explainable artificial intelligence can help develop clinical implications and enhance education for improved colon cancer care and its results.

title: Exploring YOLO Inference Using Digital-Analog Hybrid Photonic Processor
authors: Xiansong Meng, Kwangwoong Kim, Po Dong, Hao Hu, Deming Kong
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We explore application of a high-precision digital-analog hybrid optical MVM processor in a real-world pretrained YOLO NN model and achieve high confidence scores in object detection replacing the first convolution layer with pre-trained weights, while simulation shows analog-only optical computing fails under realistic signal-to-noise ratios. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: High-power REC-DFB Laser Array Integrated with Phase Com-pensators for Optical I/O Technology
authors: Yue Zhang, Zhenxing Sun, Jie Zhao, Rulei Xiao, Xiangfei Chen
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a high-power REC-DFB laser array with wide waveguides and integrated phase compensators, enhancing single-mode yield and wavelength precision. The slab-coupled optical wave-guide improves output power, reduces resistance, and minimizes far-field divergence, achieving >100 mW power, >50 dB SMSRs, and high uniformity for optical I/O systems. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: GASTPipe: Resource-Efficient Hybrid Parallelism Scheme for Distributed AI Training Over Cross-DC Optical Networks
authors: Dianxuan Fu, Xiaomin Liu, Yihao Zhang, Xingyu Liu, Qizhi Qiu, Weisheng Hu, Qunbi Zhuge
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a novel hybrid parallelism distributed machine learning scheme GASTPipe over cross-DC optical networks. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme reduces the frequency slots consumption and time overhead by up to 55.87% and 80.35%, respectively. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Multi-Client Scenario-Based Reverse Shell Attack Simulation
authors: Malek Malkawi, Yasamin Akrami, Safa Kechaou, Reda Alhajj
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: As cybersecurity threats continue to evolve, reverse shell attacks are one of the most effective techniques to gain unauthorized remote access to compromised machines. While prior research has primarily focused on single-client reverse shell detection or post-compromise analysis, few studies address the architectural and operational challenges of multi-client reverse shell scenarios. This paper presents a novel simulation framework for implementing and evaluating multi-client reverse shell attacks in a controlled environment. The proposed system employs a threaded, socket-based server architecture capable of maintaining concurrent sessions with multiple client agents by using Python. We analyze realistic attack vectors, including social engineering delivery methods such as phishing and baiting, and implement a custom communication protocol for secure and reliable command execution. Performance testing demonstrates the system’s ability to maintain stable, responsive connections under various client loads. Our study highlights the limitations of conventional firewalls and intrusion detection systems in detecting such attacks and provides insights into mitigation strategies, including behavioral analysis and zero-trust architecture. The simulation platform serves as a valuable tool for education, red teaming, and future research into advanced threat detection and defense mechanisms.

title: StegoGAN: A Generative Adversarial Network Approach for Secure and Imperceptible Image Steganography
authors: Preeti Bansal, Vandana Batra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: In the age of digital communication, the need to securely and unobtrusively transmit sensitive data is critically important. Image steganography is a useful way to store information in images imperceptibly. Nonetheless, the classical algorithm of hidden-data carving usually hardly keeps the delicate balance of invisibility, payload and robustness. Motivated by these drawbacks StegoGAN, a novel GAN-based steganography framework is proposed to improve quality and security of the communication. The proposed method employs deep neural networks as base to hide secret messages into a cover image adaptively and imperceptibly. The proposed method is comprised of a generator, which is trained to encode a given secret message into a realistic stego image, a discriminator which discriminates real images and stego images for the generation of visually better stego images, and a decoder, which aims to recover the secret message in a lossless manner. The model is trained with a loss that incorporates adversarial loss, reconstruction loss and perceptual similarity measurements which can guarantee visual quality and message recovery. The experimental results show that the proposed novel StegoGAN achieves better imperceptibility, capacity and robustness than traditional methods. This work creates new opportunities in secure visual communication and provides one promising step toward combining deep learning with information hiding.

title: Multi-Octave Modified Uni-Travelling Carrier Photodiode Packaging Exploiting a 100 - 500 GHz Waveguide Transition
authors: Shuya Iwamatsu, Himanshu Gohil, Marcel Grzeslo, Hui Wang, Nick Brewster, Mark Merritt, José Luis Fernández Estévez, Jessica Strah, Tom Neerfeld, Jonas Tebart, Sumer Makhlouf, Daniel Headland, Muhsin Ali, Guillermo Carpintero, Peter G. Huggard, Andreas Stöhr
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We present a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100-500 \text{GHz}$</tex> device to waveguide transition for ultra-wideband THz integrated circuits for 6G. A modified uni-traveling-carrier photodiode (MUTC-PD) source using this transition demonstrates maximum output powers of -1 and -20 dBm at 100 and 500 GHz respectively.

title: Application of Double-DQL in Improving the Secrecy Performance of IRS-Aided NOMA on THz Communications
authors: Ngan Chu-Thi, Thuc Kieu-Xuan, Linh Nguyen Thi Dieu, Anh Le Thi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the application of double deep Q-learning (Double DQL) to enhance the secrecy capacity of NOMA communication systems assisted by Intelligent Reflecting Surfaces (IRS). In our proposed system model, a ground base station (GBS) communicates with destination users on THz communications. Using IRS elements reconfigurability and the allocation of transmitted power to NOMA users, our goal is to dynamically adjust phase shifts and power factors to enhance legitimate channel conditions while simultaneously mitigating the eavesdropper’s influence. We formulate the secrecy capacity maximization and design a double-DQL framework that is developed to efficiently explore the high-dimensional state-action space, enabling the agent to converge towards policies that maximize long-term secrecy performance. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed DDQL-based scheme outperforms DQL approaches, achieving significant improvements in secrecy capacity in various channel scenarios and key system parameters. These findings highlight the potential of combining deep reinforcement learning with IRS technology to improve physical layer security in future wireless networks.

title: Demonstration of Millimetre-Wave Antenna Distribution over IFoF System with TDD Timing-Aligned Remote Beam Control
authors: Shinji Nimura, Kazuki Tanaka, Ryo Inohara, Takehiro Tsuritani
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a novel IFoF system achieving TDD timing-aligned beam control for millimetre-wave antenna distribution by simultaneously transmitting radio and control signals and providing control timing extracted from the radio frame. Successful5G-compliant 38.5-GHz signal transmission and TDD timing-aligned real-time remote beam control are demonstrated. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Ultra-Low Crosstalk FSO Circulator for Full C-Band WDM Bidirectional Satellite Communication
authors: Takashi Kan, Kensuke Murakami, Shota Ishimura, Akihiko Nishitani, Tomonori Yazaki, Shin Fukuhara, Akira Akasaka, Hidenori Takahashi, Takehiro Tsuritani
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We present a free-space optical (FSO) circulator with ultra-low crosstalk of less than −90 dB, operating within 1535-1567 nm wavelength range. Using this developed circulator, we demonstrate 1 Tb/s C-band wavelength-division multiplexed communication for bidirectional satellite FSO communications. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Prisma Guided Systematic Review of Large Language Model (LLM) Applications in Business Intelligence
authors: Ibrahim Yuluce, Fatih Dagdeviren, Murat Orun, Ismail Duran, Orhan Dagdeviren
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Business Intelligence (BI) refers to a set of architectures, tools, and methods designed to transform raw corporate data into meaningful insights, enabling data-driven decision-making at all levels of an organization. In this paper, we provide a PRISMA 2020–guided systematic review that examines the integration of large language models (LLMs) into BI work-flows. The most prominent themes emerging from the literature were natural language querying and text-to-SQL translation. To facilitate comparative analysis and provide a consolidated overview of the BI–LLM landscape, this review offers a shareable, coded dataset. The findings suggest that LLMs currently enhance the user-interaction layer of BI. Although applications remain limited, research activity in this area has grown significantly, highlighting both the opportunities and the lack of systematic integration of LLMs into BI workflows. Existing studies are largely exploratory and methodologically fragmented, emphasizing the need for integrated conceptual frameworks and robust empirical evidence. By tracing this trajectory, the review establishes a structured foundation for more rigorous and cumulative research on the BI–LLM interface.

title: Modeling and Experimental Assessment of QKD Systems in Coexistence with QKD-Encrypted High-Capacity DWDM Transmission
authors: Eliana Mazza, Alessandro Gagliano, Alberto Gatto, Pierpaolo Boffi, Paolo Martelli, Paola Parolari, Eliana Colonna, Maurizio Gazzola, Ilaria Vagniluca, Claudia De Lazzari, Alessandro Zavatta, Davide Bacco
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We experimentally validated a design tool for optimizing integrated quantum-classical communication links with Raman flux measurements. We assessed commercial QKD system performance co-propagating with multiple coherent classical channels over 40- and 70-km fibers.

title: Localization of Autonomous Guided Vehicles in Dynamic Environments Using Chipless RFID
authors: Raymundo Amorim, Ashkan Azarfar, Zeshan Ali, François Gautier, Louis Gautier, Guillaume Gérin, Arcady Ruvidic, Denis Sabatier, Etienne Perret
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper investigates the robustness and performance of chipless RFID technology for identification and tracking, emphasizing its localization capabilities in dynamic and challenging warehouse environments. We examine how chipless tags placed on the ground can facilitate and enhance the realtime localization of autonomous guided vehicles. An evaluation of chipless RFID tags under harsh electromagnetic conditions, including moisture, dust, and physical obstructions, demonstrates their reliability in challenging environments. A co-polarized bistatic antenna pair, mounted on a tilted support, enhances the signal-to-noise ratio by reducing specular reflections, thereby improving detection performance. The impact of the tag's tilt orientation and translational movement on location accuracy is also analyzed. Dynamic measurements are conducted for two tag orientations: inclined placement (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\phi=30^{\circ}$</tex>) and flat placement (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\phi=0^{\circ}$</tex>). These measurements assess detection performance under motion tests, showing that the system can track tags at realistic warehouse speeds without any degradation in location performance.

title: UHF RFID-Based Battery-Free Wireless Strain Sensor for EV Battery Management Systems
authors: Badar Muneer, Valentina Palazzi, Federico Alimenti, Paolo Mezzanotte, Luca Roselli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: The development of wireless battery management systems (wBMS) for the next generation of electric vehicles (EVs) is increasingly gaining traction as a superior alternative to traditional wired BMS. Strain monitoring within lithium-ion battery cells is critical for assessing mechanical stress, which impacts state-of-charge (SOC) and state-of-health (SOH). This paper presents a novel idea of battery-free, wireless strain sensing system based on ultra-high frequency (UHF) RFID technology. The system features a flexible meander line inductor acting as RF strain gauge or sensing element (SE), integrated with a Magnus®S3 M3D RFID chip. The chip's self-tuning capabilities to dynamically adjust its impedance to maintain optimal antenna matching are utilized to design a passive (battery-free) RFID based wireless strain sensing system. The SE when integrated with an RFID Tag antenna, operates well in challenging metallic environments like metal-caged EV battery packs, offers an interesting solution for wireless passive measurement of battery cell inflammation (strain). By employing polynomial fitting a precise correlations of SE's capacitance/inductance with SE expansion/contraction is established in this paper. The proposed system addresses limitations of traditional strain sensors, such as high power consumption, complex wiring, and limited scalability while eliminating the need for a dedicated power source, this approach provides a sustainable and efficient wireless passive solution for next-generation automotive wBMS using UHF RFIDs.

title: H2O AutoML for Malware Detection: A Signal Processing Perspective on Accuracy, Efficiency, and Interpretability
authors: Minakshi Arya, Shubhavi Arya, Saatvik Arya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Signals and Systems (ICSigSys)
abstract: We benchmark H2O AutoML against individual H2O models such as Distributed Random Forest (DRF), Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM), XGBoost, and Deep Learning for Android malware detection using the TUANDROMD dataset. From a signal-processing perspective, malware behaviors (e.g., API calls, broadcasts, and network events) are treated as discriminative signals subject to classification under strict training-time budgets (3–3600 s). Across precision, recall, F1, AUC, log loss, and accuracy, AutoML achieves the best calibrated performance (AUC ≈ 0.9998, log loss ≈ 0.0147 at 600 s) and the highest accuracy (up to 0.997), while DRF delivers the most stable results with the best accuracy-time-efficiency (near-peak accuracy in ∼5–6 s). Deep Learning exhibits lower time-efficiency due to slower convergence, requiring longer training durations (≥1000 s) to reach competitive performance and showing instability at shorter time budgets. By combining machine learning, pattern recognition, and explainable AI techniques in signal-processing, we demonstrate operational suitability for real-time security and forensics pipelines. These findings position AutoML as the best choice when probability calibration and peak accuracy are critical, while DRF is recommended for latency-constrained deployments. Notably, while Deep Learning achieved high accuracy, it remained less efficient under strict time budgets; tree ensembles offered the most favorable latency-accuracy trade-off.

title: Efficient Swarm Consensus: Comparative Evaluation of RLR vs Raft, RaBFT and VSSB-Raft
authors: Sathishkumar Ranganathan, Muralindran Mariappan, Karthigayan Muthukaruppan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Consensus mechanisms are essential in swarm robotics to maintain uniformity of decisions and states across distributed agents. Earlier methods often relied on approaches such as majority voting, averaging techniques, or leader election. In recent years, blockchain-based algorithms including Proof of Work (PoW), Proof of Stake (PoS), Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT), and Raft have been adopted for this purpose. While these methods provide certain advantages, their application to swarm robotics is restricted by issues such as limited computational power, energy constraints, scalability challenges caused by message complexity and latency, and weak protection against Byzantine agents. This study introduces a consensus approach specifically designed to address these gaps and to improve collaborative decision-making in swarm environments. The work outlines the motivation for the proposed solution, describes the simulation-based experimental design, and presents a detailed analysis of the observed results.

title: First Demonstration of MRM on Low-Loss SiN-SOI Platform for High-Density and Low-Power Optical Interconnection
authors: Xu Wang, Wen Zheng, Changran Hu, Yuan Xia, Fangyi Tang, Lingbo Zhou, Chengwen Xu, Ruiqiang Ji
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrated a 224 Gbps microring modulator (MRM) transmitter based on a low-loss silicon nitride (SiN)-silicon on insulator (SOI) platform. The small footprint of MRM and the low-loss of SiN waveguides will pave the way for high density and low power consumption short-distance interconnection systems. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: LLM Assistant for TAPI Context and Client Code Translation
authors: Aydin Jafari, Behnam Shariati, Hussein Zaid, Pooyan Safari, Vignesh Karunakaran, Philomena Moek, Ramon Casellas, Achim Autenrieth, Johannes Karl Fischer
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: This paper presents an LLM-based mediator for disaggregated optical networks, designed to address inconsistencies in TAPI interpretation and generation. By integrating TAPI-YANG models, shared TAPI context, and advanced prompting, it enables a translation architecture between the optical orchestrator and OLS controllers, effectively resolving these inconsistencies. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: A Semi-Supervised Remaining Useful Life Prediction Approach Based on Self-Attention Mechanism-Sequential Variational Autoencoder
authors: Jiusi Zhang, Kai Chen, Fan Wu, Yuhua Cheng, Shen Yin
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: With the accelerating pace of smart technologies and digital transformation across industrial domains, ensuring the reliability of sophisticated systems has become fundamentally important for manufacturing productivity [1] – [4] . Nevertheless, the complex systems inevitably become degradation due to operational conditions, environmental changes, and material aging. As a logical consequence, accurate prediction of remaining useful life (RUL) in complex systems represents a fundamental component of effective maintenance strategies and asset management [5] . Accurate RUL prediction can help users plan maintenance resource allocation [6] . Furthermore, the unnecessary downtime and repair costs are decreased, thereby promoting production efficiency. The primary motivations for this research emerge from the following factors: • The degradation data of complex systems have strong temporal characteristics. Consequently, how to focus on key parts of the time window, and make full use of the temporal information requires further research [7] . • Conventional deep networks are usually regarded as black box model, the meaning of whose internal latent spaces is difficult to interpret. Furthermore, most of the RUL prediction approaches are point estimation, which requires in-depth work on uncertainty description [8] . • Conventional data-driven approaches demand massive labeled samples for supervised model training. How to effectively utilize unlabeled degradation data from a semi-supervised perspective requires further work [9] .

title: Microscopic Debris Classification of Pasig River Philippines Using Unsupervised Learning Clustering Algorithms
authors: Amelie Claire Festin, Jianette Mari Go, Antonio Santino Chan, Aidan Radley Sy, Melchizedek Alipio
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This study addresses the need for a deeper understanding of the microscopic composition of debris in freshwater bodies. This research focused on developing an image dataset to characterize microscopic debris in water samples collected from the Pasig River, Philippines, which can be used for water monitoring. The methodology involved collecting water samples from seven sampling sites, followed by physical processing and microscopic imaging. 1248 raw images were collected from the water samples. Preprocessing techniques, including noise reduction, pixel normalization, image resizing, contrast enhancement, and data enhancement, were applied to the images, where different noise reduction and contrast enhancement techniques and parameters were tested. K-means clustering, Hierarchical clustering, and Gaussian mixture models were employed to categorize the debris based on extracted features such as area, perimeter, circularity, color, and Hu Moments. The optimal preprocessing methods tested include the median filter with a kernel size of 3, CLAHE with a brightness of 120%. After preprocessing, the dataset had a total of 7488 images. Using RMSE, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and MSE, it was determined that K-Means clustering had demonstrated the best clustering performance on the debris dataset.

title: Optimal Holistic Cold-Start Management in Serverless Cloud Computing Using Artificial Intelligent
authors: Sai Arundeep Aetukuri, Rajeev Agarwal, Kapil Kumar Goyal, Pavan Nutalapati, Quazi Taif Sadat, Upasana Lakhina
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Serverless cloud computing a flexible, scalable, and cost-effective execution model for modern applications, but it suffers significantly from the cold start problem—delays in function execution caused by the dynamic allocation of underlying resources. These delays have a critical impact on latency-sensitive applications, especially in fields such as healthcare, finance, and the Internet of Things. The approaches used in cold session management are often fragmented, focusing only on isolated layers such as the application or infrastructure, and lacking intelligent coordination across the entire stack. To address these challenges, this article proposes an optimum holistic cold-start management framework (OHCSMF), which uses an artificial neural network (ANN) to accurately predict function calls and optimize color harmony (CHO) to precisely adjust resource allocation strategies at various system levels. The ANN model predicts workloads for short periods (5-15 minutes), allowing for proactive decisions regarding pre-warming and cache reuse. At the same time, the CHO algorithm dynamically optimizes the configuration of the caching and preloading policy to reduce cold start time, while balancing memory usage and computational resources. Large-scale experiments using serverless logs show that the proposed OHCSMF reduces cold start latency by 43.6%, improves resource utilization by 37.8%, and outperforms leading techniques in terms of prediction accuracy and adaptability to changing loads. This AI-powered intelligent framework offers a robust and scalable solution to cold start challenges and paves the way for more interactive and flexible serverless systems.

title: Enhanced State Estimation of Railway Switch Machine Based on Deep Extended Kalman Filter
authors: Junqi Liu, Jincheng Wang, Chenglin Wen
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The condition monitoring of switch machines (SM), which are critical actuators in railway turnout systems, is essential for ensuring the safe and reliable operation of railways. However, traditional extended Kalman filters (EKF) face challenges in effectively capturing high-order nonlinear characteristics and accurately modeling the dynamic behaviors of short-term periodic systems. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a deep extended Kalman filter (DEKF) framework designed specifically for short-term periodic nonlinear systems. The proposed approach integrates a long short-term memory (LSTM) network to extract intermediate features from the EKF, thereby enhancing the utilization of nonlinear dynamic information. Furthermore, a time-series sample set covering complete operation cycles is constructed to improve the representation of prior knowledge embedded in short-term periodic actions of the switch machine. By employing an offline training and online fusion strategy, the DEKF achieves high-precision real-time state estimation of the switch machine system. Simulation experiments conducted on a nonlinear switch machine model demonstrate that the proposed DEKF significantly outperforms the traditional EKF in state estimation accuracy, providing strong theoretical support for real-time condition monitoring and fault diagnosis of railway signaling systems.

title: Eco-Friendly RFID Antennas and Sensors by Laser-Induced Graphene Transfer on Bio-Degradable Substrates
authors: Alessio Mostaccio, Ginevra Cicuti, Gaetano Marrocco
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Biodegradable materials offer a promising route toward sustainable electronics, yet their widespread adoption is limited by fabrication complexity and cost. In this work, we present a novel strategy for fabricating transient RFID antennas by transferring Laser-Induced Graphene (LIG) traces on Poly-Vinyl Alcohol (PVA), a water-soluble polymer. The influence of process parameters, i.e., LIG morphology and transfer temperature, on the electrical performance of the transferred conductors is systematically investigated. The results indicate that defocused laser scribing along with with moderate heating (60° C) are the optimal settings to minimize the increase in the sheet resistance down to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \Omega/s q$</tex>. The optimized process is applied to fabricate a fully dissolvable UHF RFID dipole antenna operating at 900 MHz. Experimental results confirm good agreement with simulations, yielding a measured realized gain of −18 dB. The device fully dissolves in water within minutes, validating the potential of LIG/PVA systems for biodegradable and transient wireless applications.

title: Real-Time Object Recognition and Tracking in High-Resolution Aerial Imagery
authors: Sathish Rao, Parshv Praful Gala, Kartheek Dokka, Vibhoo Sharma, Gopal Kumar Gupta, Abhishek Jain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Object detection and tracking Object detection and tracking Research Object detection and tracking are increasingly practical applications in high-resolution aerial images Its applications are varied (surveillance and disaster management) to city planning and environment monitoring. Indicatively: satellite and aerial imaging platforms are far more easily accessible today than it was five or ten years ago. It now permits us that the system should automatically obtain high-resolution imagery of large portions of the world. The quantity of data is so tremendous to a point it is difficult to manage and extract associated contents. The purpose of this work is to come up with the algorithms and techniques required to aid in the automation of the detection and tracking of objects of interest in such high-resolution images. Simply put, these images are processed by using a series of computational characteristics acquired by computer vision and machine learning algorithms to recognize the objects in them as living and divide according to their shape, size, and texture among others. It further employs parallel computing technology and real time data processing technology to process the data and produce results nearly instantly. Such a model can be of great use and of immense value in many situations like who to locate the destroyed infrastructure to assist disaster response personnel, identify suspicious activities to aid the police, and document the land cover to assist in environmental supervision. Such a technology has the potential to transform the way we handle aerial images to make applications and for use in time.

title: Analyzing Machine Learning Models for Demand Forecasting in Fast-Moving Consumer Goods on Responsible Consumption and Production
authors: Jing Yao Yap, Yik Junn Kuan, Preethi Subramanian, Li June Tan, Mahdiyehsadat Moosavi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: The fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) industry involves products with short shelf lives, rapid consumption, and large-scale production, often relying on single-time packaging, raising environmental sustainability concerns. Accurate production planning is essential for FMCG businesses to address these issues, and demand forecasting using machine learning can play a key role. This study experiments with three algorithms —Random Forest Regression, XGBoost Regression, and LSTM. XGBoost Regression emerges as the best-performing model with the highest R-Squared, lowest Mean Absolute Error, and Weighted Absolute Percentage Error. The significance of this study lies in its comprehensive review of FMCG business practices related to demand forecasting.

title: Frequency Domain Transformation and Loss Adjustment for Enhancing Transferability of Adversarial Examples_supp1-3640532.pdf
authors: Hongying Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: Due to the exponential disparity in the magnitude of high- and low-frequency components in the image frequency domain, existing frequency-domain enhancement methods for adversarial examples often fail to balance the perturbations of high- and low-frequency information. To address this issue, we propose a novel Spectral Space Transformation and Loss adjustment (SSTL) method. Specifically, SSTL introduces a frequency-domain rotation-and-self-mixing strategy that adaptively balances perturbations across high- and low-frequency components, thereby generating more transferable adversarial examples. Furthermore, to mitigate semantic degradation during reconstruction, we design a logits fine-tuning mechanism that up-weights the logits of true labels while suppressing others, effectively preserving the original semantic information and avoiding misleading gradient propagation. Various experimental results demonstrate that SSTL effectively improves adversarial transferability while significantly preserving the semantic information of each image.

title: Computationally Efficient Calculation of PWM-Induced AC Copper Losses in Concentrated Winding Axial Flux Machines
authors: Dae-Yong Um, Rajesh Kumar, Tushar Batra, Lars Sjöberg
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics
abstract: This paper presents a computationally efficient methodology for evaluating pulsewidth modulation (PWM)-induced alternating current (AC) copper losses in concentrated winding axial flux permanent magnet (AFPM) machines. The proposed approach combines complex permeability modeling (CPM) with homogenization modeling (HM) of the coil region. The calculation algorithm consists of two sequential steps: AC copper loss evaluation under fundamental current and under PWM-induced harmonics. For the former, time-stepping finite element analysis (FEA) is performed to obtain the magnetic field and current density vectors within the coil domain, and the AC copper loss is calculated in the post-processing stage, similar to conventional iron loss evaluation. For the latter, time-harmonic FEA is employed to incorporate the complex permeability and account for high-frequency effects that cannot be captured in time domain post-processing. To validate the proposed method, two case studies using two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) models are conducted, as full PWM waveform application in a detailed 3D model is computationally infeasible. In addition, a complete machine-level validation under PWM excitation demonstrates good agreement with full FEA. The results confirm that PWM harmonics significantly increase both localized loss density and total AC copper losses by approximately 54% compared to the case neglecting PWM effects. These findings highlight the critical importance of incorporating PWM-induced harmonic effects in loss evaluations to avoid underestimating temperature rise and potential performance degradation in AFPM machines.

title: A hybrid deep learning framework for solid rocket motor performance prediction based on mechanism modeling and residual learning
authors: Weile Xu, Xingchen Li, Hao Zhu, Wen Yao, Guobiao Cai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Solid rocket motor (SRM) stands out as a pivotal aerospace propulsion system. In response to growing need for the intellectualization of launch vehicles and their propulsion modules, achieving real-time completion and prediction of key performance parameters, such as chamber pressure and thrust of SRM through online measurement data holds paramount importance in aerospace engineering. To overcome the limitations of traditional modeling methods and the scarcity of data, this paper introduces a hybrid deep learning framework that amalgamates mechanism modeling and residual learning. The deep neural network identifies key system parameters within low-fidelity mechanism model for internal ballistic simulation. Subsequently, the prediction results are generated based on a low-fidelity surrogate model. The introduction of a residual sequence as a model discrepancy function enhances the precision of prediction results. The study demonstrates that the proposed framework significantly improves prediction accuracy of SRM performance, with a 26.2% boost compared to data-driven methods and a 34.4% improvement over mechanism-driven methods in interpolation tests. Addressing the critical challenge of limited data in SRM engineering due to high costs, the proposed method exhibits a particularly pronounced enhancement effect on small samples, which achieves 30.2% improvement in a 64-sample dataset. This effectively strengthens the generalization of deep-learning-based prediction models, offering a practical pathway for intelligent SRM monitoring. Extrapolation tests further validate robust generalization of the model, showcasing an average improvement of 27.7% compared to pure data-driven models. This underscores the method's capability to deliver reliable prediction performance even when SRM parameters exhibit deviations. The hybrid deep learning framework, therefore, emerges as a promising approach for real time prediction of SRM performance in aerospace applications.

title: Real-Time Path-Reconfigurable Coverage Planning for Multi-UAV Missions over Disjoint Areas
authors: Cai Luo, Jintao Guo, Zixuan Liu, Lei Liu, Chunbo Luo
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Multi-UAV cooperative coverage missions across geographically separated regions face significant challenges due to potential UAV failures during mission execution. To address the challenges of efficient multi-region coverage and dynamic failure handling, this paper presents a novel real-time path-reconfigurable coverage-planning algorithm for multi-UAV coverage path planning across separated geographical areas with real-time path reconfiguration capabilities. The proposed approach, GRIT-M (Greedy Repair Initializes Tabu search for Multiple regions), extends the GRIT algorithm to efficiently handle both initial planning and online path repair when UAVs fail during mission execution. Unlike existing methods that either focus on single-region coverage or lack failure handling mechanisms, GRIT-M incorporates region-specific knowledge through three key innovations: (1) a composite transition cost function that optimizes inter-region movements, (2) a region-priority greedy repair mechanism that minimizes transition costs during replanning, and (3) a region-preserving Tabu search that maintains area coverage coherence while balancing workload. Extensive simulations demonstrate GRIT-M's scalability and robustness against operational constraints. The algorithm reduces inter-region flights by up to 27% compared to baselines and maintains excellent workload balance (CV <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< $</tex-math></inline-formula> 7%). Crucially, it shows effective scalability with larger teams (up to 12 UAVs), maintaining a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$>$</tex-math></inline-formula> 91% replanning success rate with average repair times under 2.1 s. Its resilience to variations in battery capacity, sweep patterns, and initial UAV distributions confirms its suitability for time-critical aerial surveys over disjoint areas.
