title: Design and Control of a Bidirectional Multiport DC-DC Converter for Bipolar DC Microgrids with Integrated PV and Battery Interface
authors: Mohammad Kazemi, Saman Dadjo Tavakoli, Mohsen Hamzeh
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: The bipolar DC microgrid (BDCMG) has gained increasing relevance with the widespread adoption of DC sources and loads, primarily due to its higher efficiency, reliability, and flexibility. However, multiport DC–DC converters for interfacing multiple sources with BDCMG still face significant challenges, including voltage balancing, bidirectional power exchange capability, and source requirements. To overcome these challenges, this paper presents a new four-port DC-DC converter for interfacing PV and battery to low-voltage BDCMG. The proposed converter allows fully independent bidirectional power flow among all four ports, enabling flexible power management between the BDCMG, PV, and battery. Owing to its completely independent output poles, the converter inherently compensates for voltage imbalance, even in the absence of PV generation. A robust control strategy is implemented to ensure stable and efficient operation over a wide range of conditions. The proposed design is verified through detailed simulation and experimental validation using a 2 × 600 W laboratory prototype. The main advantages of the proposed solution include: (a) inherent voltage balancing, (b) bidirectional power flow capability, (c) high performance and robust control across a wide operating range, (d) suitable voltage gain, low component stress, and minimal component count, (e) simple voltage and current control across all ports, (f) MPPT support, (g) battery charging control, and (h) continuous current interfaces for both the PV and battery ports.

title: Identification of Multiple Critical Parameters in Undersea Wireless Power Transfer System Integrating Primary-Side Phase Acquisition
authors: Tao Li, Yijie Wang, Zhigang Liu, Zhichao Sun, Wei Tian, Jian Cui, Jianwei Mai, Dianguo Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: This paper addresses the need for multiple critical parameters identification in undersea wireless power transfer (UWPT) systems, where high and variable sea conductivity significantly impacts impedance and renders unreliable pre-measurement. So we propose a method to identify primary/secondary coil impedances and mutual impedance during system startup. Furthermore, a novel primary phase acquisition technique using a low-latency simultaneous power and data transmission channel is presented. This is essential because the phase difference between primary and secondary currents in UWPT systems, which deviates from 90 degrees at full resonance, is influenced by the mutual impedance. Furthermore, a double synchronous reference frame (DSRF) model of the UWPT system is established. By utilizing this model for power analysis in conjunction with the primary-side phase information, the proposed approach achieves effective parameter identification.

title: Analyzing Groundwater Dynamics in Chhattisgarh Using Multi-Feature Correlation and Interactive Mapping with Folium-A Case Study of the Kharun Basin
authors: Jalina Subhadarsini, Jayadipti Chattopadhyaya, Srajit Bhardwaj, Mridu Sahu, D.C. Jhariya, Vikas Kumar Vidyarthi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Groundwater resources management is extremely important in areas of climatic variability, increased urbanization, and intensified agriculture. The case of Chhattisgarh has been alarming concerning groundwater depletion in the Kharun River Basin area, for proper evaluation of the spatiotemporal patterns and hydro-environmental aftereffects. This paper presents a approach for the geospatial visualization and data analysis of groundwater level changes in 143 observation wells of the Kharun Basin. This included data cleaning using the Python Pandas library, seasonal classification of water levels, and geospatial mapping via the Folium library. Correlation matrices which helped understand inter-feature relations by the deployment of supervised learning models such as Random Forest (RF), Logistic Regression (LR), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN) and classify groundwater level trends to understand which Model Performs Good. The trend analysis reveals a general decline in groundwater levels, with around 65% of the sites experiencing a considerable depletion rate. A maximum of 98.11% classification accuracy is by the Logistic Regression model. Feature importance analysis revealed that the pre-and post-monsoon water levels are as the top predictive features which we have used. Certain zones along surface water bodies indicate natural recharge. The decision-relevant recommendations for aquifer sustainability and city planning are supported by geospatial outputs and statistical results which can be used in this model. With open-source computational tools, the presented method is interpretable, scalable, and, above all, highly visual for studying groundwater depletion patterns. The method supports formulating some policy-relevant strategies to conserve groundwater resources, especially in semi-arid basins under hydro-environmental stress.

title: Deep Vision-Based Diagnosis of Monkeypox using Enhanced CNN and Vision Transformer Architectures
authors: Kimmi Gupta, Lahar Srivastava, Parnavi Sharma, Shivanshu Garg, Aditya Kumar, Priyanka Sengar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The recent Monkeypox outbreak highlighted the urgent need for rapid, precise, and scalable diagnostic assays. In this paper, we introduce a multi-model deep learning architecture for the detection of Monkeypox based on skin lesion images from the Mpox Skin Lesion Dataset v2.0 (MSLD v2.0) containing original and augmented images for six disease classes. Our strategy is to train and compare four various architectures: (1) a basic convolutional neural network(CNN),(2) a sophisticated CNN constructed from scratch using the ResNet50V2 model architecture, (3) an adjustable CNN featuring four residual blocks for improved feature extraction, and (4) a Vision Transformer (ViT) model based on self-attention mechanisms to learn global contexts. All models undergo training with a 5-fold cross-validation protocol to provide rigorous and consistent comparison. Performance within folds is compared, providing a detailed analysis of the convolutional neural networks over transformer-based alternatives. This research contributes to the development of efficient machine-based diagnostic resources for Monkeypox and comparable skin diseases.

title: Design of Passive and Semi-Passive RFID Tags
authors: Amir Fereshtian, Jordi Berenguer, Manel Gasulla Forner
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation and assessment of two tags, Tag D1 and Tag D2, for UHF-RFID (865–868 MHz) applications. The design includes a custom antenna and a commercial chip. The chip's impedance varies between passive (no external power supply) and semi-passive (external supply) tags, so an appropriate antenna must be designed for each case to achieve optimum matching. Two tags, D1 and D2, were optimized as a passive and semi-passive tag, respectively. At an EIRP of 35 dBm (standard value), and acting as passive tags, the maximum read ranges were measured as 7.5 m and 5.5 m for tags D1 and D2, respectively. Acting as semipassive tags, they achieved remarkable read ranges with corresponding values of 25 m and 26 m. Both cases mainly agreed with theoretical calculations, where tag D1 outperforms tag D2 acting as a passive tag and the reverse happens acting as semi-passive tags. Finally, the performance of the custom tags was also compared with that of commercial tags.

title: A Deep Learning Approach to Image Colourization Using U-Net with Benchmarking and Structural Evaluation
authors: Puneet Kumar, Aviral Sharma, Gyanendra Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper proposes an automatic image colourization method built on a U-Net convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture within a deep learning framework. The model learns to generate colour representations of grayscale images by estimating the chrominance components (a*, b*) from the luminance (L) channel in the CIELAB colour space. With its encoder–decoder structure with skip connections, our UNet model efficiently captures both low-level and high-level semantic features, allowing precise colour restoration while maintaining fine spatial details. A custom dataset of paired greyscale and coloured images is used to train the network, and Mean Squared Error (MSE) is used as the loss function for optimisation. Quantitative evaluation metrics such as PSNR and SSIM, along with qualitative assessments, demonstrate that the model produces high-fidelity, visually pleasing results with minimal artefacts and colour bleeding. The experimental results validate the generalization capability of our model across diverse image domains. This work holds practical potential for digital media enhancement, restoration of old black-and-white photographs, and real-time image processing applications. In addition, We also evaluate our model against advanced colourization techniques, showing better structural coherence and overall generalization performance.

title: A Review of Condition Assessment and Life Extension Strategies for Key Components in Transmission Tower Cable Systems
authors: Yunqing Liu, Lirong Xie, Yifan Bian, Yu Cheng, Weishan Song, Binkai Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The transmission tower cable system is stationed in the field all year round. Under the impact of extreme weather conditions such as strong winds, it is prone to serious accidents such as metal fatigue, component damage, and even tower collapse and disconnection, posing a serious threat to the safety and stable transmission of electrical energy backbone structures. In this context, this article mainly systematically elaborates on the existing research results in three aspects: weak member identification, fatigue life prediction, and life extension reinforcement strategies. Existing research has shown that in the transmission tower cable system, weak areas are mainly distributed near the tower legs, cross arms, and main materials at the slope changes, which can be identified through stress ratio determination, refined finite element analysis, and dynamic failure simulation; The life prediction of members relies on multivariate fatigue analysis, wind-induced cumulative damage models, and a full probability evaluation framework; In terms of structural reinforcement, innovative methods such as buckling restrained angle steel reinforcement and bidirectional gas spring dampers are used to enhance the durability and wind resistance of transmission towers and lines. Intended to provide theoretical and key technical support for enhancing the precise life prediction maintenance and improving the structural resilience of transmission corridor projects, for future reference by relevant personnel in this field.

title: Tiny ViT-Batten: Few-Shot Vision Transformer with Explainable Attention for Early Batten-Disease Detection on Pediatric MRI
authors: Khartik Uppalapati, Bora Yimenicioglu, Shakeel Abdulkareem, Adan Eftekhari, Bhavya Uppalapati, Viraj Kamath
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Batten disease (neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis) is a rare pediatric neurodegenerative disorder whose early MRI signs are subtle and often missed. We propose TinyViT-Batten, a few-shot Vision Transformer (ViT) framework to detect early Batten disease from pediatric brain MRI with limited training cases. We distill a large teacher ViT into a 5 M-parameter TinyViT and fine-tune it using metric-based few-shot learning (prototypical loss with 5-shot episodes). Our model achieves high accuracy (≈91%) and area under ROC ⩾0.95 on a multi-site dataset of 79 genetically confirmed Batten-disease MRIs (27 CLN3 from the Hochstein natural-history study, 32 CLN2 from an international longitudinal cohort, 12 early-manifestation CLN2 cases reported by Çokal et al., and 8 public Radiopaedia scans) together with 90 age-matched controls, outperforming a 3D-ResNet and Swin-Tiny baseline. We further integrate Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) to highlight disease-relevant brain regions, enabling explainable predictions. The model’s small size and strong performance (sensitivity >90%, specificity ≈90%), demonstrates a practical AI solution for early Batten disease detection.

title: Steerable Low-Complexity Antenna Array with Super-Realized Gain
authors: Donal P Lynch, Aaron M. Graham, Manos M. Tentzeris, Spyridon Nektarios Daskalakis, Stylianos D. Asimonis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Superdirective antennas, capable of achieving high directivity, are essential components for modern wireless communication systems. However, their practical deployment faces significant challenges, primarily due to impedance mismatch and substantial ohmic losses stemming from strong mutual coupling required for supergain. This paper introduces a novel approach to address these challenges through the design of a single-feed, reactively-loaded five-dipole antenna array. By employing a global particle swarm optimization algorithm, the lengths and radii of the driven and parasitic elements, which are approximately half a wavelength long, along with four lumped reactive loads, are co-optimized in a full-wave method-of-moments electromagnetic model. The resulting impedance matched to 50Ω antenna array achieves steerable radiation across a complete 360-degree azimuthal scan at 3.5 GHz, with a realized gain between 8.5 and 10 dBi To the authors' knowledge, this work presents the first steerable superdirective antenna array achieving high radiation efficiency and impedance matching through combined optimization of reactive loads and physical element dimensions, providing a practical, low-complexity solution suitable for sub-6 GHz wireless communication applications.

title: Simulation and Experimental Studies of DWDM Nonlinear Phase/Polarization/Power Crosstalk Between DFOS and Communication Channels in $27.6-\text{Tb} / \mathrm{s} 800 \text{ZR}$ Metro Network
authors: Jingchuan Wang, Maoqi Liu, Liwang Lu, Alan Pak Tao Lau, Chao Lu
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We comprehensively analyze the fiber nonlinearity crosstalks between DAS and communication channels through numerical results and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \times 800 ~\text{Gb} / \mathrm{s} 90-\text{km}$</tex> experimental demonstration. Our findings indicate that conventional pulse-based DAS is unsuitable for in-band DWDM coexistence system, whereas pulse-compression DAS shows negligible penalties with legacy coherent transceivers. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Enhancing Sliding Mode Control for a Mobile Patient Lifting Device
authors: Thi Ly Tong, Van Thanh Duong, Thanh Phuong Tran, Minh Duc Duong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: In the contemporary landscape, where patient lifting devices are often neglected, caregivers persist in dedicating considerable time to aiding patients with mobility. Although modern ceiling-mounted systems present sophisticated features, they may pose safety hazards and are limited in their range of movement. An automatic lifting device can reduce dependence on manual effort, bolster safety, and enhance user convenience. This study proposes a sliding mode controller (SMC) integrated with a particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm for an automatic mobile patient lifting device, aimed at ensuring precise positional control and mitigating oscillatory vibrations during operation. The controller is formulated based on the Integral of Time-weighted Squared Error (ITSE) objective function, employing the PSO algorithm to determine optimal control parameters. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed methodology significantly improves positional accuracy and effectively dampens load oscillations. This approach holds substantial promise for real-world applications, particularly in healthcare environments where safety and user-friendliness are critical.

title: AI-Enabled UAVs for Rapid Response in Roadside Medical Emergencies: A Real-Time Lifeline Framework
authors: Manisha Bhende, Nagendar Yamsani, Abid Salati, Karthikayen A, Suriya M, Vinod Kumar Shukla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Timely emergency medical response continues to be a significant problem, especially in the case of car crashes, where a delay can mean death. This article describes an AI-powered Real-Time Lifeline Framework using autonomous UAVs to expedite the provision of pre-hospital care. The framework aims to rapidly identify roadside crashes and to dispatch UAVs carrying valuable medical payloads. The framework consists of three parts: deep learning models (CNNs, RNNs) for identifying roadside incidents, adaptive Hybrid A*/D* algorithms for on-demand UAV navigation, and LTE/5G communication-based management system for EMS, police, and triage coordination. Performance assessments showed a 93.2% accuracy for identifying crashes, a 56.8% decrease in response time, and a 89.4% routing success rate compared to traditional practices. The results establish the framework's ability to improve response delay times and assist with triage support. Overall, the framework provides an impactful solution to emergency medical services by enabling pre-hospital care delivery within an urban traffic-congested location and in underserved rural settings; its positive implications for population health acceptability in urban traffic-congested areas, and potentially contribute to local smart city initiatives.

title: Bilevel Optimization Framework for Urban Toll Pricing under Stochastic User Equilibrium: A Metaheuristic Approach
authors: Mahbub Hassan, Md. Emtiaz Kabir, Touhid Bhuiyan, Md Maruf Hassan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This paper presents a behaviorally consistent and computationally efficient framework for optimal toll design in congested urban transportation networks. The toll-setting problem is formulated as a bilevel optimization model that captures the hierarchical interaction between a central planner and individual travelers. At the upper level, the planner aims to minimize Total System Travel Time (TSTT) by adjusting link-based tolls. At the lower level, user route choice behavior is modeled via a Stochastic User Equilibrium (SUE) using a logit-based formulation, which accounts for probabilistic decisions under bounded rationality. Due to the derivative-free, non-convex nature of the bilevel model, a hybrid solution approach is proposed by integrating a real-coded Genetic Algorithm (GA) with the embedded SUE traffic assignment. The GA evolves toll vectors using TSTT as the fitness criterion, while the SUE module computes equilibrium link flows in response to toll adjustments. The proposed method is validated on a synthetic 6-node network with fixed origin-destination demand. Numerical experiments demonstrate a 5.02% reduction in TSTT compared to the no-toll baseline. The results reveal that strategic tolling on critical links redistributes traffic effectively, mitigating congestion and enhancing system efficiency. Flow visualizations further confirm user adaptation under the influence of tolls, validating the model’s behavioral realism. This research highlights the potential of metaheuristic–equilibrium hybrid models for dynamic pricing policy in Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS). The framework is extensible to larger-scale networks, time-varying demand, and multi-objective planning, offering a robust foundation for future research and practical deployment.

title: Bearing Fault Diagnosis Using CNN-LSTM with Complex Wavelet Transform and Squeeze-and-Excitation Attention Mechanism
authors: Shiyan Sun, Yujun Shi, Jiwei Wang, Lirong Xie, Tiantian Du, Haifeng Lu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Bearing fault diagnosis is a critical task for ensuring the safe operation of industrial equipment. However, traditional methods suffer from low fault identification accuracy and computational inefficiency due to the time-varying characteristics of non-stationary vibration signals and the scarcity of fault samples in industrial scenarios. This paper proposes a method named "CNN-LSTM with Complex Wavelet Transform (CWT) and Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) Attention Mechanism (SEAM)", which can achieve high-precision fault identification under small-sample conditions by extracting and deeply fusing spatiotemporal features of faults. First, this paper elaborates on the theoretical foundations underpinning the key components of the proposed method. Subsequently, experimental validation is performed using the bearing dataset from Case Western Reserve University (CWRU). The results indicate that the proposed fault diagnosis method achieves 99.7% average diagnostic accuracy with limited training samples, while maintaining 99% accuracy even when the sample size is further halved. Finally, two critical conclusions are ultimately drawn.

title: 4405 Fbg Array Sensor Interrogation Using Coherent Correlation OTDR with Hybrid Wavelength Tuning
authors: André Sandmann, M. Ali Allousch, Christian Voigtländer, Angelo Manetta, Patrick Bowen Montague, Poul Varming
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Wavelength-swept interrogation of two concatenated fiber Bragg grating arrays, consisting of 2500 gratings with 2 cm spacing and 1905 gratings with 5 cm spacing, is demonstrated at different temperatures using coherent correlation OTDR combined with accelerated hybrid laser tuning, which incorporates thermal and piezo tuning. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: An Ultra-Compact 50-Gbaud × 16-Channel CPO Transceiver Employing a 1060-nm Single-Mode VCSEL Array and Multicore Fibres
authors: Wataru Yoshida, Tomonori Azuma, Liang Dong, Kazuya Nagashima, Sho Yoneyama, Kensho Nishizaki, Jumpei Miike, Makoto Miyoshi, Xiaodong Gu, Satoshi Ide, Hideyuki Nasu, Fumio Koyama
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate an ultra-compact 50-Gbaud NRZ/PAM4 CPO transceiver employing a 1060-nm single-mode VCSEL array and single-mode MCFs. A 2-km MCF link using the transceivers exhibits a BER of below the KP4-FEC threshold. A 106.25-Gb/s PAM4 2-km MCF link achieves record low en-ergy-per-bit of 3.95 pJ/bit.

title: A Hybrid CEEMDAN and BiGRU Approach to Predicting Rolling Bearing Remaining Useful Life
authors: Zhengrui Zhang, Lirong Xie
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To overcome issues related to acoustic disturbances, inadequate characteristic identification, and extended temporal correlation difficulties in forecasting bearing remaining operational lifespan (RUL), this research introduces a CEEMDAN-BiGRU framework. Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition with Adaptive Noise (CEEMDAN) preprocessing suppresses noise and extracts multi-band features, resolving the issues of mode mixing. The Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (BiGRU) network captures bidirectional degradation patterns through efficient temporal modeling, wavelet denoising and polynomial fitting enhance the prediction interpretability. Tests conducted using the PHM-IEEE-2012 benchmark reveal the suggested approach attains a mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.0438 alongside a relative error (RE) of 1.85%, outperforming models based on EMD/EEMD decomposition and networks such as LSTM, BiLSTM, and GRU, which validates its robustness and prediction accuracy under complex operating conditions.

title: HBC-Med: A Hybrid Blockchain Model for Medical Data Management. Balancing Privacy, Interoperability and Decentralization
authors: Emiliyan Petkov, Stefan Georgiev
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This paper introduces HBC-Med, an original hybrid blockchain model for managing electronic health records (EHR), combining a public Ethereum layer for immutable auditing with a private Hyperledger Fabric layer using Raft consensus for secure storage and access control. The architecture integrates smart contracts for consent and role management, enabling automated validation and transaction traceability. Security is ensured through SHA-256 hashing, AES-256 encryption, ECDSA signatures, and TLS/SSL communication, fully compliant with FHIR, GDPR, and eIDAS standards. Experimental results demonstrate latency between 100– 150 ms, throughput of 5,000–7,000 TPS, 95% success rate in FHIR integration, and resilience against cyberattacks. HBC-Med provides a comprehensive, secure, and efficient solution for decentralized healthcare, combining transparency, privacy, access control, and interoperability with existing health information systems.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Deep Learning Models for Retinal Disease Diagnosis Using Fundus Imaging
authors: Diane Mujawayezu, Ahmet Ilhan, Boran Sekeroglu, Şerife Kaba, Omid Mirzaei
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Retinal diseases are the primary causes of vision loss and blindness. Early and accurate diagnosis is crucial to prevent irreversible damage. In recent years, transfer learning using pretrained deep learning models has achieved remarkable success in medical image analysis. This study compares three new-generation pretrained deep learning models, EfficientNetV2-M, SE-ResNeXt101-32x4d, and ConvNeXt-Base, to exhibit the capacity of the AI-based diagnostic systems in binary classification of healthy and retinal diseases from fundus images. The models were evaluated on a public dataset, RFMiD, and EfficientNetV2-M outperformed the others, achieving the highest F1 (0.959) and F2 (0.949) scores. The results demonstrate that EfficientNetV2-M is the most suitable model for retinal disease diagnosis, while SE-ResNeXt101-32x4d may serve as a complementary tool for confirmatory diagnosis, achieving the highest specificity (0.933) and PPV (0.980). The incorporation of artificial intelligence-based systems enhances ophthalmic diagnostics by enabling scalable, accurate, and efficient screening for retinal disorders.

title: Adaptive Digital Compensation of Cascaded SOA Nonlinearities in Metro-Access Networks Without Prior Parameter Knowledge
authors: Ryosuke Matsumoto, Shiyi Xia, Zhouyi Hu, Boyang Zheng, Satoshi Suda, Nicola Calabretta
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a systematic data-aided scheme that adaptively post-compensates for cascaded SOA-induced nonlinear distortions by tuning unknown SOA parameters. Nonlinear post-compensation demonstrates a 3-dB sensitivity improvement in 20-Gbaud PAM-4 experiments, enabling a symbol rate higher than 50 Gbaud after three-cascaded SOA transmission in simulations.

title: Distributed Coherent Radar System Fully Implemented as Heterogeneous SOI-InP Photonic Integrated Circuits
authors: Federico Camponeschi, Valentina Gemmato, Filippo Scotti, Muhammad Imran, Claudio Porzi, Paolo Ghelfi, Antonella Bogoni, Mirco Scaffardi
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: A distributed coherent radar system implemented as packaged heterogeneous SOI-InP integrated photonic circuits, interconnected with optical fibres, is demonstrated for the first time. The system performs range and Doppler measurements with X-band radar signals, centralizing digital processing and frequency up/down-conversion in a single node.

title: Recurrent Neuron Analysis for Dynamic Nonlinear Process Monitoring
authors: Weichen Hao, Dazi Li
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Process monitoring plays a vital role in improving economic and environmental benefits; however, nonlinear and dynamic process characteristics are extremely common in process monitoring. To address the above issues, we combined neural component analysis (NCA) with a recurrent neural network (RNN) structure and proposed a novel recurrent neuron analysis (RNA) method. RNA inherits the nonlinear fitting ability of NCA while taking advantage of the memory function of RNNs. As such, RNA simultaneously processes the nonlinear and dynamic characteristics in NCA framework. The results of a numerical simulation model showed that RNA can extract uncorrelated components from data with nonlinear and dynamic characteristics and that it performs better than traditional multivariate statistical process monitoring methods.

title: Deep Learning Techniques for Analysing Consumer Preferences in Fashion Planning for Emerging Entrepreneurial Projects
authors: Junkai Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The profitable performance of fashion planning depends on entrepreneurs' ability to understand their market consumers for adapting to market trends. The current sales forecast methods based on historical data prove inadequate due to their inability to know about shifting trends and changing consumer choices in fashion market demand. The research limitation gets addressed through a deep learning algorithm that uses image-based feature extraction with machine learning methods. The system acquires vital visual characteristics from clothing image databases through the combined deployment of AlexNet and MobileNetV3 along with InceptionV3 deep learning networks. The analyst uses k-means clustering algorithms to analyze fashion purchase patterns after they extract data plus historical sales information. Future market outlook and fashion product preference evaluation depend on classification models based on decision trees. Experimentation with clothing products from a European-based fashion company with available sales data and picture information validates the model. Experimental tests have proven that the designed framework achieves more accurate forecasts as it develops essential insights to help fashion business owners execute data-centric decisions regarding product development and inventory management.

title: Training Time, Economics, and Energy for Distributed AI Training in the GenAI Era
authors: Venkata Virajit Garbhapu, Gabriel Charlet, Yvan Pointurier
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a holistic framework for evaluating training time, cost, and energy across distributed AI training configurations. With optimal DCI bandwidth, metro-distributed training(time) takes 7% longer than single-datacenter; long-haul, 37% longer at equivalent cost. Protocol advancements like Bifrost further reduce long-haul training time by 26%.

title: Heterogeneous Integration for Silicon Photonics Based on Micro-Transfer Printing
authors: Gunther Roelkens
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Micro-transfer printing is an enabling technology to heterogeneously integrate thin-film components onto silicon photonics wafers. This tutorial will cover the basics of micro-transfer printing as well as demonstrations such as GaAs and InP opto-electronic device integration, LiNbO3 modulator integration and electronic IC integration. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Optimising Global Digital Economy Growth Using Advanced Data Transmission Techniques and Real-Time Data Processing
authors: Lufan Chen, Shuangjun Wu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study investigates the role of advanced data transmission techniques and real-time data processing in optimizing global digital economic growth. This study adopts a quantitative research approach to align more closely with the technical nature of the topic—optimizing global digital economy growth using advanced data transmission techniques and real-time data processing. Instead. Key technologies, including 5G, blockchain, and edge computing, have shown transformative effects, particularly in e-commerce, smart utilities, and healthcare. Real-Time analytics enables more agile decision-making, while edge computing enhances response times and data security. The study also identifies challenges such as data privacy concerns and interoperability issues. Looking ahead, emerging innovations like quantum computing and AI-powered analytics offer promising avenues for further growth. The findings highlight the crucial contribution of advanced data transmission and processing methods in driving efficiency, scalability, and value across sectors, thereby accelerating the global digital economy.

title: Optimizing Distributed Machine Learning Algorithms for Cloud Deployments
authors: Arpit Jain, Swamy Sai Krishna Kireeti Athamakuri, Vijay Paruchuru, Sathish Rao, Evashish Ghanshyambhai Patel, Srinath Muralinathan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Cloud infrastructure is limiting the ability to apply distributed algorithms to the processing of huge datasets. The algorithms also need to be optimized to leverage the advantages of using cloud environment resources and velocity. Therefore, this work aims to identify methods for optimizing and enhancing the performance of distributed machine learning algorithms on the cloud. It focuses, in particular, on improving the efficiency of resource use, reducing communication overhead, and eliminating computation time in the cloud. We also plan to develop adaptive algorithms to handle various cloud data and workloads. We would also investigate methods for ensuring end-to-end fault tolerance fault tolerance and scalability for cloud-based distributed machine learning systems. Algorithms, combined with high-end computing and storage, will be capable of handling extensive, highly complex data sets that are immune to failure and can be scaled with a higher level of scalability to support ever-larger volumes of data. Our work aims to make big data processing for machine learning in the cloud exponentially faster, more scalable, and more affordable by developing and optimizing distributed model training algorithms on the cloud. It will also enable new opportunities for businesses and organizations to analyze large volumes of data and extract valuable insights instantly and seamlessly.

title: 240 Gbit/s Bidirectional Coherent PON Using Uncalibrated ONU Lasers and Blind Coarse Alignment
authors: Md Mosaddek Hossain Adib, Christoph Füllner, Laurens Breyne, Michael Straub, Dora van Veen, Rene Bonk
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate a bidirectional 240Gbit/s coherent PON with a novel blind wavelength alignment technique that is applied to both ONU lasers during ONU startup. The proposed technique allows using cost-effective wavelength-uncalibrated lasers in the coherent ONU.

title: Long-Range, High-Capacity FSOC System for Rural Wireless X-Haul Using COTS Transceivers
authors: Xun Li, Ataberk Atalar, Md Nadim, Sarath Babu, Christian Joseph Margison, Mustafa Mert Bayer, Arsalan Ahmad, Daji Qiao, Hongwei Zhang, Ozdal Boyraz
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We present a 10.15 km long publicly available free-space optical communication testbed using commercially available multi-channel 10G-SFP+ transceivers deployed in rural Iowa, USA. The effective bit rates, scintillations, and channel dropout rates are studied. ©2024 The Author(s)

title: Congestion Reduction in Robotic Swarms Through Multi-Line Formation Algorithm and Waiting Sub-States
authors: Luiz Felipe L. Pimentel, Anderson G. Pires
publish: 2025 Latin American Robotics Symposium (LARS)
abstract: Inspired by natural phenomena such as fish schools and colonies, robot swarms aim to solve complex tasks through the cooperation of multiple simple robots. However, multi-agent systems face challenges in shared-target scenarios, where trajectory conflicts can cause congestion. This paper proposes a multi-line formation algorithm coordination to optimize the organization and flow of robots in narrow environments. The proposed approach combines flocking behavior with trajectory planning based on potential fields, introducing waiting sub-states to regulate access to the congestion area. The experiments demonstrated that the proposed limited-size multi-line coordination strategy effectively reduces both the distance traveled by robots and the duration of close encounters within congestion zones when compared to unlimited and limited-size multi-line motion. By introducing waiting sub-states and restricting line sizes, the method reduces swarm congestion during passage and demonstrates scalability, maintaining robust performance across different swarm sizes.

title: IoT-Based System for Nanoampere to Milivolt Amplification in Amperometric Biosensors
authors: M. N. Afnan Uda, George Wong Teck Siang, Uda Hashim, M. N. A. Uda, Lorita Angeline, Min Keng Tan, Kit Guan Lim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This paper presents an IoT-based system developed for amperometric biosensors, focusing on the amplification of nanoampere-level signals into measurable millivolt outputs. The system is capable of detecting extremely low current signals, ranging from 0 to 230 nA, through a precision amplification circuit utilizing the MAX4238 operational amplifier, known for its ultra-low input bias current and high gain accuracy. Circuit performance was first validated via simulations in LTSpice, followed by PCB design and layout using Proteus 8 Professional to realize the hardware implementation. The complete setup comprises five main modules, a display for real-time output, a microcontroller for signal processing, a voltage converter for power stabilization, a high-gain amplifier for current-to-voltage conversion, and a dedicated power supply circuit. The IoT feature, enabled by the HC-05 Bluetooth module, facilitates wireless data transmission to smartphones or cloud platforms, enabling remote monitoring. Experimental results confirmed that the system successfully amplifies ultra-low biosensor currents with stable and low-noise output, making it suitable for portable biosensing applications.

title: K-Means-BRB based health state assessment for FSW welding machine system
authors: Xiaojing Yin, Zongpo Shi, Ming Lv, Jingru Liu, Siqi Li
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Friction stir welding (FSW), an innovative solid-phase bonding technology, offers significant advantages in processing lightweight materials such as aluminum alloys. The health of its equipment is critical as it impacts welding process stability and product quality. Assessing the health state of the welding machine system is an effective means to improve welding quality. Existing methods are difficult to effectively use various types of information (expert knowledge, monitoring information, etc.) to establish a dynamic health state assessment model. The Belief Rule Base (BRB), an advanced method integrating quantitative and qualitative knowledge, is widely used in health state assessment of electromechanical equipment. This paper proposes a K-Means-BRB model for health state assessment of welding machine systems. The model employs BRB to establish the assessment framework by integrating monitoring information and expert knowledge. K-Means clustering optimizes the reference values of the premise attributes in the original BRB, while the projected covariance matrix adaptive evolutionary strategy (P-CMA-ES) updates the BRB's initial parameters. Taking the FSW welding machine system for aluminum alloy battery casings as the research object, the model's feasibility is verified, providing a practical solution for health state assessment of welding machine systems.

title: High Power Wideband Quantum Dot Comb Laser with 200GHz Mode Spacing for Short Reach Optical I/O Applications
authors: Guanlin Lou, Han Li, Xiangjie Zhao, Jiangwei Man, Bo Zhou, Shiyong Zhang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We report an O-band InAs quantum dot comb source suitable for high capacity short-reach optical interconnects. At 45 °C, the laser has up to 9 wavelengths at 200 GHz mode spacing and 810dBm optical power per channel.

title: Observation of Precursor of the Kamchatka Earthquake by Monitoring an Optical Fiber Link in the Mediterranean Sea
authors: Antonio Mecozzi, Cristian Antonelli, Alberto Marullo, Danilo Decaroli, Luca Palmieri, Luca Schenato, Siddharth Varughese, Pierre Mertz, Mohammad M. Hosseini, Antonio Napoli
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: By monitoring the state of polarization of cables belonging to the MedNautilus submarine system in the Mediterranean Sea, we unambiguously observed the signature of the recent <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$M_{w} 8.8$</tex> Kamchatka earthquake in two different cables. A clear precursor of the earthquake is observed in one of the cables. ©2024 The Author(s)

title: Novel Polarization-Dependence-Free Optical Injection-Locking Circuit Using $\lambda / 4$ Phase-Shift-Free HR DFB LD at $1.5 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$
authors: Keisuke Kasai, Shun Otsu, Masato Yoshida, Toshihiko Hirooka, Masataka Nakazawa
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate a novel polarization-dependence-free injection-locking circuit with a λ/4-phase-shift-free HR DFB LD. This circuit enabled us to achieve stable phase-locking for randomly polarization-modulated injection-light with a modulation-speed of 600 krad/s. Furthermore, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$240-$</tex> Gbit/s64 QAM transmission was demonstrated under a random polarization-rotation condition.

title: Demonstration of ±0.5 GHz Lasing Frequency Stability of DFB-CAN with One-Chip Wavelength Monitor and Evaluation of 16QAM 40-km Fiber Transmission
authors: Junichi Suzuki, Kiyotomo Hasegawa, Hiroshi Miura, Kei Masuyama, Nobuo Ohata
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Lasing frequency stability of less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.5 \text{GHz}$</tex> was demonstrated by controlling DFB-CAN with a one-chip wavelength monitor with a feedback circuit. Furthermore, a 40-km fiber transmission was evaluated and shown to have sufficiently low phase noise for DCI applications.

title: A Normal Operating Zone Model for Monitoring of Tennessee Eastman Benchmark Process
authors: Fangjia Li, Jiandong Wang, Mengyao Wei
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Process monitoring plays an extremely crucial role in ensuring the safe operation of actual industrial production processes. This paper takes the Tennessee Eastman (TE) process as the object and builds a normal operating zone model for monitoring of Tennessee Eastman benchmark process. Firstly, based on the basic conservation laws such as material conservation and energy conservation, the mechanism models of each device in the TE process are constructed. Then, combined with the mechanism models and the control limits of some variables, the allowable variation ranges of monitoring variables under normal working conditions form a geometric space. The convex hull is used to depict the boundary of the geometric space, and the normal operating zone model of the TE process is obtained. Finally, a simulation case is designed using the TE process simulation model, which verifies that the established model can effectively monitor whether the TE process is in an abnormal state, providing a solid guarantee for the safe operation of the production process.

title: Transformer-Based Novelty Scoring of Research Ideas: An End-to-End NLP Pipeline
authors: Necip Gozuacik
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The rapid advancement of Generative Artificial Intelligence and Large Language Models has transformed research and innovation, offering new opportunities and challenges in assessing the novelty of research ideas. Traditional methods, such as expert peer review and citation-based metrics, often suffer from subjectivity and inefficiency, highlighting the need for automated, scalable solutions. This study aims to address this gap by developing an end-to-end Natural Language Processing pipeline that leverages transformer-based models for novelty scoring of research ideas. The proposed framework integrates modules for literature collection, data organization, and semantic similarity analysis, using recent publications from the Web of Science database as a benchmark. Key findings indicate that the pipeline effectively differentiates between novel and less original ideas, with higher novelty scores corresponding to lower similarity with existing literature. This suggests that transformer-based embeddings can provide a robust and interpretable measure of research originality. The study contributes a replicable methodological approach that bridges literature retrieval with automated novelty scoring, offering practical value for academic and industrial innovation processes. The framework’s scalability and objectivity have significant implications for research institutions and funding bodies, enhancing the efficiency of idea screening and portfolio management.

title: Real-Time Egg Inspection with YOLOv5-Seg: From Crack Detection to Mobile Application
authors: Thien van Nguyen, Thai Dinh Kim, Quang-Anh Nguyen Duc, Duc Minh Pham, Tien-Thanh Do, Trung-Hieu Nguyen, Phuong-Hoa Ngo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Manual inspection of egg quality, a critical process in the global food supply chain, is frequently hampered by the inherent inefficiencies and high error rates of traditional methods like candling, especially in detecting minor defects such as microcracks in large-scale production. To address these limitations, this study proposes and validates a deep learning framework for automated, real-time egg quality assessment and defect segmentation using the YOLOv5-seg model. A custom dataset comprising 660 images, categorized into four distinct quality classes (5-day, 15-day, cracked, and broken), was collected and annotated for this purpose. The framework’s performance was rigorously evaluated across five model variants, demonstrating exceptional results with optimal precision of 98.8%, recall of 97.7%, and a mean Average Precision (mAP@0.5) of 97.3% for both detection and segmentation tasks. Furthermore, to bridge the gap between research and practical application, the trained model was successfully deployed into a mobile application featuring an intuitive interface for on-site image capture, defect visualization, and real-time classification. This work presents a robust, scalable, and highly accurate solution that significantly enhances the efficiency and reliability of egg quality control, offering a pivotal technological advancement for the modern poultry industry.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Demand-Driven PON Configuration for Fixed-Mobile Convergence
authors: L. Inglés, L. Anet Neto, C. Rattaro, M. Morvan, A. Castro, L. Nuaymi
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Here, we address fixed-mobile convergence using an SDN-enabled PON with dynamic T-CONT configuration. Sub-millisecond PON latency is demonstrated for mobile traffic while reducing bandwidth usage by up to 80 % during off-peak periods. We also compare different network configuration approaches with a Random Forest prediction model.

title: MIMO Reader for Chipless RFID Systems Utilizing Antenna Diversity and Combining Techniques
authors: Mohamed El Hadidy, Ines Bakri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Main objective of this work is to introduce a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> Multiple Input Multiple Out (MIMO) reader for chipless RFID system in dense multipath indoor environments utilizing antenna diversity and applying enhanced calibration and combining algorithms. The deterministic MIMO channel of a real-world indoor scenario is simulated using hybrid 3D EM ray-tracing simulation tool, considering the chipless RFID Radar Cross Section (RCS), antenna effects and the multipath components of the channel. Antenna diversity technique is applied illustrating the enhancement of the system performance using directional horn antennas pointed at different orthogonal directions insted of using omni-directional half-wave dipole antennas. A mathematical framework for the system is presented and an enhanced calibration and combing techniques are applied. Simulation results illustrate robustness and a significant enhancement of the system performance for the notch detection capability of the chipless RFID tag, which opens the door for enormous realistic indoor industrial applications.

title: Who Invented the Non Linear Junction Detector?
authors: Simon Hemour, Paul Reuvers, Marc Simons, Nicolas Barbot
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents an historical retrospective on the development of the nonlinear junction detector (NLJD), a device that can be used to remotely detect (hidden) objects based on their nonlinear electric behavior. After presenting the principle of the device and its architecture, the development of the nonlinear junction detector is highlighted in chronological order, and C. Bovill is acknowledged for this technological milestone. The work done in this article can be used by researchers working in the field of harmonic and intermodulation transponders and radars.

title: 10 G/400 G Reliable Bidirectional FSO Transmission Over Turbulent Channels With Reciprocity-Driven Power Adaptation
authors: Vitor D. Correia, João O. Gonçalves, Paulo P. Monteiro, Fernando P. Guiomar, Gil M. Fernandes
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Free-space optical (FSO) communications have emerged as a high-capacity wireless technology for 6 G networks and last-mile connectivity. However, their performance is significantly affected by weather conditions and atmospheric turbulence, limiting both capacity and reliability. Optical amplification offers a promising approach to overcome the resultant power fluctuations. In particular, Erbium-doped fiber amplifiers (EDFAs) operating in automatic power control (APC) mode can effectively compensate for signal fading by stabilizing the received power level prior to detection, thereby enhancing link reliability under dynamic channel conditions. In this paper, we experimentally demonstrate the adaptive optical power pre-compensation of atmospheric turbulence using two counter-propagating signals. A 400 Gbps upstream signal, affected by turbulence, is wavelength-multiplexed with a 10 Gbps downstream on-off keying (OOK) signal, and subsequently both signals are launched into an EDFA in APC mode. Leveraging the coherence time of atmospheric turbulence, we achieved joint upstream pre-compensation and downstream post-compensation of turbulence. The Rytov variance of both signals is analyzed under various turbulent conditions resorting to an atmospheric chamber, considering the different power ratios between both signals. The results reveal a reduction in the upstream Rytov variation of two orders of magnitude, effectively achieving turbulence suppression. Furthermore, real-time upstream signal analysis indicates reliability gains up to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\approx 90\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>.

title: Real-Time Deployment of Pruned Unsupervised DNN for Blind Equalization in a Photonics-Aided W-Band Wireless System
authors: Jie Zhang, Wen Zhou, Qihang Wang, Sheng Hu, Sicong Xu, Chengzhen Bian, Jingtao Ge, Jingwen Lin, Siqi Wang, Zhihang Ou, Tengsheng Zhang, Tong Wang, Jianjun Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: The evolution beyond 5G and the advent of new 6G applications pose increasing challenges for communication in dense urban and hotspot areas. Photonics-assisted millimeter-wave (mm-Wave) communication systems have emerged as attractive solutions to meet these demands. Various enhancement schemes based on traditional digital signal processing (DSP) and neural networks have been proposed. However, the limitations of traditional DSP algorithms and the high complexity of supervised neural networks hinder real-time transmission. To address this issue, this article proposes an unsupervised DNN-based equalizer built upon the traditional constant modulus algorithm (CMA) for blind equalization of PAM signals, with structured pruning applied to facilitate practical deployment. Compared to the conventional CMA, the blind DNN equalizer effectively handles both linear and nonlinear impairments and achieves better bit error rate (BER) performance. Structured pruning reduces model floating-point operations (FLOPs) by 34%, successfully transforming the originally nondeployable architecture into a compact model executable in real-time on a field programmable gate array (FPGA), at the cost of a slight BER increase from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3.53\times 10^{-3}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$6.84\times 10^{-3}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. We demonstrate a real-time photonics-assisted W-band wireless system based on an FPGA, employing the blind DNN equalizer to enhance performance. The system achieves real-time transmission of 14.7456-Gb/s PAM4 signals over a 200-m free-space link, attaining a BER of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$6.84\times 10^{-3}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. This work explores high-capacity real-time communication in dense AI environments and serves as a representative case of integrating traditional DSP algorithms with data-driven neural networks.

title: Memory-Efficient Training for Deep Speaker Embedding Learning in Speaker Verification
authors: Bei Liu, Yanmin Qian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Recent speaker verification (SV) systems have shown a trend toward adopting deeper speaker embedding extractors. Although deeper and larger neural networks can significantly improve performance, their substantial memory requirements hinder training on consumer GPUs. A number of memory-efficient training techniques have been explored in the MLSys community, including reversible networks and optimizer state quantization, which aim to reduce activation and optimizer memory usage. However, these general techniques have rarely been adapted or systematically analyzed for SV models operating on time–frequency representations. In this paper, we revisit these two classic directions and introduce a joint memory-efficient training strategy tailored for deep speaker embedding learning under resource-constrained conditions. Specifically, we (1) design two types of reversible architectures for SV, including a reshape-based reversible downsampling mechanism (Type II RevNets) to enhance the degree of reversibility across all layers, and (2) propose a dynamic, tree-based 8-bit quantization scheme for optimizer states that preserves numerical stability under heavy-tailed parameter distributions. The proposed joint reversible–quantized optimizer framework achieves up to 16.2x memory savings while maintaining nearly identical parameters and performance compared to the original systems. Extensive experiments on VoxCeleb show that our method enables training of deep ResNet and DF-ResNet models using only one or two consumer-grade GPUs, without sacrificing performance.

title: Machine and Deep Learning-Based Network and Web Attack Analysis with a Web-Based IDS Platform
authors: Sultan Tazefidan, Gülay Çiçek
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: In recent years, rapid technological advancements have led to a significant increase in cyber-attacks, making timely threat detection critical for both individuals and organizations. In this study, the NF-CSE-CIC-IDS2018-V2 dataset is utilized to evaluate machine learning algorithms (such as KNN and RF) and deep learning algorithms (such as CNN and DNN), together with dimensionality reduction techniques. A comprehensive experimental and practical analysis is conducted. The proposed hybrid model achieved an accuracy of 97.02% on raw data, 96.88% with the VAE representation, and 59.46% with the PCA representation, demonstrating consistently high performance except for PCA. Furthermore, the developed web-based IDS Analysis Platform provides interactive analysis and reporting capabilities, contributing to the field of cybersecurity.

title: EmoKT: Emotion-Aware Fusion Enhanced Knowledge Tracing Using Joint Graph–Transformer Model
authors: Tao He, Zhitian Zhong, Shimin Kang, Xuri Fang, Kaihang Yang, Xiaoming Cao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Knowledge tracing is a foundational task in intelligent education, aiming to predict students’ future performance by modeling their historical interactions. Traditional knowledge tracing methods primarily focus on analyzing students’ learning behaviors, often neglecting their dynamically changing emotional states during the learning process. Given that emotion is an integral part of the cognitive process, neglecting emotional states will limit the representation capacity of knowledge tracing models for modeling students’ learning processes. To address this issue, we propose a novel emotion-aware knowledge tracing method to explore the impact of complex emotions (e.g., concentration, frustration, boredom, and confusion) on knowledge states throughout the learning process. Specifically, we design an emotion-aware fusion module to capture the joint influence of multiple coexisting emotional states on students’ answers during each exercise session. Additionally, we utilize graph convolutional networks to propagate embeddings and obtain the complete knowledge structure information of exercises. We further integrate exercise attributes and students’ emotional information through a feature fusion module, thereby incorporating emotional states into the knowledge tracing task. Finally, we apply a transformer-based knowledge evolution module to model students’ evolving knowledge states, achieving multiview fusion modeling of emotions, knowledge topology, and learning sequences. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method outperforms previous knowledge tracing methods in predicting student performance.

title: Characterization and Minimization of Commutation Loop Inductance in Reconfigurable Battery Systems Using Magnetically Coupled Auxiliary Loops
authors: Christian Hanzl, David Wenninger, Christian Endisch
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: This study presents a novel analysis of the commutation loop inductance in reconfigurable battery systems (RBS) based on a half-bridge topology. The investigation considers variations in the number of series connected battery cells before being linked of the half-bridge. Based on these findings, three methods are explored to minimize loop inductance: (1) introducing magnetically coupled conductor/auxiliary loops to create a freewheeling path for the magnetization current, with parts of the auxiliary loop formed by sections of the power loop to achieve near-ideal coupling, (2) employing a solid copper shield as an alternative to auxiliary loops, and (3) optimizing the physical arrangement of the series connected battery cells. Experimental results show a reduction in loop inductance of up to 59% using the magnetically coupled auxiliary loop, and up to 66% with the solid copper shield.

title: Efficient Pilot Assignment for D2D-Underlaid NOMA Cell-Free Massive MIMO Systems: A Hypergraph Coloring Approach
authors: Qin Wang, Haotian Chang, Yongxu Zhu, Mei Chen, Li Gao, Wenchao Xia, Haitao Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: In this paper, a cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF-mMIMO) system coexisting with device-to-device (D2D) pairs is investigated under ultra-dense wireless networks (UDWNs), aiming to accommodate the growing number of devices and escalating data traffic demands in future sixth-generation (6G) networks. To overcome the challenge of pilot shortage in UDWNs, non-orthogonal multiple-access (NOMA) and successive interference cancellation (SIC) technologies are employed, enabling users within the same cluster to share pilots efficiently. A closed-form expression for the spectral efficiency of conjugate beamforming receivers is derived, revealing that pilot contamination caused by pilot sharing severely degrades system performance. A novel hypergraph coloring (HGC)-based pilot assignment algorithm is proposed to address this issue, effectively capturing the complex cumulative interference among multiple users and D2D pairs. The algorithm constructs users' interference hypergraphs using a user-centric access point (AP) selection strategy and allocates pilots based on interference weights within these hyperedges. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed scheme significantly improves spectral efficiency, offering a promising solution for interference management in CF-mMIMO systems under UDWNs.

title: Graph Chirp Signal and Graph Fractional Vertex–Frequency Energy Distribution
authors: Manjun Cui, Zhichao Zhang, Wei Yao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing
abstract: Graph signal processing (GSP) has emerged as a powerful framework for analyzing data defined on irregular domains. In recent years, many classical techniques in signal processing (SP) have been successfully extended to GSP. Among them, chirp signals play a crucial role in various SP applications. However, graph chirp signals, despite their potential importance, have not yet been formally defined. Here, we define graph chirp signals and establish a comprehensive theoretical framework for their analysis.We propose the graph fractional vertex–frequency energy distribution (GFED), which provides a powerful tool for processing and analyzing graph chirp signals.We introduce the general fractional graph distribution (GFGD), a generalized vertex–frequency distribution, along with the reduced-interference GFED that effectively suppress cross-term interference and enhance signal clarity. Furthermore, we develop a novel GFED domain filtering method for detecting graph chirp signals, enabling robust signal analysis in noisy environments. Moreover, this method demonstrates strong practical potential in real-world denoising tasks, achieving performance superior to several state-of-the-art approaches. Finally, we explore the potential applications of graph chirp signals, highlighting their usefulness in denoising and compression.

title: ECFuzz++: An Enhanced Fuzz Testing Framework for Large-Scale System Configuration Vulnerabilities Based on Multimodal AI
authors: Yuanzhe Feng
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Configuration-related problems can seriously jeopardize the strength and security of big computing setups. The existing methods of fuzzing often fail to spot misconfigurations because they do not consider enough details and cannot produce adequate input. For this reason, this paper introduces ECFuzz++, a new fuzz testing tool that makes use of various types of AI to discover hidden and deep problems with configurations in advanced systems. The framework uses a multimodal analysis engine, a context-aware configuration extractor, a neural AI for generating mutations and also a system to prioritize flaws. It packs natural language processing, system log extracts, the content in the documentation and recordings of historical issues into profiles of system settings. This extractor locates and decodes the settings that link several software and hardware features together. Mutation generator uses transformers trained with real-world data to make new inputs that pass syntax checks and are still semantically different. The system ends with prioritization which uses graphs to determine the risks of each vulnerability by considering how easy it is to exploit and how significant its impact is. Good results have been achieved by running ECFuzz++ on both benchmark data and on actual enterprise configurations; it is better than other fuzzing frameworks when it comes to finding issues, how much it explores the programs and the relevance of the problems found. My findings show that the framework can greatly increase the strength of key systems using smart and scalable fuzzing of configurations.

title: InGaP-on-insulator Waveguides for Entangled Pair Generation
authors: L. C. Ahler, L. Thiel, P. H. Godoy, A. Qarar, X. Li, J. Castro, Y. Pang, M. Meunier, L. Wang, E. J. Stanton, J. E. Bowers, G. Moody, N. Volet, E. Z. Ulsig

title: A Novel Fault Tree Analysis Method Based on Interval Type-2 T–S Fuzzy Model
authors: Xiao Fan, Peng Liu, Meilin Xie, Feng Jing, Fan Wang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This article presents an interval type-2 (IT2) T–S fuzzy fault tree analysis (FFTA) method to improve the ability of dealing with uncertainties in the process of reliability analysis (RA). IT2 T–S fuzzy gate is adopted to establish the fuzzy fault tree, which no longer needs the exact membership function. In the procedure of establishing T–S fuzzy rules, a novel weighted distance determination method is proposed to evaluate the occurrence probability of top events automatically. Particularly, experts only need evaluate the high and low failure rate of bottom events instead of exact value. In addition, the existing aggregation approach of expert views is not suitable to IT2 T–S FFTA, so this paper proposes a new aggregation method. Finally the proposed IT2 T–S FFTA is applied in an electro-optical tracking system (EOTS) and the failure rate of EOTS is obtained.

title: Leveraging Digital Twins for Enhanced Predictive Analytics in Smart Manufacturing
authors: Gurpreet Singh, Manish Sharma, Harinder Kaur, Nilesh Shelke, Rajeshwar Balla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Smart manufacturing faces challenges such as unexpected equipment failures and operational inefficiencies, leading to costly downtime and reduced productivity. This paper proposes a novel framework leveraging digital twins—virtual replicas of physical systems—to enhance predictive analytics in smart manufacturing. By integrating real-time sensor data with machine learning and scalable digital twin simulations, the framework predicts equipment failures with 95% accuracy and optimizes production processes. A comprehensive methodology is presented, including data collection, digital twin creation, and a real-time failure prediction algorithm. Tested in a car parts manufacturing plant, the framework achieves a 25% reduction in downtime and a 15% increase in production efficiency compared to traditional methods. A state-of-the-art comparison demonstrates superior accuracy and scalability, addressing limitations of existing approaches. This work offers a practical, scalable solution for smart factories, paving the way for more resilient and efficient manufacturing systems.

title: Secure and Authenticating X-Ray Images Based on Histogram Segmentation, Fractional Fourier Transform (FRT) and Firefly Algorithms
authors: Vijay Krishna Pallaw, Pancham Kumar, Rishki Tyagi, Parmeshwar Tak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Security and authenticity of medical images is very crucial in present-day healthcare systems, especially in X-ray imaging which plays a major role in determining diagnosis and treatment. Thus, this paper proposes a novel structure for X-ray image authentication involving Histogram Segmentation, Fractional Fourier Transform (FRT) and Firefly Algorithm. The purpose behind this technique is to have enhanced image authentication accuracy with robustness by using these methods together. In other words, Histogram Segmentation provides the preprocessed X-ray images through dividing them into sections based on intensity levels thus allowing a better feature extraction. FRT converts these segmented images into a space that makes easy finding of several features, which are unique to each kind of picture and is secure from unauthorized use or access. Finally, the Firefly Algorithm is applied to optimize parameters of FRT so that it can find unauthorized changes in X-ray pictures more effectively. The experimental outcomes indicate that this proposed framework has good performance as far as authentication precision, computational efficiency and resilience against typical image attacks are concerned. On this account; this framework stands significant advancement in protecting medical images in a secure manner thus guaranteeing that the data regarding patients within health care units is intact and confidential.

title: Generative Adversarial Networks-Driven Synthetic Patient Data Creation for Risk Identification in Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
authors: Utku Kose, Osman Ceylan, Muhammet Enes Karatas, Ilhan Uysal, Ahmet Koca
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study aims to enhance real-world clinical data in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) patients and enable more detailed patient analysis through risk category classification. New synthetic patient samples were generated via Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) model. Here, the GAN discriminator used patient data derived from a Graph Neural Network (GNN). The similarity between the synthetic patient data generated by the model and real patient data was assessed using various metrics. Distribution similarity analyses (t-SNE, PCA, and various statistical metrics) demonstrated substantial alignment between the synthetic and real patient datasets. The findings of the study demonstrated the effectiveness of GAN-based patient data augmentation in terms of data privacy and patient diversity. Furthermore, synthetically generated patient data can serve as a robust foundation for clinical digital twin applications and decision support systems.

title: Spacecraft Fault Inference based on Multi-source and Multi-level Knowledge Graphs
authors: Xiaoyu Xing, Shuyi Wang, Wenjing Liu, Chengrui Liu, Hanyu Liang, Yan Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper classifies spacecraft fault knowledge graphs into two categories based on fault knowledge sources and system structure levels: data-driven and knowledge-driven fault knowledge graphs. Distinct fault inference methods are proposed for each type. For data-driven fault knowledge graphs, a multilayer perceptron model is employed to capture semantic information from measuring points and on-orbit data, enabling spacecraft health monitoring and fault location identification. For knowledge-driven fault knowledge graphs, the Graph Attention Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (GADDPG) is utilized to achieve precise fault path inference. These methods are integrated within a unified fault knowledge graph of the overall control system, constructing a comprehensive fault diagnosis system that combines knowledge and data. Experimental validations using on-orbit data and actual fault cases demonstrate the system's capability to achieve accurate fault localization and hierarchical fault diagnosis.

title: Comparison of Clustering Algorithms for Indoor Environmental Time-Series Data
authors: Quoc-Dung Ngo, Dinh-Dat Nguyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Clustering multivariate time-series data from indoor environmental sensors is challenging due to data complexity and noise. This paper compares feature-based, raw data-based, and model-based clustering methods to identify the most effective approach for extracting meaningful patterns. We evaluate these methods using Silhouette Score, Davies-Bouldin Index, and Calinski-Harabasz Index. Results show that model-based methods, especially Gaussian Mixture Models, outperform others in cluster compactness and separation, despite some negative Silhouette scores. Feature-based methods provide moderate stability, while raw data-based approaches yield mixed results. Limitations include zone-level data without inter-zone links, absence of benchmark datasets with labels, and a limited range of tested algorithms. Future work will address these by expanding data scope, incorporating benchmarks, and exploring more clustering techniques. This study offers a concise comparison of clustering strategies for indoor multivariate time-series data, aiding future research in environmental monitoring and smart buildings.
