                    Fault Detection for Demagnetized Permanent Magnet Synchronous Machine via Interval LPV Observer Approach
authors: Junxing Che, Yanzheng Zhu, Fen Wu, Donghua Zhou
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In this paper, a novel interval-observer-based fault detection method is proposed for a class of permanent magnet synchronous machines (PMSMs) with demagnetization faults. The linear parameter varying modeling and observer design schemes are developed to address the fault detection issue for demagnetized PMSMs. According to the characteristics of demagnetization faults, an interval-observer-based fault detection filter is designed to generate dynamic residuals, and the finite frequency H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−</inf>/L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> performance criteria are established to improve the sensitivity for a specified fault frequency and the robustness against bounded disturbances. By using the parameter-dependent Lyapunov function approach, sufficient conditions are presented ensuring that the corresponding error systems are cooperative and the generated residuals are sensitive to faults while robust against measurement noises. Finally, the motor-to-towing experimental platform with 5.5-KW surface-mount demagnetized PMSMs is constructed to validate the applicability and effectiveness of the presented approach.

title: Dynamic Risk-Aware Reconfiguration in Coherent P2MP Extended Access Networks Under Time-Varying Demands
authors: P. Soumplis, K. Christodoulopoulos, A. Napoli, K. Yiannopoulos, E. Varvarigos
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We study the dynamic P2MP light-tree reconfiguration problem under correlated, time-varying access demands. A greedy heuristic leverages a risk model and computes the access node assignments to light-trees, minimizing spectrum under provision risks and reconfiguration penalties. Simulations show higher acceptance and lower blocking than static provisioning. ©2024 The Author(s)

title: A Time-Series Forecasting Framework for Stock Market Prediction Using LSTM and Technical Indicators
authors: Pallav Anand, Sunita Yadav
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper proposes a real-time framework of stock market prediction based on Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks and prominent indicators. The first is to enhance the effectiveness of more accurate forecasting by measuring temporal dependencies and the non-linearity model in the data on finance. The Yahoo Finance API retrieves historical stock information augmented to indicators like the Relative Strength Index (RSI), Moving Averages (SMA, EMA), MACD, and Bollinger Bands. The model is an LSTM tested and compared against conventional machine algorithms such as Linear Regression, Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Random Forest. Performance evaluation is done through Mean Squared Error (MSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and R 2 Score. The findings prove that the offered LSTM model demonstrates even better accuracy, with the value of MSE equal to 0.004 and R Sq Score reaching 0.95. By combining real-time information and deep learning, the interplay opens up an effective stock prediction model, a massive advancement compared to traditional forecasting systems.

title: Partial-MIMO Application for Mode Groups Transmission Over 15-Mode and 6-Mode Multi-Mode Fibers
authors: S. Gaiani, R. S. Luis, B. Kalla, D. Orsuti, M. v.d. Hout, H. Chen, N. K. Fontaine, R. Ryf, P. Sillard, G. Rademacher, T. Bradley, C. Okonkwo, P. Parolari, A. Gatto, P. Boffi, H. Furukawa
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We evaluate the use of partial-MIMO demultiplexing using multi-mode fibers with 15 and 6 modes. We show effective signal recovery without the need for full-MIMO at the cost of throughput and evaluate the limits of the system. ©2025 The Authors

title: An Empirical Comparison and Complexity Analysis of AutoEncoders for Dimensionality Reduction of Images
authors: Yashvi Bhadania, Nileshkumar Patel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper explores the empirical comparison and complexity analysis of autoencoders (AE) for dimensionality reduction. AutoEncoders, as a deep learning technique, has been widely adopted for dimensionality reduction of the data and also preserving significant features of the data. The dataset used for dimensionality reduction is MNIST, to compare the various types of autoencoders. All AEs have a compression ratio of 91.84% and they are compared using four evaluation metrics, the first two are statistical metrics and the next two are visualization metrics; Mean Squared Error(MSE), Wasserstein Distance (WD), Structural Similarity Index(SSIM), and Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) respectively. Contractive AE shows superior performance by giving highest scores for the visual metrics, SSIM (0.8959), and PSNR (24.00), which are of most importance in dimensionality reduction of images. A complexity analysis is then carried out in order to evaluate the efficiency of the various autoencoders in terms of its time complexity and space complexities respectively. Additionally, Contractive AE has a tradeoff between performance and time and space complexities. Finally, this paper is concluded giving insights for future research direction.

title: FPGA-Based Hardware Realization of PTBC DSP for 100 Gbps 16-QAM Transmission in Coherent-Lite Optical Network
authors: Hae Young Rha, Chanho Park, Jung-Yeol Oh, Jongwan Kim, Hun-Sik Kang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We present a real-time FPGA-based PTBC system, validated by 100 Gbps 16-QAM over 20 km fiber. The design achieves a 34.6 dB power budget at BER <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 10^{-2}$</tex> with 7 dBm launch power, proving its feasibility for coherent-lite optical networks.

title: Net 6.4 and 7.6 Tbps BiDi Transmission Over 10 km Hollow-Core Fiber for AI Data Center Based on $8 \lambda-225$ GBaud PAM4/6
authors: Yao Zhang, Haiyun Xin, Jin Tang, Qiang Guo, Haofan Yang, Maxim Kuschnerov, Huixiao Ma
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate the first bi-directional 8λ 225 GBaud IMDD-WDM transmission through hollow-core fiber. A total net rate of 6.4/7.6 Tbps over 10 km transmission is achieved using PAM4/6, respectively considering a BER threshold of 4.8e-3(HD-FEC)/2.4e-2(SD-FEC).

title: RUL Prediction of Lithium-ion Battery Based on Meta-Learning Under Small Samples
authors: Zengyu Deng, Zehui Mao
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Due to the swift increase in worldwide demand for clean energy and energy storage solutions, lithium-ion batteries are widely utilized in electric vehicles, drones, and energy storage systems. Accurately predicting their remaining useful life (RUL) is vital for maintaining operational safety and economic efficiency. Nevertheless, gathering adequate, high-quality, whole-life-cycle data under real-world operating conditions presents difficulties, resulting in a "small sample" challenge for prediction methods based on deep learning. To tackle this problem, this paper introduces a meta-learning framework that utilizes an enhanced Relation Network (RN). An embedding module combining a Convolutional Neural Network and a Transformer (CNN-Transformer) is crafted to effectively capture both local and global temporal features. The relation module is used to assess the similarity between the operating condition and the initial state of lithium-ion batteries, facilitating the construction of health state representations and enabling RUL predictions. Comparative experiments conducted on publicly available NASA and eVTOL datasets reveal that the proposed method achieves impressive accuracy and robustness, even when data availability is limited. This research provides new perspectives on predicting the lifespan of lithium-ion batteries in scenarios with small sample sizes.

title: Design Guidelines for EM Wireless Powering of Miniature Battery-Free Implantable Devices
authors: Denys Nikolayev, Icaro V. Soares
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Wireless power transfer enables battery-free operation of implantable bioelectronic devices, ensuring long-term functionality without relying on bulky batteries. This paper provides design guidelines for efficient electromagnetic WPT to miniature deep-body implants. It compares near-field, mid-field, and far-field methods, focusing on mid-field WPT for improved efficiency for miniature devices at greater depths. Key factors such as frequency selection, transmitter and receiver design, and methods to reduce tissue losses are discussed. Strategies like wavefront shaping and metasurfaces are examined to enhance power delivery while meeting safety constraints.

title: An electromagnetic control method of electromagnetic levitation spherical rotor in a supergravity reactor
authors: Feng Wang, Xiaozhi Li, Zhenghui Zhang, Yan Bai
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Material adhesion on rotor surfaces in supergravity reactors induces creates uneven mass distribution, leading to imbalance vibrations that degrade bearings and seals, ultimately resulting in hazardous leakage. While conventional rotor dynamics provides temporary mechanical equilibrium, it fails to resolve persistent imbalance caused by material adhesion. To address this limitation, this study proposes an innovative electromagnetic levitation spherical rotor system that combines structural redesign with adaptive control. This system fundamentally departs from traditional cylindrical configurations by eliminating the motor, shaft, and bearings. Instead, the rotor is reconfigured as a hollow sphere filled with packing material and embedded with surface magnetic poles. Dual coil arrays generate contactless levitation forces and multidirectional torque, enabling three-degree-of-freedom rotation about the sphere's geometric center. When material adhesion disrupts mass symmetry, a PID control algorithm dynamically adjusts the currents in both suspension and rotation coils. This active control mechanism simultaneously repositions the rotor's center of mass to align with its rotational axis and cancels the unbalanced mass radius, thereby continuously neutralizing centrifugal forces. By maintaining zero effective eccentricity despite ongoing material accumulation, the system eliminates imbalance vibration at its source.This approach effectively solves the persistent leakage problem in conventional supergravity reactors while significantly improving operational stability and service life.

title: Dual Band Quarter Mode Substrate Integrated Waveguide (QMSIW) MIMO Antenna for WiMAX and Sub-6GHz Applications
authors: V Shiva Prasad Nayak, Manjunathachari K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: In this manuscript, a compact 2-port Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) antenna is proposed, operating within the sub-6GHz range, specifically within the frequency ranges of 3.43GHz to 3.52GHz and 4.30GHz to 4.45GHz. The proposed antenna utilizes Substrate Integrated Waveguide (SIW) technology, where in each MIMO element is designed in a Quarter Mode Substrate Integrated Waveguide (QMSIW) configuration. The essential parameters of the antenna, such as resonance frequency, gain, radiation pattern, Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR), and bandwidth have been meticulously analyzed utilizing CST Studio Suite software. This analysis is anticipated to be beneficial for sub-6 GHz 5G applications. The proposed antenna resonances at 3.475GHz and 4.385GHz and exhibits bandwidths of 90MHz and 150MHz centered around a -10 dB reference line and maintains a VSWR of 2:1. The physical realization of the MIMO antenna is executed using FR-4 material, with overall dimensions measuring 14.1 × 52 × 1.67 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. The simulation results indicate that the developed antenna demonstrates an impressive radiation pattern and gain, rendering it highly advantageous for effective implementation in contemporary 5G communication systems.

title: Improving the Ergodic Capacity of RIS-Aided UAV System Employing RSMA
authors: Ba Cao Nguyen, Thien Duc Le, Tran Manh Hoang, Thu Phuong Nguyen, Thi Thanh Huyen Le, Xuan Nghia Pham
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the ergodic capacity (EC) of a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-aided unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) system employing rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA). We derive a closed-form EC expression over Nakagami-m fading channels, accounting for practical parameters such as carrier frequency, bandwidth, and noise figures. Monte-Carlo simulations confirm the accuracy of our analysis. Numerical results show that the proposed RIS-RSMA-UAV system significantly outperforms a baseline RSMA-UAV system without RIS, nearly doubling the EC in the low transmit power regime, while the gain diminishes at high transmit powers, suggesting that simpler configurations may suffice when power is abundant. Based on these insights, we propose design guidelines for RIS sizing and UAV altitude selection under varying power constraints.

title: High-Quality 98.5-GHz Carrier Generation with Silicon Photonics mm-Wave Band Synthesizer Embedding a Multi-Resonant Optical Filter
authors: Muhammad Imran, Antonio Malacarne, Antonella Bogoni, Claudio Porzi
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: A silicon-photonics multi-resonant distributed feedback resonator-based filter is designed and employed into an integrated millimeter-wave band synthesizer performing ideal fivefold multiplication of a 19.7 GHz local oscillator frequency, leading to a phase noise of −125 dBc/Hz at 1 MHz offset from the generated 98.5 GHz carrier.

title: UAV Flight Path Optimization Using EM-Based Estimation of Superior Quality Communication Areas
authors: Koyo Aoyama, Takahiro Matsuda, Tomotaka Kimura, Hiroyuki Shimizu, Takefumi Hiraguri
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: In complex urban propagation environments, communication coverage and quality are often degraded due to multipath fading and shadowing. Conventional fixed relay stations cannot flexibly adapt to these dynamic conditions. To address this issue, we propose a dynamic network construction method that employs unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) as wireless relay nodes. The key novelty of the proposed method lies in the autonomous flight path control of UAVs, which leverages their mobility to dynamically navigate toward locations with superior communication quality, defined here as received power above -68 dBm. In the proposed method, the UAV sequentially estimates the distribution of signal arrival directions during flight using the expectation–maximization (EM) algorithm, and is guided toward directions expected to provide higher received power. For performance evaluation, we conducted ray-tracing simulations that consider urban propagation characteristics. The results show that the proposed method improves the average received power by approximately 6.6 dB compared to simple straight-line flight, demonstrating the effectiveness of UAV mobility and flight path control for aerial network optimization.

title: Dual-modal WGAN-VAE for Fault Detection in Non-stationary Dynamical Processes
authors: Wenqiang Yang, Maoyin Chen
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Non-stationary characteristics of time series data pose challenges for fault detection, including difficulties in feature extraction and insufficient generalization capabilities. This paper presents a dual-modal wasserstein generative adversarial networks-variational autoencoder (WGAN-VAE) based on generative-reconstructive co-optimization. By decoupling stationary and non-stationary components, it aims to enhance fault detection accuracy. WGAN erforms cross-generation on data to separate stationary and non-stationary parts and strengthens the feature representation. WGAN’s adversarial training between generator and discriminator produces high-quality samples of both types, offering richer features. VAE is then adopted to reconstruct and extract features from the generated data. The dual-modal WGAN-VAE is optimized using KL divergence and reconstruction errors, capturing global data features and enhancing robustness through latent-space regularization. Simulation results show that the proposed method achieves high accuracy and robustness in fault detection, particularly in handling non-stationary data.

title: Rate-Adaptive Partial MIMO Equalization for Mode-Group Selective Transmission Over Few Mode Fibers
authors: Ruby S. B. Ospina, Amirhossein Ghazisaeidi, Stefano Gaiani, Ruben S. Luís, Daniele Orsuti, Besma Kalla, Menno Van Den Hout, Pierre Sillard, Frank Achten, Giammarco Di Sciullo, Georg Rademacher, Hideaki Furukawa, Cristian Antonelli, Chigo Okonkwo, Tom Bradley, Pierpaolo Boffi, Jeremie Renaudier
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a novel scheme to achieve fine-grain data rate versus complexity trade-off based on rate-adaptive partial MIMO equalization for SDM transmission systems and demonstrate the proof of concept in a polarization-multiplexed 15-mode transmission experiment. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: In-band Power Ripple Detection using Longitudinal Power Monitoring
authors: Junho Chang, Choloong Hahn, Qingyi Guo, Zhiping Jiang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate the application of longitudinal power estimation to monitor in-band power ripple using either sub-band-wise power estimation or reference-sweeping method. These approaches can effectively identify non-flat power profiles caused by optical amplifiers or abnormal filter response. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: An fault diagnosis method based on self-organizing map neural networks for the artillery automatic machine
authors: Zheyan Liu, Qirui Zhan, Tingyu Zhao, Zhuoyuan Wang, Zhiyu Deng, Xining Yang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To address the diagnostic challenges associated with rotating chamber bushings, curved sliding plates, and cam mechanisms in artillery automatic systems, this paper presents a fault diagnosis method leveraging Self-Organizing Map (SOM) neural networks. Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition (EEMD) is employed to decompose multisensor signals under both fault and normal conditions, followed by the use of Kullback-Leibler (K-L) divergence to extract informative Intrinsic Mode Functions (IMFs). Feature vectors constructed from four characteristic parameters (peak, waveform, margin, and kurtosis indices) serve as inputs to a SOM neural network for clustering-based classification. Simulation experiments conducted on six operating states using 54 datasets (36 for training, 18 for testing) demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. The SOM network achieves full cluster separation after 1,000 training iterations, and testing yields a fault identification accuracy of 94.44%, validating the method's robustness and diagnostic precision across multiple failure modes in artillery automatic mechanisms.

title: 39.5- Tb/s O-band Coherent Data Channels Coexistence with C-band DV-QKD and Bidirectional Service Channels
authors: Shohei Beppu, Daniel J. Elson, Shinya Murai, Han Wang, Akira Murakami, Kosuke Komatsu, Hiroki Yamamuro, Noboru Yoshikane, Yuta Wakayama, Takehiro Tsuritani
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We multiplex a C-band discrete-variable quantum key distribution (DV-QKD), C-band bidirectional service channels for synchronization and key generation, and 39.5-Tb/s Q-band coherent data channels, transmitting them over a 71-km single mode fiber.

title: Multi-level Data-driven Predictive Control for Industrial Manufacturing Processes
authors: Yuanye Dong, Wenlong Li, Ying Yang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Multi-objective predictive control problems in industrial manufacturing processes are characterized by no specific mechanism model, which poses challenges to traditional methods. To address these problems, a multi-level data-driven predictive control method is proposed based on Willems’ fundamental lemma. Firstly, a multi-level data-driven predictive control scheme is developed according to different priorities of objectives. Furthermore, a hierarchical solving method is introduced to solve the multi-level problem. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by a finishing rolling case.

title: Energy Efficiency Maximization with Dynamic Reflection Coefficient based Physical Layer Security: A Symbiotic Approach for Cellular Networks
authors: Muhammed Yusuf Onay
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Increasing security requirements and limited energy budgets in cellular networks are driving the need for methods that combine physical layer security with energy efficiency. This paper presents a system design and optimization framework that supports secure transmission and operates under practical constraints. The proposed model is based on a transmission structure divided into three time slots, where a base station interacts with two users, two energy-harvesting relays, two friendly jammers, and two eavesdroppers. The backscattering mechanism implemented by the users symbiotically reinforces both legitimate transmission and feeds the energy harvesting of the relays. The goal is to maximize energy efficiency without violating privacy requirements. To achieve this, time margins and reflection coefficients are jointly optimized, observing realistic constraints such as quality of service and power thresholds. Numerical results reveal consistent gains across different channel and noise levels, a low-to-moderate range for jammer power, adaptation of reflection and time margins according to thresholds, and a security-energy tradeoff that increases but approaches saturation. The findings provide feasible tuning recommendations for safe and energy efficient cellular system design.

title: Utilizing Degeneracy in a Few-Mode Fiber to Demonstrate Entanglement Distribution
authors: Tasbiha Rafiq, Tomi Getselev, Sarah Sommermeier, Nino Walenta, Nicolas Perlot, Andy Schreier, Carsten Schuck, Ronald Freund
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: The degenerate modes of a few-mode fiber retain entanglement and allow for distribution over 50-km of single-mode fibers, paving the way for future research towards multi-port bidirectional beam splitters with a consistent coupling ratio across the C-band and over time, potentially maintaining hyperentanglement.

title: Sub-optimum IQ Imbalance Compensation using TFI-OFDM for Cell-Free Environments
authors: Ryotaro Ishihara, Naoki Omi, Haruki Inoue, Aoba Morimoto, Riku Sato, Mone Kasahara, Jaesang Cha, Chang-Jun Ahn
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: In recent years, the growing use of mobile terminals, such as smartphones and IoT devices, has drastically increased communication demands. To accommodate, this ever-increasing demand, cell-free systems have emerged as a promising solution, significantly contributing to the two requirements of 6th generation (6G): " ultra-high-speed, ultra-large-capacity communications " and "reliable communications". The cell-free environment is attracting attention in 6G communication systems because it enables optimal antenna placement according to inter-cell interference and demand, which are problems in a cellular environment. However, in practical systems, communication performance can be degraded by In-phase/Quadrature (IQ) imbalance caused by imperfections in analog hardware. This paper presents an approach for alleviating IQ imbalance in cell-free networks by adaptively selecting a transmitter based on received signal strength. The phase shift caused by IQ imbalance is corrected by estimated adaptively using time frequency interferometry-orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (TFI-OFDM) to achieve more accurate channel compensation. Simulation results confirm that the method improves bit error rate (BER) performance.

title: Constraint-Aware Power Allocation for OFDM-ISAC: A Joint PSL–CRB Optimization Approach
authors: Muhammad Iqbal, Tabinda Ashraf, Hidayat Ali, Muhammad Jazib, Muhammad Zubair, Steven S. W. Lee, Jen-Yi Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: This paper presents a novel power allocation strategy, referred to as Joint Sensing-Constrained Optimization for Dynamic Allocation (JSCO-DA), designed for orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) systems operating in integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) environments. Unlike traditional water-filling methods that prioritize communication performance alone, JSCO-DA incorporates critical sensing constraints namely, Peak Sidelobe Level (PSL) and Cramer-Rao Bound (CRB) into the optimization framework. The algorithm dynamically fuses the classical water-filling approach with sensing-aware power profiles to ensure compliance with both communication and sensing objectives, while keeping the resulting capacity loss within an acceptable bound. Simulation results reveal that JSCO-DA consistently outperforms conventional dynamic allocation techniques by delivering enhanced capacity, energy efficiency, and spectral efficiency under joint PSL–CRB constraints. These results highlight the potential of JSCO-DA as a practical and efficient solution for emerging ISAC-enabled OFDM systems.

title: Design of Millimeter Wave Antenna for MMID Application on Bio-Sourced Substrate
authors: Thi Thu Huong Nguyen, Nhu Huan Nguyen, Romain Siragusa, Thanh Huong Nguyen, Pascal Xavier, Tan-Phu Vuong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This study presents the design of monopole and slot antennas in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \text{GHz}-30 \text{GHz}$</tex> band for MMID applications on paper substrates. This paper shows that it is possible to use these antennas on bio-sourced substrates. Efficiency is affected by paper losses to reach 66 %. Matching and bandwidth remain compatible with RFID applications. The monopole antenna achieves 40 % bandwidth with a maximum gain of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 9 8 ~ d B i}$</tex>.

title: Performance and Efficiency Trade-offs in Transformer Models for Kannada Sentiment Analysis
authors: Meghana D. K., Kiran K., Sahar Mariam Baig, P. Deepa Shenoy, Venugopal K. R.
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Sentiment analysis in resource-scarce languages like Kannada is difficult because of lack of labeled data and the complex linguistic characteristics of Dravidian languages. A machine translation tool is used to create the labeled dataset in Kannada from a high resource language English. The created dataset is analyzed by finetuning Transformer models like MuRIL, IndicBERT, mBERT, XLM-RoBERTa(XLM-R), and DistilBERT, for sentiment classification in Kannada. The sentiments are classified into three classes: positive, negative, and neutral. We analyze the performance of these models on native-script Kannada text, highlighting the advantages of language-specific pre-training in MuRIL and the efficiency of IndicBERT in resource-constrained settings. Our experiments reveal that MuRIL and XLM-R outperform other models in capturing the intricate syntactic and semantic features of Kannada. Additionally, we discuss the trade-offs between performance and computational efficiency, with DistilBERT and IndicBERT offering a viable option for real-time applications. The results demonstrate the critical role of tailored pre-training and fine-tuning strategies for low-resource sentiment analysis, paving way for improved natural language understanding in Kannada and other Dravidian languages.

title: Improved RT-DETR Model for Automated ROI Localization in Railway Locomotive Sanding Device Monitoring
authors: Jianjun Li, Jin Tan, Zhongbin Zhao, Yuting Hu, Yujia Fu, Ling Zhao
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: During the process of braking the locomotive to a halt for maintenance, the sanding device effectively enhances braking efficiency by improving the wheel-rail adhesion coefficient, ensuring maintenance efficiency while improving operational safety. Accurate detection of the locomotive sanding device is critical for monitoring its sanding state. Aiming at the challenges of model redundancy and insufficient feature extraction in existing detection methods under resource-constrained scenarios, this paper proposes an improved RT-DETR (Real-Time Detection Transformer)-based detection method for locomotive sanding devices. The method replaces the original ResNet-18 with MobileNetV4 as the backbone network, significantly reducing model parameters while maintaining performance. Additionally, a Local Feature Extraction (LFE) module is introduced to optimize the RepC3 (Reparameterized Convolution Block 3), enhancing the network’s representational capability for fine-grained features of the sanding device. Through comprehensive experimental validation, the optimized RT-DETR framework demonstrates a 1.9% enhancement in mean average precision (mAP), together with a 43.7% reduction in parameter quantity and a 32.3% decline in computational demand (GFLOPs). These improvements collectively establish a robust, industrial-level approach for intelligent operation and maintenance within rail transit applications.

title: Designing Cybersecurity Ecosystems: Lessons from the Kyiv Breach and the ECLIPSE Economic Model
authors: Sashidhar Siddamsetty, Bhushan Bhimrao Chavan, Vishalkumar Langaliya, Bishwajeet Pandey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Cybersecurity is not only a technical problem anymore; it’s also a problem of ecosystem, where technology, economics, and governance are challenged. In this paper, authors analyze the 2017 Kyiv streets surveillance system compromise in order to illustrate shortcomings of centralized infrastructure with small or per-verse incentives. Learning from such a high-profile failure means that we bring forth the ECLIPSE Economic Model, a Cryptoeconomic architecture that seeks to incentivize stakeholders, spread risks and make cybersecurity ecosystems more resilient. ECLIPSE uses decentralized technologies, token-based participation, and federated threat intelligence to solve the classic adoption paradox: solutions that are technically feasible are often the wrong economic or operational fit. By integrating case study with an economic design model, this paper provides a roadmap for constructing a cybersecurity architecture that is resilient and self- sustainable. The implications of the proposed approach are in smart cities, public infrastructure and anywhere any connected environment that require: security, transparent, incentive alignment. Our analysis shows that cyber-security needs to be no less grounded in trust, diversely aligned incentives and system-wide simultaneity than are security measures physically anchored in walls, doors and a good solid safe.

title: Reward-Scheduling for Enhanced Energy Management Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Taner Yaşa, Ozan Yazar, Serdar Coskun, Fengqi Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: In this study, a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)-based Energy Management Strategy (EMS) developed for hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) is presented. The Deep Q-Network (DQN) algorithm is chosen as the control structure and implemented on a power-split HEV architecture. The main objective of the study is to investigate the impact of the weighting coefficients of multiple objectives, such as fuel consumption, battery state of charge (SOC), and emission reduction, included in the reward function, on system performance. To this end, scenarios with different weight combinations are defined, and each configuration is evaluated under the HWFET driving cycle. The results reveal that the selection of appropriate weights is a determinant of energy efficiency and emission performance. The findings indicate that the design of balanced weighting coefficients is crucial for achieving an effective trade-off among fuel economy, SOC regulation, and emission reduction, confirming the potential of DRL-based EMS in addressing multi-objective optimization challenges.

title: Unlocking Dynamic Financial Insights with the RAGNN Framework by integrating graph structures and Tribal Evolution Optimization
authors: Uma Maheswari V, Shaik Shabbir Basha, Anitha Patil, Kuni Venkata Subbaiah, Mallellu Sai Prashanth, Dhruba Jyoti Bora
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) method improves the accuracy of financial market risk predictions by integrating generative AI models with the retrieval of pertinent financial data. Risk assessment and governance (RAG) systems create context-aware risk assessments and insights by combining real-time and historical data. This method makes it easier to understand and adjust to changing market circumstances. Things like scenario-based forecasting, sentiment analysis, and evaluating the risk of a portfolio benefit greatly from it. Financial market risk prediction is a dynamic field where using both structured and unstructured data sources is crucial. Here, to present the RAGNN framework, an innovative method that combines graph-based financial entity structural representations with semantic insights extracted from external unstructured financial documents and news in a complementary fashion. Graph Construction Layer encapsulates relational structures among financial entities; Retrieval-Augmented Embedding Layer enriches graph nodes with external contextual knowledge; Graph Neural Network with Fusion Mechanism harmonises graph and semantic embeddings; and Tribal Intelligent Evolution Optimisation (TIEO) Engine enhances model performance by optimising hyper parameters and fusion weights through evolutionary techniques. These four core components make up the model architecture. By surpassing state-of-the-art optimisation algorithms like Genetic Algorithm (GA), Ant Colony Optimisation (ACO), Firefly Algorithm (FA), Sinh Cosh Optimiser (SCHO), Reptile Search Algorithm (RSA), Red Fox Optimisation Algorithm (RFO), Grey Wolf Optimisation (GWO), Sperm Swarm Optimisation (SSO), and Particle Swarm Optimisation (PSO), TIEO-RAGNN achieves a superior performance in benchmark comparisons. The results show that the TIEO-RAGNN framework is good at predicting financial market risks, which is a strong tool for making smart decisions in ever-changing financial markets.

title: Design of Voice Based Security Protocol For IoT-Driven AI-Enabled Industry 5.0
authors: Siddhant Thapliyal, Mohammad Wazid, D P Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The advent of Industry 5.0 has resulted in a seamless merger of human creativity with machine intelligence, propelling new levels of automation and innovation. Within this paradigm, the Internet of Things (IoT) and machine learning (ML) are critical technologies that enable smart and adaptable industrial processes. However, increased connectivity and data interchange across IoT devices expose Industry 5.0 systems to a wide range of security vulnerabilities, including data breaches and adversarial assaults on ML models. This study presents a strong security framework designed for IoT-driven, machine learning-enabled settings in Industry 5.0. The protocol uses sophisticated encryption technologies, blockchain-based data integrity verification, and federated learning approaches to improve data privacy and system resilience. Furthermore, it uses anomaly detection methods to detect and mitigate real-time threats. A thorough study of the proposed protocol proves its capacity to provide data confidentiality, integrity, and availability while being computationally efficient. This study is an important step toward creating safe and trustworthy Industry 5.0 ecosystems.

title: Experimental Investigation of Availability in a 4.6 Km Terrestrial Urban Coherent Free-Space Optical Communications Link
authors: Vincent Van Vliet, Menno Van Den Hout, Kadir Gümüş, Eduward Tangdiongga, Chigo Okonkwo
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We measured the outage probability of a 4.6-km urban free-space optical communication link over six days. High-speed power measurements reveal slow and fast fading effects, with link availabilities of 92% including and 99% excluding slow fades for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$500 \text{Gb} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> transmission. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Joint Localization and Monitoring of Multipath Interference in DMT Systems Using LFM Pilot
authors: Zhijin Zhao, Chen Cheng, Siyu Chen, Xuchen Hua, Ming Tang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate a joint MPI localization, monitoring and frame synchronization scheme in DMT system utilizing a LFM pilot. A 3.5-m localization accuracy and 28-Gbaud transmission over 20-km SSMF are achieved without any power penalty. The system achieves a maximum transmission rate of 65 GBaud.

authors: Feifei Jin, Ningning Guo, Vittorio Curri, Gangxiang Shen
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a novel multi-band optical cross-connect (MB-OXC) architecture that employs inter-band wavelength conversion on a subset of ports. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed MB-OXC achieves a cost-effective trade-off, maintaining low blocking probability while significantly reducing overall node cost. ©2025 The Author(s)

authors: Shohei Beppu, Daniel J. Elson, Han Wang, Shinya Murai, Akira Murakami, Kosuke Komatsu, Noboru Yoshikane, Yuta Wakayama, Takehiro Tsuritani

abstract: We experimentally investigate spontaneous Raman scattering (SpRS) generated by Oband classical channels. The results reveal the impact of the SpRS on coexistence transmission of O-band classical channels and a C-band discrete-variable quantum key distribution (DV-QKD) channel. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Efficient Fault Diagnosis via Information Bottleneck and Split Centralized Feature Fusion
authors: Junnan He, Fangyu Li
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Fault diagnosis for complex rotating systems with multi-source data is crucial. Recent studies have highlighted correlations in multi-source data through centralized interaction to facilitate data fusion. However, the centralized strategy heavily relies on the quality of global representation. Motivated by the need for efficient high-quality global representation, we propose an information bottleneck-enhanced global representation with split centralized interaction (IGSC). First, we develop an information bottleneck-enhanced variational approximation to achieve a compressed and preserved global representation. Second, we split the multi-source data to individually interact with the global representation. Finally, we verify the proposed fault diagnosis method using the Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) bearing fault dataset. The experimental results of IGSC demonstrate improvements in terms of accuracy, efficiency, and generalizability.

title: High-Laser Linewidth-Tolerance Photonics-aided 300 GHz Terahertz Wireless Transmission System
authors: Xiongwei Yang, Jianjun Yu, Xianming Zhao, Mingxu Wang, Yi Wei, Chen Wang, Long Zhang, Jianyu Long, Wen Zhou, Kaihui Wang, Feng Zhao

abstract: We experimentally demonstrate a high linewidth tolerance photonics-aided THz-wave wireless transmission system based on a radio frequency (RF) pilot-aided scheme, achieving 30 GBaud single-carrier/OFDM PS-64QAM transmission with rate of 174 Gbit/s over the 300 GHz.

authors: Kohki Shibahara, Akira Kawai, Megumi Hoshi, Manabu Arikawa, Kohei Hosokawa, Takaya Maeda, Ryota Imada, Takayoshi Mori, Taiji Sakamoto, Yusuke Yamada, Kazuhide Nakajima, Soichi Endo, Takemi Hasegawa, Koichi Maeda, Shigehiro Takasaka, Ryo Nagase, Takayuki Kobayashi, Yutaka Miyamoto

abstract: We present FPGA-supported real-time 68-km transmission results over field-installed 12-cou-pled-core fibre cable. By using frequency-domain 24×1 MIMO equalisation with reduced complexity, stable transmission performance was obtained for 12 coupled SDM channels in dynamically varying-channel field environments. © 2025 The Author(s)

title: Breaking the Bandwidth-Efficiency Trade-Off of Soliton Micro-Combs via Strong Mode Coupling
authors: Yang Liu, Andreas Jacobsen, Thibault Wildi, Yanjing Zhao, Chaochao Ye, Yi Zheng, Camiel Op de Beeck, José Carreira, Michael Geiselmann, Kresten Yvind, Tobias Herr, Minhao Pu
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We present a coupled-mode pumping strategy that overcomes the long-standing trade-off between conversion efficiency and optical bandwidth in soliton microcombs. Using this approach, we experimentally demonstrate an octave-spanning single soliton microcomb that achieves nearly 50% pump-to-comb conversion efficiency. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Application of Machine Learning Algorithms for Early Prediction of Diabetes using Lifestyle and Physiological Data
authors: Meena Ravikumar, Sudikshya Shrestha, Mohammad Dabbagh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) is a major global health concern, emphasizing the need for early detection to improve patient outcomes. This paper conducts a comparative study of four supervised machine learning classifiers, Two-Class Boosted Decision Tree, Decision Forest, Logistic Regression, and Neural Network, leveraging the Pima Indian Diabetes dataset within Azure ML Studio, a low-code cloud-based platform. Model performance was rigorously assessed using accuracy, precision, recall, F1 score, and AUC-ROC. Among the models evaluated, the Boosted Decision Tree achieved the most balanced performance with an accuracy of 0.774, recall of 0.663, and F1 score of 0.671. In contrast, Logistic Regression and Neural Networks demonstrated higher precision but lower recall, underscoring important trade-offs for clinical application. This study highlights the practical potential of low-code machine learning platforms in accelerating healthcare analytics. However, limitations include the specific demographic of the Pima dataset, lack of model interpretability methods, and no assessment of fairness. Future research will focus on model generalizability, integration of explainable AI techniques, and fairness evaluation. Overall, the results support the potential of accessible and responsible AI solutions to advance preventive healthcare.

title: Resilience-Oriented Optimization Framework for Multi-UAVs Formation Reconfiguration
authors: Wenliang Zhang, Xingshuo Hai, Weike Chen, Xing Guo, Qiang Feng, Gantian Gong, Zeyu Wu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (multi-UAVs) systems operating in specific topological formation exhibit high mobility and flexibility, making them widely applicable in real-world scenarios. However, in complex and dynamic environments, such systems are inevitably susceptible to disruptions, necessitating formation reconfiguration to restore performance and ensure mission continuity. In this brief, we propose a resilience-oriented optimization framework for multi-UAVs formation reconfiguration, providing a comprehensive solution through the design of a resilience metric and a customized algorithm. Specifically, the novel resilience metric tailored for multi-UAV formation reconfiguration integrates key aspects of time efficiency, topological reconfiguration accuracy, and operational availability. Building on this, we enhance the sheep flock migration optimization (SFMO) by introducing an adaptive parameter updating mechanism, enabling the algorithm to computationally optimize the resilience metric and derive the optimal recovery solution. Simulation experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

title: Conversations with Andrea: Visitors’ Opinions on Android Robots in a Museum
authors: Marcel Heisler, Christian Becker-Asano
publish: 2025 34th IEEE International Conference on Robot and Human Interactive Communication (RO-MAN)
abstract: The android robot Andrea was set up at a public museum in Germany for six consecutive days to have conversations with visitors, fully autonomously. No specific context was given, so visitors could state their opinions regarding possible use-cases in structured interviews, without any bias. Additionally the 44 interviewees were asked for their general opinions of the robot, their reasons (not) to interact with it and necessary improvements for future use. The android’s voice and wig were changed between different days of operation to give varying cues regarding its gender. This did not have a significant impact on the positive overall perception of the robot. Most visitors want the robot to provide information about exhibits in the future, while opinions on other roles, like a receptionist, were both wanted and explicitly not wanted by different visitors. Speaking more languages (than only English) and faster response times were the improvements most desired. These findings from the interviews are in line with an analysis of the system logs, which revealed, that after chitchat and personal questions, most of the 4436 collected requests asked for information related to the museum and to converse in a different language. The valuable insights gained from these real-world interactions are now used to improve the system to become a useful real-world application.

authors: L. Romero, A. Aitkulov, M. Stegmaier, T. Geisler, M. Santagiustina, A. Galtarossa, L. Palmieri

Results, supported also by numerical simulations, show how spin can effectively reduce the differential group delay also in multi-core fibers, if properly designed. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: FPGA Design and Implementation of BCH Encoders and Decoders Using Pipelined Architecture for High Throughput Applications
authors: Thuan Van Le, Nam Van Dinh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper presents the design and FPGA implementation of a high-throughput BCH (n,k) encoder and decoder using a fully pipelined architecture. Unlike conventional designs based on finite state machines (FSM), the proposed pipeline structure significantly improves throughput performance by processing data continuously across multiple stages. The decoder utilizes the Berlekamp-Massey algorithm to efficiently determine the error locator polynomial and employs Chien’s Search method to accurately identify error positions. The entire system is implemented and verified on an Altera Cyclone V FPGA device (5CEFA2F23C8). Simulation results and on-hardware execution demonstrate that the pipelined approach achieves considerably higher throughput compared to traditional FSM-based designs while maintaining decoding accuracy. The experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed architecture for high-speed communication applications.

title: The Gendered Lens: Analyzing Indian Occupational Bias and Stereotypes in Text-to-Image Generative AI Models
authors: Abhishek Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This research investigates the presence of gender stereotypes in AI generated images of significant Indian occupations using three advanced Text to Image models namely DALLE-3, FLUX.1, and GEMINI 2.0 FLASH.By generating and analysing multiple images per occupation the study examines how these models represent gender across 15 occupations deeply rooted in Indian society, such as sabziwala, chaiwala, jeweller and rickshawala. The findings reveal a consistent under-representation of women in most occupations, with models pre-dominantly depicting male-presenting individuals in traditionally male or gender neutral roles, while female-presenting figures appear mainly in female dominated occupations. This pattern reflects and potentially amplifies existing biases permeating throughout the society, raising concerns about the reinforcement of occupational stereotypes through AI-generated media. The paper highlights the need for culturally aware AI development and ongoing bias auditing to foster fairer and more inclusive representations in generative AI system, especially within the Indian context.

title: A Fault Diagnosis Method for the TE Process Based on the Improved SPBO Algorithm to Optimize AE - BiGRU
authors: Wenhu Zhao, Kun Li, Yongbiao Ning
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of chemical engineering data, such as nonlinear distribution, diverse categories, large scale, and difficult-to-distinguish fault characteristics, this paper proposes an combination fault diagnosis model of the improved student psychology based optimization algorithm - autoencoder - bidirectional gated recurrent unit (ISPBO-AE-BiGRU) to improve the accuracy and reliability of the fault diagnosis of the Tennessee Eastman (TE) process. Firstly, the AE is used to extract the features of the TE process data, which effectively reduces the data dimension and retains the key feature information. The bidirectional gated recurrent unit has the ability to capture sequence data bidirectionally, and it can better handle the time series characteristics in the chemical process data, thus improving the accuracy of fault diagnosis. In order to further optimize the parameters of the AE-BiGRU model, the student psychology based optimization algorithm is introduced. The Tent mapping and Cauchy mutation strategies are used for improvement, and then the optimal solution is quickly searched in the search space to obtain the optimal parameter combination and improve the performance of the model. The experimental results show that compared with other single fault diagnosis methods and combined fault diagnosis methods, the proposed method has significant advantages in terms of fault recognition accuracy, precision, recall rate, and F1 value, and it can accurately and quickly diagnose a variety of fault types.

title: URDM: Hyperspectral Unmixing Regularized by Diffusion Models
authors: Min Zhao, Linruize Tang, Jie Chen, Bo Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Hyperspectral unmixing aims to decompose the mixed pixels into pure spectra and calculate their corresponding fractional abundances. It holds a critical position in hyperspectral image processing. Traditional model-based unmixing methods use convex optimization to iteratively solve the unmixing problem with hand-crafted regularizers. While their performance is limited by these manually designed constraints, which may not fully capture the structural information of the data. Recently, deep learning-based unmixing methods have shown remarkable capability for this task. However, they have limited generalizability and lack interpretability. In this paper, we propose a novel hyperspectral unmixing method regularized by a diffusion model (URDM) to overcome these shortcomings. Our method leverages the advantages of both conventional optimization algorithms and deep generative models. Specifically, we formulate the unmixing objective function from a variational perspective and integrate it into a diffusion sampling process to introduce generative priors from a denoising diffusion probabilistic model (DDPM). Since the original objective function is challenging to optimize, we introduce a splitting-based strategy to decouple it into simpler subproblems. Extensive experiment results conducted on both synthetic and real datasets demonstrate the efficiency and superior performance of our proposed method.

title: Tensor-Based Hybrid-Field Channel Estimation for Extremely Large-Scale Massive MIMO Systems
authors: Jingyue Cao, Chunbo Luo, Yang Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Channel estimation in extremely large-scale multiple-input multiple-output (XL-MIMO) systems presents substantial challenges, especially under low pilot overhead. This paper proposes a novel tensor-based hybrid-field (TBHF) channel estimation scheme for XL-MIMO. We first develop a unified hybrid-field tensor decomposition framework that models received signals as a third-order low-rank tensor, from which channel parameters, including angle of arrival/departure (AoA/AoD), distance, time delay, and path gain, are jointly estimated via factor matrices. To distinguish far-field and near-field components, we propose a path classification mechanism that does not require prior knowledge of path component proportions. For near-field estimation, we introduce an angle-adaptive distance grid design and a two-step estimation strategy, enhancing accuracy and reducing complexity. We analyze the uniqueness of the Canonical Polyadic Decomposition, demonstrating the potential of TBHF to substantially reduce training overhead. The Cramér-Rao Bound for hybrid-field parameter estimation is derived, and simulations verify that TBHF outperforms existing methods in normalized mean square error.

title: Triple-Way Visual Modulation for Zero-Shot Sketch-Based Image Retrieval
authors: Haoxiang Zhang, Qiqi Kou, He Jiang, Tianshu Song, Liangliang Chen, Deqiang Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Zero-Shot Sketch-Based Image Retrieval (ZS-SBIR) seeks to correlate unseen hand-drawn sketches with unseen real images by leveraging trained models on visible categories. Recent CLIP-based models, which primarily focus on visual-textual interaction, have demonstrated strong competitiveness in ZS-SBIR. However, they still fall short in the exploration of cross-modal visual representations, especially in terms of cross-modal visual shared and specific information. Differing from the aforementioned researches, we start with class-level, prompt-level, and patch-level visual information, committed to unlocking the potential of visual feature representation. On this foundation, we introduce the vision-centric Triple-way visual modulATion (TAT) framework to enhance the model’s perception of visual shared and specific information. Specifically, we establish unified multi-modal perception by integrating visual-level modality prompter into the CLIP architecture. We then conduct triple-way modulation modeling on prompt, token, and patch levels to effectively mine shared and specific features. Lastly, we develop an enhanced calibration strategy incorporating prompt-aware, token-aware, and logit-aware alignment modules to amplify the model’s proficiency in probing shared-specific features. We thoroughly test our approach to confirm its excellence and the efficacy of individual components. The comparison results on the popular datasets Sketchy, Sketchyv2, Tuberlin, and QuickDraw show that the developed algorithm significantly surpasses the current state-of-the-art technologies.

title: Machine Learning-Based Ultrasonic Sensing of Glycerol in Direct Fuel Cells
authors: Gabriel A. Ginja, Alvaro A. A. De Queiroz, João P. P. Do Carmo
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: This work presents a machine learning-enhanced ultrasonic sensing framework for real-time glycerol concentration monitoring in direct fuel cell environments. Glycerol is a promising biofuel due to its high hydrogen content, low toxicity, and waste-to-energy potential. Accurate concentration tracking is essential to optimize oxidation pathways, maximize faradaic efficiency, and extend catalyst longevity. A custom piezoelectric array operating at 5 kHz and 40 kHz, under excitation voltages of 3.3, 5, and 9 V, was used to measure acoustic attenuation in aqueous glycerol solutions. The attenuation response exhibited sigmoidal behavior with R² > 0.99 and sensitivity peaks aligned with electrochemically relevant ranges. Model robustness was assessed via non-parametric bootstrap resampling. To enable predictive generalization, synthetic data were generated using interpolation and noise injection, supporting the training of polynomial, support vector, and multilayer perceptron (MLP) regression models. The MLP achieved superior accuracy with the lowest RMSE and highest R² under 30×5 Monte Carlo cross-validation. Sensitivity analysis identified acoustic features at 5 kHz/5 V and 5 kHz/9 V as dominant predictors, consistent with viscous media propagation theory. The proposed approach offers a low-cost, non-invasive, and embedded solution for in situ glycerol sensing, supporting intelligent diagnostics and enhanced energy conversion efficiency in renewable fuel cell systems.

title: Spatio-Temporal Data Enhanced Vision-Language Model for Traffic Scene Understanding
authors: Jingtian Ma, Jingyuan Wang, Wayne Xin Zhao, Guoping Liu, Xiang Wen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Nowadays, navigation and ride-sharing apps have collected numerous images with spatio-temporal data. A core technology for analyzing such images, associated with spatio-temporal information, is Traffic Scene Understanding (TSU), which aims to provide a comprehensive description of the traffic scene. Unlike traditional spatio-temporal data analysis tasks, the dependence on both spatio-temporal and visual-textual data introduces distinct challenges to TSU task. However, recent research often treats TSU as a common image understanding task, ignoring the spatio-temporal information and overlooking the interrelations between different aspects of the traffic scene. To address these issues, we propose a novel Spatio-Temporal Enhanced Model based on CILP (ST-CLIP) for TSU. Our model uses the classic vision-language model, CLIP, as the backbone, and designs a Spatio-temporal Context Aware Multi-aspect Prompt (SCAMP) learning method to incorporate spatio-temporal information into TSU. The prompt learning method consists of two components: A dynamic spatio-temporal context representation module that extracts representation vectors of spatio-temporal data for each traffic scene image, and a bi-level ST-aware multi-aspect prompt learning module that integrates the ST-context representation vectors into word embeddings of prompts for the CLIP model. The second module also extracts low-level visual features and image-wise high-level semantic features to exploit interactive relations among different aspects of traffic scenes. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to integrate spatio-temporal information into vision-language models to facilitate TSU task. Experiments on two real-world datasets demonstrate superior performance in the complex scene understanding scenarios with a few-shot learning strategy.

title: SAR-D-FINE: A Context-Aware Detector for Small and Densely Packed Ship Detection in SAR Imagery
authors: Xiaobing Fan, Bowen Xing, Xingchen Wang, Hongdan Liu, Chuanxu Yan, Pengfei Zhi
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) provides all-weather imaging, yet small-scale, densely clustered ships remain difficult to detect because coherent speckle noise and coastal clutter often mask target echoes. Current detectors, derived mainly from optical imaging methods, fail to extract weak signatures from minute vessels and to separate closely spaced targets from background clutter, leading to frequent missed detections and elevated false-alarm rates. This paper presents SAR-D-FINE, a context-aware detection framework tailored for SAR imagery. Extending the D-FINE architecture, we design a hybrid backbone with a StarStage module that strengthens nonlinear feature extraction under heavy noise. A Focusing Diffusion Encoder, integrating a Multi-Kernel Aggregation Module (MKAM) and a parameter-free Shuffle-and-Shift Upsampling (SSU) unit, is adopted to aggregate multi-scale features without sacrificing fine spatial details. Experimental results on SSDD and HRSID indicate that SAR-D-FINE surpasses existing methods, including dedicated SAR detectors such as YOLO-SARSI and SW-Net, achieving AP improvements of 2.0% and 1.8% over the baseline, respectively. The results confirm the advantages of the proposed model, particularly for detecting small, densely distributed vessels.

title: Radial-Electromagnetic-Force and Vibration Analysis of Hybrid-Excitation Doubly-Salient Machine
authors: Wanying Jia, Yumeng Hua, Xiaomei Liu, Hongbo Qiu, Wenbo Chen, Dongxue Fu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion
abstract: Hybrid excitation doubly salient machine (HEDSM) has been considered to have good application prospects in electric vehicles and aerospace due to its advantage of high power density. However, HEDSM suffers from serious vibration because of the doubly salient poles structure. Therefore, a detailed analysis of the electromagnetic force and vibration characteristics of HEDSM is presented. Firstly, the spatial distribution and frequency characteristics of the radial electromagnetic force acting on the stator tooth surface are derived analytically and validated using two-dimensional fast Fourier transform (FFT-2D). Furthermore, a comparison is made between the natural frequency and modal shape of the single stator core and the composite stator core which contains windings and permanent magnets (PMs). A multiphysics model is established to calculate the vibration of the HEDSM. Through the mode superposition method, the vibration acceleration on the motor surface under the rated operating conditions is computed. Finally, an 18/11 pole HEDSM prototype is fabricated. Experimental measurements of the natural frequency of the assembled stator core and the vibration acceleration are conducted, demonstrating good agreement with the theoretical analysis and simulation results.

title: A Comprehensive Protection Scheme for Solid- State Transformers in Power Substations
authors: Anand Mandal, Kashem M. Muttaqi, Md. Rabiul Islam, Danny Sutanto
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: This paper proposes a novel protection setup for the solid-state transformer (SST) for its reliable and healthy operation in power grids. The protection configuration for the conventional power transformer in IEEE Std C37.91-2021 and the countryspecific grid codes are no longer relevant to the SST because of its diverse topologies and functionalities. Furthermore, most of the protection configuration for the SST is designed considering its standalone operation. In this context, this paper proposes a protection system for the SST for its operation in a substation within a power grid, rather than focusing solely on its protection for the standalone operation. The potential faults and their recommended protection functions have been proposed compared with the existing protection setup utilized for the conventional power transformer (CPT). Additionally, the paper details the differential currents required to activate the differential protection for internal faults for different operating modes of the SST. The proposed protection scheme incorporates several protection features aimed at holistic protection of the SST, and its effectiveness has been validated at the system level by employing an IEEE-13 node test feeder.

title: High Performance Autonomous Target Tracking and Control Method for Quadrotors Using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Trong-Thanh Han, Anh Le Duy, Tai Nguyen Van, Hung Dinh Tan, Anh Do Trung
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have garnered significant practical applications in recent years. The use of UAVs, particularly quadrotors equipped with onboard cameras for tasks such as aerial filming, reconnaissance, and search and rescue (SAR) has received growing attention due to their flexibility and superior maneuverability compared to other UAV platforms. With the advancement of AI-powered object tracking algorithms, real-time visual data constitutes a highly promising contribution to quadrotor control systems. Motivated by these trends, this study proposes a lightweight tracking algorithm that is specifically designed for efficient deployment on embedded hardware platforms. The proposed algorithm not only offers a low computational footprint but also improves performance and accuracy in real-time object tracking tasks. In addition, a quadrotor control system capable of following a target in GNSS-denied environments is developed. To validate the effectiveness and deployability of the proposed system, a Software in the Loop (SITL) simulation is conducted, and a Hardware in the Loop (HITL) simulation framework is developed for the Raspberry Pi 5 platform using the PyBullet simulation environment.

title: Reinforcement Learning in Production Control: An Agent-Based Approach to Sequencing
authors: J. Schneider, T. Hamfeld, P. Nyhuis, M. Schmidt
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Increases in market turbulence, a broad spectrum of customer requirements, and the dynamics of highly saturated markets pose significant challenges to production systems and their production planning and control (PPC). Alongside the necessity to accommodate an expanded range of products, these systems are required to facilitate elevated throughputs and offer a substantial degree of adaptability against process fluctuations and unanticipated occurrences. To address these challenges, reinforcement learning (RL) has emerged as a promising approach for optimizing PPC. In contradistinction to alternative machine learning methodologies, RL engages in direct interaction with its environment, thereby facilitating real-time responses to system alterations and direct interventions in the PPC. The primary focus of this work is the implementation of an RL agent with a specific emphasis on production control and a comprehensive examination of the sequencing process at individual workstations. For the purpose of this study, an RL agent was employed, which uses Q-learning as a widely used RL algorithm, to automate the task of sequencing as a central PPC task. From a production logistics perspective, the agent integrates the schedule-oriented and setup time-oriented perspectives in its decision-making processes. The implementation of the RL agent is embedded within the process chain of the IFA Learning Factory. The findings indicate that the RL agent can reliably automate the task of sequencing following a learning process that is clearly discernible. Concurrently, the RL agent is capable of establishing a balanced prioritization between a solely setup-time-oriented and a solely schedule-oriented perspective, while concurrently pursuing both perspectives.

authors: Raditiana Patmasari, Andriyan Bayu Suksmono, Donny Danudirdjo, Koredianto Usman
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Signals and Systems (ICSigSys)
abstract: Compressive Sensing (CS) has emerged as a new paradigm in signal processing for efficient sampling and reconstruction of signals. In magnetostatic applications, reconstructing vector magnetic fields from limited measurements is important for modeling various engineering phenomena yet remains challenging under undersampling conditions. This study presents modeling and simulation of CS applied to a static magnetic field scenario involving the presence of ferromagnetic object. By sparsely and randomly sampling the magnetic field data in both the x and y directional components, the complete magnetic field distribution across the entire area can be succesfully reconstructed. Visual inspection and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) analysis generally show that the Total Variation (TV) method outperforms Orthogonal Matching Pursuit (OMP), producing smoother magnetic field images in homogeneous regions, while TV tends to be less accurate in areas with sharp field variations. Conversely, based on 20 trials for each tested sampling ratio, the standard deviation analysis indicates that OMP tends to produce more consistent results than TV, especially when the sampling rate exceeds 40%. This work presents a comparative study of OMP and TV in reconstructing vector magnetostatic fields from undersampled data – a scenario less explored in existing compressive sensing literature – indicating that OMP and TV each have strengths in certain aspects of vector magnetostatic field reconstruction under CS frameworks.

title: Federated Cycle-Consistent Latent Attention Method for Missing Feature Generation
authors: Jiechen Sun, Funa Zhou, Hanwen Chang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The health condition of bearings directly affects equipment reliability. Monitoring data often exhibit fragmented characteristics due to sensor failures and data communication packet loss. This paper proposes a federated cycle-consistent latent attention method for missing feature generation (Fed-CCLA), which reconstructs missing features by sharing degradation information across clients within a federated learning framework. The missing feature generation is optimized by matching features with similar degradation levels between clients using cycle-consistent feature alignment. At the same time, a latent attention mechanism dynamically assigns larger weights to the most relevant features and ensures consistency of the complementary features in terms of degradation trend, stage evolution, and feature distribution, thereby improving the accuracy of missing feature generation from fragmented data. Experimental results demonstrate that Fed-CCLA effectively reconstructs missing degradation features under various scenarios involving fragmented data.

title: LFM Carrier Enabled Integrated Sensing and Communication in Self-homodyne Coherent Detection Transmission System
authors: Shuyan Chen, Bowen Yin, Huan He, Yang Shi, Mingming Zhang, Zhiyong Zhao, Ming Tang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate integrated communication (25-Gbaud DP-16QAM, <1 dB penalty) and distributed sensing (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2-\text{cm}$</tex> spatial resolution) over 10-km MCF using linear-frequency-modulated carriers and self-homodyne coherent detection. Simultaneous optical multipath interference, transmission loss, and vibration monitoring are achieved without spectral overhead. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Lite-RVFL: A Lightweight Random Vector Functional-Link Neural Network for Learning Under Concept Drift
authors: Songqiao Hu, Zeyi Liu, Xiao He
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The change in data distribution over time, also known as concept drift, poses a significant challenge to the reliability of online learning methods. Existing methods typically require model retraining or drift detection, both of which demand high computational costs and are often unsuitable for real-time applications. To address these limitations, a lightweight, fast and efficient random vector functional-link network termed Lite-RVFL is proposed, capable of adapting to concept drift without drift detection and retraining. Lite-RVFL introduces a novel objective function that assigns weights exponentially increasing to new samples, thereby emphasizing recent data and enabling timely adaptation. Theoretical analysis confirms the feasibility of this objective function for drift adaptation, and an efficient incremental update rule is derived. Experimental results on a real-world safety assessment task validate the efficiency, effectiveness in adapting to drift, and potential to capture temporal patterns of Lite-RVFL. The source code is available at https://github.com/songqiaohu/Lite-RVFL.

title: Quality of Wine Prediction Using Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Rajanish Kumar Kaushal, Sandhya Soman, Aditya Sharma, Satyanand Vishwakarma, Rakesh Dani, Isarar Ahamad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The quality of Wine evaluation is a very subjective and intricate process that is mainly carried out by human specialists. Machine learning (ML) has become a very important tool which is used for different objectives and also to find out the accurate wine quality prediction, as a result of the growing availability of chemical and physical data pertaining to wine characteristics. The main use of the different supervised machine learning algorithms in this research paper is to predict the wine quality based on the physical and the chemical properties. Red and white wine samples with characteristics like pH, alcohol content, acidity, and Sulphur dioxide levels were used in the datasets. Based on the different characteristics of wine and the different performance parameter metrics like accurateness, exactness, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC were used for training and testing different machine learning (ML) models like Decision Trees (DT), Random Forests (RF), Support Vector Machines (SVM), k-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Gradient Boosting. During the machine learning models' training and assessment, cross-validation techniques were used to guarantee model generalization and avoid overfitting. As per the feature importance examination, volatile acidity and alcohol content were two of the most important variables influencing wine quality. This research shows the outputs obtained from the ML models can improve quality control procedures in the wine business and provide a data-driven method to assist with wine production and classification plans.

title: TrVLM: A Turkish Vision-Language Model for Captioning and Visual Question Answering
authors: Berkan Bucak, Emre Ceniklioğlu, Cihan Deniz Ekiz, Melike Akdağ, Gazi Erkan Bostancı, Ali Berkol
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: We address the scarcity of Turkish multimodal resources by introducing TrVLM, a Turkish vision–language model for image captioning and visual question answering. The model couples a frozen SigLIP image encoder with a learnable projection into a Turkish LLaMA decoder, and is trained with a two-stage recipe: feature-alignment pretraining on Turkish caption pairs followed by multitask fine-tuning, augmented with a targeted LoRA adaptation for short captions. On Turkish benchmarks, TrVLM delivers strong results. For example, it achieves BERTScore-F1 0.67 for short captioning and 0.65 for VQA, alongside consistent gains across ROUGE, BLEU, and METEOR. A GPT-4o judge study further supports instruction following and semantic fidelity. Our contributions are: a compact SigLIP and Turkish-LLaMA architecture tailored for low-resource Turkish multimodal AI, curated task-balanced Turkish datasets (short/long captioning and VQA), and an efficient training and inference strategy (LoRA with prompt-conditioned checkpointing) that balances specialization and generalization.

authors: R. S. Luis, G. Di Sciullo, M. v. d. Hout, R. Emmerich, N. Braig-Christophersen, Q. Wu, B. J. Puttnam, D. A. Shaji, F. Graziosi, A. Mecozzi, A. Marotta, C. Schubert, T. Hayashi, T. Nagashima, C. Okonkwo, G. Rademacher, C. Lasagni, P. Serena, A. Nespola, C. Antonelli, H. Furukawa

abstract: We report the highest throughput on any field-deployed fiber of 927.7 Tb/s (GMI-based) using a record wide 19.2 THz signal on a randomly-coupled 4-core-fiber, supported by the first reported Raman amplification in this class of fibers. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Assessment of Software Security Measures
authors: Andrii Tkachov, Andrii Hapon, Illia Bukatych, Mykhailo Zhyhalov, Yehor Kudriavtsev, Stanislav Milevskyi
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The rapid advancement and integration of information technologies, while offering significant societal benefits, have also led to the expansion and evolution of cyber threats across all areas of life. Ukraine has the potential to strengthen its cyber security capabilities to effectively address these modern challenges. The militarization of cyberspace and the increasing sophistication of cyberweapons now enable adversaries to carry out covert cyberattacks, take remote control of critical systems, and damage or destroy vital information infrastructure. Additionally, there has been a notable rise in the technological expertise of those committing cybercrimes, using methods like social engineering, artificial intelligence, and cryptography to infringe on the interests of the state, society, and individual citizens. This has escalated the risk of citizens' rights being violated in cyberspace. Moreover, Ukraine's priority focus on digital transformation, while vital to its development, presents new challenges in cyber security. The introduction of emerging technologies, digital services, and systems for citizen-state interaction, including the electoral process, has created a web of hidden technological and procedural interdependencies. Without a comprehensive approach to cyber security and risk management, there is a risk of undermining public trust in the nation's digital transformation efforts.
