title: High-Speed Coherent Receiver Array on Silicon Photonics for Turbulence-Resilient Communication Links
authors: Alireza Fardoost, Fatemeh Ghaedi Vanani, Steven Silverio, Aneesh Sobhanan, Dhruvkumar Desai, Shuo Pang, Inwoong Kim, Olga Vassilieva, Paparao Palacharla, Guifang Li
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We implemented an array of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> coherent receivers on a CMOS-compatible SiPh chip which can spatially sample distorted wavefronts. The spatially sampled coherent fields are combined using maximum ratio combining to compensate for turbulence-induced wavefront distortion, achieving nearly theoretically-limited combining efficiency.

title: Enhancement in Link metric of RPL Protocol for improving energy in IoT Networks
authors: Shikha Yadav, Shreya Pandey, Suneeta Mishra, Vidushi Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) offers seamless communication among connected devices. Routing Protocol for Low power Lossy Networks is popular standard yet in some cases it also experiences high energy consumption, inefficient link metric selection and congestion which leads to shorter lifespan of the network. The current works focus on static objective functions and static link metrics which do not adjust according to the changing network conditions. We aim to solve these issues by a regression based model for optimal MAX_LINK_METRIC selection for RPL which maximises the energy efficiency and routing effectiveness. We created an equation that automatically adjusts the MAX_LINK_METRIC based on the number of nodes present in the network. The recommended method is developed after running multiple simulations in the Cooja simulator and evaluating important performance metrics like power consumption, Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR), Expected Transmission Count (ETX) and hop count. Our study shows that the proposed model reduces energy consumption making the network more stable and reliable. Compared to traditional RPL implementations our approach is more scalable and ensures better efficiency and a longer network lifespan.

title: Classification of Cleft Lip Among Children using Convolutional Neural Network Architectures
authors: Nor Salwa Damanhuri, Nur Zulaika Izzati Abdul Rahman, Belinda Chong Chiew Meng, Nor Azlan Othman, Nur Najiha Kamarulzaman, Paulina Yap
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Cleft lip abnormalities can cause a serious oral health issue if it is not treated properly in a timely manner. Having a child with a cleft lip can be financially straining, as the child will require extra care since the cleft will not only affect their feeding and speech development but also face aesthetics and overall psychological health. However, general hospitals especially in rural areas lack dependable medical resources, which makes the diagnosis of the cleft subjective and inconsistent between medical professionals. This study aims to develop a convolutional neural network (CNN) model that is able to classify types of cleft lip among children. A total of 1976 cleft lip images, collected from various internet websites was utilized in this study. Transfer learning was used to assess the CNN’s models, namely AlexNet, GoogLeNet, and ResNet-50. Classifiers like Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Random Forest (RF) was embedded in the CNN to optimize the results. With an accuracy of 94.06%, ResNet-50 with SVM classifier performed the best in classifying the type of cleft lip among children. Based on this result, it shows that the CNN with classifier is able to accurately classify cleft lips classes. Furthermore, a Graphical User Interface (GUI) was developed based one CNN-classifier model which help clinicians classifying type of cleft lip in real time mode. Hence, this study demonstrates how deep learning potentially be used to improve medical diagnosis, even in environments with limited resources.

title: Fault Tolerant Control of Aircraft System via the Sliding Mode-Learning Observer
authors: Haolin Yang, Xiaoxiao Guo, Rongni Yang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This article addresses the challenge of fault reconstruction and fault-tolerant control in aircraft system, leveraging a sliding mode-learning observer (SMLO). In particular, an SMLO is designed, which not only overcomes the problems of chattering, but also improves estimation accuracy and dynamic response speed. Firstly, employing small-perturbation theory, a mathematical model for the aircraft system is constructed and linearized. Subsequently, an SMLO performs concurrent estimation of unmeasurable system states and faults, and dynamic gain adjustment is performed using historical data. Then, a state feedback fault-tolerant (SFFT) controller is synthesized using these estimations to ensure system safety and tracking accuracy, with its asymptotic stability rigorously demonstrated via Lyapunov theory. Finally, an example of the Lockheed F-104 fighter aircraft model is provided to verify that the control strategy can accurately estimate faults.

title: Hardware Design for Abnormal Beat Detection in ECG Signal Base on Template Cluster Algorithm
authors: Thi Le Hang Bui, Phat Nguyen Thanh, Quoc Thinh Tran, Thi Diem Tran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Unsupervised clustering plays a vital role in electrocardiogram (ECG) analysis by enabling the automatic grouping of heartbeats based on morphological similarity, without the need for large, annotated datasets. This is particularly important for long-term ECG monitoring, where manual labeling is infeasible and adaptability to signal variation is essential. However, implementing such algorithms on wearable or ambulatory devices remains challenging due to strict constraints on power, latency, and hardware resources. To address these limitations, we propose a real-time, resource-efficient clustering engine based on a dynamic template-matching algorithm. The method integrates Pearson waveform similarity with RR-interval timing to adaptively update templates and detect outlier beats as potential arrhythmias. The algorithm is mapped to a parallel FPGA architecture, featuring pipelined processing elements, a template-management unit, and high-bandwidth on-chip memory to meet real-time performance demands. We implement the design on an Xilinx Kria KV260 FPGA platform operating at 166MHz. The system classifies every beat in the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Database in real time, achieving 95.52% overall accuracy and per-class sensitivities of 100% for normal beats, 99.64% for ventricular premature beats, and 99.91% for atrial premature beats. The resulting IP core offers a compact and reusable hardware solution suitable for energy-efficient, patient-adaptive ECG monitoring in next-generation wearable healthcare systems.

title: Constructing a Novel Dataset for Android Bug Prediction
authors: Amany Saies, Samer Zein
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Mobile apps running on smartphones have remained in the researchers’ spotlight since their inception in 2007. Google Android has only progressed over the years and Google has kept it up to date by releasing new and powerful components. With millions of apps available on online platforms such as Google Play, the quality of these apps has always been a concern for users and developers. Therefore, mobile app developers aim to produce high-quality and bug-free apps. The detection and removal of software bugs pose one of the most significant challenges for developers, consuming considerable time and effort during the traditional testing process. Researchers have explored different techniques to help developers discover software bugs in the early stages of the project. One of the most successful and popular techniques is the machine learning (ML) approach, where the dataset plays a crucial role in any bug prediction model. The researchers have explored different ways to build bug datasets that can serve as input for these ML models.In this research, we constructed a public Android bug dataset by utilizing various open-source Android apps from GitHub platform, using commit numbers to identify buggy classes. In contrast to the previous datasets, which utilize different app types such as web apps, desktop apps, and Android apps, our dataset is created by utilizing Android apps exclusively. Focusing solely on Android apps makes the dataset more homogeneous and efficient. The produced dataset consists of 38 source code class metrics and contains 7,530 instances, with 6,844 negative instances and 690 positive instances. We evaluated our dataset using five ML algorithms. The results show that the Random Forest algorithm outperformed the others. Further, our results show that the constructed dataset achieved promising results, with an F-measure value above 0.71.

title: Hybrid Optical / RF Feeder for 6G Radio Access with Shared FSO / FR3 Aperture and $\Sigma\Delta$-Modulation Switching
authors: Bernhard Schrenk, Florian Honz, Michael Hentschel, Fotini Karinou
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We present a simplified air interface for facilitating a wireless RF/FSO relay in an optically fed amplify & forward radio access architecture. We accomplish EVMs of 5.9% and 9.4% for an optical fronthaul budget of 19 dB when switching between FSO and FR3-band modes.

title: Analysis and Visualization of EV Energy Consumption Under Varying Conditions and Driving Profiles
authors: Burhan Doğuhan Leventerler, Mehmet Sezgin
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: A MATLAB-based simulation tool with graphical user interface (GUI) capability has been created for this study in order to examine the energy consumption features of electric vehicles (EVs). Different vehicle types, driving profiles (constant and variable speed modes), and climatic circumstances may all be defined by the user in the developed system. Performance metrics like battery status (SOC), range, battery power, and current can be monitored in a variety of scenarios. A nonlinear energy consumption model serves as the foundation for the simulation, which accounts for physical forces including road slope, rolling resistance, and aerodynamic drag. Furthermore, in negative power conditions, the system considers battery charge and mimics the regenerative braking process. Each vehicle's time series data is shown graphically so that energy efficiency comparisons can be conducted. In order to anticipate and assess the energy consumption of electric vehicles under various road and environmental circumstances, the created platform provides a versatile and easy-to-use simulation environment that can be utilized for both educational and research purposes.

title: Adaptive Remaining Useful Life Prediction Method for Devices With Random Failure Threshold
authors: Qing Dong, Changhua Hu, Dangbo Du, Jialing Zhang, Hong Pei, Zeming Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: For nonlinear stochastic degraded devices in practical engineering, existing methods have overlooked the variability of adaptive drift as well as the impact of random failure threshold on remaining useful life (RUL) prediction. In this study, we propose an adaptive RUL prediction method for nonlinear degraded devices with random failure threshold by utilizing the adaptive Wiener process. Firstly, the nonlinear degradation model incorporating adaptive drift is developed based on diffusion motion. The RUL life distribution, defined by the first hitting time, is derived while accounting for the impact of random failure threshold. Subsequently, the model parameters and the random failure threshold distribution are estimated offline based on historical monitoring data. Meanwhile, we employ the Kalman filter technology to dynamically update these estimation model parameters. Finally, the proposed method’s effectiveness is verified through a case study involving gyroscopes.

title: Prediction of Rolling Bearings' Remaining Useful Life Based on Efficient Channel Attention TCN and Bidirectional GRU
authors: Saihan Ma, Xiuqing Wang, Yuqing Li, Honghao Wang, Xudong Liu, Wenxia Du
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Rolling bearings are key parts of mechanical device, and performance degradation and failures may cause system downtime or damage. Therefore, predicting the remaining useful life (RUL) of rolling bearings accurately is crucial for effective equipment maintenance. To address the problems of laborious feature extraction processes, insufficient feature extraction, and low prediction accuracy of traditional methods, we propose the model named ETCN-BiGRU for predicting rolling bearings' RUL, which combines the temporal convolution and bidirectional gated recurrent unit, and employs the efficient channel attention. We utilize dilated convolution to extract both local and global features for the ETCN-BiGRU model simultaneously. Additionally, the proposed model incorporates the BiGRU to capture the temporal relationships between the rolling bearings' sensor data, which is collected in both forward and backward time steps. Moreover, the ECA is employed in the TCN-BiGRU network to enhance the channel dimension's feature representation capacity. Experimental results of the PHM 2012 bearing datasets show the proposed model can accurately predict rolling bearings' RUL. The ETCN-BiGRU model has higher prediction accuracy and better stability than the comparison models.

authors: D. A. Shaji, B. J. Puttnam, R. S. Luís, D. Orsuti, N. Fontaine, M. Mazur, L. Dallachiesa, G. Di Sciullo, L. A. Zischler, R. Ryf, D. Neilson, L. Palmieri, A. Mecozzi, C. Antonelli, H. Furukawa

Our results show distance-dependent data-rate improvements of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5 \%, 5.3 \%$</tex>, and 40.0 % at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 ~\text{km}, 100 ~\text{km}$</tex>, and 150 km, respectively. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Air Quality Forecast With Deep Learning Models Processing
authors: Marko Bochvarov, Teodor Kalushkov, Georgi Shipkovenski
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study conducts a comparative analysis of Simple Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) models for predicting hourly PM10 concentrations, a critical air quality metric. Utilizing a dataset combining historical PM10 measurements with weather variables (temperature, humidity, wind speed, and wind direction), the data is preprocessed by rounding features to two decimal places and encoding temporal patterns (e.g., hour, day of week) with sine/cosine transformations. The models аre trained on 24-hour sequences, achieving a validation mean absolute error (MAE) of 9 µg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, demonstrating the efficacy of integrating weather data. Predictions for the year 2020, however, revealed challenges, with the MAE rising to 13 µg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and a maximum error exceeding 200 µg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. The LSTM model consistently performs slightly worse than the simple RNN, particularly in handling temporal dependencies, though both models benefited from weather integration. This analysis highlights the potential of deep learning for air quality forecasting while underscoring the need for robust outlier management and data validation. Future work will focus on refining model architectures increasing the amount of weather variables and addressing real-world prediction limitations to achieve an MAE below 9 µg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and reduce maximum errors.

title: Prescribed Performance Fault-Tolerant Tracking Control of Firefighting Tethered Quadrotor UAV
authors: Chengxian Duan, Tian Le, Taiyu Qian, Jiantao Shi, Moshu Qian, Jiang Bin
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In this paper, the prescribed performance fault-tolerant tracking control problem is investigated for a firefighting tethered quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicle (FTQUAV) with the input saturation and actuator failure. First, the dynamics of a FTQUAV with the saturation, failure, disturbance and uncertainty is built. Second, the double loop control structure is introduced. Third, a novel sliding mode tracking controller is designed to eliminate the adverse effect of the actuator fault and multi-source disturbances, which is combined with the fixed time prescribed performance constraint function developed to improve the tracking control performance. Finally, simulation results of a FTQUAV is given to verify the effectiveness of this scheme.

title: Ultrasmall Mode Exchangers Based on Mosaic Structure Designed by Gradient Direct Binary Search Method
authors: T. Fujisawa, Y. Tsuji, T. Mitarai, Y. Sawada, T. Okimoto, T. Hiratani, K. Komatsu, H. Yagi, N. Fujiwara

title: Rapid Disease Diagnosis using a Lightweight Deep Neural Network in Low-Resource Healthcare Environments
authors: Narenthirakumar Appavu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This study targets the necessity for efficient health care in This paper introduces a lightweight deep neural network that can quickly analyse medical pictures, addressing the problem of providing efficient healthcare in situations with limited resources. The suggested model combines a simplified classification head that guarantees excellent diagnostic accuracy while drastically lowering memory consumption and processing demands, with a small yet potent convolutional backbone for reliable feature extraction. The architecture's exceptional efficiency is confirmed by extensive testing on a variety of medical imaging datasets, which makes it ideal for deployment on mobile mobile embedded devices in underserved or distant locations. Along with its technological benefits, the model prioritizes safety, usability, and rapid diagnostic support, which helps healthcare practitioners reach more patients in areas with limited medical infrastructure and allows for faster illness identification. In the end, this approach helps close the gap in healthcare accessibility, encourages early intervention, and enhances patient outcomes in environments with limited resources.

title: Contois Model Related to Constructed Wetland System
authors: Irwan Iqbal Ihsanuddin, Amir Syafiq Syamin Syah Amir Hamzah, Zatul Alwani Shaffiei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Constructed wetlands are widely recognized as sustainable, cost-effective solutions for wastewater treatment, offering efficient pollutant removal through natural processes. This study develops a biokinetic model describing microbial growth, pollutant concentration (COD) and dissolved oxygen (DO) in a planted constructed wetland. Monod and Contois kinetics are applied, producing two models with different microbial growth formulations. These models are tested against an experimental data set, and their fit and dynamics are compared. The Contois-based model provides a slightly better fit with the experimental data. The results are expected to be useful for the computational applications in other fields involving decomposition processes in wastewater.

title: Digital Subcarrier-Based Synthesis for On-Site Transceiver Calibration with Separate Tx/Rx Frequency Responses
authors: Masaki Sato, Hidemi Noguchi, Junichiro Matsui, Jun'ichi Abe, Kohei Hosokawa
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We proposed transceiver calibration using digital subcarrier-based synthesising to separate Tx/Rx frequency-dependent IQ common distortion. A flat signal spectrum and up to 0.1-dB Q-penalty within a ±3-GHz frequency offset range were demonstrated with 128-Gbaud PM-64QAM transmission over 120-km SMF, performing comparably to calibrating at back-to-back.

title: Financial Analytics for Green Supply Chain Optimization: A Machine Learning Approach to Investment Decision Making
authors: Yuanxi Mao
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Based on machine learning algorithms, this study constructs a green supply chain financial investment decision-making model, aiming to provide efficient and intelligent decision support for the comprehensive evaluation of supply chain data decision-making and management. Through the further enhancement and improvement of the algorithm model, this study uses machine learning algorithms to carry out real-time prediction, evaluation and optimization of green financial investment. The experimental results show that after using the model, the accuracy of enterprise investment monitoring is significantly improved, which can effectively integrate the decision-making accuracy of managers, greatly improve the efficiency of financial investment management of enterprises, and provide accurate data support for green supply chain financial investment decision-making. It can be seen that the construction and application of the investment decision-making model of green supply chain finance based on machine learning method is reliable and practical.

title: State-Of-The-Art Smart Technology For Real-Time Monitoring And Analysis of Palm Oil Mill Effluent (POME) Wastewater
authors: Thamilvaani Arvaree Alvar, Yap Chiew Lin, Yap Lip Vun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: The palm oil industry, a vital component of the global agricultural economy, generates substantial amounts of Palm Oil Mill Effluent (POME), which poses significant environmental hazards if not properly managed. Traditional methods of POME treatment are often labor-intensive and inadequate for real-time monitoring, leading to potential regulatory non-compliance and environmental degradation. This paper aimed to develop a novel Smart POME Wastewater Monitoring System using Internet of Things (IoT) technology, integrating real-time sampling with ammonia monitoring and mobile app or web based visualization. The primary objective was to continuously monitor critical water quality parameters, including pH, temperature, Total Dissolved Solids (TDS), and ammonia nitrogen across different treatment stages: Concrete Pond, Final Discharge Pond, and Anaerobic Pond. The methodology involved the integration of advanced sensors with IoT-enabled data acquisition and transmission systems, facilitating real-time data collection and analysis. Water samples were collected from the specified ponds to validate sensor accuracy and performance. Testing was conducted in phases, starting with system setup and calibration, followed by continuous monitoring and periodic data validation. The expected outcome was a robust monitoring system that provided accurate, real-time data on POME quality, enabling prompt corrective actions and ensuring compliance with environmental regulations. The results demonstrated significant improvements in monitoring efficiency and environmental management. The conclusion underscored the system’s potential to revolutionize POME management, promoting sustainability and regulatory adherence in the palm oil industry.

title: Single-Fiber Single-Wavelength Bidirectional Digital Subcarrier Point-to-Multipoint Coherent Systems for Beyond 5G Transport
authors: P. Torres-Ferrera, G. Parisi, M. Distefano, R. Kapuscinski, G. Gambari, R. Magri, H. Olsson, M. S. Erkilinç, J. Bäck, C. Fludger, A. Tartaglia, A. Napoli
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We experimentally investigate on single-fiber bidirectional coherent transmission for nextgeneration mobile transport in Point-to-Multipoint (P2MP) architecture, using power optimization to improve the performance in the presence of fiber reflections and crosstalk.

title: Neural Network-based Information-Theoretic Transceivers for High-Order Modulation Schemes
authors: Ngoc Long Pham, Tri Nhu Do
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Neural network (NN)-based end-to-end (E2E) communication systems, in which each system component may consist of a portion of a neural network, have been investigated as potential tools for developing artificial intelligence (AI)-native E2E systems. In this paper, we propose an NN-based bitwise receiver that improves computational efficiency while maintaining performance comparable to baseline demappers. Building on this foundation, we introduce a novel symbol-wise autoencoder (AE)-based E2E system that jointly optimizes the transmitter and receiver at the physical layer. We evaluate the proposed NN-based receiver using bit-error rate (BER) analysis to confirm that the numerical BER achieved by NN-based receivers or transceivers is accurate. Results demonstrate that the AE-based system outperforms baseline architectures, particularly for higher-order modulation schemes. We further show that the training signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) significantly affects the performance of the systems when inference is conducted at different SNR levels.

title: Secrecy Outage Performance of NOMA-Aided MIMO Relay Systems in the Presence of an Eavesdropper
authors: Bo Quoc Bao, Nguyen Van Quang, Nguyen Thi Nguyen, Phan Dang Hung, Le Thi Trang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper investigates the security aspects of a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) network that utilizes a relay and non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) to serve multiple users under a potential eavesdropping scenario. Given the security vulnerabilities inherent in spectrally efficient systems, our work establishes a mathematical framework to analyze this specific architecture. We derive new closed-form expressions to characterize the secrecy outage probability (SOP) for individual users and the system as a whole. Through extensive simulations covering various antenna configurations and signal-to-noise conditions, our analysis confirms that the NOMA protocol can provide superior security compared to conventional orthogonal multiple access (OMA) in certain operational domains. These findings underscore the viability of NOMA as a foundational technology for constructing secure, next-generation wireless systems.

title: Modern virtual reality technologies for education and training
authors: Slavena Tihova, Emiliyan Petkov
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study examines the application of virtual reality (VR) technologies in education, with a special focus on their hardware foundation and pedagogical benefits. A comparative review of the most widely used VR devices in educational environments is presented, including tethered, standalone and hybrid systems. Their technical characteristics, ease of use and applicability in different educational contexts are all also analysed. The report outlines device selection criteria, integration strategies and key recommendations for effective implementation in the learning process based on real-world cases and practical examples. The main advantages of learning through VR are highlighted – increased engagement, the ability to visualise complex concepts and the safe practice of risky or expensive simulations. Despite challenges such as high costs, cyber sickness and the need for teacher training, the increasing availability of standalone VR systems (e.g., Meta Quest 3, PICO 4) reveals the potential for their wider application, including in budget-constrained educational institutions. The report concludes with conclusions about the importance of the right choice of hardware and integration with teaching methodologies to achieve effective and modern education.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Feed Rates Control for Fed-Batch Penicillin Fermentation
authors: Rosmawati Rumi, Min Keng Tan, Kenneth Tze Kin Teo, Sivakumar Kumaresan, Heng Jin Tham
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: The fed-batch penicillin fermentation process is inherently complex and nonlinear due to the sensitivity of microbial growth and product synthesis to environmental and operational conditions. Conventional control methods like Exponential Feeding (EF) or fixed strategies, lack adaptability when faced with dynamic process changes. Reinforcement Learning (RL), a branch of Artificial Intelligence (AI), offers a model-free approach that enables an agent to learn optimal actions through environmental interaction using rewards and penalties. This study employs a reinforcement learning-based adaptive control technique to dynamically adjust the feed rate in penicillin fermentation, with the objective of maximizing productivity while minimizing substrate inhibition. A streamlined kinetic model incorporating substrate inhibition and product synthesis was written in MATLAB. The RL controller employs a Dynamic Programming (DP) framework to determine the ideal feed rate, with the reward function structured to promote penicillin production while penalizing high substrate concentration. The feed rate action space had increments of 1 L/h and covered 0 to 50 L/h over a 400-h batch time. According to the simulation findings conducted under both nominal and variable initial conditions, the RL controller maintained the residual substrate concentration below 0.003 g/L while achieving a total batch penicillin product ranging from 141,858 g to 148,523 g. This adaptive approach shows potential for intelligent, reward-driven process control that optimizes fed-batch penicillin production.

title: Performance Enhancement of Position Controller for Gear Motor Using Linear Quadratic Regulator with Disturbance Compensator
authors: Tien Nguyen-Minh, Hoai-Linh T. Nguyen, Hoang Nguyen-Minh, M. H Hoang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Gear motors are widely used in critical position tracking systems such as robotic arms and wind turbines, due to their ability to deliver high torque in a compact form factor. This research proposes an enhanced position control strategy that combines a Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR)—an optimal control method—with a disturbance observer, eliminating the need for a current control loop. The LQR is designed to minimize both position and stator current errors, thereby ensuring accurate trajectory tracking and effective load handling. To further improve control performance, the disturbance observer estimates the load torque and uses it to compute the reference current. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through simulations under two types of load conditions: constant load and position-dependent variable load. The results are also compared with a conventional cascade control structure that includes current and position controllers in the inner and outer loops, respectively, demonstrating the superior performance of the proposed approach.

title: Broadband 205-GHz Vertical-Illumination Photodiode Enabled by Interference-based Absorption and Field Engineering
authors: Yuki Yamada, Ikue Hiraoka, Shohei Kosuga, Takahiro Nakamura, Yusuke Araki, Fumito Nakajima
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate a high-speed, high-responsivity vertical-illumination In GaAs/lnP photodiode (PD) using interference-based absorption enhancement and field-control doping. The PD exhibits a 205 GHz bandwidth and 0.51 A/W responsivity. A 1-dB compression current of 10 mA at 200 GHz shows high-power tolerance for optical input.

title: Wireless & Batteryless High-T Probe for Real-Time Monitoring of Rotating Automotive Components
authors: Alessio Mostaccio, Francesco Lestini, Carolina Miozzi, Nicola D'Uva, Sara Amendola, Gaetano Marrocco
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Accurate and robust temperature monitoring of rotating and high-temperature components remains a critical challenge in automotive Test & Measurement, particularly during dynamic vehicle testing. Traditional wired sensing approaches, such as thermocouples, are not viable for components in motion, while current wireless solutions often fail to withstand the harsh conditions of critical subsystems like brake assemblies, wheel rims, and powertrain interfaces. Moreover, commercially available passive RFID tags with integrated temperature sensors are typically limited to operational temperatures below 130° C, rendering them unsuitable for applications where temperatures can exceed 250° C. In this work, we present the design and characterization of a novel passive RFID-based sensing architecture for high-temperature applications on rotating vehicle components. The system is based on the AS2312 UHF RFID chip by Asygn, which enables direct interfacing with external resistive sensors. A thermally robust sensing node is realized by integrating an NTC thermistor via a half-bridge configuration, with the RFID chip and antenna placed in cooler zone and the sensing element positioned near the thermal hotspot. Inlab characterization demonstrated the feasibility of measuring temperatures exceeding 250° C with an RMSE of 16.5° C, mainly concentrated at low temperatures.

title: SmartTrack: Online RFID Card Attendance System using Ardiuno UNO
authors: Amit Kumar Singh, Ashish Singh Chauhan, Anshul Mahajan, Abdul Rahim, Srinivas Aluvala, Praveen Kumar Malik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: In today’s fast-paced environment, the demand for efficient, automated, and reliable attendance systems is growing rapidly in both educational and corporate settings. This paper explores the design and implementation of an affordable, RFID- based smart attendance system utilizing the Arduino Uno micro- controller, an SD card module for local data storage, and an ESP32 Wi-Fi module to upload attendance records to a cloud-based IoT platform. RFID tags, assigned to users, allow for contactless and secure identification, significantly reducing errors, preventing fraudulent activities (such as proxy attendance), and lessening the manual workload. The system’s performance is assessed based on scanning success rates, response times, and data synchronization. Various data visualization methods, including histograms, box plots, and heat maps, are employed to analyze attendance patterns. This research showcases a scalable and cost-effective solution that is ideal for educational institutions, small businesses, and large-scale operations, offering real-time data access and efficient attendance management at a fraction of traditional costs.

title: A Novel Decision-Aided Detection Algorithm for Performance Enhancement in Bandwidth-Limited FTN-DMB Systems
authors: Hao Deng, Yi Cai, Jian Zhao
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a novel decision-aided detection algorithm for bandwidth-limited Faster-thanNyquist (FTN) digital-multi-band (DMB) systems. Experiments at 50 GBaud show that this algorithm outperforms LUT-based MLSE and BCJR, and enables FTN-DMB to yield a 2 -dB gain over conventional Nyquist-DMB at the same data rate. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Explainable Vision Transformer Enabled Convolutional Neural Network for Plant Disease Classification
authors: Vikky, Neha Mittal, Satendra Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Plant diseases significantly have threatened the world agriculture through the decrease in food availability, economic sustainability and the survival of the farmers. The significance of timely and proper detection of plant diseases is that it helps to get them before they cause the outbreak thus curbing crop losses. Common methods of detection do not usually scale all the way given that they resort more on the skills of the personnel making the analysis. Plant disease can be diagnosed by using image data, and since the development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) especially deep learning is very prompt, we focus into probing the task of detection and classification of plant leaf diseases based on Kaggle dataset, more than 53k plant leaf images, and 38 classes using deep learning techniques. Until the stage of pre-processing the image, learning model, measuring model performance, it has been taking an entire data science pipeline of the study. They employed the VIT trained and transfer learning based on the pre trained architectures like VGG19 and ResNet50. The significant issue was the imbalance and visual similarity of classes of disease during the data analysis which was mitigated by data augmentation and hyperparam optimization. VIT model produced validation accuracy of 99.7 % as opposed to VGG19 model whose accuracy was 80.56 %. The accuracy recorded on the last performance is 91.93 on the EfficientNet model. Since the solution to the identification of plant diseases turns out to be effective with preprocessing and model adoption through deep learning. It also aids to create AI driven tools of precision agriculture and demonstrates future works such as application of the models to the mobile and real time diagnostics to the farm systems.

title: Utilizing Regression Techniques to Predict Anxiety and Depression
authors: Suvidha Agarwal, Sachin Kumar, Anubhi Bansal, Hirdesh Sharma, Preeta Rajiv Sivaraman, Mayank Parashar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Mental health disorders like anxiety and sadness affect a sizable section of the world's population. By facilitating prompt treatment, early detection of these illnesses may lessen their detrimental effects on people's health. In light of several risk factors, including demographic data, lifestyle choices, past medical history, and psychological evaluations, this study investigates the application of regression techniques to forecast anxiety and depression levels. Using both quantitative and qualitative data, regression models such as polynomial, Ridge, Lasso, and linear regression were used to determine the degree of anxiety and depression. This study used information about the participants' age, gender, sleep habits, physical activity, social interactions, and past mental health history that was collected from clinical records and mental health questionnaires. Preprocessing methods like normalization, feature selection, and missing variable correction were used to improve model performance.

title: Analysis of Vibration Signal Characteristics of Micro-Faults in Aero-Engine Rolling Bearing
authors: Li Peng, Zhang Zhi, Shi Yong Yun, Wang Zhi Xiong, Wei Xiang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To address the challenge of weak and difficult-to-identify features of early micro-faults in aero-engine bearings, this study collected vibration signals from bearings in normal states and with micro-defects in the inner ring, outer ring, and rolling elements based on a self-built high-speed multi-load test platform. Through comparative experiments of time-domain statistical feature analysis and deep learning models (CNN, LSTM, EMD-CNN-LSTM), the characteristics of micro-fault vibration signals were revealed: their amplitude indicators have certain discriminability for fault types but are prone to overlap due to noise interference. Deep learning experiments showed that the LSTM model has unique sensitivity to the time-series evolution patterns of micro-faults (such as slow amplitude increase and periodic phase distortion), achieving a classification accuracy of 99.08% on a self-built 7-class weak fault dataset, significantly better than CNN (93.01%). Although the EMD-CNN-LSTM model fuses multi-scale features, its accuracy is 95.22% due to limited feature discriminability under low signal-to-noise ratios. The research results can provide a reference for early fault warning of aero-engine bearings.

title: Pyrolyzer Assisted Vapor Transport Deposition of Antimony-Doped Cadmium Telluride_supp1-3633076.pdf
authors: Bin Du
publish: N/A
abstract: In this study, we developed a new method for in situ Sb doping of CdTe thin films combining vapor transport deposition with a Group V pyrolyzer to address Sb doping concentration and doping efficiency. The Sb doped CdSeTe (CdSeTe:Sb) films were deposited in solar cell structures under variations of Sb dopant source heater, vapor pyrolyzer temperature, and Cd vapor excess. Results indicate that although these parameters do not affect the CdTe morphology or crystal structure, they critically influence doping efficiency and trap concentration. Capacitance–voltage measurements show that a higher dopant heater (T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</sub>) or pyrolyzer (T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">P</sub>) temperature leads to higher net carrier concentration, achieving a net carrier concentration of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">16</sup> cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup> and 20% doping efficiency with a T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</sub>/T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">P</sub> combination of 600 °C/1100 °C. By tuning the Cd/Sb flux ratio during CdSeTe:Sb deposition, the lowest defect concentration is achieved at Cd/Sb of 1.4:1, which produced the best V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OC</sub> CdSeTe:Sb cell. This demonstrates a path to produce high net carrier concentration polycrystalline CdTe thin film with a low concentration of dopant-induced defects.

title: Silicon Microcuvette-Based Testing System for Optical Absorption Spectroscopy of Vegetable Oils
authors: Suchismita Paul, Alakananda Das, Anirban Bhattacharyya
publish: IEEE Transactions on AgriFood Electronics
abstract: A fast and simple testing method for micro-nano liter volumes of agricultural products can be very advantageous in the food industry for quality control purposes. In this work, optical transmittance spectra of olive oils, heated to different temperatures, were compared using a custom-built test system. Results indicate that testing at two specific wavelengths of 370 nm and 470 nm is sufficient to determine their state of oxidation and to distinguish them from other oils. A novel microcuvette (μCUV) was designed with integrated heating as well as optical detection capabilities for this purpose. Silicon micromachining techniques were used to fabricate an inverted pyramidal structure, with an opening 750 μm × 750 μm, sidewall slope of 54.7° and an optical window of 30 μm × 30 μm at the bottom. To carry real-time spectroscopic measurements, while maintaining a liquid under test at controlled elevated temperatures, microheater structures surrounding the μCUV were designed. The design parameters were the dimensions of the silicon structure, microheater geometry, thickness of the heating element, and inter-element spacing. While several geometries were compared, simulation results indicate that due to the sloped sidewalls of the μCUV and presence of corners, multiple specially designed heaters at the top as well as the bottom of the structure are necessary to obtain a temperature variation of less than 8% across the inner surface of the μCUV. The silicon-based system can be directly integrated into on-chip control electronics catering to a wide range of applications. We propose a fast and versatile liquid test system based on our results.

title: A Practical High-Quality ULA SIMO Radar Calibration Based on Synthetic Aperture Radar Imaging Artifacts With Exceptionally Low Requirements on the Measurement Scene and Setup
authors: Michael Braunwarth, Johanna Geiss, Erik Sippel, Martin Vossiek
publish: IEEE Journal of Microwaves
abstract: Phase coherent signal processing for radar imaging relies on the precise estimation and compensation of unavoidable manufacturing inaccuracies, component variations, and aging effects in multichannel radar systems, as these imperfections limit the achievable image quality and can even render target detection impossible. The demand for radars with higher resolution requires higher frequencies, bandwidths, and apertures, imposing more stringent requirements on calibration quality. Conventional calibration methods often offer limited quality while necessitating expensive positioning systems and large-scale anechoic chambers. To address these challenges, this paper presents a novel calibration method for uniform linear array (ULA) single-input multiple-output (SIMO) radar systems that can be performed outside an anechoic chamber, even in a highly reflective environment. Moreover, its setup requirement is limited to a single linear unit, enabling a practical and cost-effective calibration that avoids strict constraints on the measurement scene and equipment. This is achieved by enhancing and expanding an existing calibration technique that minimizes artifacts in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images caused by the coherent superposition of channel imbalances. As a result, these artifacts serve as a highly sensitive and precise metric for the calibration process, enabling an exceptionally high calibration quality while requiring the evaluation of only a few Fourier coefficients, thus ensuring low computational effort. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated by calibrating a 77GHz frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) SIMO radar system with an eight-element ULA receive (RX) antenna array in a highly reflective environment. The calibration quality is validated by comparing processed images from an independent test scene against uncalibrated data and the results of two other calibration methods.

title: AMEE: Automatic Modulation Open Set Recognition Through Deep Metric Learning With Embedding Enhancement
authors: Dongwei Xu, Jiaye Hou, Fuxing Song, Zhuangzhi Chen, Shilian Zheng, Qi Xuan, Yun Lin, Xiaoniu Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: Automatic modulation recognition is essential for large-scale wireless communications, but traditional methods often ignore unknown signals in open-set conditions, leading to their incorrect classification as known types and thereby compromising system reliability and communication security. To handle this challenge, a novel automatic modulation open set recognition (AMOSR) model based on deep metric learning with embedding enhancement is proposed in this article. First, for each known example, deep neural model is employed to separately extract the original in-phase and quadrature (IQ) signal and its instantaneous features, which are then fused to obtain embedding. Second, random erasing is employed to the original IQ signal and instantaneous features separately to obtain an augmented example, which has similar structure but different semantics with known example, and the embedding of this example is obtained by using first step. Then, the embedding space, in which tuplet loss and margin loss are combined with the embeddings of known and augmented examples, is trained to improve the overall performance of the model. Finally, after training, AMOSR is implemented using the class centers of known classes. Experiments on three automatic modulation datasets show that our model has better average performance than several mainstream methods in the field of computer vision.

title: From Vision to Touch: Bridging Visual and Tactile Principles for Accessible Data Representation
authors: Kim Marriott, Matthew Butler, Leona Holloway, William Jolley, Bongshin Lee, Bruce Maguire, Danielle Albers Szafr
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Tactile graphics are widely used to present maps and statistical diagrams to blind and low vision (BLV) people, with accessibility guidelines recommending their use for graphics where spatial relationships are important. Their use is expected to grow with the advent of commodity refreshable tactile displays. However, in stark contrast to visual information graphics, we lack a clear understanding of the benefts that well-designed tactile information graphics offer over text descriptions for BLV people. To address this gap, we introduce a framework considering the three components of encoding, perception and cognition to examine the known benefts for visual information graphics and explore their applicability to tactile information graphics. This work establishes a preliminary theoretical foundation for the tactile-frst design of information graphics and identifes future research avenues.

title: Large AI Model and Loss Variation Empowered Dual-Importance Prioritized Semantic Transmission
authors: Yueling Liu, Li Zhou, Yichi Zhang, Haitao Zhao, Kuo Cao, Zhaolong Ning, Jibo Wei
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: In scenarios with extremely harsh channel conditions and severely limited communication resources, the reliability and effectiveness of semantic communication require urgent enhancement to satisfy the increasing demands of 6G technology. To address this issue, we propose an importance prioritized framework that integrates both message importance and feature importance to identify critical semantics for reliable and efficient semantic transmission. Considering service personalization and task intelligence, we analyze the message importance by factoring the receiver’s preferences and the communication tasks requirements. Specifically, a large AI model is introduced to quantify message importance, while an importance-based metric for semantic accuracy is established to evaluate the overall reliability of semantic communication. To safeguard significant messages in harsh channel conditions, an unequal error protection strategy based on message importance is employed. Furthermore, we propose a novel approach for feature importance analysis based on loss variation to accurately identify critical features. A feature importance prediction network is designed for algorithm deployment. Additionally, a semantic compression strategy based on feature importance is utilized to prioritize the transmission of essential features in limited communication resources scenarios. Extensive experimental results demonstrate substantial performance advantages of our framework and methods, especially in low signal-to-noise ratio and communication resource shortages, providing a reliable and efficient solution for semantic communication in adverse communication environments.

title: Interference-free causality learning promotes cross-level, fine-grained diagnosis of coronary artery disease in coronary CT angiography
authors: Xinghua Ma, Xinyan Fang, Gongning Luo, Xingyu Qiu, Xin Liu, Chao Huang, Kuanquan Wang, Zhaowen Qiu, Tong Zhang, Yue Li, Lei Wei, Xin Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: With the growing global threat of coronary artery disease (CAD), automated CAD diagnosis techniques based on coronary CT angiography (CCTA) have been developed. However, their clinical applicability remains limited due to the heterogeneity of stenosis and plaque attributes, as well as confounders within the causal relationships of CAD diagnosis. This work introduces the Attribute-Decoupled Intervention Network (ADI-Net), a confounder-free CAD diagnosis framework designed for fine-grained analysis at both the artery and patient levels, aligning with real-world clinical practice. ADI-Net employs an attribute-decoupled representation that effectively captures the heterogeneous features of stenosis and plaque with differential constraints, enabling precise, fine-grained classification. Additionally, the dynamic-updating causal intervention continuously refines confounder banks and applies the Do-expression within a complete causality, ensuring comprehensive, cross-level assessments. Experiments on CCTA datasets from three clinical centers demonstrate that ADI-Net outperforms state-of-the-art methods in cross-level, fine-grained CAD diagnosis, exhibiting superior robustness, domain adaptability, and data efficiency.

title: Asymmetric Cosine Jerk Trajectory Optimization for Robust Vibration Suppression
authors: Yi Fang, Ruoyi Hao, Hao Fan, Yu Tian, Hongliang Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Rapid and precise movements of industrial equipment necessitate reference trajectory design to mitigate motion-induced vibrations, which becomes more challenging in the presence of system uncertainties. This article develops a novel trajectory planning method based on an improved cosine jerk model to robustly suppress residual vibration under actuator limits. Incorporating tunable asymmetry into the model allows trajectories to start faster and shorten motion duration. By applying a linear transformation in the complex domain, the vibration suppression capability is extended to accommodate both undamped and damped systems. The profile parameters are modulated to align the intrinsic trajectory zeros with the system poles, attenuating spectral components near the critical modal frequency that excite resonance. Unlike much current work that provides only partial solutions or requires numerical optimization, a complete analytical solution is derived for all possible trajectory types using a designed coefficient that manages the acceleration ratio. The effectiveness and robustness of the method are validated experimentally across different systems. The results show that the proposed method can achieve better vibration mitigation performance under modeling errors than existing benchmark methods.

title: Super-Resolution Imaging of Sparse Sea Surface Targets by Multi-Feature Divide-and-Conquer Framework
authors: Jiahao Shen, Deqing Mao, Mingjie Yang, Yin Zhang, Jianyu Yang, Yulin Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Real aperture radar superresolution imaging of sea surface targets has significant applications in sea surface surveillance and maritime rescue. However, its performance rapidly deteriorates when the echo data of the valid targets are merged into the strong sea clutter. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a multi-feature divide-and-conquer (MF-D&C) framework by forming a complex multi-feature enhancement network (CMFE-NET) and data-divide-and-conquer-based (DD&C-based) sparse Bayesian learning (SBL) algorithm. First, to separate sea clutter echo from valid targets’ echo, a CMFE-NET is proposed to transform the complex echoes into four distinct feature spaces: amplitude, phase, frequency, and dwell time. Second, based on the separated sea clutter echo and the valid targets’ echo, a DD&C-based SBL algorithm is proposed to perform Bayesian parameter estimation on both the clutter and target components, which improves the model parameter estimation performance within the Bayesian framework. Finally, a parameter pruning solver is introduced in EM estimation to eliminate inactive parameters during the iterative super-resolution process, significantly reducing computational overhead. The proposed framework demonstrates superior capabilities resolution enhancement in sea surface target superresolution imaging.

title: Online Learning-Based Dual Balancing of SOC and Temperature in Lithium-Ion Battery Packs
authors: Hoda Sorouri, Arman Oshnoei, Remus Teodorescu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Battery management systems (BMSs) are critical for optimizing the performance and extending the lifespan of lithium-ion battery packs by maintaining uniform state of charge (SOC) and temperature across cells. While SOC balancing has traditionally been the primary focus, recent studies highlight the importance of temperature balancing to prevent accelerated degradation. This article presents a brain emotional learning (BEL)-based active balancing method that jointly regulates SOC and cell temperature within a unified, adaptive control policy designed to handle operating variability and measurement uncertainty. The proposed approach is evaluated against proportional–integral, model predictive control, and deep reinforcement learning controllers through case studies on a heterogeneous battery pack model in the MATLAB/Simulink environment, and further validated using both a virtual prototyping platform and a control hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) platform. Results demonstrate that the BEL-based approach achieves faster convergence, greater robustness to measurement noise, and improved long-term balancing performance compared with all benchmark methods.

title: Thermal Interference Analysis and Compensation for Monolithic Integrated Thermopile Infrared Sensors
authors: Jiagen Cheng, Wanli Jiang, Chenxi Yue, Weihuang Yang, Yu Gao, Chaoran Liu, Dehui Xu, WangHuai Xu, Linxi Dong
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: To meet the demand for high-performance, miniaturized, and low-cost sensing systems in the field of temperature monitoring, chip-level monolithic integration of sensors and integrated circuits (ICs) is an effective solution for constructing sensing-processing integrated intelligent microsystems. However, this monolithic integrated structure inherently introduces thermal interference issues, directly limiting the system's temperature measurement accuracy. In this work, we designed a monolithic integrated thermopile infrared sensor developed using standard CMOS (Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor) process technology and conducted thermal interference coupling analysis and temperature compensation studies based on its structural characteristics. First, through structural analysis of this type of sensor, we identified the presence of thermal mismatch between the hot and cold ends, as well as thermal transient temperature rise phenomena. The former manifests as spatial temperature imbalance causing static error, while the latter manifests as temporal temperature changes causing dynamic error. Subsequently, we experimentally validated these two types of errors and constructed a static reference correction model combined with an RC network dynamic compensation model, achieving synergistic suppression of both types of thermal interference. Experimental results show that after static reference correction, the static deviation caused by thermal mismatch between the hot and cold ends decreased from 0.22°C to 0.06°C, with an error reduction of 73%. After dynamic temperature compensation, the dynamic error caused by the self-heating temperature rise of the tube shell decreased from 0.42°C to 0.08°C, with an error reduction of 80.9%. This study provides the theoretical basis and compensation methods for improving temperature measurement accuracy in monolithic integrated temperature measurement systems.

title: A High Gain Horn Antenna Array with Shared Aperture Operating in Epsilon-Near-Zero (ENZ) Mode
authors: Lin Zhao, Jiaxin Li, Dan Long, Huaning Wu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: To address the issues of high loss and low efficiency in feeding networks of conventional antenna arrays at millimeter-wave frequencies, this letter presents a high-gain endfire antenna array with shared apertures based on the epsilon-near-zero (ENZ) mode. We introduce shorting vias at the horn aperture based on composite right/left-handed transmission line (CRLH TL) theory, enabling ENZ mode operation in the non-uniform aperture with broadened bandwidth, which surpasses the bandwidth limitation of conventional waveguide ENZ antenna. A SIW operating in the ENZ mode is employed as the feeding network, which excites a four-element shared-aperture array through slot coupling. A dipole array integrated with a reflective structure is introduced to create a magneto-electric complementary radiation mechanism, thereby enhancing endfire gain. The radiation pattern function of the antenna is derived and validated through full-wave simulations and measurements. Measured at 24.39 GHz, the prototype exhibits a peak gain of 12.03 dBi, a total efficiency of 84.2%, and a sidelobe level of -21.1 dB under an in-phase excitation via a single feeding point. The proposed design provides a high-performance, low-cost, and compact endfire antenna solution for millimeter-wave communication, radar, and satellite systems.

title: Compact and Lightweight Planar Harmonic Tag for Operation in Challenging Environments
authors: Andrei Mogilnikov, Arjun Kumar, Anastasia Lavrenko
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study presents a compact and lightweight planar harmonic transponder tag for passive sensing and tracking in challenging environments. Harmonic tags are batteryless devices that, when illuminated by an electromagnetic wave from the reader, reradiate a signal at a harmonic frequency, enabling robust operation in highly cluttered or interference-prone settings. Conventional harmonic tags often rely on wire-based dipole structures that, although very lightweight, are limited in performance and scalability. The proposed tag features an asymmetric folded meander-line dipole antenna printed on an ultrathin 25 μm flexible polyimide substrate that is directly matched to a low-voltage Schottky diode at fundamental and second harmonic frequencies (2.9 GHz and 5.8 GHz, respectively). This dual-band antenna design enables improved harmonic backscattering efficiency while maintaining a minimal form factor of 15 mm × 11.8 mm and a total weight of 22 mg. The tag demonstrates a significant improvement in conversion efficiency of up to 18 dB over traditional wire-based designs, effectively doubling the detectable range. Performance evaluations were conducted through simulations and experimental measurements in an anechoic chamber, validating the effectiveness of the tag in free space. The proposed harmonic transponder provides an efficient and scalable solution for smart sensing and tracking applications where size, weight, and robustness are critical.

title: MDC-Net: A Multidimensional Dynamic Convolutional Network for the Cellular Detection of Vaginitis Pathogens
authors: Zhaolin Lu, Maoxin Wen, Yiran Liu, Wen Zhang, Hongliang Bi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Vaginitis, a common gynecological condition in women, is diagnosed with the use of immunofluorescence microscopy to identify five cell types in vaginal secretions: trichomonas, leukocytes, epithelial cells, clue cells, and spores. The risk of manual diagnosis errors is relatively high due to large numbers of samples and complex morphology. Automated detection of vaginal secretions through fluorescence microscopy is essential; however, current methods fall short of meeting clinical requirements for detecting vaginal inflammation pathogens. To establish an efficient and accurate system for detecting vaginitis pathogens at the cellular level, this study has created a high-quality fluorescence microscopy image dataset of vaginal secretions with sufficient samples, named VagFluor. To address issues such as artifactual interference, blurred boundaries, and cell adhesion occlusion in the VagFluor dataset, this study has proposed a new algorithm for auxiliary diagnosis and treatment of vaginitis: MDC-Net. The feature extraction stage has introduced a full-dimensional adaptive module that retains complete information from the cell edge to the bacterial colony, enhancing model sensitivity. Additionally, a cross-stage multi-scale spatial pyramid pooling module has been built, which can capture subtle discriminative features in non-central positions of similar categories. Furthermore, a multi-channel feature fusion module has been introduced to guide the network in focusing on target details, effectively resolving the problem of feature confusion. Experimental results have demonstrated that MDC-Net can achieve higher accuracy on the VagFluor dataset than current state-of-the-art detectors.

title: Robust Fibre Longitudinal Power Monitoring with Few Measurements Using Two-Stage Sparse Regularization
authors: Hiroyuki Ishihara, Takeo Sasai, Toru Mano, Atsushi Yamamoto, Hideki Nishizawa, Etsushi Yamazaki, Yoshiaki Sone
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a sparse regularized model for fibre-longitudinal power monitoring without prior knowledge of link parameters. Experimental results show that RMSE of the power profile improved by 0.40 dB, and detection of 0.72 dB anomaly loss was successful with few measurements. ©2025 The Author(s)

authors: Isaac N.O. Osahon, Othman vounus, Tongyun Li, Sina Babadi, Hossein Safi, Du Yang, Juan Macias, Panos Mystridis, Siddharth Tripathi, Ashweeni Beeharee, Michael Crisp, Richard Penty, Harald Haas, Iman Tavakkolnia
