title: Cost Effective and Robust Transmitter IQ Skew Compensation Scheme for High Speed Coherent Digital Subcarrier Multiplexing System
authors: Yongchao Jin, Qian Xiang, Siyu Gong, Chen Cheng, Linsheng Fan, Pengxi Yang, Yanfu Yang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We proposed a low-complexity transmitter IQ skew equalization scheme for DSCM systems, achieving 50% complexity reduction compared to 4×4 RV-MIMO while maintaining comparable performance, incurring only a 0. 19 dB ROP penalty under 2 ps IQ skew at a BER of 3.8e-3.

title: Fault Estimation for a Class of Nonlinear Systems Using a New Neural Network Based Reinforcement Learning Scheme
authors: Zhengquan Chen, Yuanhui Huo, Jiayuan Yan, Yandong Hou, Yankun Han
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In this paper, we presents a novel Neural Network (NN) based Reinforcement Learning (RL) strategy for accurately estimating the faults in nonlinear systems. More specifically, this NN-RL fault estimation strategy takes advantage of the remarkable generalization and function approximation capabilities of the NN and exceptional optimal decision-making and strong learning capabilities of the RL method. The NN-RL performances are comprehensively evaluated by applying them to fault estimation problems in nonlinear manipulator systems. In addition, a comparative analysis of the NN-RL approach is also made to a pure RL fault estimation strategy. Performance comparison on the fault estimation problems of manipulator indicate that the NN-RL method results in better fault estimation as evidenced by high accuracy and overshoot rejection.

title: Wirelessly-Powered Devices Using UHF ESD Energy Capture
authors: Stewart J. Thomas, Brian P. Degnan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This research explores the potential of utilizing already-existing electrostatic discharge (ESD) protection circuits as energy harvesters for wireless power transfer. ESD circuits are structures common to all ICs intended to protect sensitive internal circuitry. The internal ESD diodes can be combined with discrete capacitance and wires acting as a dipole antenna to realize a simple charge pump-the basic circuit of most UHF RFID tags. In this work, we characterize the ESD-based energy harvesting capability of several low-power microcontrollers using UHF signals. We also demonstrate fully-passive, battery-free operation of an off-the-shelf Bluetooth low-energy (BLE) temperature sensor with only the addition of a single off-chip capacitor, and a wire dipole antenna. While ESD protection circuits are not intended to act as energy harvesting circuits, this work shows that may be used as UHF harvesting circuits.

title: Blind Massive MIMO Signal Transmission by High Efficiency Compression If Over Fibre Using Cost-Effective EML-CAN
authors: Junya Nishioka, Sojiro Masada, Takatoshi Akamatsu, Keita Mochizuki, Masaki Noda
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: By using non-interfering OFDM pilots, the PAST-IFoF transmission scheme we have proposed does not need complicated information exchange. We demonstrated that PAST-IFoF can transmit <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 256$</tex> OFDM-64QAM massive MIMO signals in a blind environment using a wideband EMLCAN to supress degradation due to analogue transmission. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Stealth FDI Attack Detection Based On Multi-Scale Wavelet Transform Spatial-Temporal Graph Convolutional Network
authors: Shiyu Cao, Wei Li, Yajie Li
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Aiming at the feature differences of Industry Cyber-Physical Systems (ICPS) data at different scales and the strong spatial-temporal topology relationship of the system, a Multi-Scale Wavelet Transform Spatial-Temporal Graph Convolutional Network (MSWTSTGCN) concealed False Data Injection (FDI) attack detection algorithm is proposed. Firstly, discrete wavelet transform (DWT) is used to decompose the original data into high-frequency and low-frequency components, and the high-frequency details are decomposed multiple times to fully extract potential attack features; Secondly, the temporal and spatial associations in ICPS data are extracted using spatiotemporal graph convolution, the interactions between adjacent nodes, and the key features that lead to system anomalies are captured; Then the inverse wavelet transform is used to reconstruct the input data, and the residual error is used to determine whether the attack occurs.

title: RFID-Based Distributed Control of a Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface
authors: Daniel Poehl, Ulrich Muehlmann, Franz Amtmann, Peter Thueringer, Jasmin Grosinger
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents an RFID-based control system for distributed reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS), addressing scalability, flexibility, and low power consumption to reduce the implementation complexity of RIS systems and to make a step in the direction of completely passive RIS systems. Building upon a modular controller design, each RIS tile integrates a 915 MHz RFID antenna, an RFID chip with inter-integrated circuit (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{I}^{\mathbf{2}} \mathbf{C}$</tex>) interface, and a dedicated control board to enable wireless configuration of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6} \mathbf{2. 4 ~ G H z}$</tex> RIS unit cells (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> unit cells on a single RIS tile with the dimensions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 \times 25 ~\text{cm}$</tex>). This distributed approach eliminates the need for centralized and wired control units, simplifying deployment and enabling scalability. Key contributions include a detailed hardware implementation of the RFID-based control mechanism with a detailed power analysis, to highlight ultra-low power consumption. Experimental results validate the system performance, demonstrating robust wireless control over a long distance with minimal power consumption.

title: Designing Customized Wearable Devices: A Novel AI-Based Framework for Product Development
authors: Stefan Resch
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The development of personalized wearable devices, including orthopedic products, requires individual customization to ensure user satisfaction and sustained usage over time. Recent advances in image-generative Artificial Intelligence (AI), such as DALL-E from ChatGPT, have shown promise for creating individualized designs tailored to user preferences. However, the structured integration of such AI tools into broader iterative product development workflows (including 3D-modeling, personalization, and physical manufacturing) remains largely unexplored in this application context. This work presents a user-centered design process that incorporates image-based generation into early design phases to address both functional and aesthetic user needs. A case study was conducted to demonstrate the process, resulting in the design and fabrication of a customized foot orthosis using additive manufacturing. To assess the design outcome, the prototype was evaluated through a subjective user questionnaire and supplemented by qualitative feedback from an orthopedic professional. The results highlight both strengths and limitations of AI-assisted workflows in personalized product design. Overall, the findings illustrate how AI can be effectively embedded in user-centered design processes and provide implications for applications beyond orthopedic footwear design.

title: Enhancing Maritime Surveillance: A Multi-Model Analysis on a Curated Multi-Dataset Benchmark
authors: Joniel B. Barreto, Carlos H. Q. Forster
publish: 2025 Latin American Robotics Symposium (LARS)
abstract: Maritime object classification plays a crucial role in surveillance, search and rescue, and autonomous navigation, yet remains challenging due to varying object sizes, occlusions, and environmental conditions. In this work, we conduct a systematic comparison of three deep learning architectures, a Convolutional Neural Network, a Vision Transformer, and a YOLO-based model, examining both scratch-trained and pretrained configurations to assess the impact of transfer learning. To ensure a realistic evaluation, we curated a benchmark dataset from three public sources, divided into five test subsets representing diverse operational scenarios. Our results reveal that pre-trained models consistently surpass scratch-trained counterparts, underscoring the importance of leveraging prior knowledge. In particular, ViT-Pretrained achieves the highest overall performance, excelling at detecting small and human-sized objects, while YOLO-Pretrained offers a compelling balance of speed and accuracy.

title: Integrated Renewable Energy Performance in Tropical Climates: A Review
authors: R. Dutis, M. A. Ismail, M. K. W. Ibrahim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Traditional renewable energy modelling frameworks designed for temperate climates inadequately predict system performance in tropical regions, limiting deployment accuracy in areas with unique environmental challenges. This systematic review adheres to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) 2020 guidelines to assess the performance of integrated renewable energy systems across tropical climate zones. A comprehensive search of IEEE Xplore, ScienceDirect, Scopus, and Web of Science databases identified relevant studies that record key parameters, including Köppen-Geiger climate zone classification, system configurations and capacity ranges, performance metrics and efficiency data, economic parameters (CAPEX, OPEX, LCOE), and the duration of the validation methodology. Analysis reveals significant performance variations across all renewable technologies in tropical conditions, with integrated photovoltaic-wind-battery systems demonstrating superior performance compared to standalone configurations. Economic analysis indicates that an optimized levelized cost of electricity can be achieved through proper system integration. The review identifies promising research areas, including long-term validation datasets, enhanced modelling approaches, and comprehensive environmental impact assessment. These findings lay the groundwork for developing tropical-specific design frameworks to accelerate the deployment of renewable energy in rapidly developing tropical regions that host substantial global populations.

title: Multi-Sensor Fault Detection Based on Wavelet Time-Frequency Maps
authors: Zhaoliang Chen, Maoyin Chen
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Many existing frequency-domain fault detection approaches rely on only a subset of the information contained in multi-sensor data, typically focusing on frequency-domain features or simple inter-sensor coupling. To enhance detection performance, this study introduces a fault detection framework based on wavelet time–frequency representations. First, the wavelet transform is employed to generate time–frequency maps that reveal the temporal evolution of different frequency components within the signals. These maps are then segmented along the time axis to enable a more detailed extraction of local time–frequency patterns, after which the covariance matrix of each segment is calculated to characterize sensor correlations. Finally, a two-dimensional convolutional neural network (2D-CNN) is designed to perform fault detection using the covariance matrices as inputs. Experiments conducted on the Tennessee Eastman Process (TEP) dataset verify that the proposed method effectively captures both time–frequency information and inter-sensor dependencies, achieving strong accuracy and robustness in multi-sensor fault diagnosis.

title: Automated Test Case Generation Using Machine Learning And Natural Language Processing
authors: Arya Devi M R, Abdul Jabbar P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Software testing is a prominent step in software quality assurance, as it helps to provide high quality software product with reliability. Traditional methods for creation of test cases are not efficient to handle complex problems in which causing error and resulting in difficulties in the overall testing method. Automated test case generation is an approach to solve these difficulties in testing and helps to increase efficiency and software quality. This paper presents a method to improve the test case development process by integrating machine learning (ML) and natural language processing (NLP) techniques. ML methods, such as supervised and reinforcement learning, are used to predict ideal test cases based on the past defect patterns, while NLP methods will process and understand the software requirements and user stories to automatically generate relevant test scenarios. Transformer-based language models and deep learning classifiers are used inorder to extract and structure test cases from natural language specifications. The results obtained show a considerable increase in test coverage, defect detection rates, and overall reliability. A comparative analysis of Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing-based models such as combinations of classification algorithms and language representations shows that combining both approaches helps to enhance the overall performance of test case generation, as measured by evaluation metrics showing improvements in test coverage, defect detection rate, execution time, precision, recall, and a reduction in the false positive rate. The proposed method reduces human labor and speeds up the testing process while retaining accuracy and effectiveness. Finally, deal with the potential for merging advanced deep learning models with large language models (LLMs) to refine automated test case production and increase software quality.

title: A Solar-Powered Smart Dustbin with Integrated Air Purifier and IOT- Based Real Time Monitoring System
authors: Riya Phull, Puneet Rathi, Rajan, Rahul Jha, Purnendu Shekhar Pandey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: With cities expanding at an ever-increasing rate and the number of people in urban centres increasing even further, efficient waste management is among the key challenges in building smart, sustainable cities. Traditional waste collection practices fail - as bins overflow and conditions become unhygienic, with increased operations cost on the inefficient routes. In order to solve this, our research presents a HSM which is a hybrid smart dustbin system that will make waste management smarter, cleaner, and more energy-efficient.Using IoT technology, the system monitors bin fill levels in real time using ultrasonic sensors. It also includes global system for mobile communication module GSM. As the container fills up to its maximum level, the system will automatically notify the control centre that the bin is full. At the same time, it sends an SMS alert to the assigned driver for garbage collection with the exact bin details that should be attended to immediately. This prompt notification mechanism ensures that waste is removed in time avoiding overflow. The solution is helpful in minimizing unnecessary pickups and fuel consumption hence reducing both environmental and economic costs.Besides waste level monitoring, the system is equipped with an air purification feature that triggers under the presence of dust or odor – enhancing the surrounding hygiene and air quality around the bin. Powered by a AQI sensor and a 12V fan which is controlled through a relay module and controlled by an ESP32 microcontroller. A small LCD display with indications of system status on the spot, and everything is powered from a solar battery providing independence from external sources and the absence of the load on the environment.This paper describes the design of the system, its hardware elements, and logic of its communication. The results demonstrate that our smart dustbin not only increases the efficiency of waste collection, but also improves the cleanliness of urban areas — practical and scalable solution for smart cities.

title: Hybrid Power-Frequency Multiple Access for SIC-Free Ambient Backscatter Communication in IoT Networks
authors: Mui Van Nguyen, Sang-Quang Nguyen, Anh Le Thi, Quy Duc Hoang, Thuan Dinh Tran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel hybrid power-frequency multiple access (HPMA) framework for enabling successive interference cancellation (SIC)-free ambient backscatter communication in low-power Internet-of-Things (IoT) networks. Unlike conventional non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) systems that require SIC at receivers, the proposed HPMA design leverages both orthogonal and non-orthogonal subcarriers to allow multiple users to coherently combine their signals without interference cancellation. A passive backscatter device (BD) modulates information onto a carrier emitted by a base station, reflecting both user-specific and superposed signals to end users. We develop a unified analytical model under Nakagami-m fading and derive exact closed-form expressions for outage probability and throughput using the Meijer G-function. Asymptotic analysis further reveals the system’s diversity behavior and the impact of bandwidth and power allocation. Simulation results validate the theoretical findings and demonstrate that HPMA achieves significantly better performance than NOMA in terms of outage and throughput, especially in the low-to-moderate SNR regime. The proposed scheme offers a promising solution for SIC-free, energy-efficient, and spectrally efficient communication in large-scale IoT deployments.

title: Evaluating Conversion Loss of a Self-Resonant Patch-Type Harmonic Transponder
authors: Milan Polivka, Milan Svanda
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents the evaluation of the conversion loss (CL) of a novel self-resonant dual-band differentially fed dual quarter-wave harmonic transponder antenna of dimensions <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${81} \times {10.7} \times {0.76} \text{mm}^{3}$</tex> loaded by a Schottky diode HSMS 2820 operating at frequencies <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$f_{0}={1} \text{GHz}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 f_{0}={2}\text{GHz}$</tex>. We explain the setting up of the antenna operating modes to achieve selfresonant behavior, which provides an input impedance complex conjugate to the diode impedance without the need for external matching elements. The CL of the diode is calculated from the measured power balance, which includes the radiation efficiency of the antenna and the transmission coefficient between the antenna and the diode impedance. The result is compared with the analytical value of the diode CL.

title: Investigation of Power Levels and Phase Variations from Interference between Bi-Static Ambient Backscattered and Direct Signals in 5G-NR Free Space Scenario
authors: Sahbi Baccar, Mariem Lefki, Moni Sankar Saha, Hanen Shall, Moncef Kadi, Mohamed Ghorbel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper addresses several key challenges in bistatic ambient backscatter communication (AmBC) regarding the direct path interference (DPI) problem, contributing to both theoretical insight and practical feasibility. To predict the power of the backscattered signal (BS) from the total power in the presence of an interfering direct signal without using complex signal processing algorithms, a power-centric theoretical model based on the phase difference of the interference between the AmBC signal and the direct signal (DS) is proposed for 5 G-NR free space. As a first approach, only a direct continuous wave (CW) signal at 3.5 GHz was considered. Knowing the BS power level is important for estimating the potential AmBC range. Knowing the ratio of AmBC power to the direct signal power (in dB) is also important for a robust reception of the AmBC signal without interfering with the active communication systems. Predicting this ratio allows to check if AmBC could co-exist with active communication by examining the interference at the legacy receiver (LR).

title: PoliBERT: Dynamic Computation Allocation via Policy Networks
authors: Vishnunand Pillai, Mubashir Ahmed Farooqui, Darsh Tibrewal, Gokul Raj Rajasekaran
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: The computational burden associated with transformer architectures like BERT presents obstacles for deployment in resource-constrained environments. Contemporary compression methodologies primarily employ uniform compression strategies across diverse input instances, neglecting the inherent variability in computational requirements among different examples. In this paper, we present a distinct example-aware adaptive layer pruning framework that dynamically orchestrates transformer layer selection contingent upon input complexity characteristics. Our methodology incorporates a compact policy network architecture that generates binary activation masks for individual layers, allowing for personalized computational resource allocation per input instance. Through the implementation of differentiable Gumbel-Sigmoid relaxation mechanisms, we enable end-to-end optimization protocols while preserving classification accuracy. Comprehensive empirical evaluation on the Stanford Sentiment Treebank (SST-2) corpus demonstrates our approach achieving 93.0% classification accuracy while utilizing just 3.81 layers on average from the complete 12-layer architecture, yielding a substantial 3.15 × compression ratio. This methodology outperforms established compression techniques including DistilBERT, TinyBERT, and conventional static pruning approaches, establishing a superior equilibrium between accuracy preservation and computational efficiency in BERT compression paradigms.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Federated Learning: A Smart Contract-Based Architecture for Decentralized AI Systems
authors: Pragya Singh, Aditi Sharma, Mukul Aggarwal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) development in all major fields including healthcare, finance, and intelligent infrastructure raised the need for private, transparent, and secure learning systems. Federated Learning (FL) addresses data privacy by enabling parties to cooperate to train machine learning models without sharing their raw data; however, conventional FL paradigms are based on central aggregators, which introduce vulnerabilities such as single points of failure, decreased transparency, and trust issues among the cooperating parties. This work proposes a novel theoretical framework that integrates blockchain, smart contracts, and Federated Learning to develop a fully decentralized, secure, and auditable AI training platform where smart contracts manage major processes like model aggregation, verification, and reward distribution, disentangling third-party coordination. Blockchain is used as an immutable ledger that openly keeps track of all the updates to the models and participant behavior, enhancing auditability and building trust. The design further incorporates a token- based reward system that will be used to incentivize honest behavior and discourage malicious behavior, addressing root problems of data poisoning and free- riding. This decentralized approach not only improves data confidentiality and system resilience but also promotes fairness and accountability in multi- stakeholder settings. By conceptual analysis and theoretical modeling, the paper lays the foundation for an ethical and scalable AI system that takes advantage of the strengths of Federated Learning, blockchain, and smart contracts, which is a key step towards decentralized intelligence without compromising privacy, integrity, or trust.

title: Ultrafast Tunable Photonic Integrated Pockels Extended-DBR Laser
authors: Simone Bianconi, Anat Siddharth, Zheru Qiu, Rui N. Wang, Mohammad J. Bereyhi, Johann Riemensberger, Tobias J. Kippenberg
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate a hybrid integrated frequency-agile laser based on an InP gain chip and an extended electro-optic Bragg waveguide reflector manufactured with a wafer-scale lithium niobate-oninsulator process featuring 10 GHz tuning range with high optical output power of more than 10 mW and kilohertz linewidth. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Wireless Millimeter-Wave Electro-Optic Modulators on Thin-Film Lithium Niobate
authors: Aleksei Gaier, Karen Mamian, Yazan Lampert, Shima Rajabali, Leticia Magalhaes, Amirhassan Shams-Ansari, Marko Loncar, Ileana-Cristina Benea-Chelmus
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)

title: Photonic Switching for Dynamic Bandwidth Sharing in Optically Networked Heterogeneous Computing Systems
authors: Dae-Ub Kim, Sang-Rok Moon, Jongtae Song, Jyung Chan Lee, Sanghwa Yoo, Kwang Koog Lee, Joon Ki Lee

The key enablers are photonic switches with a switching time of -250ns, CXL with optical interface, and controller. We verified key features including optical bandwidth sharing for chip-to-chip interconnection above Tbps.

title: Real-Time Fake News Detection Using NLP and Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Zeynep Selcen Doğan, İsmail Şeker, Meltem Çap, Alpay Doruk, Özgü Özkan, Ali Berkol
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: In today’s digital era,iInformation spreads quickly on social media and online platforms in the current digital era. This makes it more difficult to discern reliable sources from fake content, which promotes the spread of fake news even as it makes communication easier. The public is misled by such disinformation, which also erodes confidence in trustworthy media. This study uses Deep Learning and Natural Language Processing to create a real-time fake news detection system. The dataset includes 10,000 news articles, evenly divided between real and fake, each containing a title and full text to capture linguistic and semantic patterns. The system uses a pre-trained language model called BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) to process text. Tokenizing and transforming articles into contextual embeddings makes it possible to identify minute syntactic and semantic variations. The detection framework combines dropout regularization (50%) and BERT with fully connected layers (64 neurons, tanh activation). Binary classification is carried out by a sigmoid layer. Training employs learning rate reduction, early stopping, batch size of 100, and a learning rate of 1 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−5</sup>. Accuracy, ROC-AUC, Precision-Recall curves, Cohen’s Kappa, Matthews Correlation Coefficient, Brier Score, and Log Loss are all included in the thorough model evaluation. Word clouds and subject distributions are examples of visualizations that draw attention to the linguistic distinctions between fake and real news. The hybrid framework, which blends content-based analysis with potentially context-aware analysis (e.g., source credibility and propagation), is a significant contribution. The two-pronged strategy significantly increases the reliability of early detection by both preventing misinformation and protecting the integrity of digital ecosystems.

title: Wind Turbine Fault Detection Technology: Patent Analysis and Development Trends
authors: Shao Yuan, Yierxiati Asihaer, Xie Lirong
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper analyzes patents in wind turbine fault diagnosis technology using data from the Incopat and Innojoy platforms. It explores technological development and innovation trends, noting that while markets in developed regions like Europe, the U.S., and Japan are stabilizing with declining patent activity, China shows significant growth potential. Leading companies are expanding patent layouts and transferring technology to emerging markets, with Chinese enterprises working to bridge gaps in technology and patents. The paper investigates application trends, regional distribution, major applicants, and key technological components, identifying research hotspots and challenges. Methods include patent retrieval, text analysis, and trend forecasting, aiming to highlight technical gaps and research deficiencies. The study offers theoretical support and practical guidance for advancing wind turbine fault diagnosis, contributing to the growth of China’s wind power industry.

title: Real-Time Seizure Detection and Prediction in Epilepsy Patients Using Deep Neural Networks on EEG Signals
authors: Meenakshi Sharma, Ramnedra Singh, Vinish Kumar, Bakshish Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The objective of this work is real-time seizure prediction and detection in patients with epilepsy utilizing deep neural networks on EEG (electroencephalogram) signals. Epileptic seizures are unstable and have considerable health implications, so early diagnosis is essential to enable timely action. For that purpose, the hybrid deep learning method that involved Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks was examined. Four state-of-the-art CNN-LSTM-based models ChronoNet, CNN-LSTM, EEGNet + LSTM, and ConvLSTM were implemented to extract both spatial and temporal patterns in EEG signals. A total of 3,200 EEG recordings were gathered from several participants over six months, with a series of experiments conducted in controlled clinical settings. The EEG signals were preprocessed with denoising, normalization, segmentation, and feature extraction to make them ready for model training. Each of the models was trained and tested to identify EEG patterns into interictal (normal), preictal (prior to seizure), and ictal (during) states. All of these performances were measured through accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, AUC-ROC, and confusion matrices. Amongst all the models, ChronoNet performed the best with accuracy as 98.76% and AUC-ROC as 0.997, making it the most suitable model to deploy in real-time. This study illustrates the capability of deep learning to provide accurate, efficient, and automatic seizure prediction in wearable and clinical monitoring systems.

title: Feature Extraction from Sheet Metal Parts Using Semantic Segmentation
authors: Gül Sığındı, Ali Kılıç, Sadettin Kapucu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The analysis of sheet metal is crucial in determining the features of cut metal parts, performing quality control, and optimizing production. This study offers a new approach to extracting and analyzing the features of sheet metal parts. First, the metal parts are manually separated from the background, creating a clean dataset. Next, semantic segmentation methods are applied to accurately identify the different components and features of the metal parts. Using machine learning techniques, this segmentation enables accurate determination of the features of metal parts. The extracted features include metrics like maximum area, aspect ratio, rectangularity, elongation ratio, perimeter length, circularity, thinness ratio, and the lengths of the longest and shortest axes. These features can be used later to determine similarity rates between original and machined metal parts. These techniques play a key role in improving quality control and operational efficiency in sheet metal production. By analyzing the accuracy of feature extraction and comparison, they ensure more reliable and accurate outcomes. This method provides an analysis of metal part features and helps refine manufacturing processes.

title: Weather-Based Smart IoT Irrigation System with AI-Driven Decision Making
authors: Priyanka Tiwari, Shivani Verma, Narendra Singh, Yojna Arora, Princy Diwan, Gaurav Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The paper presents the design, implementation, and evaluation of a novel IoT-based smart irrigation system that combines soil moisture sensing, real-time weather data, artificial intelligence, and cloud monitoring to tackle water waste in agriculture. The system is built around the ESP8266 microcontroller, which collects data from soil sensors and connects to the OpenWeatherMap API to make smart irrigation decisions based on both current soil conditions and predicted rainfall. ThingSpeak is integrated to create a user-friendly dashboard that farmers can access remotely through a web interface. When the system as tested against traditional methods, it was found that AI-enhanced approach cut water consumption by 27-40%, while the machine learning algorithms continuously improved irrigation scheduling by learning from historical patterns. This research offers a practical contribution to sustainable farming through an affordable, scalable solution that boosts crop yields while using significantly less water.

title: Interval Principal Component Analysis for Fault Detection of Wastewater Treatment Processes with Uncertainty
authors: Meng Zhou, ZhuoZhou Zhao, Jing Wang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In practical industrial processes, measurement data collected from various sensors are often contaminated by uncertainty due to measurement noise and unknown disturbances. These uncertainties introduce undesirable spikes into the process data, which can significantly impact subsequent fault detection. To overcome this problem, this study develops an improved interval principal component analysis (PCA) fault detection approach capable of handling data uncertainty. First, Uncertain single-valued data are transformed into interval representations using sensor manufacturer–specified error bounds to better capture their underlying characteristics. Second, an improved interval PCA method is designed, which integrates multiple algorithms to obtain the smallest possible interval eigenvalues. Using the obtained interval eigenvalues and eigenvectors, high-dimensional interval data are projected onto a lower-dimensional space for feature extraction. Finally, four monitoring statistics are established to assess process states and identify faults. Simulation experiments on the BSM1 benchmark indicate that the proposed method outperforms existing techniques in fault detection.

title: A Spatial-Temporal Convolutional Network for Remaining Useful Life Prediction of Turbofan Engines
authors: Wenxiao Yin, Zhibin Huang, Chuanfang Zhang, Qiang Min, Ruihua Jiao
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The prediction of Remaining Useful Life (RUL) is integral to maintaining operational reliability and preventing catastrophic failures within industrial systems. While the application of deep learning has yielded significant advancements in this domain, present models mostly adopt RNNs or combined model methods for prediction. In this article, we propose a spatial-temporal convolutional network(STCN) to predict the RUL of aircraft engines based on data from multiple sensors. This model extracts the spatial-temporal features of the input sequence from three dimensions: variable, feature and time series. Empirical validation on the C-MAPSS benchmark dataset confirms the efficacy of the STCN approach. The methodology achieves an average Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 13.73 and an average scoring of 697.87.

title: Unsupervised Learning-Based Joint Beamforming and Far User Clustering for Near-Field Massive MIMO-NOMA Systems
authors: Ngo Minh Nghia, Nguyen Dung, Nguyen Thi Xuan Uyen, Nguyen Van Dieu, Pham Hoai An, Dang Le Khoa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper presents an integrated convolutional neural network (CNN) and residual network (ResNet) architecture for near-field beamforming and far-user clustering with power allocation (BFPA-Net) based on unsupervised learning in massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) downlink systems. In high-frequency carrier scenarios, such as millimeter wave (mmWave), several users may operate in the near-field region. Then, the beamforming is designed for near-field users and can transmit information to far-field users using the NOMA technique. Recently, machine learning approaches have been explored to enhance beamforming performance; however, their application to pairing and power allocation for far-field users in near-field massive MIMO-NOMA systems remains underexplored. In this study, we propose an integrated model not only for beamforming but also for far-field users that pairs with near-field users. The simulation results show that the proposed approach improves the average data rate for far-field users to approximately 2.19 bps/Hz compared to Greedy-Branch and Bound (BB), while maintaining the data rate of nearfield users at a predefined level.

title: Comparative Analysis of MOSFET and BJT Switching Devices in Boost Converter Applications
authors: Abdullah Hamadi, Md Shahin Alam, Shima Afshar, S. Ali Arefifar
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of MOSFET and BJT switching devices in a DC–DC boost converter operated over the 20–100 kHz range. Both devices are evaluated under identical operating conditions to isolate the influence of switching frequency on converter performance. Analytical models for conduction, drive, and switching losses are established, and results are verified experimentally using time-domain waveforms and thermal measurements. Normalized performance indices are introduced to combine efficiency, thermal behavior, and output ripple into a composite score. The MOSFET consistently obtains outstanding indices over the studied frequency range, with a composite score hovering around 0.8 and peaking at 0.84 at 50kHz. In contrast, the BJT composite score drops from 0.34 at 20 kHz to 0.19 at 100 kHz, indicating storage-dominated turn-off loss and constant base-drive power consumption. Switching energy tests show that the MOSFET decreases dynamic loss by 74-78% compared to the BJT, resulting in a smaller thermal increase. Harmonic spectrum research indicates that the MOSFET has lower distortion and better ripple shaping as well. The findings indicate that MOSFETs are the preferred devices for boost converters operating above 50 kHz, offering a more favorable trade-off among efficiency, thermal stability, and harmonic performance.

title: Emotional AI and Adaptive user Interfaces
authors: Arnav Khadkatkar, Rashmi Rane, Surab Sebait, Marasanapalle Kalle Chidrupee, Abubakar Siddiq AbdulKhadar Hunchalkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Adaptive User Interfaces (AUI) and Emotional AI advance human-computer interaction by allowing computers to identify and dynamically adapt according to user states. Emotional AI uses Facial Emotion Recognition (FER), Speech Emotion Recognition (SER), sentiment analysis, and EEG-based emotion tracking for understanding user states, while AUI adapts layouts, contents, and operations in real-time. Both are used widely for applications in the healthcare, educational, virtual space, and customer service domains. Even with progress, issues like emotional recognition bias, privacy, real-time performance constraints, and ethical threats need to be resolved. Multimodal emotion detection, privacy-enhancing AI, and cross-cultural emotional intelligence will be the focus of future research to provide equitable, secure, and adaptive user experiences. Emotional AI and AUI continue to influence more intelligent and responsive systems with the integration of explainable AI.

title: Efficient Task Offloading in Edge Computing Using Priority Based Queuing and Energy Optimisation
authors: Satvik Tiwari, Zaineb Naaz, Vidushi Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The rapid growth of IoT devices has increased the demand for efficient computational technology. While cloud computing offers vast resources, its centralised structure causes high latency, network congestion and unreliable connectivity, making it unsuitable for real time applications like autonomous vehicles, industrial automation and smart healthcare. Edge computing solves these issues by processing data closer to users but limited resources at edge nodes lead to congestion, increased energy consumption and task queuing. To address this issue this paper presents a priority based task offloading model using an M/M/1 queuing system to optimise task execution. The model prioritise high priority tasks and distributes normal tasks across other Edge nodes based on their energy levels and queue lengths. An energy aware offloading mechanism is introduced with energy regeneration which allows Edge nodes to recover energy during inactive periods which enhances system longevity. MATLAB based simulations evaluate performance metrics like waiting time, packet loss and energy consumption. Results shows a 92.65% reduction in task waiting time, zero packet drops and improved energy efficiency compared to random selection models. The proposed model enhances system responsiveness and optimise energy which makes it highly suitable for real time applications that demand low latency and reliability.

title: Parity Space-Based Fault Detectability Analysis for Linear Discrete Time-Varying Systems
authors: Yang Song, Yijia Lu, Longlong Liu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper develops a fault detectability assessment method for linear discrete time-varying (LDTV) systems based on parity space schemes. Using the time-varying system matrices, the parity equation is constructed. Then, the assessment indices of fault detectability are introduced using Euclidean distance for system analysis, where prior information on actuator and sensor faults are taken into account. Furthermore, an optimization strategy based on an H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−</inf> / H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">∞</inf> function is introduced to design the parity space-based residuals. Based on this, a residual-based measures are proposed to analyze the detection performance. These two indices support the evaluation of detection performance, which can provide guidance for determining the parameters of the parity space-based diagnosis approaches. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is validated through simulations on the flight control system of an unmanned automotive vehicle (UAV).

title: The Need for a Compact, User-friendly Battery Simulator for Research
authors: Ömer Arda Özdemir, Deniz Arslan, Havin Karabulut, Serhan Özdemir
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Battery simulators have become one of the main tools in design, testing and validation for almost all of the battery-operated devices, appliances, machines, and last but not least, electric vehicles. Simulator products from various manufacturers have been known for a while. The common denominator for almost all of these devices is that they require a specific interface,/or a coding environment, and/or specific training to exploit these simulators to their full extent. The need for a rapid implementation of battery simulators into research, development, testing or validation without specific device-specific training has obviously become a must. Some of the current products are to be discussed, and a design and control mentality to this end is to be presented.

title: Privacy by Design: User-Centric Control in Online Photo Sharing
authors: Shivani Joshi, Palak Gupta, Rajiv Kumar, Avinash Dwivedi, Sudheer Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: In today’s digital world, where social media is a big part of everyday life, protecting personal privacy is more important than ever—especially when it comes to sharing photos. This paper takes a closer look at how people share images online and how much control they really have over who sees them. It reviews how current privacy settings work on popular platforms, pointing out both their useful features and their limitations. The study also explores newer privacy tools like advanced settings, encryption methods, and systems built around user consent. By analyzing how users think, behave, and what concerns they have, the paper sheds light on the growing awareness around online privacy. It also touches on the responsibilities of social media companies to protect user data and the real-life effects of privacy violations.

title: Design of Broadband Aperture-Stacked Patch Microstrip Antennas Based on Third Order Filtering Equivalent Circuits
authors: Ignacio M. Delgado-Lozano, Rafael R. Boix, Vicente Losada, Armando Fernández-Prieto
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: In this paper the authors describe the design of a broadband aperture-stacked patch (ASP) microstrip antenna based on a filtering equivalent circuit. The antenna consists of two stacked microstrip patches that are fed by a microstrip line through a resonant aperture. An equivalent circuit is proposed for the antenna consisting of three LC parallel resonators, out of which two resonators are inductively coupled and two resonators are capacitively coupled. The equivalent circuit is de-embedded from the antenna response by means of the least squares method, and the dimensions of the antenna are adjusted in such a way their equivalent circuit matches the response of a broadband third order filter. The reference filter is used as a mean to ensure broadband matching of the antenna. Following this design strategy, a broadband ASP antenna has been designed, fabricated and measured at a center frequency of 5.5 GHz with a bandwidth of roughly 45%.

title: Solid-Phase Fraction Computation via Multi-Scale Hybrid Mamba-CNN and ERT Measurement
authors: Ye Wang, Yuchong Zhao, Tao Yu, Zifan Zhao, Shihong Yue
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Solid-phase fraction (SPF) is a critical parameter in solid-liquid two-phase flow, and can be measured using the convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with electrical resistance tomography (ERT) measurements. But CNNs can estimate SPF from the time series of ERT measurements under stable conditions rather than under rapidly changing flow patterns and complex measuring conditions. To address this issue, this study proposes a novel multi-scale hybrid Mamba-CNN model, termed State Space CNN (SSC). Compared with CNNs, the SSC has linear scalability and synergistic integration between global state-space patterns from the Mamba module and local spatiotemporal features from CNNs. Moreover, SSC presents a robust modeling of the complex multi-scale temporal dynamics and conductivity-related ambiguities present in the ERT measurements. Experiments shown that the SSC significantly outperforms existing CNNs, and can achieve a 34.2% re-duction in MAPE (12.3% vs. 18.7%) and a 19.7% reduction in MAE (2.41 vs. 3.05). Consequently, the SSC provides a robust solution for accurate, real-time SPF estimation and enhanced accuracy in dynamic complex measuring conditions.

title: Pre-Training and Personalized Fine-Tuning via Over-the-Air Federated Meta-Learning: Convergence-Generalization Trade-Offs_supp1-3640114.pdf
authors: Hong Xing
publish: N/A
abstract: For modern artificial intelligence (AI) applications such as large language models (LLMs), the training paradigm has recently shifted to pre-training followed by fine-tuning. Furthermore, owing to dwindling open repositories of data and thanks to efforts to democratize access to AI models, pre-training is expected to increasingly migrate from the current centralized deployments to federated learning (FL) implementations. Meta-learning provides a general framework in which pre-training and fine-tuning can be formalized. Meta-learning-based personalized FL (meta-pFL) moves beyond basic personalization by targeting generalization to new agents and tasks. This paper studies the generalization performance of meta-pFL for a wireless setting in which the agents participating in the pre-training phase, i.e., meta-learning, are connected via a shared wireless channel to the server. Adopting over-the-air computing, we study the trade-off between generalization to new agents and tasks, on the one hand, and convergence, on the other hand. The trade-off arises from the fact that channel impairments may enhance generalization, while degrading convergence. Extensive numerical results validate the theory.

title: Daily Load Forecasting Using Explainable AI-Driven Method with Integrated Error Correlation
authors: Ei Thu Thu Tun, Kamal Chapagain, Pyae Pyae Phyo, Yung-Cheol Byun, Vannak Seng, Panharith Chhom, Chawalit Jeenanunta
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents a novel, explainable, and weather-independent day-ahead load forecasting (DALF). The proposed methodology integrates calendar-based segmentation using Classification and Regression Trees (CART), hybrid modeling with Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) and Gaussian Process Regression (GPR), and post-hoc error correction via Generalized Least Squares with Autoregressive Residuals (GLSAR). To enhance interpretability, Shapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) are employed to quantify the influence of lagged load features and calendar variables across segmented forecasts. The framework is evaluated on real-world half-hourly data from the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT), encompassing both regular and holiday-specific load profiles. Experimental results demonstrate that the MLR–GPR–GLSAR configuration achieves superior performance, with a Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) of 0.72% and an R² of 0.99, outperforming Generalized Additive Models (GAM), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGB), Convolutional Long Short-Term Memory (CNN-LSTM), and Neural Hierarchical Interpolation for Time Series (NHITS), as baselines. The proposed framework offers a scalable and interpretable solution for utilities operating in data-sparse environments. These findings affirm the importance of residual autocorrelation correction and calendar-aware segmentation in advancing DALF accuracy and transparency.

title: Joint Beamforming Optimization for User-Centric Multi-Satellite Systems with Backhaul Constraints
authors: Jinsong Yu, Cunqing Hua, Lingya Liu, Pengwenlong Gu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Interference cancellation based on spectrum sharing is a key solution to improve the network performance of multi-satellite systems. In this paper, we investigate a user-centric multi-satellite communication system where users are collaboratively served by multiple satellites. In this system, the integrated access and backhaul (IAB) networks, i.e., the satellite-to-user access network and the gateway-to-satellite backhaul network, are jointly considered. Our objective is to maximize the weighted sum rates (WSR) of all users by jointly optimizing the beamformers of multiple satellites and the gateway while considering the backhaul link constraints. To solve this non-convex optimization problem, a centralized algorithm is developed using the block coordinate update (BCU) method, assuming that global channel state information (CSI) is perfectly known. In addition, a low-complexity distributed algorithm based on multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MA-DRL) is further proposed. This approach offers enhanced flexibility for implementation in multi-satellite systems and adaptability to dynamic environments. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed distributed algorithm based on MA-DRL can achieve a performance almost equivalent to that of the centralized algorithm. It also reveals that the spatial diversity can be fully exploited through the joint beamforming of a multi-satellite system compared with a single-satellite system, while the growing number of satellites makes the backhaul constraint a more critical bottleneck for system capacity.

title: A Reinforcement Learning based FEM Solver for Accelerating Contact-Influenced Simulation of Continuum Robots_supp1-3640425.mp4
authors: Hao Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Continuum robots exhibit exceptional flexibility and multi-degree-of-freedom maneuverability, offering significant advantages for navigating confined luminal spaces. However, rapid simulation of their contact-influenced behavior remains challenging. This paper presents RLFEM, an innovative finite element method (FEM) featuring a reinforcement learning-enhanced quadratic programming solver, specifically designed for efficient continuum robot simulation updates. To address complex robot dynamics, we employ a quasi-static FEM formulation. Our core contribution integrates an accelerated solver scheme within this framework, leveraging reinforcement learning to rapidly resolve FEM contact problems without accuracy compromise. RLFEM exhibits significant gains in runtime performance for continuum robot simulations, as evidenced by numerical experiments showing a 16.20-fold acceleration compared to the baseline at the 150-node discretization level.

title: QBIC-terahertz metasurface for quantitative detection of chlorpyrifos in soybean oil in a liquid state
authors: Fang Wang, Gan Liu, Binggang Xiao, Jianyuan Qin
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Resonances originating from the concept of bound states in the continuum have been shown to produce high quality factors and strong field enhancements. Here, an ultra-sensitive terahertz metallic metasurface based on bound states in the continuum is developed to address the limited sensitivity of terahertz sensing technology. The metasurface employs a u-shaped resonator and a l-shaped resonator as the unit cell, and a resonance around 0.7 THz can be excited. The analysis of the quality factor and the band structure confirm that this resonance is induced by bound states in the continuum mode. Based on the calculations, it can be concluded that the frequency shift changes linearly as a function of analyte thickness within the range of 0 μm to 10 μm, and the sensitivity can be as high as 151 GHz/RIU. The feasibility of the detection of chlorpyrifos concentration in soybean oil is assessed experimentally, and a liquid cell is applied as sample holder to maintain the sample in a liquid state. It can be concluded that the metasurface enables effective detection of chlorpyrifos in soybean oil, with a limit of detection as low as 0.007 mg/L. Our work enables the detection of trace chlorpyrifos in soybean oil, facilitating the application of terahertz technology in food safety.

title: Torsional Vibration Mitigation in Wind Turbines Using BESS in a Microgrid
authors: Yi-Wei Chen, Yuan-Yih Hsu
publish: IEEE Open Access Journal of Power and Energy
abstract: The paper introduces a damping control scheme utilizing a battery energy storage system (BESS) to mitigate torsional vibrations for wind turbine generators (WTGs) in a microgrid. As WTGs are tasked with providing frequency regulation in response to the challenges of low system inertia caused by renewable energy integration, the WTG ancillary frequency controllers can induce undesired torsional vibrations in the drivetrain system. Moreover, WTG torsional vibrations can also be electromechanically excited by grid voltages or mechanically induced by changes in wind speed. To address undesired WTG torsional vibrations, this study proposes a hybrid control scheme that combines linear controller and sliding mode controller (SMC) to mitigate torsional vibrations in WTGs using a BESS. The contribution of the paper lies in extending BESS applications and presenting an efficient control scheme for mitigating WTG torsional vibrations when the microgrid is subjected to unplanned islanding and wind speed variations. Time-domain simulations are conducted to validate the analysis and demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.

title: FPGA-Based Hierarchical Efficient Driving Framework for Multiphase MLPM
authors: Fengqiu Xu, Shun Zhou, Menglong Zou, Yaping Jie, Xianze Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article proposes a hierarchical driving framework for a magnetically levitated planar machine (MLPM) based on an field-programmable gate array (FPGA), which can be easily extended to extend the motion stroke by increasing the number of coils. In the commutation strategy, only the coils underneath the magnet array are energized to reduce the computation burden. The physically constrained data-driven wrench model (PCDWM), considering the end-effects of the coil and magnet array, is introduced in the real-time (RT) control system to distribute the coil current at each control cycle. The H bright circuit driving every coil independently maintains the low cost and high efficiency with the inherent parallelism of the FPGA, promising the synchronous driving of each coil. In the experiments, the constructed prototype realizes a micro-meter positioning resolution. A series of comparative tests highlights the lower power consumption of the driving method and the better motion decoupling performance resulting from the data-driven wrench model (DWM).

title: Impact of Oxide Diffusion Space Effect on 14-nm FinFET Performance and Layout-Driven Optimization for Advanced Digital Circuits
authors: Yafen Yang, Jianbin Guo, Tianyang Feng, David Wei Zhang, Hang Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: With the continuous scaling down of the feature size, the effect of shallow trench isolation (STI) on integrated circuit (IC) performance has become increasingly critical. This study pioneers the systematic investigation of oxide diffusion (OD) space effect (OSE) in 14nm fin field-effect transistor (FinFET) technology, proposing novel layout design strategies through isolation mode and structural optimizations to enhance digital unit performance. The results show significant performance improvements in specific digital units: AOI22V1 (72.33%), NAND3V1 (18.94%), MUX2V1 (13.96%), OAI211V1 (6.90%), OR3V2 (6.43%), and XNOR2V1 (6.41%). Alternating Current (AC) characterization reveals that replacing single diffusion breaks (SDB) with double diffusion breaks (DDB) in inverters improves operating frequency by 13% with a 10% dynamic power tradeoff. This work establishes OSE-aware layout design as an essential paradigm for FinFET optimization in advanced technology nodes.

title: CoFIB: A Memory-Efficient NDN FIB Design for Programmable Edge Switches
authors: Eduardo Castilho Rosa, Daniel Nunes Corujo, Flávio de Oliveira Silva
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Designing high-performance and memory-efficient data structures for the Forwarding Information Base (FIB) in Named-Data Networking (NDN) is a challenging task. Since the FIB size is orders of magnitude larger than IP routing tables, scaling it to store millions of prefixes in SRAM/TCAM memory in programmable switches is an open problem. To address this issue, we propose a Compressed FIB data structure called CoFIB, designed to run on edge programmable switches in an SDNbased environment. The CoFIB is a collection of exact-match tables placed in an optimized manner in both ingress and egress pipelines. We propose a LNPM algorithm that carefully recirculates packets in the pipeline. We also introduce the concept of canonical name prefixes to reduce memory footprint and propose an algorithm to extract canonical prefixes from the Routing Information Base (RIB). Experimental results show that CoFIB can compress memory up to 16.58× compared to the state-of-the-art, with no significant impact on throughput compared to hardware-based solutions. Additionally, our proposed table placement optimization for LNPM increases the number of packets processed at a line rate by 23.17% compared to the linear table placement approach using a large NDN name dataset.

title: A Behavioral Model for Pulse Current Analysis of Series-connected Thyristors
authors: Pengcheng Xing, Qingbo Wan, Jie Huang, Heng Zhang, Xudong Zhu, Binghui Li, Kai Wang, Xiaochen Shen, Zhihua Zhang, Liang Shi, Ruize Sun, Chao Liu, Wanjun Chen, Bo Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: High-power pulse systems often require stacking multiple thyristors in series to withstand high operating voltage, yet the optimal number of devices for maximizing pulse performance has remained unclear. This work develops a behavioral model for the pulse current in series-connected thyristors that links device-level conductivity modulation with circuit-level behavior. First, the drift region resistance of thyristors under high-current pulse conditions is characterized, accounting for drift region conductivity modulation in devices of different voltage ratings. This device behavior is then incorporated into a RLC discharge circuit model to derive analytical expressions for key pulse parameters, including the peak current (Ipeak) and current rise rate (di/dt). The model reveals how increasing the number of series-connected thyristors can strengthen conductivity modulation and reduce the drift region resistance, thereby improving Ipeak and di/dt up to an optimal point. Simulation and experimental validations are presented for various operating voltages and configurations. The results show that the proposed model predicts the pulse current waveform and performance metrics for different series counts, matching measured waveforms closely. The model, for the first time, provides a quantitative design tool for high-voltage, highcurrent pulse power systems, and offers guidance on determining an optimal number of series-connected thyristors to achieve the best pulse performance.

title: Dynamic Temperature Prediction of the Magnetic Coupler in Wireless Charging Systems
authors: Xianzhen Li, Zhenjie Li, Dechun Yuan, Yabiao Zhao, Mingfei Ban, Yiqi Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: As the core component of wireless charging systems (WCS), the magnetic coupler usually accounts for a significant proportion of total system power losses, resulting in substantial cumulative temperature rise. This article proposes a multi-point dynamic temperature prediction method for magnetic couplers, integrating multiphysics finite element simulation with a deep learning algorithm to achieve real-time, accurate prediction of temperature variations under ambient temperature fluctuations, coil misalignment, and continuous charging conditions. First, an electromagnetic-thermal coupled model is constructed using the finite element method to generate temperature datasets under various operating conditions. Then, the random forest algorithm analyzed the influence of input parameters on temperature predictions at different timesteps, screening key variables as model inputs. A dynamic temperature prediction model combines long short-term memory (LSTM) networks with a temporal self-attention mechanism. Finally, the model outputs show that the method outperforms conventional prediction accuracy and speed approaches. Finally, a 3.3 kW experimental prototype was built to simulate continuous charging scenarios under varying coil misalignment conditions, with real-time temperature acquisition at key locations of the magnetic coupler. Experimental results show average prediction errors of 5.7%, validating the correctness of the proposed method.

title: Fault Diagnosis of Photovoltaic Systems Based on Multi-Digital Twins and SWIN-T
authors: Yiming Shi, Yongsheng Qi, Yongting Li
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Photovoltaic systems are susceptible to faults caused by variations in product quality and environmental factors, making fault diagnosis essential for ensuring reliability. The limited availability and uneven distribution of fault samples pose significant challenges to data-driven models. This paper presents a data augmentation method that combines mechanism simulation with a one-dimensional denoising diffusion probabilistic model (1D-DDPM) and integrates it with an Efficient Spatial Attention Mechanism (ESAM) enhanced Swin-Transformer (Swin-T) for fault diagnosis. A multi-twin model is developed to expand the dataset and enhance diversity. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed 1D-DDPM exhibits strong generative performance. When combined with the ESAM-enhanced Swin-Transformer (ESAM-Swin-T), the model achieves a fault recognition accuracy of 97.5%, underscoring its effectiveness in advancing intelligent operation and maintenance systems for photovoltaic applications.
