authors: Susumu Noda, Takuya Inoue, Shota Ishimura
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Photonic-crystal surface-emitting lasers (PCSELs) feature high-power single-mode lasing with narrow spectral linewidths, which are potentially suitable for long-distance free-space optical communications (FSO) such as intersatellite optical communications. In this paper, we review our recent devel-opment of PCSELs for high-power high-speed FSO communications.

title: A Quadratically Interpolated and Minimum-Mean-Square-Error-Optimized Pre-rake Receiver for Multipath Channel
authors: Aoba Morimoto, Ryotaro Ishihara, Naoki Omi, Haruki Inoue, Riku Sato, Mone Kasahara, Jaesang Cha, Chang-Jun Ahn, Incheol Jeong
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: Pre-rake processing is a pre-filtering technique implemented at the transmitter. This method pre-aligns the transmitted signal with the anticipated characteristics of the wireless multipath channel, thereby simplifying the receiver’s design. This method is particularly effective in time division duplex (TDD) direct-sequence code division multiple access (DS/CDMA) systems, where it leverages channel reciprocity. However, an inherent asymmetry exists between the uplink and downlink channel responses in Time Division Duplex (TDD) systems. This lack of channel reciprocity can degrade the performance of pre-rake processing, leading to suboptimal results in certain scenarios. To overcome this limitation, we propose a hybrid approach that combines a matched filter-based rake receiver with multiplexed pre-rake filters to improve the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Although symbol multiplexing introduces inter-symbol interference (ISI), this interference can be effectively suppressed using a minimum mean square error (MMSE) filter. Furthermore, the accuracy of channel estimation, critical to the performance of pre-rake filtering, can be significantly enhanced by employing linear or quadratic interpolation methods, enabling more robust prefilter design even under high Doppler frequency conditions. Simulation results show that the proposed system improves bit error rate (BER) performance compared to conventional approaches, particularly in rapidly varying channel environments.

title: Rolling bearing fault diagnosis based on improved VMD optimized CNN-GRU neural network
authors: Zhang Bangcheng, Hu Bowen, Li Bo, Song Jingyuan, Yin Yungao, Gao Zhi, Chen Hongrui, Zhang Dingyuan
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To address the challenge of identifying early rolling bearing faults under complex operating conditions, this paper proposes a hybrid VMD-CNN-GRU model optimized using the Osprey-Cauchy-Sparrow search algorithm (OCSSA). First, we design the OCSSA algorithm by integrating the global optimization capability of the Ospreys Search with the local perturbation mechanism of Cauchy mutation, enabling adaptive optimization of both the penalty factor and mode number in variational mode decomposition (VMD). This effectively mitigates modal aliasing issues. Subsequently, an end-to-end deep diagnostic framework is constructed to extract the time-frequency fusion features of the decomposed signals using CNNs and introduce gated recurrent units (GRUs) to model long-term dependencies in the sequences, thereby improving the recognition of weak fault features. Experimental validation on the Case Western Reserve University (CWRU) bearing dataset demonstrates the superiority of the proposed model over benchmark methods,achieving 99.67% fault recognition accuracy and 3.92-second diagnostic latency, which highlights its strong generalization capability and engineering applicability.

title: A voltage correlation correction based robust detection and location method for internal short-circuit faults of lithium-ion batteries
authors: Kaitao Chen, Guang Wang, Jianfang Jiao, Shen Yin
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Internal short circuits (ISCs) in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) typically exhibit continuous, subtle, and unpredictable early characteristics, making them increasingly difficult to monitor under cell inconsistency and low-quality data conditions. To address this challenge, a robust diagnosis scheme based on voltage correlation compensation and kernel independent component analysis (KICA) is proposed. First, a modified correlation coefficient and KICA-based abnormal sample separation strategy is designed to extract normal samples affected by cell inconsistency. Then, the voltage relative slopes between each cell voltage and the reference voltage are updated based on the normal samples. Within each interval, the voltages are corrected using the updated voltage relative slopes, and the residuals between the corrected and reference voltages are further modeled using the KICA model to detect ISC faults. Finally, the faulty cell is identified and located using a cumulative relative partial contribution rate method. Experimental results on a real LIB pack platform demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits strong adaptability under conditions of cell inconsistency and poor data quality.

title: Rationale-Guided Retrieval: Fusing Multimodal Chain-of-Thought and Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Grounded Reasoning
authors: Ankush Rastogi, Vanchhit Khare
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have demonstrated significant capabilities in processing and interpreting complex, real-world information that spans text, images, audio, and video. However, they often struggle with tasks requiring deep, verifiable reasoning, particularly when external knowledge is needed. Existing Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) Systems can fetch relevant information but lack a sophisticated mechanism to synthesize it through a transparent reasoning process. Concurrently, Multimodal Chain-of-Thought (MCoT) Methods generate reasoning steps but often hallucinate information not present in the provided context. This paper introduces a novel architecture that synergistically integrates these two paradigms. Our system employs a dynamic, rationale-guided retrieval process where the intermediate reasoning steps generated by an MCoT module actively refine subsequent queries for the RAG component. This iterative loop between reasoning and retrieval allows the model to dynamically seek and ground its thought process in high-precision, contextually relevant information. Our experimental results on the ScienceQA and A-OKVQA benchmarks show that this architecture significantly outperforms traditional unimodal and multimodal models in both accuracy and the faithfulness of its generated explanations.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Risk Prediction of Anemia Disease: Bioinformatics Scoping Review
authors: George Pena, Jose Cornejo, Silvia Rodriguez
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Anemia and other hematological disorders represent a major global health burden, affecting over 1.6 billion people, particularly women and children. These conditions are often underdiagnosed due to limited access to diagnostic resources and medical infrastructure. In recent times, Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become a valuable tool for the prediction and identification of such disorders using structured clinical data, hematological parameters, and medical imaging through techniques like Deep Learning and Machine Learning. This review systematically analyzes studies published between 2019 and 2025 that applied AI methods to predict or classify anemia and associated disorders. Research articles in English were retrieved from databases such as Scopus, PubMed, and ScienceDirect, with 25 relevant studies selected based on defined inclusion criteria using the PICOC framework. Findings show that AI models often achieve high performance, with accuracy frequently exceeding 80 percent, and strong sensitivity and specificity. Supervised learning approaches were the most applied and consistently effective. Despite these promising results, challenges remain in clinical validation, data variability, and model interpretability. This review highlights the growing role of AI in medical diagnostics and underscores the necessity for strong, transparent, and widely models for reliable use in the clinical environment.

title: Enhanced Model Predictive Control for Hybrid Energy Storage Systems in Microgrids Using ESO for Real-Time Disturbance Compensation
authors: Zhonghua Liu, Wei Li, Weiyi Wang, Yupeng Luo, Yanyu Zhang, Xibeng Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Hybrid Energy Storage Systems (HESS) coordinate the operation of batteries and supercapacitors, enabling rapid energy absorption and release in microgrids. By effectively smoothing fluctuations between renewable generation and load demand, they ensure a stable and reliable power supply. Consequently, efficient control strategies for HESS are critical to enhancing overall microgrid performance. Model Predictive Control (MPC), with its ability to handle multivariable constraints and predict future behavior, has demonstrated excellent performance in HESS control. However, conventional MPC typically assumes that the battery voltage remains constant throughout the prediction horizon, leading to accumulated model errors and inaccurate predictions. To address this issue, this paper proposes an Extended State Observer Model Predictive Control (ESO-MPC) method. In this approach, the unmodeled battery voltage dynamics are treated as an unknown disturbance, with ESO used for real-time estimation and compensation, thereby updating the system state and improving control accuracy. Simulation results show that the ESO-MPC method significantly reduces DC bus voltage ripple and battery current ripple in an HESS microgrid, thus enhancing system stability and power quality.

title: Outlier-Aware Road Traffic Speed Estimation: A Comparative Framework for Detection and Modeling Techniques
authors: Garima Rathi, Shailesh Kamble, Nonita Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Outliers in road traffic data have a significant impact on speed estimation models, resulting in inaccurate traffic analysis and misguided planning decisions. This paper presents a comparative framework for detecting and mitigating outliers in traffic datasets using statistical, density-based, and machine learning methods. By injecting synthetic anomalies into traffic simulations, we evaluate the impact of outlier removal on downstream speed modeling. The proposed pipeline integrates outlier detection with speed estimation through regression and smoothing models. Key contributions include a unified empirical evaluation of six detection techniques, robust speed recovery using regression models, and a replicable methodology for anomaly-aware traffic speed estimation. The results validate that managing anomalies enhances model accuracy and reliability, offering practical insights for intelligent transportation systems.

title: An Enhanced Hybrid Deep Learning Architecture for Android Malware Detection Using CFG and DeepWalk Embeddings
authors: Mohammad Sarwar Hossain Mollah, Mohd Fadzli Bin Marhusin, Syaril Nizam Omar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Android malware propagation poses increasing security risks to mobile ecosystems, with conventional detection techniques fighting an uphill battle against advanced evasion strategies and polymorphic variants that take advantage of static analysis limitations. Existing approaches including signature-based detection and conventional machine learning techniques have moderate performance against advanced obfuscation techniques and cannot capture complex structural relationships inherent in malicious code execution behavior. These limitations necessitate advanced techniques capable of carrying out in-depth structural analysis and dynamic pattern detection for malware detection. This paper proposes a new hybrid deep learning technique that combines Control Flow Graph (CFG) analysis with Deep Graph Convolutional Neural Networks (DeepGraphCNNs) and Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCN) to overcome current limitations. Our technique meticulously reverse-engineers APK packages, decompiles Dalvik bytecode to extract CFG representations and utilizes sophisticated graph embedding methods (DeepWalk, Node2Vec, Word2Vec) in the feature transformation process. The experiment is conducted on 2,349 samples from CICMalAnal2017 and MalwareBazar. Our DeepWalk-DeepGraphCNNs and TCN model demonstrated superior performance with 95.10% accuracy and 93.67% AUC-ROC. Our experimental results ensure the success of the technique for addressing contemporary Android security issues.

title: 112.5 Gbps PAM4 and 150 Gbps PAM8 Signals for 3.2 Tbps DCI Utilising Off-the-Shelf High Power Fabry-PéRot Laser
authors: Lakshmi Narayanan Venkatasubramani, Ahmed Galib Reza, Liam Barry
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate a record transmission rate of 112.5Gbps PAM4 and 150Gbps PAM8 signals over 1 km and 5 km -SMF for intra-data centre (DC) links employing off-the-shelf Fabry-Pérot laser. Using spatial multiplexing and this <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.2125 \text{pJ} /$</tex> bit energy-efficient laser source, the system can support nextgeneration 3.2T DC optical links. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Development of Machine Learning-based Revenue Forecasting Models for Electronic Payment and Money Institutions
authors: Zehra Sude Sarı, Cem Bezmen, Hasan Hüseyin Yurdagül, Ceren Ulus, M. Fatih Akay
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: In today's economic and technological world, electronic payment and money institutions are among the key players in the rapidly digitizing financial system and are achieving significant transaction volumes. Therefore, financial sustainability and efficient use of resources become more important. In this context, electronic payment and money institutions must be able to forecast their revenues and plan accordingly. Developing revenue forecasting models is a strategic action that significantly contributes to the financial planning processes of electronic payment and money institutions. In this study, models have been developed using machine learning-based Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Categorical Boosting (CatBoost) to forecast the weekly and monthly revenues of an electronic payment and money institution. The study also analyzed the effects of feature selection and lookback (LB) integration on forecasting performance. Revenue forecast models have been developed for two different weeks and two different months. The performance of the developed models has been evaluated by Mean Absolute Percent Error (MAPE). The findings indicated that the SVM and CatBoost models provided comparable results for different months and weeks. Different effects have been observed for LB and FS integrations. This suggests that factors such as seasonality and variability in data patterns should be considered in the model selection process.

title: An Implantable RFID-Controlled Reconfigurable FSS for Securing Cardiac Devices
authors: Francesco Lestini, Fabiola Bassano, Gaetano Marrocco, Cecilia Occhiuzzi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents an implantable, RFIDcontrolled, reconfigurable Frequency Selective Surface (FSS) designed to enhance the cyber-physical security of cardiac Implantable Medical Devices (IMDs) operating in the 2.45 GHz ISM band. The proposed system dynamically modulates its electromagnetic response to selectively block unauthorized wireless access while preserving secure communication with trusted external programmers. The shield consists of a planar grid of unit cells based on a Jerusalem Cross structure surrounded by an external metallic grid, each integrating varactor diodes controlled by passive RFID Integrated Circuits (ICs), enabling batteryless and distributed programmability. Full-wave electromagnetic simulations demonstrate a transmission coefficient variation exceeding 30 dB between shielding and transparent states, with excellent transparency and angular robustness with respect to the incident field. A key innovation of this work is the transition from epidermal to fully implantable deployment, ensuring continuous protection of the IMD without reliance on patient compliance or external wearable components. The proposed architecture provides a scalable, flexible, and permanently implantable solution to enhance the security of next-generation IMDs.

authors: Linqiao Gan, Xinglin Zeng, Birgit Stiller
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)

authors: Qiaojun Hu, Wei Wang, Xiaoyu Wang, Yongli Zhao, Yajie Li, Jie Zhang

title: A Weather-Aware Risk Stratification Framework for RLF Prediction Using Contrastive Autoencoders and Survival Analysis
authors: M M Sadman Shafi, Tasnia Siddiqua Ahona, Yasin Hasan Saad
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: Ensuring reliable radio connectivity in next-generation wireless networks is critical, particularly under dynamic weather-induced impairments that significantly influence link stability. Traditional Radio Link Failure (RLF) prediction approaches primarily focus on binary classification, failing to estimate when a failure is likely to occur. In this work, we propose a novel weather-aware RLF prediction framework that integrates multi-modal feature fusion, contrastive representation learning and survival analysis to produce interpretable time-to-failure estimates. Using a real-world dataset from Turkcell comprising radio key performance indicators (KPIs) and measurements from weather stations, we first employ a supervised autoencoder to learn a fused latent representation of triplet-based meteorological features. A contrastive autoencoder trained with triplet loss then captures discriminative latent embeddings, stratifying links into high and low reconstruction error groups. Survival analysis, leveraging Kaplan–Meier and Nelson–Aalen estimators, demonstrates that higher reconstruction errors correlate strongly with accelerated failure risk, providing actionable insights into temporal link reliability. Furthermore, we incorporate Isolation Forest anomaly detection on learned representations to enhance predictive capability under imbalanced data conditions. Experimental results show that our proposed methodology achieves robust performance in modeling the temporal dynamics of RLF, enabling proactive resource allocation, optimized handover scheduling, and informed Service Level Agreement (SLA) risk management in weather-sensitive wireless environments.

title: Application of Deep Learning in Helicopter Fault Diagnosis and Prognostic
authors: Fu Gao, Jie Chang, ShiChuang Han
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Deep learning is one of the hottest research directions in the field of industrial technology. Research and practice of deep learning in helicopter fault diagnosis and prediction, is an important significance to improve the accuracy of fault diagnosis and prediction. This paper analyzed the feasibility of deep learning in helicopter fault diagnosis and prediction, researched the application of DNN(Deep Neural Network), CNN(Convolution Neural Network), RNN(Recurrent Neural Network), DBN(Deep Belief Network). Take fault diagnosis and health prediction based on vibration data as an example, verified the ideas for the application of deep learning in helicopter fault diagnosis and prediction.

title: QML Algorithm for Market Pattern Detection in High-Frequency Trading for Banking
authors: Hari Gupta, Deepesh Vinodkumar Semlani, Naveen Kumar Vayyasi, Jagadeesh Thiruveedula, Parshv Praful Gala, Kartikey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: HFT is also referred to as high-frequency trading, is a trading model that is used in the financial markets. Market conditions are analysed by computer algorithms and buy and sell actions made in milliseconds to profit. It will fail through huge amounts of statistics and the intricate market trends that HFT analytics will work with, the investors will inadvertently and swiftly understand market trends. That leads to missed business opportunities and missed capacities. One way to solve this challenge is a QML algorithm designed on DSLs in HFT in banking which uses quantum device mastering techniques at the lowest implementation level. In terms of quantum computing principles, this algorithm is thought to integrate the classical machine-mastering techniques of 1 st principles with the quantum computing requirements of more effective and faster pattern-finding in HFT. At the heart of the algorithm is quantum entanglement, which creates a graph of information nodes related to each other dynamically. This allows the guideline set to quickly determine and analyze the elaborate designs on huge databases appropriately, tenting the buyers with the readout expander, the finest move near marketplace. The following features make the QML algorithm a powerful instrument in the buying and selling of the fast-changing and volatile environment. Its speed and accuracy should provide the buyers with a vicious advantage to be able to make well-informed and profitable trading decisions. QML algorithm marketplace sample Detection in HFT banking offers a solution to banks and financial institutions that want to streamline their HFT strategies and gain more income.

title: A Multimodal Framework for Real-Time Disaster Event Classification and Prioritization Using Social Media
authors: Thai Dinh Kim, Khanh-Phuong Luong, Oanh Thi Tran, Ta Ngoc Bao An, Do Thi Trung Anh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Natural disasters generate vast amounts of multi-modal social media content on platforms like Twitter, containing both textual and visual information crucial for emergency response. However, existing disaster monitoring systems often analyze text and images in isolation, leading to incomplete situational awareness and delayed crisis response. This study proposes a comprehensive multimodal framework that integrates natural language processing and computer vision techniques through a context-aware late fusion strategy. Our system employs a dual-pipeline architecture: the text pipeline utilizes XLNet for binary disaster detection, BERTweet for 16-category disaster type classification, and Gemini for zero-shot semantic intent analysis (Disaster Information, Emergency Help, and Emotion Sharing), while the image pipeline applies EfficientNet-B4 for informativeness assessment, humanitarian categorization, and damage severity evaluation. The multimodal outputs are integrated using weighted voting, where weights are assigned proportionally to each model’s validation accuracy, and validated against ReliefWeb for real-time verification. Experimental results on the Disaster Tweets Normalized and CrisisMMD datasets demonstrate exceptional performance: XLNet achieved 98% F1-score for disaster detection, BERTweet attained 96% F1-score for type classification, and Gemini reached 94% F1-score for intent analysis. EfficientNet-B4 showed consistent performance across visual tasks with F1-scores of 82% (informativeness), 76% (humanitarian), and 65% (damage severity). The multimodal fusion approach significantly outperformed unimodal baselines, successfully prioritizing critical disaster events through severity-based ranking, thus providing emergency responders with actionable intelligence for effective crisis management.

title: A Hybrid FXC-WXC Network Architecture with Low-Cost Pluggable Transceivers for Metro-Scale Optical Networks
authors: Shunya Shimoi, Hayato Yuasa, Taisei Sekizuka, Takuma Kuno, Yojiro Mori, Wakako Maeda, Shigeyuki Yanagimachi, Hiroshi Hasegawa
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a hybrid FXC-WXC network architecture for metro-scale optical networks, incor-porating low-cost pluggable transceivers, ZR+. Multifaceted simulations demonstrate efficient resource utilisation and improved receiver OSNR. Consequently, the proposed architecture reduces total cost by 30%, offering a scalable and cost-effective solution for ZR+ deployment.

title: Experimental Quantification of Stimulated Raman Scattering Penalties Induced by VHSP in PON Coexistence Scenario
authors: Gaël Simon, Stéphane Le Huérou, Brendan Torillec, Fabienne Saliou, Jérémy Potet, Philippe Chanclou
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We simulate and measure Raman scattering interactions where multiple PONs coexist with VHSP. XGSPON-US might suffer from 1. 1 dB depletion. Our field data suggest that about 1 % of the links might be affected.

title: Early Termination of Low-Density Parity-Check Codes for Continuous-Variable Quantum Key Distribution
authors: Kadir Gumus, Joao dos Reis Frazao, Vincent van Vliet, Menno van den Hout, Aaron Albores-Mejia, Thomas Bradley, Chigo Okonkwo
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We analyse the impact of log a-posteriori early termination on the decoding throughput of reconciliation for continuous-variable quantum key distribution. Increases in decoded secret key rate throughput of up to 182% are reported in both simulations and experiments. © 2025 The Author(s)

title: Multi-Attribute Clothing Classification Using Modular Deep Learning Models: A ResNet-Centric Architecture
authors: Boran Kuzukıran, Emrah Horkar, Esra Akşit, Sevgi Koyuncu Tunç
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Automatic clothing labelling in the e-commerce industry is an emerging field where deep learning techniques are proving invaluable. This research explores the use of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for classifying and categorizing clothing items. The study employs a modular ResNet-based approach, trained on the DeepFashion and Fashion Product Images datasets, to create specialized models for various attributes such as category, colour, gender, and additional clothing features. The models demonstrate strong performance, with accuracies ranging from 82% to 95%, indicating their potential for improving automated product recognition in e-commerce.

title: A Review of Approaches and Challenges in Recommender Systems: From Classical Algorithms to Deep Learning Hybrids
authors: Krishna Kumar, Abhishek Kumar, Sachin Ahuja
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This Systematic Literature Review (SLR) considers 85 peer-reviewed articles between 2019 and 2025, providing an overall insight into advancements in recommender systems (RS). The review centers around three main recommendation methods—Collaborative Filtering (CF), Content-Based Filtering (CBF), and Hybrid Filtering (HBF)—with explorations of recent developments related to deep learning, graph neural networks, and trust-aware methods. The most common challenges like cold-start, sparsity of data, scalability, over-specialization, and privacy are exhaustively classified and treated. Among the 85 reviewed studies, approximately 45% employed CF methods, 33% adopted hybrid filtering, 13% focused on CBF, and the remainder explored deep learning or graph-based approaches. The discussion of how hybrid methods and privacy-enhancing methods like federated learning and explainable AI are critical to surmount these limitations is presented. Benchmark datasets like MovieLens, Amazon Product Review, and Netflix Prize are treated in their application for model ranking. Also, commonly employed measures of effectiveness like RMSE, MAE, Precision, and NDCG are examined together with measures of fairness, diversity, and novelty. The review highlights a move from traditional algorithms to intelligent, transparent, and human-centered systems and presents avenues of future directions centered around adaptability, ethical personalization, and interdisciplinarity.

title: Predictive Modelling of Heart Disease Risk Using Hybrid Ensemble Learning Techniques
authors: Prince, Anupam Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Heart disease is among the top causes of death in various parts of the globe and therefore requires technological intervention through the creation of data-driven and smart systems to facilitate its early detection and prevention. This paper provides a strong hybridized ensemble model that is able to forecast with great accuracy and outcome concerning the assessment of heart disease. The model combines the advantages of various classifiers thanks to the combination of stacking and soft voting algorithms (Decision Tree, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, XGBoost, Support Vector Machine, and Logistic Regression) and achieves better predictive results. The suggested system was trained and tested using a combined record set of UCI and Kaggle consumer bases, which contained 1100 records of patients with 16 clinical parameters. Severe preprocesses and feature selection methods were used in order to increase the effectiveness of the model. The fourth hybrid model had the highest accuracy of 94.8%, precision, and recall, and an AUC-ROC score of 0.96, which proves that it is better than the traditional and individual ensemble models. The criterion of data feature importance confirmed the clinical importance of such attributes as type of chest pain, ST depression, and exercise-induced angina as well. Findings indicate the effectiveness of the model as an accurate clinical decision support engine in the detection of heart disease at an early stage. Its implementation can largely support health care providers to make better diagnoses, treatment plans, and minimize cardiovascular risk.

title: Hybrid Photonic Integrated Circuit for Tunable, Narrow-Line-Width mmWave to Sub-THz Signal Generation
authors: Tianwen Qian, Ben Schuler, Martin Kresse, Madeleine Weigel, Jakob Reck, Klara Mihov, Philipp Winklhofer, Csongor Keuer, Laurids von Emden, Marcel Amberg, Crispin Zawadzki, Moritz Kleinert, David de Felipe, Norbert Keil, Martin Schell
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate a photonic integrated circuit (PIC) that generates tunable mmWave signals with Hz-level linewidths. Utilizing on-chip optical frequency combs and injection locking, the phase-locked optical signals exhibit beat notes ranging from 30 GHz to 105 GHz. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Leveraging Digital Twins for All-Photonics Networks-as-a-Service: Enabling Innovation and Efficiency (Tutorial)
authors: Hideki Nishizawa, Kazuya Anazawa, Toru Mano, Takeo Sasai, Giacomo Borraccini
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: This tutorial presents an architecture and methods for all-photonics networks-as-a-service in distributed AI data center infrastructures. We discuss server-based coherent transceiver architectures, remote transponder control, rapid end-to-end lightpath provisioning, digital longitudinal monitoring, and line-system calibration, demonstrating their feasibility through field validations. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Comparison of Channel Equalization Methods for an OTFS-Based Underwater Acoustic Communication System
authors: Tanay Agrawal, Ravi Kadlimatti, Naveen Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: In this paper, an underwater acoustic communication system based on Orthogonal Time-Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation is designed and simulated. OTFS modulation represents a time-varying multipath channel in a sparse two-dimensional delay-Doppler domain. It is thus suitable for underwater communication environments that are time-varying and doubly dispersive, i.e., with significant delay spreads and high Doppler shifts. In this paper, the statistically equivalent underwater acoustic (UWA) channel model that considers both small-scale and large-scale perturbations is implemented, and the channel is represented in the delay-Doppler domain. In the receiver design, the performance of three equalization techniques of increasing complexity, namely, the linear minimum mean square error (LMMSE), maximal ratio combining (MRC) in delay-time, and the message passing algorithm is examined. Simulation results show that the MRC delay-time detector can most effectively equalize the UWA channel with a large number of delay and Doppler coefficients. The time-domain LMMSE equalizer is preferable in sparse channel conditions due to its low complexity.

title: A Compact Design of MIMO Antenna Using Quarter-Wavelength Patch and Defected Ground Structure for IoT Applications
authors: Trang Hoang-Thi-Thu, Hung Pham-Duy, Chien Nguyen-Viet, Hung Tran-Huy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper introduces a compact microstrip patch antenna array designed for Multiple-Input-Multiple-Output (MIMO) applications in the Internet of Things (IoT). The design begins with a foundational quarter-wavelength patch antenna, which is then miniaturized by approximately 20% by properly adding two side slots and two stubs. To enhance the antenna’s performance, an I-shaped Defected Ground Structure (DGS) is etched into the ground plane between the MIMO elements, effectively improving inter-element isolation. The final 2-port MIMO antenna features a compact overall size of 0.36λ× 0.36λ × 0.02λ and operates from 3.55 to 3.60 GHz. Throughout this band, the antenna maintains isolation greater than 24 dB and a broadside gain exceeding 2.4 dBi, making it a suitable solution for compact IoT devices.

title: Satellite Link Status Prediction: LSTM Approach Using RSSI and Doppler Data
authors: Sankani Sarathchandra, Muhammad Asad Ullah, Antti Anttonen, Konstantin Mikhaylov, Hirley Alves
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: The performance of satellite communication systems strongly depends on line-of-sight (LoS) conditions between the satellite and the ground terminal. This paper presents a data-driven approach for predicting satellite visibility periods using a long short-term memory (LSTM) network. The model is trained on simulated beacon signals characterized by received signal strength indicator (RSSI) and Doppler shift values, generated for one-year period based on realistic orbital parameters and the 3GPP TR 38.811 S-band propagation model. The dataset includes both LoS and non-line-of-sight (NLoS) conditions, incorporating obstruction effects caused by a cylindrical obstacle. Once trained, the proposed LSTM model predicts satellite visibility for a stationary ground terminal solely from downlink radio signal features, without requiring two-line element (TLE) data, ephemeris information, or terminal location. This enables efficient, real-time classification of LoS and NLoS conditions for satellite communication links.

title: Design and Performance of a 5.8 GHz RFID System for Item Level Surgical Instrument Tracking
authors: Thorben Grenter, Sebastian Böller, Yixiong Zhao, Anton Grabmaier
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: In this Paper a fully functional 5.8 GHz RFID system for item level tracking of surgical instruments based on the EPC Gen2 protocol is presented and tested in realistic scenarios. Design considerations are elaborated, the main system components are examined and measurements with multiple instruments in a metallic medical sieve are shown. An instrument's ID can be read with high reliability, although being arranged chaotically in the sieve with multiple other instruments in a single scanning procedure. A maximum read range of 61 cm utilizing a completely passive tag was achieved using 2 W ERP output power in measurements with a single instrument in a metallic environment. This technology is able to identify individual instruments of a surgical set inside a sieve or opened container almost instantly, even when the tag is partially covered by other instruments. Therefore, it is conveniently usable, as instrument sieves only need to be placed under a scanning antenna and all instruments being identified automatically.

title: AI for Chipless RFID Tag Detection: Generalization and Deployability on Embedded Digital Signal Processors
authors: J.J.F. Sokoudjou, P. García-Cardarelli, A. Rezola, E. Perret, I. Ochoa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms have emerged as a suitable solution for chipless RFID tag detection. However, key considerations for AI-based detection approaches include the generalization capability of the models and their deployability on computationally limited embedded digital signal processors, for their use in real-world applications. This paper presents a brief review of recently presented AI models in the literature. We evaluate the models' generalization capabilities by training and testing on measurements collected at different times, without guaranteeing the same exact set-up. Deployability is assessed based on two indicators: memory requirements and computational cost. The provided results manifest the necessity of evaluating AI models on entirely distinct datasets, with observed differences in accuracy of up to 0.2319 between testing on a subset of the training dataset and testing on a distinct dataset. The memory requirements of all the presented models indicate that they could be stored on simple embedded digital signal processors, with the largest model requiring less than 35 MB of memory. However, most of the models are computationally expensive, with the most demanding model requiring more than 825 million floating-point operations to perform an inference.

title: Methodology for developing software projects at high school stage
authors: Mariyana Nikolova, Diana Lazarova
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The article examines the profiled preparation of students in secondary schools in informatics and, in particular, the methodology approved by the authors for developing software projects at the high school stage. The training is part of national systems that depend on the educational policy, technological development and social requirements of a given country. This article presents an author's methodology for building skills and competencies in high school students for creating software projects. The methodology under consideration is based on the one hand on the approved International Baccalaureate program (IB) system for developing software projects, applicable to the high school stage of education, and on the other hand, on the experience of the authors as teachers and researchers. Basic regulatory documents are indicated, defining and synchronizing common actions for the development of digital competence of citizens in the European Union. The focus of the presented methodology is the understanding and correct application of the criteria for creating a project, with emphasis also on using the capabilities of AI in several directions.

title: Dyna-Q Learning Algorithm for Temperature Control in Exothermic Process
authors: Yan Yi Vun, Huiyi Xu, Min Keng Tan, Helen Sin Ee Chuo, Heng Jin Tham, Kenneth Tze Kin Teo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This paper explores the application of Dyna-Q Learning algorithm in temperature process control especially in the chemical batch reactor. Since the precise control of temperature in batch is the most important aspect to ensure stability, safety and yield. The application of Dyna-Q Learning algorithm is rare especially in chemical process. This might be due to Dyna-Q complexity when it is used to control continuous process which is full of uncertainty especially in the chemical batch process. In most of the existing studies, Dyna-Q is used for discrete process control. There is still study gap in Dyna-Q Learning on the continuous process control such as chemical batch process. In this paper, the algorithm will implement with discretized version of temperature error as the state of the system and the increment and decrement of the fluid temperature as the action of the system. Both Dyna-Q and the conventional controller will be tested under both nominal and robustness cases to evaluate the controller’s performance. The Dyna-Q controller performs equally as the conventional controller in nominal cases but improves by 86% in terms of temperature overshoot in robustness cases. This project shows Dyna-Q is capable of continuous process control. This result further supports the future integration of reinforcement learning type of control in continuous processes especially in chemical processes.

title: Spectrally Efficient FDM with Sector Antennas for Rayleigh Fading Channel
authors: Haruki Inoue, Naoki Omi, Ryotaro Ishihara, Riku Sato, Aoba Morimoto, Mone Kasahara, Jaesang Cha, Chang-Jun Ahn
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices and the deployment of fifth-generation (5G) networks have led to a dramatic increase in wireless data traffic, thereby exacerbating the issue of spectrum scarcity. Spectrally Efficient Frequency Division Multiplexing (SEFDM) enhances spectral efficiency by reducing subcarrier spacing and allowing spectral overlap, at the cost of orthogonality loss, which introduces severe Inter-Carrier Interference (ICI). In frequency-selective multipath environments, the combination of ICI and multipath effects significantly degrades the bit error rate (BER) performance. Despite its potential, the robustness of SEFDM under fading conditions has not been thoroughly investigated. In this paper, we propose a novel receiver architecture that utilizes sector antennas to spatially separate multipath components based on their Angle of Arrival (AoA). Additionally, we evaluate a sector selection scheme optimized for SEFDM systems. Simulation results show that the proposed sector selection method effectively mitigates the Inter-Symbol Interference (ISI) while improving BER performance.

title: EDFA-BDFA Cascaded S-Band Amplification from 1452nm to 1526nm with Flat-Gain and Low Noise Figure by Placing 980nm Pumped EDFA First with Very High Population Inversion
authors: Youichi Akasaka, Jiawei Luo, Vitaly Mikhailov, Rasmus Jensen, David DiGiovanni, Paparao Palacharla
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: EDFA-BDFA cascaded S-band amplification is realized by 2.5 m EDF with single 980 nm pump and 400 m BDF with single 1341 nm pump. Flat gain <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>25 \text{dB}$</tex> from 1452 nm to 1526 nm and low NF from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.6 d B$</tex> is demonstrated by placing 980nm pumped EDFA first with very high population inversion.

title: Advance Fake News Detection
authors: Rohan Gupta, Mradul Gupta, Ishita Bansal, Naman Narang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The rapid dissemination of misinformation across online and social media platforms necessitates the development of robust and intelligent fake news detection systems. Misinformation not only misinforms the people but also undermines social and political stability. Classical fact-checking mechanisms tend to lag behind in terms of speed and scale with regard to online material. To address this, paper propose an automated system leverages advanced machine learning techniques—including logistic regression, decision trees, and deep learning models—to accurately distinguish between authentic and fabricated news. The system evaluates language patterns, sentiment, and source credibility to assess the veracity of information. Trained on true and false samples of news, the model learns day by day to detect misleading content and applies fact-checking mechanisms. This study adds to the improvement of digital media literacy and offers a scalable response to reduce the social impact of false news.

title: Trajectory Tracking Guidance for Mars Atmospheric Entry Phase Based on LESO-MPC
authors: Zhen Yang, Yajie Ma, Bin Jiang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The atmospheric entry phase of Mars is a crucial stage in accomplishing Mars exploration missions, facing challenges such as high non-linearity, strong coupling, and external uncertain disturbances. To enhance the trajectory tracking accuracy and robustness of the spacecraft during the entry phase, this paper proposes a trajectory tracking guidance method based on a Linear Expanded State Observer (LESO) combined with Model Predictive Control (MPC). First, the LESO is utilized to real-time observe and estimate the unknown mismatched disturbances and model linearization errors in the system, thereby achieving compensation for lumped disturbances. Secondly, by leveraging the rolling optimization capability of MPC, an optimal control law is designed to enable the spacecraft to accurately follow the predetermined trajectory under external disturbances and system uncertainties. Simulation results demonstrate that this method exhibits strong robustness and control performance in the trajectory tracking task during the Mars entry phase, effectively improving guidance accuracy and significantly reducing trajectory tracking errors.

title: Real-Time All-Optical Signal Equalisation with Silicon Photonic Recurrent Neural Networks
authors: Ruben van Assche, Sarah Masaad, Emmanuel Gooskens, Stijn Sackesyn, Joris van Kerrebrouck, Xin Yin, Peter Bienstrnan

abstract: We experimentally demonstrate real-time all-optical equalisation of nonlinear fibre distortions using a silicon photonic recurrent neural network. A 28 Gbps OOK signal is equalised with BER below the GFEC threshold <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.8\times 10^{-5}$</tex> for fibre links up to 50 km. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Weighted Mixture of Probabilistic PCA with Shared-Private Subspaces for Process Monitoring under New Operating Conditions
authors: Kai Wang, Xinlong Yuan, Xiaofeng Yuan, Yalin Wang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In modern process industries, frequent shifts in operating conditions often lead to complex multimodal data distributions. Traditional fault detection methods usually have difficulty generalizing to new operating modes, especially when only limited samples are available. Moreover, industrial data commonly contain anomalies introduced by sensor malfunctions or external disturbances. To cope with these challenges, this paper proposes a Mixture of Probabilistic PCA framework enhanced with a shared–private subspace decomposition and a sample-level weighting mechanism. The resulting model improves robustness to outliers and enables more effective extraction of global structural information across multiple modes. Industrial case studies show that the proposed method achieves superior fault detection performance, particularly under zero-shot and noisy new-condition scenarios.

authors: Florian Honz, Bernhard Schrenk
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We present a straight-lane OWC link with beamformers at mobile user and hotspot. We offset free-space path loss through diversity gain realized by a mode-coupling receiver, enabling reception at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1-\text{Gb} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> at a BER of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−10</sup> for an OWC budget of 55.2 dB - without optical amplifier.

title: A Tri-Port Wearable Tag for Indoor Communication with Power Delivery Through Near-Field and Far-Field Energy Harvesting
authors: Giacomo Paolini, Francesca Benassi, Giulia Battistini, Elisa Augello, Diego Masotti, Alessandra Costanzo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This work introduces an innovative hybrid simultaneous wireless information and power transfer architecture that integrates both near-field and far-field wireless power transfer mechanisms into a single compact receiving tag. The system features a dual-mode energy harvesting design: a resonant coil operating at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 3. 5 6 ~ M H z}$</tex> for efficient near-field power transfer, and a cross-polarized antenna system for far-field energy harvesting and data communication in the 2.4 GHz band. The antenna employs a dual-fed configuration that combines coaxial and microstrip feeding techniques, optimizing radiation performance and polarization diversity for robust communication. Detailed electromagnetic simulations are corroborated by antenna and power transfer measurements, which demonstrate the effectiveness of the design. This multifunctional tag is tailored for low-power applications such as Internet of Things devices, radiofrequency identification systems, and wireless sensor networks, offering a highly integrated solution for simultaneous energy acquisition and wireless data transmission.

title: Imbalanced fault diagnosis based on spatial and temporal features of knowledge association
authors: Jiawei Yao, Hongbo Shi
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Due to the long-term stable operation of the system, certain fault modes occur very infrequently in the actual industrial processes, making it difficult to meet the training requirements of data-driven models. This category imbalance problem significantly reduces the generalization ability of the fault diagnosis model, making its recognition accuracy of rare faults insufficient. To address this challenge, an imbalanced sample fault diagnosis method based on knowledge-associated spatio-temporal features is proposed in this paper, which utilizes the spatio-temporal correlation of data to enhance the model's ability to discriminate the minority class of faults. The method adopts a hybrid architecture of graph convolutional network (GCN) and long short-term memory network (LSTM) to mine the spatial topological information and dynamic temporal features of the process variables, respectively, and then fuses them to obtain more discriminative knowledge-associated spatio-temporal representations. To further optimize the model performance, a two-stage training strategy is adopted: firstly, the generic feature representation is pre-learned with the majority fault class; then, the sample number of the minority fault class is used as the benchmark, and all fault classes are randomly sampled to construct a balanced sample set to fine-tune the model and improve its adaptability to the minority class. Finally, the effectiveness of the model is verified on the TE dataset.

title: Demonstration of a 270 Gb/s 300 GHz Entropy-Loaded IM/DD $2 \times 2$ MIMO THz Wireless Transmission System

title: Deep Learning Framework for Multi-Class Segmentation of Photovoltaic Systems_supp1-3640268.pdf
authors: Svea Krikau
publish: N/A
abstract: Accurate mapping of photovoltaic (PV) installations supports renewable energy monitoring, capacity assessment, and policy planning. We introduce a deep learning framework for the simultaneous segmentation of rooftop (RTPV) and ground-mounted (GMPV) PV systems from 0.2m aerial imagery. The approach integrates automatically generated labels from registries and crowdsourced geographic information data with a small set of manually refined annotations, enabling scalable training with high spatial fidelity. A dual-head U-Net++ with a ResNet50 encoder jointly performs pixel-wise segmentation and image-level classification, reducing false positives in heterogeneous landscapes. Exemplarily applied to the state of Hesse, Germany, the model achieves a balanced accuracy of 87.52%, precision of 94.74%, and a recall of 82.89%, with F1-scores of 75.75% (RTPV) and 88.65% (GMPV). Coupled with solar suitability data, the results indicate rooftop PV utilization of only 3.24% statewide and 2.5% in the Dietzenbach case study. This implemented deep learning framework is the first high-resolution, single-step multi-class PV segmentation applied at the federal state scale, offering a transferable tool for large-area PV monitoring.

title: A Clustering Individual Changes-driven Transfer Learning and Interpolation Strategy for Dynamic Multiobjective Optimization
authors: Shijie Zhao, Tianran Zhang, Xin Yu, Jiahao He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: Clustering-based prediction strategies have shown promising performance in dynamic multiobjective optimization. Most of them cluster a population by independent static positions of individuals and adopt a same prediction mechanism for subpopulations. However, this limits the preferred search tasks of clusters and tends to cause homogeneity of individuals. Therefore, this paper proposes a clustering individual changes-driven transfer learning and interpolation strategy method. First, a subpopulation prediction strategy based on clustering of individual features divides populations into different clusters and designs different prediction mechanisms based on the preferences of clusters, aiming to enhance the prediction accuracy of subpopulations and guide individuals to evolve in promising directions. Second, a nearest neighbor interpolation strategy inserts new objective points to sparse regions of the current Pareto optimal front according to neighboring point information, improving the geometric distribution. Third, a dual-source domain adaptation mechanism is presented to further increase the adaptability of solving problems with various types by integrating knowledge learned on two most useful environments. The comprehensive experimental results demonstrate the outstanding performance of the proposed method over six state-of-the-art competitors on the benchmark suite and good engineering applicability on a real-world task.

title: QIIS: Quaternion Inter- and Intra-Task Interaction Strategy for Multi-Task Dense Prediction
authors: Kai Huang, Guoheng Huang, Yan Li, Ming Li, Wing-Kuen Ling, Xiaochen Yuan, Chi-Man Pun, Lianglun Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: In the domain of intelligent consumer electronics, edge devices such as monocular cameras increasingly demand the ability to perform multiple visual perception tasks simultaneously, including semantic segmentation, depth estimation, and boundary detection. However, most existing multi-task dense prediction frameworks suffer from inefficient task interaction and limited feature integration, which significantly constrain their applicability in resource-constrained consumer environments. To address these limitations, we propose a Quaternion Inter- and Intra-task Interaction Strategy (QIIS), a unified framework designed to enhance task collaboration through quaternion-based feature fusion. Specifically, we introduce a Dual-stream Patch Embedding (DPE) module to extract rich local features, a Cross-prompt Quaternion Interaction (CQI) block to achieve efficient inter-task communication, and an Intra-Task Quaternion Fusion (ITQF) module that enables effective fusion of task-generic, task-specific, and cross-task representations. By leveraging the Hamilton product inherent in quaternion convolution, our approach enhances representational capacity while reducing parameter complexity. Experimental results on the PASCAL-Context and NYUD-v2 benchmarks demonstrate that QIIS achieves competitive performance across multiple tasks, with parameter and FLOPs counts that are generally lower than those of state-of-the-art methods, making it a viable solution for vision-based measurement and perception in embedded consumer systems.The code is available at https://github.com/hallynight/QIIS.

title: Resiliency Integrated Distributed Secondary Control for Islanded AC Microgrids
authors: Devakumar Annavaram, Sukumar Mishra, Deepak Pullaguram
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article proposes a resilient distributed secondary control (DSC) framework for the islanded ac microgrids to maintain the frequency and average microgrid voltage at a nominal value during cyber intrusions. In ac microgrids, any false data injection (FDI) in state variables used in DSC leads to frequency and voltage deviations. This affects the performance of connected loads and the undesired operations in the microgrids; at times, this may extend to disruption or destabilization of the ac microgrid. In this article, a steady-state FDI attack impact analysis on the conventional distributed controller is carried out to determine the deviations in terms of attack magnitude and controller parameters. Further, to mitigate the deviations, the auxiliary variables are incorporated into the conventional cooperative active and reactive power loops. The cooperative errors derived from the auxiliary variables are used to nullify the attack impacts on frequency and voltages. A steady state impact analysis is also presented for the proposed distributed control with an FDI attack to show the convergence of frequency and average voltage of the ac microgrid to its nominal values. An eigenvalue-based analysis is performed to optimally select the proposed controller gains. The proposed method is validated for various case studies in simulations and experimentally on a hardware setup for multiple communication link and local measurement FDI attacks.

title: Spectral Features of PyroCbs from Hyperspectral Infrared Sounders and their Potential Use for PyroCb Remote Sensing
authors: Xiaozhen Xiong, Xu Liu, Wan Wu, Liqiao Lei, Qiguang Yang, Allen M. Larar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Large wildfires and their induced thunderstorms, pyrocumulonimbus (pyroCb), are getting increasing interest and attention. Most previous studies are based on broadband satellite data, and the use of hyperspectral infrared data for pyroCb detection has not been explored. Australia’s unprecedented fires at the end of 2019 to early 2020 induced an extreme pyroCb outbreak, and the largest event occurred on 30 December 2019 was successfully captured by the Cross-track Infrared Sounder (CrIS) onboard JPSS-1 and S-NPP. Analysis of these CrIS data demonstrated that the slopes and standard deviations of the spectral brightness temperature (BT), derived from a linear fitting to the spectrum in 800-980 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup>, along with the split-window technique using selected CrIS channels, can aid in pyroCb detection. An inverted “V” feature in the spectra near 9.6 μm is associated with high pyroCb, and its depth, H_index, can provide information of cloud top height. These characteristics are verified through radiative transfer model (RTM) simulations and analysis of another case of pyroCb induced from California Creek fire on 5 September 2020. It is found that a combination of H_index and BT difference between 1231 and 677 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> is promising to distinguish high pyroCbs. A more accurate determination of pyroCb plume height can be achieved from the single Field of View Sounder Atmospheric Products (SiFSAP), which indicate that several pyroCb pixels reach 3-6 km above the tropopause. These approaches could be applied to study more pyroCbs using over 20 years of hyperspectral sounder data.

title: A Flyback-Integrated Phase-Shift Full-Bridge Converter for High Efficiency
authors: Dae-Hun Kwon, Ji-Yeon Kim, Jae-Hoon Sim, Jae-Kuk Kim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article proposes a new flyback-integrated phase-shift full-bridge (PSFB) converter to improve the overall efficiency of the conventional PSFB converters for applications requiring low output voltages and high output currents. It is implemented by replacing the output inductor with a coupled inductor and connecting its secondary side to the output in a flyback configuration. During the freewheeling period, the proposed converter transfers the energy stored in the coupled inductor to the output via the flyback circuit, consisting of only one coupled inductor winding and a low-voltage-rated diode. This provides the following main advantages: 1) elimination of the circulating current; 2) a lower forward voltage drop on the freewheeling diode; and 3) a reduced number of conducting components. Consequently, power losses on both the primary and secondary sides are significantly reduced. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed converter, a 300 W prototype was designed and tested. Experimental results confirmed an improvement in overall efficiency compared with the conventional converters, achieving 0.8% and 2.2% higher efficiency than the center-tapped rectifier and coupled inductor rectifier, respectively, under full-load conditions.

title: VNF-FG Placement and Admission Control in SDN and NFV-Enabled IoT Networks: A Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning Method
authors: Xi Xu, Yang Yang, Wei Huang, Songtao Guo, GuiYan Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Software Defined Networking (SDN) and Network Function Virtualization (NFV) are expected to provide greater flexibility and manageability for next-generation IoT networks. In this context, network services should be modeled as Virtual Network Function Forwarding Graphs (VNF-FGs). A key challenge is efficient allocation of resources for sequentially arriving network service requests, a process known as VNF-FG placement. Most existing algorithms either manually or partially extract features from the physical network and VNF-FG or adopt a greedy approach, allocating resources as long as a feasible solution exists, which may over-allocate resources to VNF-FG requests, ultimately harming infrastructure providers’ long-term revenue. In this paper, we propose a VNF-FG placement and admission control algorithm based on hierarchical reinforcement learning, called EAC. It consists two levels of agents: a coarse-level agent that generates placement strategies and rejects requests with no feasible placement strategies, and a refine-level agent that implements admission control and rejects requests that are detrimental to long-term revenue. To fully capture the topological features of both the physical network and the VNF-FG, we employ a customized Graph Attention Network (GAT) that incorporates link feature awareness and enables deeper exploration. To fully explore historical temporal information for admission control, we construct state triples and feed them into a Recurrent Neural Network (RNN). Using Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) as the foundational training algorithm, the corresponding agents are trained hierarchically. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed EAC algorithm outperforms existing state-of-the-art solutions in terms of acceptance rate, revenue-to-cost ratio, and long-term average revenue.

title: DP4C: A SoC Architecture for NN-driven Network Functions with the Intelligent Plane
authors: Dong Wen, Tao Li, Wenwen Fu, Chenglong Li, Zhuochen Fan, Hui Yang, Chao Zhuo, Lun Li, Zhiting Xiong, Junnan Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Neural-network-driven (NN-driven) network functions and their implementation on the data plane are emerging topics due to demonstrated accuracy and high performance. Meanwhile, we argue that deploying NN-driven network functions should satisfy two design goals: the generality to support various NN models, and the flexibility to operate various network functions. Unfortunately, existing work cannot satisfy both goals simultaneously. In this paper, we introduce the concept of the Intelligent Plane for NN-driven network functions, and propose DP4C, a cross-plane SoC architecture that integrates the intelligent, control, and data planes within a single chip. DP4C comprises the programmable NN inference engine that iteratively executes inference to ensure model generality in the intelligent plane, a multi-core RISC-V CPU that parses inference results into diverse network functions through its architectural flexibility in the control plane, and the switch fabric in the data plane. To further eliminate the performance bottleneck, we propose (i) the direct register access mechanism coupled with custom instructions to reduce the overhead of cross-plane data migration; and (ii) the multi-core pipelining with adaptive batch-processing for multi-core CPU. DP4C SoC is fabricated using 130 nm technology and has already been deployed in industrial IoT environments. We also design three distinct test cases to evaluate DP4C, fully demonstrating the model generality and operational flexibility.

title: The impact of blockchain implementation on received and provided trade credit
authors: Minhao Gu, Peizhi Zhang, Rui Chang, WaiFong Boh, Baofeng Huo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Trade credit is a financing tool used in supply chain (SC) management. Blockchain can improve transparency among transaction parties and reduce transaction costs through consensus mechanisms and automation, offering a more efficient solution for managing trade credit. This study investigates how and to what extent blockchain affects trade credit. The empirical analysis is based on data from firms listed on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges (A-share market) during the period 2015-2022. The results show that blockchain implementation reduces received trade credit from suppliers, whereas it increases provided trade credit to customers. A series of robustness procedures-including alternative variable constructions, lagged specifications, alternative identification strategies, and placebo-based Monte Carlo simulations-confirm the validity and stability of the empirical findings. This study further investigates the mechanisms of how blockchain implementation affects trade credit. The results show that blockchain implementation further reduces received trade credit from more centralized suppliers. In addition, the results also indicate that more trade credit will be provided to customers with a higher level of demand uncertainty. This study offers a comprehensive view of how firms utilize blockchain to improve trade credit efficiency. Managerial implications based on the research findings are also provided.

title: Signal-Signal Beating Interference: From Destructive to Constructive for Photonic THz Integrated Sensing and Communication System Using Self-Coherent OFDM
authors: Fengwei Liu, Xihua Zou, Ningyuang Zhong, Xiong Deng, Lianshan Yan, Wei Pan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Terahertz (THz) integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) is a key building block for future 6G networks. In the traditional fiber or radio-over-fiber communication system, signal-signal beat interference (SSBI) is a critically destructive factor to be canceled. In this work, a nonlinear matched filtering (NMF) approach is proposed to transform the SSBI from a destructive interference into a constructive component for the THz ISAC system. By reusing the energy from the constructive SSBI, the NMF significantly enhances the sensing metrics in terms of the resolution and the peak-sidelobe ratio (PSLR). Using NMF can attain higher resolution with limited bandwidth; the larger the bandwidth, the better the effect. In experiments, a self-coherent ISAC system operating at 144-GHz center frequency and 5-GHz bandwidth is demonstrated with a 20-Gb/s communication capacity and a 1.94-cm ranging resolution. More importantly, the 3-dB resolution is improved by up to 25% and the PSLR is increased by up to 8 dB for the sensing function. In addition, the peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR) of the integrated signal is reduced by up to 7 dB.

title: A Unified fNIRS Classification Framework Informed by Local Brain Activation Patterns
authors: Zenghui Wang, Songlin Du
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) is a promising noninvasive neuroimaging technique that detects cerebral hemodynamic responses in brain–computer interfaces. Recent studies have focused on task-specific and neuroscience-agnostic fNIRS classification models rather than a unified neuroscience-informed framework. We propose LoBrAFrame, a unified, neuroscience-informed fNIRS classification framework that leverages local brain activation patterns through a shared brain activation (SBA) module with a shared weight mechanism. SBA encodes shared activation dependencies into knowledge-aware hypersignals. A lightweight shared branch captures global spatio-temporal activation dependencies. Within this framework, researchers can easily enhance classification performance using simple or off-the-shelf methods on hypersignals, without redesigning complex models. To instantiate a concrete model, we introduce Mamba, a state space model, into the fNIRS domain and propose LoBrAMamba to learn activation patterns from hypersignals. Subject-specific and subject-independent experiments demonstrate the generalizability of LoBrAFrame and the superiority of LoBrAMamba on three open-access datasets. Our work will inspire interest in neuroscience-informed fNIRS frameworks.

title: Deceptive Jamming Algorithm for Moving Targets Against Highly Squint SAR Based on Keystone Transform and Extended Nonlinear Chirp Scaling
authors: Wenqiang Huang, Jiale Zhang, Wei Lu, Xiaojun Liu
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Existing synthetic aperture radar (SAR) deceptive jamming algorithms for moving targets combine low-order approximation of the instantaneous slant range with 2-D separation processing or a method based on the fast Fourier transform and interpolation calculation to rapidly generate the jammer’s frequency response (JFR). However, these methods struggle to balance the contradiction between the jamming modulation accuracy and efficiency, especially when generating multiple moving targets with varying motion parameters. In addition, the echo signals of highly squint SAR system exhibit significant spatial variability and complex Doppler characteristics, which require the jammer to increase the azimuth sampling rate and construct complex cross-coupling terms, further exacerbating the contradiction. This article proposes a deceptive jamming algorithm for moving targets against highly squint SAR based on keystone transform (KT) and extended nonlinear chirp scaling (ENLCS). The algorithm effectively reduces the azimuth sampling rate required for JFR construction and eliminates the main range-azimuth coupling by separating the linear range walk term and introducing the KT. Based on the circular model theory, the algorithm accurately derives the spatial-variant high-order range cell migration and Doppler phase, which are constructed by introducing a quartic perturbation function and the ENLCS method, respectively. Furthermore, the algorithm constructs the motion-parameter-related terms separately from the unrelated ones, reducing redundant processing steps and further improving jamming modulation efficiency. Simulation results and computational complexity analysis validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Practical WiFi Indoor Localization: Unleashing the Potential of GNNs for Accuracy and Robustness
authors: Ziqi Ye, Qiqi Xiao, Jianwei Liu, Yinghui He, Guanding Yu, Jinsong Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: WiFi-based indoor localization, supported by comprehensive infrastructure, is considered a highly promising solution. However, practical applications of existing WiFi-based methods often struggle due to dynamic antenna configurations and potential influence from obstacles, which can undermine the reliability of channel state information and frustrate localization. Even worse, environmental changes may lead to a domain shift, further degrading localization accuracy and system robustness. To address these problems, this paper introduces GraphFi, a novel system that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to deliver accurate and robust localization using nearby access points (APs). GraphFi designs two types of graph structures: intra-AP graph and inter-AP graph, to maximize the use of information from all available APs. They aggregate the local features among antennas within each AP and global features across APs, effectively addressing the problem of dynamic antenna configurations. Two specialized GNNs are utilized to derive accurate user locations from these graphs. Additionally, we introduce an anomaly detection method to identify and exclude obstacle-affected APs. This method also employs a tailored GNN to mitigate influence from unpredictable obstacles. Furthermore, we integrate an unsupervised domain adaptation mechanism based on a gradient reversal layer into GNNs. This helps maintain localization performance in a cost-efficient manner and ensures sustained effectiveness in a cross-domain setting. We prototype GraphFi using commodity WiFi devices and conduct extensive experiments in various scenarios. The results demonstrate that GraphFi achieves average localization errors of 0.17 m in a single-domain setting and 0.2851  m in a cross-domain setting, surpassing existing solutions in both precision and robustness.
