title: An Evidence-Based Paradigm for Financial GNNs: The Case for Principled Simplicity in Volatility Spillover Modeling
authors: Shengting Shen, Jason Gemsun Young, Jyh-Shing Roger Jang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Financial Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) universally assume fully-connected topologies where every asset influences every other—an unvalidated architectural dogma that we empirically refute. Through rigorous ablation studies across two independent US equity markets (DOW30, SPY TOP40) spanning six years of institutional-grade 30-minute data (2019–2025), we expose a fundamental paradox: textitless connectivity yields superior performance. Three transformative discoveries emerge. First, sparse K-NN graphs with merely 400 edges achieve 5.1% superior QLIKE accuracy versus fully-connected graphs with 1560 edges (DM test, p<0.001), while delivering 74% computational savings—directly contradicting the prevailing "more edges, better forecasts" assumption. Second, explicit network topology modeling via GNNs provides statistically robust 52–55% accuracy gains (p<0.001) across both markets versus non-graph baselines, establishing graph structure—not architectural complexity—as the dominant performance driver. Third, our optimal sparse architecture achieves production-grade efficiency (12ms inference, 13.06 MB footprint), enabling real-time deployment at portfolio scale (e.g., S&P 500). We establish an evidence-based design principle: prioritize high-quality sparse connectivity (correlation ρ ≥ 0.766) over universal dense graphs. This work transcends incremental improvement, delivering a paradigm shift from complexity-driven to structure-driven financial AI.

title: LPP-CNN: A Lightweight Privacy-Preserving Object Classification Framework for Military Vehicle Images
authors: Junyu Lai, Jie Wang, Yuchao Hou, Peiheng Jia
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In this paper, we propose a lightweight privacy-preserving convolutional neural network framework for military vehicle images classification (LPP-CNN). Existing target classification methods primarily focus on improving accuracy and recognition efficiency but often overlook security threats during data transmission and processing, making them unsuitable for high-risk battlefield scenarios. Although some approaches incorporate image security through homomorphic encryption, the low efficiency and operational complexity of such techniques hinder their applicability in battlefield environments. To this end, we design a solution that integrates additive secret sharing with edge computing by encrypting images into two ciphertexts, which are then processed independently by two edge servers to prevent data leakage during upload. The encrypted data is subsequently processed by the LPP-CNN embedded with secure computation protocols. Finally, results are combined and decrypted to achieve target classification. This method ensures efficient and accurate military vehicle classification while significantly enhancing data privacy and security. Theoretical analysis demonstrates improved response speed and reduced communication overhead. Experimental evaluations show that under a classification accuracy not less than 94%, the computational efficiency of SComp, SReLU, and SMaxPool protocols increase by 32, 4, and 0.5 times, respectively, while communication costs decrease by 2, 2, and 13 times. The overall framework achieves a 33% improvement in computational efficiency compared to existing solutions. Compared to state-of-the-art methods, our framework not only meets battlefield requirements for high-precision object classification but also substantially strengthens data privacy and security, aligning more effectively with real-world military application demands.

title: Safe reinforcement learning based eco-driving control of autonomous HEV in off-road scenarios
authors: Lingxiong Guo, Xiaolei Ren, Xueyan Cao, Rui Liu, Yechen Qin, Dongpu Cao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: With the advancement of intelligent vehicle technologies, eco-driving control integrating velocity planning and energy management offers a solution to address charge and range anxiety in autonomous HEVs. However, due to complex road conditions, off-road eco-driving control has received limited scholarly attention. This paper proposes a novel integrated control system using a safe reinforcement learning (SRL) framework for eco-driving in off-road scenarios. First, we develop a method to identify safe velocity boundaries by quantifying constraints from complex road conditions based on vehicle dynamics stability criteria, deriving an analytical representation of the dynamic safe velocity boundary. Additionally, an SRL algorithm based on Lagrangian-SAC and an action-shielding mechanism is proposed, leveraging the advantage of model predictive control (MPC) in handling explicit constraints to guide safe actions while filtering unsafe ones during RL agent exploration. Finally, simulation and real-vehicle experiment results show that the proposed method effectively balances fuel economy and travel time while ensuring vehicle driving safety by strict safe constraints, achieving zero constraint violations in challenging off-road scenarios. Compared with the benchmark method, the fuel economy of the proposed method is improved by up to 6.12%.

title: Universal Set of Observables for Forecasting Physical Systems Through Causal Embedding_supp1-3632965.pdf
authors: Manjunath Gandhi
publish: N/A
abstract: We show how a pair of points can uniquely represent a left-infinite sequence obtained from observations of an underlying dynamical system through a phenomenon called causal embedding. A driven dynamical system creates such pairs, and a function can be learned on them that can reconstruct the underlying dynamics as in Takens delay embedding. The approach assures embedding stability unlike Takens delay embedding, and learnability, which can be absent, while stability can be present in the current reservoir computing framework. This accurately models underlying systems where recent methods like the next-generation reservoir computing fail. We demonstrate results and compare with the other methods, including SINDY-PI.

title: QIPPO/CA: A Quantized Communication-Efficient MARL Framework for Fully Distributed Channel Access in Next-Generation Wireless Networks
authors: Sungweon Hong, Yeonseo Jeong, Ukjo Hwang, Songnam Hong
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Next-generation wireless networks (NGWNs) demand highly efficient, low-latency channel access schemes to support emerging applications. To capture the distributed nature of participating stations, we formulate the problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP). Building on this formulation, we propose QIPPO/CA, a communication-efficient distributed channel-access method for collision avoidance based on the Listen-Before-Talk (LBT) protocol. QIPPO/CA leverages independent proximal policy optimization (IPPO) within a decentralized training and decentralized execution (DTDE) paradigm. It is further extended with a federated learning–inspired quantized gradient update, enabling efficient coordination among distributed stations without exchanging local information. Extensive simulations demonstrate that QIPPO/CA (i) consistently outperforms legacy random-access methods such as CSMA/CA, (ii) achieves the performance of centralized training frameworks, (iii) remains robust under dynamic channel sizes and traffic loads, and (iv) substantially reduces communication overhead during agent training. These results highlight QIPPO/CA as a promising framework for scalable, efficient, and standard-compatible distributed channel access in NGWNs.

title: Testability Verification Integration Technology of Diesel Engine Electronic Control System under Complex Stress Conditions
authors: Dongjiang Xie, Chen Lu, Dengwei Song
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Multiround iterative testability verification is key to ensuring the rationality and effectiveness of testability design and guaranteeing the realization of fault diagnosis capabilities. Existing testability verification technologies for diesel engines mostly fail to meet the demands of testability verification under complex stress conditions, and the level of automation of related methods is insufficient. To address the above needs, this paper conducts research on the testability verification integration technology of electronic control systems under complex stress conditions and constructs a universal and automated testability verification technical framework. This framework includes testability verification scheme design and evaluation, fault data sequential generation, target unit operating environment, and intelligent testing and interpretation.Meanwhile, considering the characteristics of the diesel engine electronic control system and its complex stress, this paper focuses on three core technologies: the testability verification profiling design technology considering complex stress conditions, the sequential fault data generation technology oriented to multi-source information, and the verification environment construction technology considering vehicle communication conditions. Finally, based on the constructed testability verification integration technology framework, three typical components—electronic control units, sensors, and actuators—are selected for case study and analysis. The testability verification is completed for five typical fault modes, and the verification results prove that the testability design is reasonable and effective. Therefore, the testability verification integration technology support the universal and automated testability verification of electronic control systems, thereby providing support for testability design and the realization of fault diagnosis capabilities.

title: Asymmetrical Filtering Impairments Mitigation for Digital-Subcarrier-Multiplexing Transmissions Enabled by Multiplication-Free K-State Reserved Complex MLSE
authors: Hexun Jiang, Zhuo Wang, Chengbo Li, Weiqin Zhou, Shuai Wei, Yicong Tu, Heng Zhang, Wenjing Yu, Yongben Wang, Yong Chen, Ye Zhao, Da Hu, Lei Shi
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a multiplication-free K-state reserved complex maximum-likelihood-sequence-estimation (MLSE) to mitigate asymmetrical filtering impairments in digital-subcarrier-multiplexing transmissions. A required optical-to-noise ratio of 1.63 dB over the conventional real MLSE is obtained after transmitting 90 GBaud DSCM DP-16QAM signal over 14 WSSs without multiplications.

title: Joint Localization and Computing Resource Optimization for Integrated Sensing and Communication Enabled UAV Networks
authors: Dao Quang Hiep, Nguyen Duc Hai, Nguyen Van Vu, Dinh Viet Hoang, Thuan Van Le, Nguyen Cong Luong, Ngoc Hung Nguyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: In this paper, we consider an integrated sensing and communication ISAC –enabled unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) network in which a UAV serves multiple ground user equipments (UEs). Particularly, the UAV executes computation tasks for the UEs and measures the velocity of the targets requested by them. To simultaneously handle both the task offloading and target velocity estimation under the limited resources and hardware, the UAV exploits the signal sequences while its results return to the UEs based on the ISAC technique. In addition, we leverage the Cramer-Rao Lower Bound (CRB) as the lower bound of the mean squared error of the velocity estimation as the sensing performance. Both the CRB and the computation offloading latency depend on the location of the UAV. We then optimize the UAV’s localization and the computing resource allocation to the UEs to maximize the system reward that is defined according to the offloading latency and CRB requirements of the UEs. We develop a genetic algorithm to solve this. Simulation results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: $\text{CO}_{2}$ Elimination in Hollow-Core Fibre via Post-Processing
authors: Yifan Xiong, Rui Zhao, Dawei Ge, Shoufei Gao, Yizhi Sun, Dong Wang, Dechao Zhang, Han Li, Wei Ding, Yingying Wang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose and validate a post-processing method that removes <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> absorption in hollowcore fibres and establishes internal overpressure, enabling stable, contamination-resistant, reliable C+L band transmission across kilometre-scale cables for multiband optical networks. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Algorithm and Architecture for Short-Reach Coherent-Lite Optics
authors: Yixiao Zhu, Xiansong Fang, Weisheng Hu, Fan Zhang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: There is a growing interest in coherent optics for its deployment in short-reach optical interconnects. We overview the enabling algorithms and architectures in coherent-lite solutions with relaxed LO requirements, particularly in laser phase noise tracking, remote LO polarization fading elimination, and reception dimensions scaling.

title: Predictive Modeling of Drug Addiction Using Socio-Psychological and Behavioral Data
authors: Deepak Burathoki, Tamanna, Ashaq Hussain Bhat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Drug addiction is growing public health concern globally. It is one of the most common addiction the world is facing right now. This study presents a predictive model using machine learning to classify individuals at risk of future drug addiction based on socio-demographic, mental, psychological, and behavioral features. Compared to other studies that uses biological markers, this study is more focused on socio-psychological and behavioral features. A synthetic dataset was generated by integrating real-world survey indicators with demographic data, reflecting real-life class imbalance and missing values. After doing preprocessing, class balancing, and exploratory data analysis, multiple classifiers including SVM, Random Forest were trained and evaluated. Most model performs very well with high accuracy; the findings also highlighted some important psychosocial indicators that could be very insightful in early detection and intervention.

title: Evaluation of 50G-PON FEC Tolerance to Receiver Impairments
authors: L. Anet Neto, D. Chevalier, G. Simon, L. Inglés, J. Potet, P. Chanclou, R. Pyndiah
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We experimentally investigate the impacts of jitter and decision threshold resolution in a 50G-PON downstream scenario supported by an LDPC(17280, 14592) FEC. Both hard and soft input with a soft decoding scheme are evaluated in terms of BER and mean number of decoder iterations. © 2025 The Author(s)

title: First Net $800 \text{Gbps} / \lambda 120 \text{Gbaud}$ DP-16 QAM C-Band Coherent Transmission System Enabled by a BTO IQM with Linear DSP Under the SD-20 FEC Threshold
authors: Benton Qiu, Charles St-Arnault, Yixiang Hu, Santiago Bernal, Aleksandar Nikic, Kaibo Zhang, Weijia Li, Jinsong Zhang, Pascal Stark, Wouter Diels, Felix Eltes, David V. Plant
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate the first net 800 Gbps DP-16QAM coherent transmission at 120 Gbaud in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$C$</tex>-band using a packaged barium-titanate DP-IQM with integrated RF drivers and linear DSP, and achieve 933 Gbps at 125 Gbaud by employing nonlinear DSP. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: A PINN-Based Safe Model Predictive Control Framework for Nonlinear System with State Constraint
authors: Zijing Shen, Dongyang Qu, Chaoyang Dong, Qing Wang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper proposes a safe model predictive control (Safe-MPC) framework that integrates physics-informed neural networks (PINNs), model predictive control (MPC), and control barrier functions (CBFs), aiming to achieve safe trajectory tracking of nonlinear systems in complex environments with obstacles. The proposed approach leverages PINNs to learn system dynamics from limited data while preserving physical consistency. The learned model is then embedded into the rolling prediction module of MPC, enabling accurate and real-time solvable control strategies. In parallel, CBFs are incorporated in a soft-constraint formulation to enforce safety constraints on the system states, ensuring that they remain outside unsafe regions throughout the optimization process. Simulation results on a two-dimensional nonlinear system demonstrate that the proposed method can accurately track the reference trajectory and effectively avoid static obstacles. The system trajectory converges stably, validating the effectiveness and safety of the proposed method. Compared with traditional MPC methods based on explicit physical models, the proposed Safe-MPC framework exhibits superior performance in terms of modeling flexibility and tracking accuracy. Future work will extend the framework to higher-dimensional systems and validate its performance on real-world robotic platforms.

title: Development of a Sensor Driven Autonomous Vehicle for Real-Time Obstacle Avoidance on a Microcontroller Based Platform
authors: Alvin Wong, Aroland Kiring, Mohamed Aizad Bin Mohamed Ghazali, Lyudmila Mihaylova, Muhammad Nur Afnan Uda, Liawas Barukang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: The performance of an autonomous vehicle system is significantly influenced by sensor reliability and microcontroller limitations. Challenges such as limited detection range, environmental sensitivity, constrained processing power, and slower response can lead to delays and inaccuracies in obstacle detection and navigation. Although integrating various sensors in the system can overcome the detection range constraint, its real-time decision-making will be affected due to the increased data load. In addition, dynamic environments hinder the system’s path planning, as it requires robust real-time decision-making and adaptability. Therefore, the goal of this paper is to develop an autonomous vehicle system that can avoid obstacles in real time while travelling between designated points. This paper presents the design, implementation, and performance evaluation of an autonomous vehicle prototype that uses a real-time obstacle avoidance algorithm implemented on a microcontroller through integrated hardware and software. Performance evaluation in terms of efficiency, consistency, and reliability demonstrated the capability of the prototype to handle obstacles across various path types. Although the results show a decline in performance with an increasing number of obstacles, the findings serve as a basis for future enhancements of the developed system.

title: TrashVLM: Lightweight and Efficiently Fine-Tuned Vision-Language Models for Waste Classification
authors: Thuan Trang, Hung Viet Pham, Son Dinh Vu, Tuan Minh Le, Hieu Minh Tran, Son V. T. Dao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Accurate and scalable solid waste classification is vital for sustainable recycling and effective waste management, yet remains a challenging task due to the complexity and variability of municipal waste streams. In this paper, we introduce a lightweight and highly efficient finetuning approach based on a compact vision-language model, Perception Encoder using Quantized Low-Rank Adaptation (QLoRA). Our work eliminates the need for manual feature engineering and costly full-model training by leveraging a pre-trained multimodal backbone, adapted to the TrashBox dataset containing 17,785 labeled images across diverse waste categories. QLoRA reduces training memory and time by more than 10× while fine-tuning only 1% of the model’s parameters, yet it delivers over a 10% improvement in classification accuracy compared to previous fine-tuning baselines and achieves competitive performance relative to transfer learning approaches. Furthermore, our method consistently outperforms conventional CNN-based classifiers across nearly all evaluation criteria. Through detailed analysis, we demonstrate that the few remaining misclassifications stem from labeling errors in the dataset rather than model limitations. Our findings establish QLoRA-tuned vision-language models as a state-of-the-art, cost-effective solution for real-world solid waste classification and broader environmental AI applications.

title: Demonstration of Nanoseconds Reconfigurable All-Optical Switching Network for Distributed Deep Learning
authors: Xianchen Wu, Daohang Dang, Xiangfei Chen, Bingli Guo, Shikui Shen, Zihan Qiu, Yuanzhi Guo, Changsheng Yang, Yisong Zhao, Wenzhe Li, Shanguo Huang, Xuwei Xue
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We experimentally demonstrate a nanoseconds all-optical switching network based on AWGR and REC-DFB laser array for accelerating distributed deep learning. With the implementation of nanoseconds time synchronization and traffic control mechanism, the network achieves 1.5-21.5 times higher bandwidth utilization compared to MEMS-based optical switching networks.

title: Design and Performance Evaluation of a Touchless IR-Based IoT Smart Lock for Hygienic Access Control
authors: Nathan Yong X Y, Ismail Saad, Kit Guan Lim, Nurmin Bolong, Mohammad Saffree Jeffree, Kenneth Teo Tze Kin, Fatimah Ahmedy, Kukjin Chun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Conventional door locks using physical keys pose risks such as loss, theft, and unauthorized duplication. Recent advancements have introduced electronic smart locks leveraging biometric, RFID, and wireless technologies. In the post-COVID-19 era, there is increasing demand for contactless systems to reduce surface transmission of pathogens. This paper presents the development of a keyless, touchless smart door lock system based on Internet of Things (IoT) architecture using infrared (IR) technology for password input. The system replaces physical keypads with IR transmitter-receiver pairs, enabling users to enter passcodes without direct contact. The prototype was developed with custom hardware schematics and a control program, supporting hygienic and convenient access. Performance evaluations include repeatability and robustness tests under varying lighting conditions. Results show high reliability and low standard deviation in input registration times, though minor delays were observed under direct sunlight due to IR signal interference. This system offers strong commercial potential for residential, healthcare, and public access applications, particularly for hygiene-sensitive users.

title: Reset Observer with Gaussian-Type Adaptation for Entropy-Based Fault Detection
authors: Simin Zeng, Shigen Gao, Kexing Yan, Hang Zhang, Tao Wen, Hongwei Wang, Lei Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel entropy-based fault detection methodology for a class of nonlinear systems subject to potential actuator faults, nonlinear dynamics, and external disturbances. A key contribution lies in the development of an enhanced reset observer that identifies uncertain system parameters via a Gaussian-Type learning coefficient-based adaptive law. This adaptive mechanism distinguishes itself through accelerated convergence properties, while the proposed entropy-driven fault detection algorithm ensures timely and false-free fault identification by extracting abnormal information from output residuals and real-time parameter estimates. The integration of entropy metrics with adaptive learning not only suppresses false alarms but also enhances detection sensitivity. A simulation example is given to demonstrate the effectiveness of theoretical findings.

title: Predicting Plant Diseases with Deep Learning
authors: Debdatta Chatterjee, Dibyendu Ghosh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Farming stays as the primary economic activity for a considerable portion of the population like in the case of India, which is still developing. However, the agricultural sector continues to face challenges and perhaps none is more damaging than plant diseases. Outdated approaches to plant disease detection typically involve a labor-intensive visual examination by skilled personnel, which not only is difficult for the remote areas lacking trained agricultural personnel, but also takes a long time. To resolve this widespread and serious concern, a comprehensive, smart, and easy-to-use system for diagnosing and managing plant diseases with the aid of advanced machine learning technologies has been proposed. The main setup of this system is a deep learning Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model which has been trained on more than thousand labelled plant leave images. This dataset includes 38 categories of different crops, both diseased and healthy. The model has been wrapped in a RESTful web API using Flask, which enables simple integration with the responsive user interface implemented in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. A distinct aspect of the application is its functionality to cater both English and Hindi language speakers. This enhancement fosters a better remedy comprehension amongst users thus increasing proper disease management. The application also provides a voice assistant feature for the farmers. Based on our experimental, the CNN model was trained with a certain exponential clock and achieved over 87 percent accuracy yielding unmatched results on previously unseen test data validating correctness claims for a world of real implementation.

title: Transformer Models for Smishing Detection: Benchmarking BERT and ELECTRA
authors: Emre Aşkın, Muhammet Baykara
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Today, the field of artificial intelligence is becoming increasingly popular. This popularity continues to drive the introduction of new models for diverse tasks. BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) and ELECTRA (Efficiently Learning an Encoder that Classifies Token Replacements Accurately) models are also two of the popular and advanced transformer models. The aim of this study is to comparatively analyze the performance of BERT and ELECTRA models in detecting smishing attacks. For this purpose, the dataset used is compared for the first time in the literature. The tests show that the BERT model achieves a higher accuracy rate than the ELECTRA model in detecting smishing attacks. However, the ELECTRA model produces results with comparable accuracy while being faster and more resource-efficient. The results of this study show that both models were able to produce reliable classification results.

title: Performance Analysis of Coded MIMO Systems Using Superposition 64-Ary Constellation with Protograph LDPC and Low-Resolution ADCs
authors: Thang Le Nhat, Duc A. Hoang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper introduces a new coded modulation framework for massive MIMO systems that leverages low-resolution analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) alongside superposition-based 64-ary QAM modulation to increase spectral utilization efficiency. To address the complexity of signal detection, the proposed approach reformulates the original 64-ary QAM channel into an equivalent BPSK model. This reformulation supports a two-layer Tanner graph structure for the combined tasks of signal detection and channel decoding, with computational complexity that grows quadratically with the number of transmit antennas. Protograph LDPC (P-LDPC) codes are adopted in the system due to their excellent error correction performance, and integrates an "equal-weight" superposition constellation, which delivers a 0.7–1 dB gain in performance compared to the traditional "equal-distance" design under coarse quantization. Furthermore, the paper introduces a modified PEXIT analysis method that holistically accounts for the combined effects of MIMO fading, quantization noise from ADCs, and LDPC decoding characteristics. Simulation results confirm the reliability of the analytical approach and highlight the critical role of optimized power allocation in maintaining high energy and spectral efficiency in emerging 5G and 6G networks utilizing low-resolution receivers.

title: Ultra-high Linearity Silicon Dual-microring Modulator with High Extinction Ratio and High Bandwidth Based on DC Kerr Effect
authors: Xin Wang, Fenghe Yang, Ruoyu Shen, Xu Wang, Fangchen Hu, Wei Chu, Haiwen Cai
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: A silicon dual-microring modulator has been designed and experimentally demonstrated on a 300 mm silicon photonic platform, utilizing the DC Kerr effect. The device achieves a bandwidth of 58 GHz and an SFDR of 107 dB.Hz<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2/3</sup> at a 1-GHz carrier frequency. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Augmented-GPT: Leveraging Generative AI Agent for Synthesizing Biomechanical Features for Transformer Model
authors: Van Vinh Pham, Minh Tai Pham Nguyen, Trong Nhan Le
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Nowadays, data augmentation is playing a vital role in various deep learning applications, especially in biomechanical automatic analysis, where the features are hard to collect due to different sophisticated reasons. However, traditional data augmentation techniques expose their limitation by synthesizing unsuitable content that neglects the semantic, global content of the dataset. Furthermore, this problem even exacerbates the outputs of transformers, as these models normally require a large amount of data for training. Therefore, this study is conducted, introducing a new approach called Augmented-GPT that utilizes the GPT-4o as a generative AI agent and designs proper prompts to synthesize data, enriching the content of the dataset effectively by considering global content to create more relevant features for specific rare classes. As a result, our Augmented-GPT can assist the TabTransformer in reaching up to 81.0% in predicting the condition of orthopedic patients based on synthesized biomechanical features. This approach outperforms other traditional data augmentation approaches, opening a new direction to handle complex, rare occurrences in datasets for training complex deep learning models.

title: Common-mode Voltage Suppression Strategy for Odd-Phase Motor Based on Pulse Shifting and Dead-Time Compensation
authors: Chengjiang ShangGuan, Yiying Wu, Ye Lin, LiXia Chen, Yafei Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: For multiphase motor system driven by two-level multiphase voltage source inverter (VSI), the application of pulse width modulation (PWM) inevitably generates common-mode voltage (CMV), which induces electromagnetic interference (EMI) and causes bearing damage in the motor. In the case of odd-phase motor, CMV is mathematically impossible to eliminate. This paper proposes a generalized CMV suppression algorithm for odd-phase motor, based on carrier-based modulation (CBM) and pulse phase-shifting. The algorithm comprehensively addresses both the amplitude and switching frequency components of CMV, while incorporating a compensation method for dead-time effects in driving pulses to achieve common-mode voltage reduction (CMVR). The proposed CBM-CMVR algorithm suppresses the CMV amplitude to the minimum positive and negative peak values. Within one switching cycle, the CMV pulsates only twice or remains constant. Simulation results on a five-phase motor validate the effectiveness of the algorithm.

title: AI as a Surrogate for Social and Spatial Connectedness in Isolated and Confined Environments
authors: Hesam Mohseni, Johanna Silvennoinen, António Correia
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Isolation and confinement in environments such as space stations, nuclear submarines, analog habitats, scientific remote stations such as Antarctica and Hobart can lead to loneliness, depression, and stress. Although experience of place-belongingness can act as a buffer against these psychological challenges, research in this area is still limited. In this study, we first discuss the potential benefits of enhancing social and spatial connectedness in isolated and confined environments (ICEs) and then explore how artificial intelligence (AI) can be effectively used to realize these benefits by presenting a matrix of contributing factors, AI mediation roles, and impacts on mental health, social cohesion, and operational performance. The matrix can shed light on future empirical investigations aimed at leveraging AI to mitigate the negative impacts of a lack of social and spatial connectedness among ICE dwellers, including deep-sea rig workers, cabin crews, mission control teams, astronauts, and commercial space tourists.

title: Mask2Former for AV driving - A lightweight framework
authors: Ashima Narang, Kritika Soni, Latika Pinjarkar, Yojna Arora, Anuj Gupta, Devashish Devashish
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The study and understanding of underlying features of surface level available data aid us significantly while applying techniques where enriching datasets are not available in sufficient quantity. One such scenario is zero shot setting – where the details of environment, or the operating domain, is novel for the model throughout its operation. This obstruction, which has often restricted the performance of models previously formulated, has been resolved by the integration of causal understanding. The work we present here – is built upon the causal understanding represented in the form of Panoptic Segmentation. These representations provide us with much enriching object detection as each pixel, in this form, contains the detail of individual objects independent of the surroundings. Along with that, the inbuilt GPS system of CarLA simulator was combined with it to determine the location of our autonomous vehicle and path finding algorithms to optimize the path – our vehicle should take in order to reach the destination. After the modifications, we obtained the metrics of: RC as 99.87, IS as 8.0, and DS as 91.88 – in other words, the performance of system was significantly enhanced.

title: Extreme PPE Capability and its Application for End-to-End Performance Diagnosis of Millisecond-Level Transients
authors: Qingyi Guo, Mingbo He, Choloong Hahn, Junho Chang, Hao Ding, Jin Wang, Zhiping Jiang
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: The extreme performance achievable with PPE is demonstrated experimentally, showcasing up to a 200 kHz monitoring rate at 0.1 dB precision. This unprecedent capability facilitates continuous end-to-end link performance monitoring and diagnosis, capturing the full millisecond-level dynamics induced by channel add/drop processes. © 2025 The Author(s)

title: Analysis of Deep Learning and Machine Learning for Brain Tumor Classification
authors: Riddhi Awasthi, Arpit Bhardwaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Brain tumors are very serious and are becoming more common worldwide. For accurate diagnosis, it is important that MRI scans can automatically detect tumors. The study suggests using both deep learning models (ResNet-18 and ResNet-50) and machine learning classifiers (SVM, Random Forest, XGBoost) for classifying brain tumors. The three public datasets were chosen for testing, each with a different image resolution. Results indicate ResNet-18 achieved the best performance at 99.08 accuracy on the 224×224 dataset. Enhanced accuracy, robustness and efficiency in this approach make it suitable for medical use in real-life situations.

title: Force-Triggered Reward Delivery System for Rodent Behavioral Experiments Using Arduino
authors: Omer Tekin, Esma Cetinkaya
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study presents a low-cost, Arduino-based behavioral system designed to deliver liquid rewards (e.g., sugar water) to rodents upon stepping onto a designated force-sensitive platform. The system integrates a load cell and HX711 amplifier module for real-time weight detection, interfaced with an Arduino Nano that controls a peristaltic pump. When the measured force exceeds a predefined threshold, the system triggers a brief sugar water reward through a spout inside the behavioral chamber. To differentiate intentional responses from incidental movement, the setup includes both an active (rewarded) platform and a sham (non-rewarded) platform. All components are housed in a compact cylindrical enclosure with modular wiring, incorporating a relay module and DC–DC voltage converter for stable operation. Preliminary bench tests confirmed reliable force detection, rapid actuation, and consistent reward delivery. Originally developed and successfully presented as a senior Electrical and Electronics Engineering graduation project, the system is planned for future use in a neuroscience laboratory under development within the department. This open-source platform provides a reproducible, customizable, and cost-effective tool for operant conditioning tasks, with applications in spatial learning, decision-making, and motor behavior research in rodent models.

title: Filipino Sign Language Recognizer Using Hand Pose Estimation and SqueezeNet
authors: Jarl Kayne Jon V. Centeno, Jeremy C. Espera, John Paul T. Cruz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Sign Language plays a crucial role for people within deaf and mute communities. Most people do not know how to use this language, let alone understand it. With the use of modern technology, Sign Language Recognition is viable for people to understand and even use it for communication. The device developed by the researchers utilizes SqueezeNet and Hand Pose Estimation to recognize and translate certain Filipino Sign Language words. The device captures a single frame from the live video feed of the Raspberry Pi 4’s camera module and analyzes this key frame against the trained dataset. The model garnered an overall accuracy of 97.2%. The model successfully utilized deep learning for sign language recognition from a video input. The researchers also successfully utilized Raspberry Pi’s camera module for FSL recognition, implemented SqueezeNet for training and validation, and determined the performance of the model using a confusion matrix.

title: Wafer Defect Image Classification Optimization Using CNN with Cyclical Learning Rate
authors: Cascarldini Chrisson Nelson, Hariyanti Mohd Saleh, Nor Hidayah Saad
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Wafer defect classification is important for yield optimization and quality assurance in semiconductor manufacturing. Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) has demonstrated strong performance in defect classification. However, the effective training of a model often depends on learning rates tuning. This study investigates the application of Cyclical Learning Rate (CLR) as a learning rate scheduling technique to enhance the performance of CNN's model. Two models, VGG16 and ResNet50, were evaluated on the WM811K dataset under fixed learning rate and CLR settings. A sensitivity analysis on the CLR step size was conducted to evaluate its impact on model performance. Three configurations were tested: small, moderate, and large step sizes. Testing results show that CLR outperformed fixed learning rates. ResNet50 with CLR achieved a testing accuracy of 98.30% while VGG16 with CLR, 95.03%. Overall improvements were also observed in precision, recall, specificity, and F1-score. Results suggest that CLR may accelerate CNN generalization for wafer defect classification.

title: Sentiment Analysis In Social Media: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Gurkirat Singh Lamba, Neetu Rani, Vikas Mittal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Sentiment Analysis is a crucial subfield of NLP; analysing social media sentiment helps identify societal sentiments. In recent decades, the rise of various social networking sites has created a significant demand for studying public sentiment, particularly in fields such as marketing, politics, healthcare, and crisis management. This paper aims to provide a detailed explanation of sentiment analysis and its methods. The methods are classified according to their approaches: lexicon-based, machine learning-based, hybrid, and those combined with other analysis techniques. We go into great detail on a number of topics, such as metric selection, multilingualism, acrophobia, and noisy data. The available data sources and sentiment analysis metrics that are commonly employed by the community are also examined in the paper. The findings both highlight the need for more research and show how sentiment analysis can be applied in a variety of fields.

title: Fault Detection and Isolation for Vehicle Lateral Dynamic Systems with Unknown Disturbances
authors: Rongkang Zhang, Xinran Lv, Hongfei Zhang, Le Yan, Zhaodong Liu, Sen Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper investigates the problem of fault detection and isolation for a vehicle lateral dynamic system (VLDS). Firstly, the VLDS model with unknown disturbance and actuator faults is established. Secondly, based on the Luenberger observer, the robust decoupling residual is generated to detect the faults. In addition, the states are decomposed into multiple first-order components, and the minimum-order observers are designed to decouple the faults in some designated components and sensitive to the other faults. Finally, a simulation example of the VLDS is presented to verify the effectiveness and practicability of the proposed method.

title: UHF RFID Chip Parameter Optimization
authors: Nicolas Barbot, Ionela Prodan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper provides a theoretical method allowing one to optimize the parameters of an UHF RFID chip to maximize the performance of an RFID system. Thanks to the proposed method, directions and trends to optimize UHF RFID chip parameters such as the input impedance in the default state, the input impedance in the second state, the chip sensitivity or any other parameters affecting these values, can be easily identified. Instead of relying on physical or technological constraints linked to the internal chip architecture, this paper takes an opposite point of view and tries to optimize these values to maximize application metrics such as the forward and round-trip read ranges. Thus, the provided method is actually independent from the technological or physical processes used during the chip design. The results, if achievable, could be used by a chip designer to optimize the performance of any UHF RFID chip.

title: Exploring Chaotic Image Characteristics for Age Classification Enhancement
authors: Nurfarahin Binti Jemali, Renee Ka Yin Chin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Age classification using deep learning has gained significant attention due to its application in various fields. However, image classification models face challenges with noise and chaotic inputs, leading to a lack of robustness needed for consistent real-world performance. Various types of noise present in real-world images introduce confusion among classifiers. Therefore, this study focuses on establishing baseline accuracy for MobileNetV2 before introducing noise augmentation. In addition to testing noisy datasets, mixed datasets with both clean and noisy images are used to assess model robustness. To solve class imbalance, balanced datasets are generated with both uniform and unequal noise distributions. The results revealed that the model's accuracy decreased as noise levels increased, although balancing measures helped reduce the performance degradation and improve fairness across ages. While the clean dataset is normally the most accurate, in this experiment, the 50% noisy dataset had a slightly better accuracy (85.17%) than the clean dataset (84.94%). This minor improvement is most likely due to the regularization effect of moderate noise, which allowed the model to generalize more effectively to previously unseen data. Mixed datasets produced more robust findings where the uniform noise enhanced fairness across classes but reduced overall accuracy, whereas uneven noise increased accuracy for certain age groups but introduced classification bias.

title: Wideband Direction Finding of UAVs/Drones using Log-periodic Antenna Array
authors: Van Long Do, Binh Minh Tran, Minh Tung Duong, Thai Binh Nguyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: The proliferation of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) has raised significant security and surveillance challenges, necessitating high-precision direction-finding (DF) techniques for effective detection and tracking. This paper presents a novel approach to UAV direction finding using an antenna array of 16 log-periodic elements, designed for wideband operation and accurate direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation. The system utilizes an RF switch to sequentially sample signals from each antenna pair, thus reducing hardware requirements. An advanced DF algorithm, combining phase center concept and correlative interferometer, is employed to achieve accurate DOA estimation. Experimental results demonstrate the system’s ability to accurately determine the direction of UAVs under different scenarios, validating its robustness and applicability for real-world operation.

title: An Improved Random Forest Based Fault Diagnosis Method for Traction Motor under Multiple Working Conditions
authors: Shaozhi Chen, Xiaopeng Xi, Xin Zhang, Maiying Zhong, Marcos E. Orchard
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Random forest (RF)-based fault diagnosis models may struggle to maintain fault diagnosis accuracy under different working conditions. Motivated by this, an improved dual-label random forest (IDLRF) method is proposed for fault diagnosis. Considering characteristics of the fault diagnosis under multiple working conditions, such as samples with fault and working condition labels, a novel node splitting method with a dual-label Gini index is designed to implement the dual-label multi-classification decision tree algorithm. A dual-label ensemble strategy is constructed to obtain the IDLRF algorithm on the proposed dual-label multi-classification decision tree algorithm. Finally, the IDLRF method is experimentally verified by using the traction motor data collected from the traction transmission system of high-speed trains. Experimental results show that the IDLRF method acquires the satisfactory performance and outperforms other fault diagnosis methods in terms of fault diagnosis accuracy, running time, and F1-score.

title: Adaptive SNR-Based Higher-Order MOCZ for Short-Packet Communications
authors: Tuncay Eren
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Short-packet communication is a key enabler for low-latency and high-reliability internet of things (IoT) applications. Multi-user modulation on conjugate-reciprocal zeros (MU-MOCZ) is a non-coherent transmission scheme that supports multiple users without requiring explicit channel estimation, making it particularly suitable for such scenarios. This paper investigates an SNR-based dynamic modulation strategy for higher-order MU-MOCZ, inspired by adaptive modulation techniques in conventional cellular systems. In the proposed design, users are allocated different modulation orders based on their instantaneous SNR, with high-SNR users employing higher-order MOCZ to enhance throughput, while low-SNR users adopt lower-order MOCZ for improved detection reliability. Time-domain multiplexing with guard intervals is employed to mitigate inter-user interference in multipath channels. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed SNR-based allocation achieves a favorable trade-off between spectral efficiency and reliability, significantly improving bit error rate and packet delivery ratio compared to fixed-order MU-MOCZ. These findings highlight the potential of dynamic higher-order MU-MOCZ to meet the stringent requirements of ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC) and heterogeneous multi-user short-packet applications in 6G and beyond networks.

title: Multi-Contour Intellectual Cyber Protection System Methodology
authors: Yevhen Melenti, Serhii Yevseiev, Stanislav Milevskyi, Olena Akhiiezer, Vladyslav Sokol, Anton Smirnov
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The development of quantum technologies requires the construction of fundamentally new information protection systems for any security object. The authors propose a methodology for building a multi-contour intelligent system for cyber protection of critical infrastructure objects (security) based on an objective assessment of the current state of the object's security based on post-quantum algorithms and the distribution of infrastructure elements onto separate platforms, taking into account possible targeted attacks on the internal and external circuits. At the same time, for each platform, possible emergent properties of the constituent platforms of socio-cyberphysical systems – social networks, cloud and physical platform – are taken into account. Synthesis of the intellectual component for the assessment of the current state, taking into account the influence not only of social engineering methods, but also of the signs of hybridity, synergy of modern cyber threats, as well as active threats of cybercriminals (cyberterrorists). This approach provides consideration of security in the form of three components: cybersecurity, information security and security of information, and ensures the construction of an intelligent multi-contour information protection system of the protected object. In addition, the integration of post-quantum algorithms (crypto-code constructions based on LDPC codes) with digital information methods provides not only the necessary level of stability, but also the secrecy of the very fact of transmitting any information (by any communication channels).

title: Cardiovascular Disease Detection using Embedded Software for Signal Processing: Technical Review
authors: Jorge Luis Hinostroza, Gricel Mucha, Jose Cornejo, Silvia Rita Rodríguez Alvarez
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Embedded systems and specialized software have revolutionized the diagnosis of cardiovascular diseases (CVD), especially in regions with limited access to medical services. This systematic review analyzes how these technologies enable early detection and efficient processing of biomedical signals through low-cost portable devices. Using the PRISMA methodology, 396 articles were identified and 21 recent studies from Scopus were selected. The results showed that 52% used ECG signals as the main tool and 76% carried out experimental validations on real devices. Geographically, 29% of the research originated from China, followed by Europe and other Asian countries. Embedded systems stand out for their high precision, energy efficiency, and adaptability, enabling real-time analysis, arrhythmia detection, and support for clinical diagnosis. It is concluded that the integration of advanced software with embedded hardware is a promising solution to improve access to cardiovascular diagnoses in vulnerable populations. This study offers a reference framework for developers and medical institutions, highlighting the need to optimize these technologies for large-scale implementation.

title: Reconfigurable Silicon Photonic Integrated Circuit-Based Mode Repeater for Multi-Dimensional Free-Space Optical Communications
authors: SeyedMohammad SeyedinNavadeh, Alessandro di Tria, Francesco Zanetto, Giorgio Ferrari, Marco Sampietro, Andrea Melloni, Francesco Morichetti
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: A reconfigurable Silicon photonic integrated circuit is presented that can perform mode demultiplexing and multiplexing of free-space beams. The circuit consists of optical antenna arrays and Mach-Zehnder-interferometer-based processors. Apart from multiple modes, capability of the device to handle multiple wavelengths and counter-propagating beams is demonstrated.

title: Comparative Analysis of BFS, Dijkstra, and A* Pathfinding Algorithms in 2D Maze: A Time-Based Approach
authors: Rohan, Shashank Shandilya, Saurabh Rawat, Anshika Choudhary
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper presents a detailed comparison of three popular path-finding algorithms: BFS, Dijkstra’s algorithm, and A*, for solving 2D mazes. Path-finding is a widely studied problem in computer science and AI, from navigating a robot to moving an agent in a game, navigating through space, whether real or virtual, can be seen as path-finding. The objective of this research is to test the time complexity and efficiency of each algorithm in solving a selection of mazes of varying complexity levels, and to determine how well these algorithms can perform in real-time situations, where action must be taken quickly. Each algorithm is tested through simulated edge cases, giving way to a comprehensive algorithm performance assessment. After a comprehensive analysis of results, it was concluded that in mazes with obstacles the all the algorithms have similar performance, with BFS being the best, followed by A* and Dijkstra. In mazes without obstacles, BFS outperforms all algorithms, subsequently followed by Dijkstra and A*.

title: Research on the Application of Digital Twin Technology in Intelligent Maintenance of Steel Equipment
authors: Yongbiao Ning, Ye Wang, Wenhu Zhao
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In the field of iron and steel industry, the equipment maintenance support system is crucial to maintaining the operational efficiency and reliability of equipment. However, the traditional maintenance mode based on historical data has time lag and analytical limitations, making it difficult to meet the real-time and accurate guarantee needs of modern complex equipment. With the characteristics of bidirectional mapping between virtual and physical entities and dynamic collaboration, digital twin technology brings innovation to the whole life cycle management of equipment, and can significantly improve the efficiency of visual management and control, condition monitoring, fault diagnosis and maintenance decision-making. This paper focuses on the equipment maintenance support system in the iron and steel industry. It first clarifies the scope of guarantee and core elements, then constructs a digital twin theoretical model and analyzes its architectural composition. Based on the bidirectional flow of twin data, it designs a technical operation and maintenance framework and overcomes the key technical problems in platform construction, providing theoretical and practical solutions for the intelligent upgrading of the industry.

title: A comparative study of anomaly detection approaches in time-series environmental sensor data
authors: Ly-Huynh Phan, Chi Minh Hieu Nguyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Building sensor anomaly detection is crucial for operational efficiency and equipment reliability, yet standardized evaluation frameworks are lacking, leading to inconsistent method selection. This paper presents a comprehensive comparison of anomaly detection methods using a novel unsupervised evaluation framework that incorporates statistical consistency, temporal coherence, cross-method agreement, and domain logic compliance. We evaluate three paradigms—statistical (STL), machine learning (Isolation Forest), and deep learning (LSTM Autoencoder)—on real-world building sensor data spanning two years with eight sensor types. Our results show that Isolation Forest achieves the best overall performance with a total score of 0.464 and superior computational efficiency of 0.339 seconds, detecting four collective anomalies with excellent temporal coherence. Surprisingly, the LSTM Autoencoder achieves only a 0.263 total score despite 206.444 seconds training time, challenging assumptions about deep learning superiority. These findings demonstrate that well-designed traditional methods can outperform complex deep learning approaches when considering computational efficiency and practical deployment requirements, providing essential guidance for building monitoring system design.

title: Design and Analysis of Planar Surface and Perfect Quantum Error Correction Codes
authors: Mayasa Al Hinai, Hafiz M. Asif
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: Quantum Error Correction (QEC) is essential for achieving fault-tolerant quantum computation, enabling the protection of fragile quantum information from decoherence and noise. While classical Forward Error Correction (FEC) codes have been highly effective in digital communication systems, their direct application to quantum systems is inadequate mainly due to the no cloning theorem and the continuous nature of quantum errors. Unlike classical FECs, QEC is designed to detect and correct both bit-flip and phase-flip errors without disturbing the encoded quantum state. This paper presents the code structure design and simulation of two quantum error correction codes—the Planar surface code and the 5-qubit Perfect code—using Qiskit and Stim on Google Colab. It is worth mentioning here that the performance of the Steane [ [7], [1], [3]] code is included in the current work as a benchmark. The codes are evaluated under statistical noise models, including amplitude damping and dephasing, which closely mirror the physical behavior of quantum hardware. The primary performance metric, for performance assessment, is the logical error rate, evaluated across a range of physical error rates and code distances under each noise model. The simulation results show that increasing the distance of the Planar code significantly reduces the logical error rates, demonstrating superior performance compared to other similar codes under this study.

title: Interpretable Classification of Laminar and Turbulent Flow Using Gated Deep Learning Models with SHAP-Based Explainability
authors: Burçak Asal
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This study introduces a deep learning based approach for classifying flow dynamics into laminar and turbulent flow regimes by deploying two advanced models, which are GATE (Gated Additive Tree Ensemble) and GANDALF (Gated Adaptive Network for Deep Automated Learning of Features). Experimental results demonstrate that while both models achieve high performance, GANDALF outperforming GATE, by reaching an accuracy of 99.8% and an F1-score of 0.998. Ultimately, To further increase model transparency SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) analysis is conducted on GANDALF model, which reveals that features such as pressure, vertical velocity and their temporal and spatial derivatives had the most vital impact on model estimations.

title: Magnetic Resonance Image Segmentation for Myocardial Scar Detection using Multi-stage DeepLabV3+ Framework with Comparative Backbone Analysis
authors: Nur ‘Ulya Nasuha Zakaria, Muhammad Khusairi Osman, Siti Noraini Sulaiman, Dayang Suhaida Awang Damit, Zakaria Hussain, Nor Afnan Zharif Nor Kamal, Nor Ashidi Mat Isa, Noor Khairiah A. Karim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Myocardial infarction (MI) remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality globally. Accurate segmentation of infarcted myocardial regions from cardiac magnetic resonance images (MRI) is crucial for diagnosis and treatment planning. Manual segmentation, though precise, is time-consuming and subject to inter-observer variability. This study introduces a novel multi-stage deep learning framework based on DeepLabV3+ model for automatic myocardial scars detection. The framework employs three DeepLabV3+ models arranged in a multistage configuration, with each network independently segmenting the left ventricle (LV), cavity, myocardium and scar from MRI images. Two different DeepLabV3+’s backbones were investigated which are ResNet50 and MobileNetV2. A dataset of late gadolinium-enhanced cardiac MRI (LGE-CMR) images was obtained from Advanced Medical and Dental Institute (AMDI), Universiti Sains Malaysia (USM), and used with expert-annotated ground truths for training and validation of the proposed framework. The proposed framework was also compared to a single-stage deep learning model that simultaneously segments MRI images into LV, cavity, myocardium and scar to benchmark its performance. Experimental results show that the framework demonstrated promising performance in segmenting infarct regions, measured by Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC), IoU and accuracy of each. The proposed framework achieved the dice similarity of 0.68486, IoU of 0.4849 and the accuracy 0.6133 respectively. The results support the potential of the proposed method in clinical workflows, offering fast, reliable, and reproducible segmentation.

title: Coupling in Optical Fibers: A Review
authors: Luca Palmieri
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Mode coupling is a fundamental concept to model and understand light propagation in optical fibers when they are affected by irregularities with respect to an ideal case. This paper reviews the basic principles of coupled mode theory and its main applications.

title: Vibration Analysis of Multilayer Ceramic Capacitor under Pulsed Electric Field and Research in Mechanism of Frequency-sensitive Transient Breakdown
authors: Tiju Jiang, Fei Cao, Shiguang Yan, Xuefeng Chen, Haoran Bian, Hua Zhong, Genshui Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Multilayer ceramic capacitor (MLCC) is potential to be extensively utilized in pulsed power system due to its high capacitance and high dielectric strength. However, there are still some unsolvable reliability problems in realistic operations, one of which is frequency-sensitive transient breakdown: a sudden failure occurring significantly below component’s designed expected lifespan. Some previous researches suggest that transient breakdown is related to the frequency of the pulsed electric field, but lacking experimental support. In this article, Laser Doppler vibrometer (LDV) is applied for detecting the vibrational behavior of MLCC when pulsed discharge, the result indicates that the pulsed electric field can activate MLCC to vibrate at specific frequencies and even stimulates resonant vibrations. Through both destructive and nondestructive analysis, we observed a decline of electrical breakdown strength and evidence of cracks within MLCC subjected to transient vibrations. These findings underscore the notion that transient breakdown is a compound electromechanical failure, occurring when a pulsed electric field at a specific frequency triggers transient vibrations within MLCC, these resonant vibrations impair the electrical breakdown strength of MLCC and finally result in transient breakdown.

title: Low-Loss Flexible Filter Based on Compact Double Interdigital Coupling SIR With TPV Technology for Bendable Wireless Communications
authors: Le Liu, Fengjuan Wang, Xiangkun Yin, Ming Xu, Yuan Yang, Ningmei Yu, Yao Li, Yan Li
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a compact, low-loss flexible filter based on a double-interdigital coupling stepped-impedance resonator (SIR) and through-polyimide via (TPV) technology. With a fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 12.5% at 2.5 GHz, the filter achieves a low insertion loss of 1.8 dB in the flat state and only 1.95 dB under bending. Its electrical performance remains highly stable under deformation, while the structure attains a 40% size reduction over the state-of-the-art designs, offering a promising solution for wearable wireless systems demanding flexibility and spectral selectivity.

title: Optimization of Robotaxi Dispatch With Pick-Up/Drop-Off-Point and Boarding-Time Recommendation_supp1-3620487.pdf
authors: Liang Qi
publish: N/A
abstract: With the advancement of vehicular automation and communication technology, autonomous driving has emerged as a significant trend in future transportation. Robotaxis, an innovative mode of transportation that integrates robotics and artificial intelligence, are anticipated to become widely used, thereby revolutionizing urban mobility. This work proposes a multi-objective mixed integer programming model for robotaxi dispatch. Unlike previous approaches, it can recommend passengers’ pick-up points, drop-off points, and boarding time (BT) that may deviate from their initial origins, destinations, and BT, respectively. It encourages passengers to accept the recommended pick-up and drop-off (UO) points or to be picked up slightly earlier or later. The objectives are to maximize the profit per kilometer of robotaxis and to minimize the total travel expense of passengers. Subsequently, a nondominated sorting genetic algorithm with mass center (NSGA-MC) is proposed to solve the model. It outperforms nondominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA-II) and multi-objective evolutionary algorithm based on decomposition (MOEA/D) across several metrics. Some instances provide detailed results that illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. Additionally, a sensitivity analysis is performed, comparing scenarios with and without UO-point and boarding-time recommendations. An experiment is also conducted to examine various recommendation acceptance rates, demonstrating the advantages of the proposed model in developing intelligent public transportation systems.

title: MOSAIC: Mobility-Oriented Scheduling and Intelligent Resource Allocation for IoT
authors: Abolfazl Younesi, Mehrab Toghani, Sepideh Safari, Mohsen Ansari, Thomas Fahringer
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The relentless growth of mobile Internet of Things (IoT) devices has shifted computation toward a distributed computing continuum, spanning edge, fog, and cloud layers, where energy efficiency, low latency, and dynamic node mobility are critical yet often conflicting goals. Existing scheduling frameworks struggle to balance these demands under real-world conditions, especially as device movement and heterogeneous workloads increase system complexity. We present MOSAIC, a mobility-aware scheduling and resource management framework designed to optimize performance in dynamic IoT environments. Our approach introduces three key innovations. First, a refined five-tier architecture extends the traditional edge-fog-cloud hierarchy by adding proximity, local, and regional mobility layers, enabling computation to follow mobile users more effectively and reducing unnecessary network traffic. Second, MOSAIC integrates a preemption-aware dynamic scheduler with an Adaptive-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\lambda$</tex-math></inline-formula> reinforcement learning-based resource manager that adapts based on workload changes and mobility patterns, prioritizing energy-efficient edge execution while meeting strict deadlines. Third, the framework utilizes real-world mobility traces, including Levy-Walk, Random-Walk, and Geolife, to drive reconfiguration and improve decision accuracy. We evaluate MOSAIC through a large-scale deployment across three geographically distributed regions of the Grid'5000 testbed, using realistic workflows and mixed periodic/DAG task loads. Our results show that, compared to state-of-the-art schedulers, MOSAIC reduces energy consumption by 35.9%–×1.5, lowers latency by 42.8%–×4.9, and shortens makespan by 22.6%–×7.2, all while maintaining 100% deadline satisfaction across diverse mobility scenarios.

title: STAGE: STyle-controllable Action GEneration for personalized autonomous driving
authors: Zihao Liu, Xing Liu, Yizhai Zhang, Panfeng Huang
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Driving style refers to the behavioral preferences that drivers maintain during driving, shaped by their diverse experiences, habits, and needs, and is typically reflected in varying levels of aggressiveness. If humans choose to use autonomous driving systems, they would expect the driving style of the systems to closely resemble their own habit. However, this is challenging for current industrial autonomous driving systems. To address this, we developed a style controllable action generation method, STAGE, for driving tasks. Its training process is based on imitation learning, incorporating both style value and latent value action modality encoding. Preference learning is then used to identify the user's driving style as a continuous, monotonic style value. And to reduce the cost of human involvement in the preference training process, we also developed a set of rules to compare driving style in data pairs. Then, during inference, the user inputs the style value to control the generated action patterns, dynamically meeting the user's expectations. Using the STAGE method, we verified that the style-controlled action generation results in several typical road scenarios significantly align with human expectations. Furthermore, through comparisons between the STAGE method and various other approaches, we reveal the unique functionalities of STAGE, including its style controllability, style continuity, driving style alignment capability and driving safety. The code for this work is available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/CarlDegio/STAGE</uri>

title: Strategies for Improving the Accuracy of UWB Signal Classification
authors: Yupu Jia, Bingfeng Li, Penghui Jing
publish: IEEE Journal of Radio Frequency Identification
abstract: In many Radio Frequency Identification-based systems, Ultra-Wideband technology has emerged as a compelling alternative for improving positioning accuracy. Thanks to its high precision, low power consumption, and strong anti-interference capability, it shows broad application potential in complex environments. However, under non-line-of-sight conditions, the accuracy is considerably degraded due to signal obstruction and multipath interference. To address this challenge, an Ultra-Wideband signal classification method is proposed that leverages multi-level feature fusion and a cross-channel attention network. Initially, a feature selection mechanism utilizing recursive feature elimination with cross-validation is proposed to identify and retain the most salient Ultra-Wideband signal features, thereby mitigating the impact of irrelevant features and reducing computational complexity. Subsequently, to further enhance the model’s feature representation capability, a multi-level feature fusion module is introduced, which progressively integrates the outputs of each convolutional layer, consolidating features from multiple stages of the network. Concurrently, to further strengthen the proposed network’s ability to capture key features, a cross-channel attention mechanism is incorporated to adaptively assign weights based on feature importance. The results demonstrate that the proposed method achieved classification accuracies of 93.15%, 96.2%, and 98.49% on the three Ultra-Wideband datasets.

title: Differentiable Contact Dynamics for Stable Object Placement Under Geometric Uncertainties
authors: Linfeng Li, Gang Yang, Lin Shao, David Hsu
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: From serving a cup of coffee to positioning mechanical parts during assembly, stable object placement is a crucial skill for future robots. It becomes particularly challenging under geometric uncertainties, e.g., when the object pose or shape is not known accurately. This work leverages a differentiable simulation model of contact dynamics to tackle this challenge. We derive a novel gradient that relates force-torque sensor readings to geometric uncertainties, thus enabling uncertainty estimation by minimizing discrepancies between sensor data and model predictions via gradient descent. Gradient-based methods are sensitive to initialization. To mitigate this effect, we maintain a belief over multiple estimates and choose the robot action based on the current belief at each timestep. In experiments on a Franka robot arm, our method achieved promising results on multiple objects under various geometric uncertainties, including the in-hand pose uncertainty of a grasped object, the object shape uncertainty, and the environment uncertainty.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Autonomous Drift System for Abrupt Obstacle Avoidance
authors: Yang LIU, Xiaodong MEI, Bohuan XUE, Jin WU
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Autonomous vehicles face significant challenges in executing emergency obstacle avoidance maneuvers beyond conventional driving limits. Previous approaches, relying on vehicle dynamics modeling or simplified learning methods, often struggle with generalization to diverse scenarios. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning-based Drift Obstacle Avoiding (DOA) system for extreme obstacle avoidance. Our system integrates adrift path planner based on cubic spline curves with a controller trained in a high-fidelity simulator using expert demonstrations and a Refined-exploration Soft Actor Critic (RSAC) algorithm. Utilizing only real-world accessible vehicle states, the system exhibits robust performance across various scenarios, vehicle types, andchallenging road conditions. We validate our approach through extensive simulation testing and open-source our code and expert trajectories dataset at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/ustcly/DOA</uri>for further studies.

title: Meta-Reinforcement Based Multi-Path Selection in Satellite-Ground Integrated Networks
authors: Tianheng Xu, Yang Gu, Wen Du, Kai Ying, Qingqing Wu, Pei Peng, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: This letter proposes a distributed path selection algorithm based on the meta multi-agent proximal policy optimization (Meta-MAPPO). The algorithm leverages transferable knowledge to achieve faster and more stable policy optimization in dynamic satellite networks. We integrate meta-learning into the MAPPO framework, equipping agents with rapid adaptation capabilities and enhancing convergence efficiency through experience sharing. Simulation results on a 96-satellite Walker–Delta constellation demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves at least a 5% reduction in average end-to-end delay, maintains zero packet loss, and converges faster, demonstrating its efficiency and robustness in dynamic satellite network environments.

title: Impedance Modeling and Analysis of Solid/Liquid Hybrid Electrolyte Lithium-ion Batteries
authors: Zhaoyang Zhao, Yuting Liu, Herbert Ho-Ching Iu, Jiaye Wang, Hongwei Tao, Haitao Hu, Zhengyou He, Weiming Chen, Frede Blaabjerg, Pooya Davari
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely used in electric vehicles and energy storage applications. However, conventional LIB is mainly composed of flammable liquid electrolytes, which has significant potential safety hazards and thermal runaway risks. Reducing the liquid electrolyte content helps to improve the intrinsic safety of batteries. A solid/liquid hybrid electrolyte lithium-ion battery (SLE-LIB) with less electrolyte (i.e., quasi-solid-state LIB) has been chosen as a transition from liquid electrolyte LIBs to all-solid-state LIBs, and it has achieved commercial application. Although electrochemical impedance is a powerful technique for condition monitoring and degradation analysis of batteries, the impedance model considering solid/liquid hybrid electrolytes has not yet been well established. To fill this gap, this paper investigates the impedance variation of a commercial SLE-LIB under different aging cycles, temperatures, and state-of-charge conditions. An equivalent circuit model (ECM) of the impedance spectrum is established to analyze its features further. The analysis results identify the available impedance features and corresponding internal changes in SLE-LIBs for condition monitoring, e.g., the imaginary-part impedance, ECM parameters for temperature monitoring. Furthermore, three case studies are introduced based on the obtained impedance feature parameters. The results illustrate that the estimation errors of temperature and health state are less than 4%, and the proposed impedance features can be used for degradation analysis. The research results can provide references for condition monitoring and degradation analysis of SLE-LIBs.
