title: APU: Accelerate Point Cloud Neural Networks via Unified Processing-in-SRAM Architecture
authors: Chen Nie, Boning Zhang, Kang You, Yu Feng, Yu He, Chao Jiang, Limin Xiao, Weifeng Zhang, Zhezhi He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Recent advances in deep learning have expanded point cloud applications by point-based neural networks (PNNs). However, the escalating complexity and computational demands of PNNs overwhelm conventional computers. Specialized PNN accelerators have emerged, significantly outperforming modern CPUs and GPUs. Nevertheless, existing designs remain inefficient when handling performance-critical mapping kernels of PNNs, involving diverse arithmetic functions (e.g., add, multiply, sort) across separate hardware modules. This fragmentation restricts hardware sharing and data locality, leading to area overhead, redundant data movements, and under-utilization. Therefore, a unified and efficient micro-architecture for mapping kernels is needed to enhance performance and reduce data transfers. This paper presents APU, an efficient processing-in-memory (PIM) architecture for PNN acceleration. We introduce the first unified SRAM-PIM micro-architecture that supports all mapping kernels in mainstream PNNs. Data movement is reduced through extensive on-chip memory and maximized data locality via in-situ computing approach. At the algorithmic level, we introduce mask grouping and aggregation to eliminate costly sorting operations, enabled by hardware support for in-memory vector max-search. This refined strategy reduces computational overhead and data transfers while improving inference accuracy.We further enhance performance by exploiting parallelism across PNN operations and applying mixed-precision quantization. Evaluated on real-world PNN workloads, APU outperforms the state-of-the-art accelerator by 2.54× in speedup and 4.54× in energy saving.

title: Bedfellows? Managerial optimism and optimistic alignment in collaborative innovation_supp1-3640209.pdf
authors: Jie Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: In practice, firms' managers are key decision-makers and are often plagued by optimistic bias. In collaborative innovation, this optimism manifests in both alignment and divergence among parties, which affects the efficiency and stability of collaborative innovation. However, the conditions and mechanisms underlying these effects remain unclear. To explore this issue, we consider a collaborative supply chain in which the supplier and the downstream manufacturer are realistic or optimistic. Our paper demonstrates the positive promotion of managerial optimism in innovation and shows that optimistic managers can innovate even when the profit in the supply chain is negative. Moreover, aligned optimism allows the supplier to shift the burden of innovation and cost to the manufacturer, increasing the manufacturer's innovation level. However, compared to aligned optimism, divergent optimism can lead to win-win outcomes under certain conditions. Furthermore, our findings suggest that when the optimism bias in consumer innovation preference is high, the supplier should choose a collaborator with an aligned attitude. Similarly, when the bias is moderate, the manufacturer should make the same choice. In both cases, aligned attitudes help synchronize decisions, which can benefit both firms due to higher innovation levels and reasonable prices.

title: Characterization of Leakage Current in Buried Heterostructure Semiconductor InGaAsP Lasers Using a Diode-Resistor Electrical Model
authors: Ciaran D'Arcy McDonald-Jensen, Muhammad Mohsin, Mohamed Rahim, Ping Zhao, Philip Waldron, Jean Lapointe, Darren Goodchild, Bernard Paquette, Omid Salehzadeh Einabad, Donald Bedard, Christina Elliott, Xueping Zhen, Grzegorz Pakulski
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: In buried heterostructure (BH) lasers, leakage current becomes a problem at high input currents, wasting power and reducing optical efficiency. This article introduces an electrical model that represents the voltagecurrent (VI) characteristics of forward-biased BH lasers. This model can be used to explain and predict leakage current. It also gives a diagnostic tool to compare experimental BH lasers, using simple VI measurements. In this experiment, 72 BH lasers with three different mesa top layer doping levels were measured. Then, a curve fit was performed on the VI measurements using the proposed model, extracting the model parameters for each device. Nearly all the extracted model parameters, which were resistances and diode properties such as ideality factor and saturation current, had clear trends that help explain the impact of varying mesa top layer doping levels. The results showed, as discussed in previous literature, that high mesa top layer doping level reduces laser leakage current, but increases cavity loss. It was also found that by using only the fit on electrical characteristics, the model can roughly predict the measured drop in optical efficiency that the BH lasers experience at high input currents. The better understanding of leakage current that comes from this model can be used to further the development of BH lasers. As well, the model and curve fit can be used as a diagnostic tool to aid in the testing of these experimental devices.

title: Digital Twin-Based Defect Size Updating for Bearing Quantitative Diagnosis
authors: Xinyu Lu, Jing Lin, Zongyang Liu, Jinyang Jiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: Bearing quantitative diagnosis is indispensable for the reliability assessment of rotating machinery, facilitating informed maintenance decisions. Existing research typically estimates bearing defect size using signal processing techniques or machine learning tools. However, these approaches rely on elaborate hand-crafted feature extraction or require extensive training data from various fault states, making them difficult to apply in practice. In this article, a novel digital twin-based defect size updating (DT-DSU) scheme is proposed to address these challenges. As a combination of simulation and virtual-reality interaction, digital twin (DT) technology provides a fresh perspective for bearing quantitative diagnosis. A modeling-calibration-updating strategy within the DT framework is adopted to enable unsupervised defect size estimation. First, DT-DSU constructs a DT prototype by embedding fine-grained defects into a simplified dynamic model of bearing. Time-frequency similarity calibration is conducted to obtain a high-fidelity DT model. Then, unlabeled vibration measurements are exploited to build the virtual-reality connection, enabling fault state updating of the DT model. The defect size is determined through the update process. Finally, the effectiveness and superiority of DT-DSU are validated on two different bench tests.

title: GraphMatch: Subgraph Query Processing on Steroids
authors: Jonas Dann, Tobias Goetz, Daniel Ritter, Jana Giceva, Holger Fröning, Gustavo Alonso
publish: Proceedings of the ACM on Management of Data
abstract: None

title: A Fault Diagnosis Scheme for Quadrotor Formation System under Wind Disturbance
authors: Xu Cao, Yajie Ma, Bin Jiang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: As an important component of quadrotors, the real-time fault diagnosis of actuators is crucial for fault recovery and timely adjustment of flight missions. This study proposes a novel distributed fault diagnosis method which combines a self-attention-based multi-scale spatiotemporal feature extractor with a mixture-of-experts multi-task learning module (SAMST-MTMoE). It addresses the challenge of actuator fault diagnosis during quadrotor formation flights in windy conditions by leveraging flight data from neighboring communicating UAVs. This method effectively captures the spatiotemporal distribution of fault information, enabling accurate fault location and classification.

title: A Low-Cost Non-Invasive RFID-Based Framework for Human Posture Detection
authors: Debi Dutta, Andrea Motroni, Simone Genovesi, Giuliano Manara, Filippo Costa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents an RFID-based system for identifying various human postures using a few passive RFID tags integrated with furniture, such as a chair. Posture detection can be achieved through a simple and straightforward algorithm based on the error calculation between test data set and a reference one, encoded by the states of the tags. These states are represented by the normalized counting of tag EPC by a reader for a specific time duration. The algorithm selects the correct posture by identifying the test pattern with minimum error from the reference. The placement and quantity of RFID tags are optimized to balance system accuracy and complexity. The proposed method can reliably distinguish between different sitting postures achieving an accuracy of up to 90 - 94%. Also, a possible framework of extending this method to identify sleep posture in similar way.

title: A neural network training method based on adaptive observer
authors: Beining Liu, Xiaoyi Xu, Hao Luo, Mingyi Huo, Hao Wang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Assuming that neural networks can fit the dynamic characteristics of an unknown nonlinear system well, this paper develops a training method employing adaptive observer for single hidden-layer feedforward neural networks (SLFNs). Traditional SLFN training methods, such as the backpropagation (BP) algorithm, have limitations such as hyperparameter sensitivity and large iterative calculation volume. While the randomization method can improve efficiency, it lacks environmental adaptability. Inspired by the theory of adaptive observer for dynamic systems, this study first established the state space expression of SLFN and then designed an observer-based adaptive estimation mechanism. This mechanism estimates the parameters of the neural network and the values of hidden layer nodes online through input and output data, achieving the collaborative optimization of computational efficiency and generalization performance. Different from the conventional methods that require repeated training, the proposed algorithm can adapt to different operating environments and has significant advantages in time-varying systems such as battery monitoring and engine control. Finally, the effectiveness of this adaptive estimation mechanism applied to neural network training was verified through simulation experiments.

title: Air Quality Prediction by deep learning using Multimodal Data
authors: S. Thangalakshmi, Manikandan S P, P. Anitha, Khaja Mannanuddin, Hayitov Abdulla Nurmatovich, P. Shanthi, B. Venkataramanaiah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Air pollution is one of the most serious environmental and health problems faced globally, and the problem is expected to worsen with rapid industrialization and urbanization. Leveraging multi-modal data sources — such as historical air pollution data, satellite data, weather, and socioeconomic factors — this project aims to predict real time and future air quality levels. Machine learning methods, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) will be applied to key pollutants such as NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and CO, to construct pollution forecasting trends and pinpoint areas of higher risk. Moreover, by taking the spatial and temporal variations in pollution levels into account, statistical and deep learning methods will be integrated into the system to further enhance prediction accuracy.The phenomenon study will assess these issues alongside the effects of air pollution on human health in general, with respiratory diseases as the overarching health indicator, as well as on all-cause mortality. By pin-pointing pollution hotspots, the project plans to alert affected populations in advance and propose possible interventions. Additionally, global forecasts will allow policymakers to design evidence-based policies for reducing the detrimental effects of air pollution. As socio-economic parameters will be induced, we will be able to explore the relationship of industrialisation, population density and urban development with pollution trends.This project aims to provide actionable insights for environmental agencies and urban planners through large-scale data analysis and predictive modelling. The results will contribute to the design of effective policies for pollution control, increase public awareness, and foster sustainable urban development. Overall, this study adds a more comprehensive and transcendental perspective of pollution, its development through time, as well as its definitive health and environmental impacts.

title: Design and Deployment of Microcontroller based affordable Industrial Automation System
authors: Krishanu Kundu, Arsh Raj Srivastava, Abhinav Awasthi, Ayush Prajapati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Automation is the foundation of modern industry, performing tasks with increased efficiency, accuracy, and safety. While this technology is highly beneficial, the application of automation systems in practice remains a considerable hurdle for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) due to the cost of the programmable logic controllers (PLCs) and their implementation complexity. To overcome these difficulties, current work provides a low-cost industrial automation system based on the microcontroller family using programmable switching. The proposed system serves as a cost-effective alternative for sequential load switching to potentially lower the total sequential load switching cost in industrial applications where the cost of PLCs can add up to a significant amount. It provides 3 working modes — Set mode, Auto mode and Manual mode, which enable to carry out any repeated actions automatically and efficiently. It allows monitoring and controlling load operations to be performed more efficiently, reducing errors.

title: Correlation between Surface Morphology and Conductivity of Nanostructured Electrodes: A FESEM and I-V Characterization Study
authors: Uda Hashim, Saroja Rijal, M.N. Afnan Uda, M.N.A. Uda, Yuri Pamungkas, N.H. Ibrahim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This study discusses the fabrication and characterization of aluminum interdigitated electrodes (Al-IDEs) designed for cost-effective electrochemical sensing. The IDEs were created on silicon substrates using UV photolithography with a 5 μm finger width and optimized spacing. Morphological analysis via field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) showed high precision in the electrode structure. Electrical testing through current-voltage (I-V) measurements revealed a stable and linear response across multiple cycles, producing an average current output of 0.12964 nA at 1.0 V, with a relative standard deviation below 3%. These findings demonstrate the reliability of the Al-IDEs for future surface modifications in biosensing applications.

title: Bridging Two Worlds: A Pedagogical Framework for Integrating AI Literacy into HRM Curricula in Morocco
authors: Fatima Zahrae Ferehat, Abdellatif Eddakir
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is reshaping Human Resource Management (HRM), creating a critical need for AI literacy in management education. In Morocco, this global challenge is compounded by a persistent digital skills gap and the absence of a national AI strategy, creating a double gap for its higher education system. Grounded in an integrative review methodology, this paper develops a pedagogical framework through the triangulation of evidence from three distinct streams: a review of academic literature on AI in HRM and pedagogy, a benchmark of leading international university curricula, and an analysis of the Moroccan institutional context. The primary contribution is the HR-AI Bridge Framework, a conceptual model structured around three core pillars: Strategic Application, Ethical Vigilance, and Human-Machine Collaboration. This model offers a structured approach for Moroccan universities to modernize their HRM curriculum. It also contributes a contextualized, non-Western perspective to the global discourse on AI literacy, proposing a pathway to cultivate future-ready leaders capable of acting as the strategic and ethical architects of a human-centric digital transformation.

title: Edge-IoT ConvNeXt-CBAM System for Real-Time Classification of Shrimp Health Conditions
authors: Tan Duy Le, Kha-Tu Huynh, Duc Dat Pham, Hong Quan Nguyen, Minh Tu Nguyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: We present an edge IoT system for real-time classification of four shrimp health conditions (BG, Healthy, WSSV, WSSV-BG) using a ConvNeXt-Tiny backbone enhanced with CBAM. A 9,376-image multi-farm dataset was curated with expert-validated labels. Deployed on a Jetson Nano with TensorRT-FP16, the model achieves 39 ms per frame (peak 25 FPS). In deployment, the camera captured one frame every 2 s for power and uplink efficiency; during the 14-day pilot the system processed 30 frames/min and delivered alerts within ¡ 60 s end-to-end, enabling earlier interventions. In a 14-day, three-pond pilot, the system detected seven confirmed disease events approximately 6 hours earlier than technicians. An ablation study shows CBAM contributes +4.2 F1 points with only +0.4M additional parameters. These results demonstrate practical, low-power on-farm early warning. Future work will explore multimodal fusion and continual learning.

title: Reliability Analysis of SSCB Snubber Circuit with Markov Model and LSTM
authors: Seong Jin Lim, Jae-seong Jo, Sung Yong Joo, Feel-soon Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: The dc solid-state circuit breaker (SSCB) uses MOVs or MOV with resistor-capacitor-diode (RCD) snubber circuit combinations to reduce the surge voltage that occurs when breaking a fault current. The more MOV and RCD circuit components are added, the greater the surge voltage reduction effect. However, as the number of components increases, the failure rate of the snubber circuit increases. This paper analyzes the reliability of the surge voltage reduction circuit. The component failure rate is calculated by mission profile according to the circuit breaker operation based on the FIDES 2022 fault library. Also, the long short-term memory (LSTM) model is used to predict the ambient temperature to calculate the failure rate by reflecting the actual operating temperature of the component. The reliability analysis uses the Markov model to consider the surge voltage fluctuation due to the component's partial failure.

title: 0.3-dB-Loss SCF-to-MCF Power Splitter Based on a Biconical Splice Taper
authors: Sijing Liang, John D. Downie, Sergejs Makovejs, Periklis Petropoulos, Yongmin Jung
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We present a low-loss SCF-to-MCF power splitter based on a biconical splice taper. Power distribution uniformity is enhanced through a macrobending-based post-processing technique that compensates for MCF core inhomogeneity, enabling precise output balancing without additional loss and improving the practicality of scalable splitter designs.

title: On-Site Fiber Identification for PON Systems by Using Reflection Power Measurement of Optical Signal and Test Light
authors: Hiroyuki Iida, Takui Uematsu, Hidenobu Hirota, Takashi Matsui
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We propose a novel on-site optical fibre identification method to detect an unpowered ONU in PON systems. The connection with/without ONU can be identified by measuring the powers of reflected signal and test lights with both fibre bending technique and FBG mounted connectors.

title: Enhancing File Security with an Optimized Auto-Classification Framework Based on Learning Models
authors: Zeliha Açıkgöz, Serdar Arslan, Recep Sinan Arslan
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Malicious PDF files pose a significant threat to digital security. These files can compromise sensitive information and disrupt system operations. Detecting and classifying such files is therefore critical to maintaining cybersecurity. In this study, a systematic approach is introduced to effectively categorize PDF documents. From a dataset of roughly 30,000 PDF files, 43 structural and general features were identified. The dataset was analyzed using a variety of machine learning and deep learning models after being digitized using TF IDF, N-gram, and Word2Vec techniques.Results from machine learning models show high performance, with the Support Vector Machine achieving 0.9967 accuracy using TF-IDF and the Decision Tree reaching 0.9966 accuracy with the count vectorizer and N-gram. For deep learning models, CNN achieved up to 0.9967 accuracy with Count Vectorizer and N-gram, while BiLSTM and GRU also demonstrated high performance using Word2Vec. These results indicate that the proposed approach provides a reliable and effective detection of PDF-based malware.

title: Transforming Healthcare Ecosystems: Scalable Big Data Management and Analytics for Member, Provider, and Claims Intelligence
authors: Vijayanand Selvaraj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The healthcare industry is facing unprecedented challenges in managing the daily influx of massive data volumes from diverse insurance companies, provider networks, and claims repositories. This paper introduces an advanced Big Data Analytics framework to manage high-velocity, high-variety healthcare data, ensuring seamless integration across member profiles, provider files, and claims transactions. Leveraging scalable distributed architectures, semantic data models, and real-time analytics pipelines, our approach not only enhances operational efficiency but also enables early risk identification, improves claims integrity, and supports targeted clinical programs such as precision oncology and cardiac care management. More importantly, it has a significant impact on patient outcomes. The research further demonstrates the application of predictive models to oncology and cardiology datasets, optimizing clinical decision-making and claims adjudication. This paper addresses critical industry gaps in handling large-scale healthcare data while accelerating insights for improved patient and program outcomes by offering a unified, adaptive, and secure engineering solution.

title: 200G-PON Based on 4×50Gbit/s NRZ LWDM Signals Coexisting with 50G-PON, XGS-PON and G-PON
authors: Fabienne Saliou, Joseph Zandueta, Stéphane Le Huérou, Jérémy Potet, Dylan Chevalier, Gaël Simon, Georges Gaillard, Philippe Chanclou
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate 200G-PON transmission using 4×50 Gbit/s NRZ channels over 20 km of fiber, achieving optical budgets of >33 dB while coexisting with three legacy PONs. We propose reusing components similar to those in 50G-PON, ensuring flexible, cost-efficient, pay-as-you-grow upgrades up to 200 Gbit/s.

title: Privacy-preserving transmission scheduling for cyber-physical systems with unknown eavesdropper information
authors: Zengwang Jin, Yitong Liu, Fanglue Shan, Yin Liu, Menglu Ma
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The privacy challenges in Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) under eavesdropping attacks when the eavesdropper information is unknown are addressed in this paper. For the purpose of mitigating privacy leakage while ensuring estimation performance, an optimal transmission scheduling strategy is proposed in this paper to counteract the challenges of steady-state trends and noise decay in stable CPS. Moreover, this strategy reduces the exposure risk of the acknowledgment (Ack) signal by leveraging pre-arranged indicators. The sensor can transmit either real state estimates or artificial noise to disrupt eavesdroppers. To satisfy privacy requirements, the expected error covariance of eavesdropper is maintained above that of legitimate estimator through minimizing a linear combination of both. Additionally, a belief vector is introduced to construct eavesdropper error covariance, accounting for not all eavesdropper information will be available. The optimal transmission scheduling is demonstrated to exhibit a threshold structure, which is supported by theoretical analysis. Numerical results validate the efficacy of the proposed algorithm.

title: Spectrally-Sliced Longitudinal Power Profile Estimation
authors: Tarek Eldahrawy, Abel Lorences-Riesgo, Yann Frignac, Gabriel Charlet
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate that performing PPE over multiple spectral slices can improve accuracy, reduce complexity and enable obtaining frequency-resolved power evolution at the expense of a lower spatial resolution. This is used to detect intra-channel tilt over a 900km link using a commercial transponder

title: Osteoporosis Detection Using Deep Learning: A Computer-Aided Diagnosis System
authors: Sushma D S, Ranjini.A, Sivalingam T, Muthupandian V, Aditya K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Osteoporosis represents a significant skeletal disorder marked by diminished bone mineral density (BMD) and compromised micro architectural integrity, substantially elevating fracture susceptibility, especially among aging populations. This investigation introduces an artificial intelligence-based diagnostic framework that leverages deep neural networks to evaluate radiographic and DEXA imaging data. The architecture uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) framework learnt on curated medical image databases to distinguish normal and bone pattern of a diseased (osteoporotic) bone. The given technology solution can be characterized by a distributed web architecture that will integrate Flask-based analytical services, an interactive interface designed with React.js, and enable receiving instant diagnostic analysis. This study introduces a novel hybrid deep learning model for osteoporosis detection, outperforming existing methods in accuracy and additionally offering treatment and precaution recommendations and as a decision aids system meant to help the medical practitioners, this system provides an effective low-cost and scalable solution of initial osteoporosis assessments.

title: CD Pre-Compensated Tx with ODB Modulation and Direct-Detection RX for VHSP Downstream
authors: Lorenzo Andrenacci, Giuseppe Caruso, Ivan N. Cano, Ye Zhicheng, Giuseppe Rizzelli, Giuseppe Talli, Gabriella Bosco, Roberto Gaudino
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate VHSP coexistence with all ITU-T PONs by leveraging ODB modulation and fixed-tap CD pre-compensation. Digital pre-equalisation keeps the optical penalty of a 125-GB/s ODB below 3.5dB up to an accumulated CD of 72ps/nm, achieving N1 budget-class. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Short term wind speed prediction based on optimization decomposition and dynamic feature selection
authors: Li Chenghu, Wang Cong, Ma Ping, Zhang Hongli, Lu Xuehui
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Wind speed prediction in wind farms is often hindered by insufficient feature extraction and low prediction accuracy. To address these challenges and enhance both the accuracy and reliability of wind speed forecasts, a novel integrated prediction model is proposed, combining optimized variational mode decomposition (VMD), convolutional neural networks (CNN), long short-term memory networks (LSTM), and Kolmogorov Arnold networks (KAN). Initially, the maximum mutual information coefficient (MMIC) is selected as the fitness function, and the grey wolf optimization algorithm (GWO) is employed to globally optimize the modal decomposition layers and penalty factors of the VMD. The optimized VMD is then used to effectively decompose the raw wind speed data, followed by the reconstruction of the decomposed components. Finally, the dynamic feature selection mechanism of the KAN network is integrated with CNN and LSTM to construct a CNN-LSTM-KAN prediction model for wind speed forecasting. Experimental results demonstrate that the KAN network significantly improves the extraction of wind speed features, thereby enhancing the predictive capability of the model. The effectiveness and generalization of the proposed approach are further validated through simulations using measured data from various wind farms.

title: BaldPredict: AI-Driven Prediction Model for Alopecia Areata
authors: Mandeep Singh, Prabhjot Kaur, Rinku Garg
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Autoimmune diseases called the alopecia area lead to sudden staining hair loss in the face, scalp, or body. This disease can reason the entirety from small white spots to finish loss of the frame and hair on the head. There is a 1:1000 chance to develop this state. Both adults and children may be affected. The basis of traditional diagnostic methods is visual inspection, which usually results in poor accuracy. However, recent developments in machine learning (ML) have significantly improved disease diagnosis in a variety of health fields, including dermatology. This study examines the potential of computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) to improve the accuracy for prediction and to assist physicians in achieving more reliable conclusions with a data record with 1000 images of healthy hair to create a robust prediction system. This was created by web scraping and over 500 images were created that were affected by AA using DERMNET data records. Data records were further improved using preprocessing techniques such as data expansion, segmentation and image improvement. This analyzes numerous classifiers consisting of random forest classifiers, support vector machines (SVM),k-nearest network (KNN), and CNN to improve diagnostic accuracy with the accuracy rate are 89%, 90%, 83%, and 91.9% respectively. By using an ML-based classification algorithm it is better for identification alopecia areata, this work ultimately seeks to advance the diagnosis of bald prediction.

title: Branched DPS-QKD Employing a WDM-Compatible Silicon Micro-Ring Resonator as Shared Quantum State Analyser
authors: Florian Honz, Paul Müllner, Michael Hentschel, Philip Walther, Hannes Hübel, Rainer Hainberqer, Bernhard Schrenk
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We prove micro-ring resonator assisted DPS-QKD as multi-wavelength alternative to delay-interferometer based implementations. We show wavelength-agnostic generation of secure keys over 13 WDM channels ranging from 1534.3 to 1555.3nm. We further demonstrate simultaneous QKD operation over 12.8km, for which two users shared the state analyser. © 2025 The Author(s)

title: Intelligent Decision-Making in Manufacturing Transformation: A Large Multimodal Approace
authors: Wei Yang, Zhenxing Su, Weinan Zhong
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Modern manufacturing systems operate under mounting pressure to transform due to shifting market needs and intricate operations and immediate reaction requirements without sufficient success using traditional decision-making systems. The research develops a Large Multimodal Approach for Intelligent Decision-Making in Manufacturing Transformation to resolve identified difficulties. The new framework unites DQN models with ERP and MES and PCS system data using sophisticated data fusion methods to present a modern manufacturing situation that maintains synchronized real-time control. A DQN model trained using historical production data generates optimal future decisions through its system while Principal Component Analysis (PCA) streamlines the data focus on essential features. Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA) makes strategic production goals part of decision-making processes and Model Predictive Control (MPC) allows instant modification of production parameters at runtime. Online Learning operates within the system to dynamically adapt production methods when facing changes in operating conditions. The proposed method outperforms Q-Learning, PPO, and standalone DQN according to performance tests through achieving cycle time of 96 along with maximum yield at 90% and a peak decision accuracy level of 90%. The research validates that this system stands above others in achieving optimal manufacturing infrastructure enhancement through real-time and adaptive intelligent decisions

title: Cloud Belief Rule Base Model for Aero-engine Performance Degradation Prediction
authors: Bangcheng Zhang, Danyang Liu, Guanyu Hu, Shuo Gao, Yubo Shao, Zhi Gao
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: To effectively integrate qualitative knowledge and quantitative data for predicting aero-engine performance degradation, a cloud belief rule base (CBRB) prediction model is proposed. The traditional belief rule base model can effectively handle uncertain quantitative data, but it lacks precision in representing expert knowledge. The proposed CBRB model employs a cloud model for the reference points of belief rules, which can more accurately and objectively describe qualitative knowledge. Additionally, to predict the aero-engine performance degradation under both single and variable working conditions, comparative experiments are designed by using the CBRB model and other models. The findings confirm the practical utility of the CBRB model, demonstrating its superior forecasting accuracy compared to other models.

title: A Vision-Based Shared-Control Teleoperation Scheme for Controlling the Robotic Arm of a Four-Legged Robot
authors: Murilo Vinicius Da Silva, Matheus Hipolito Carvalho, Juliano Negri, Thiago Segreto, Gustavo J. G. Lahr, Ricardo V. Godoy, Marcelo Becker
publish: 2025 Latin American Robotics Symposium (LARS)
abstract: In hazardous and remote environments, robotic systems perform critical tasks demanding improved safety and efficiency. Among these, quadruped robots with manipulator arms offer mobility and versatility for complex operations. However, teleoperating quadruped robots is challenging due to the lack of integrated obstacle detection and intuitive control methods for the robotic arm, increasing collision risks in confined or dynamically changing workspaces. Teleoperation via joysticks or pads can be non-intuitive and demands a high level of expertise due to its complexity, culminating in a high cognitive load on the operator. To address this challenge, a teleoperation approach that directly maps human arm movements to the robotic manipulator offers a simpler and more accessible solution. This work proposes an intuitive remote control by leveraging a vision-based pose estimation pipeline that utilizes an external camera with a machine learning-based model to detect the operator’s wrist position. The system maps these wrist movements into robotic arm commands to control the robot’s arm in real-time. A trajectory planner ensures safe teleoperation by detecting and preventing collisions with both obstacles and the robotic arm itself. The system was validated on the real robot, demonstrating robust performance in real-time control. This teleoperation approach provides a cost-effective solution for industrial applications where safety, precision, and ease of use are paramount, ensuring reliable and intuitive robotic control in high-risk environments.

title: Optimized Tree-Based Mining Contrast Subspace for Categorical Data
authors: Nadia Mukti, Florence Sia, Lai Po Hung, Tan Soo Fun, Rayner Alfred, Ayman Al-Ani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Contrast subspace mining is the process of finding contrast subspaces in a dataset where a given query object is most similar to a target class but most different to other class. A contrast subspace typically consists of one or more features derived from the original feature set of the dataset. The obtained contrast subspace is mainly used to gain insight about the query object and thus, provide information to perform further analysis for better decision making on certain tasks. Contrast subspace mining using tree technique has shown the capability to mine contrast subspace for a query object in a categorical dataset. However, the optimization of the contrast subspace search process has not yet been explored to find contrast subspace globally. This research proposes an optimized contrast subspace search by applying genetic algorithm, called TB-CSMinerGC, to discover contrast subspace on data consisting categorical features. The likelihood contrast scoring function based on tree technique is used as a fitness function to select the contrast subspace with the most potential for a query object for evolution in order to avoid being trapped in a local optima search space. The experiment results show that the optimized method managed to determine the contrast subspaces of a query object in four real world categorical datasets and outperform the existing method in 10 out of 16 cases.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Rate-Adaptation via Hybrid Polar-BCH Product Code for Flexible PON
authors: Yifan Ye, Bin Chen, Xiang Li, Yi Lei, Zhiwei Liang, Qingqing Hu, Can Zhao, Yanni Ou
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: The flexible-rate Polar-BCH product codes are experimentally demonstrated in a coherent passive optical network system with 16QAM for the first time. Using a new hybrid soft- and hard-decision decoder, we achieve a power gain of upto 1.75 dB over traditional BCH-BCH product codes after 48 km transmission.

title: Entanglement Purification by Integrated Silicon Photonics
authors: Yonghe Yu, Siyan Zhou, Mujtaba Zahidy, Caterina Vigliar, Karsten Rottwitt, Leif K. Oxenløwe, Yunhong Ding
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate the first on-chip deterministic entanglement purification based on silicon photonics. To evaluate the purification performance, we simulate the bit-flip and phase-flip errors by reconfigurable circuits on chip. The state fidelity improves from 0.71 to 0.82 under a 20 % bit-flip error rate.

title: Cost-effective and Flexible Coherent Optics for Next-Generation Optical Access Networks
authors: Junwen Zhang, Penghao Luo, An Yan, Jianyang Shi, Nan Chi
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Coherent Passive Optical Network (CPON) is emerging as a promising solution for next-generation 200G or even 400G optical access. This paper reviews recent advances in cost-effective optimization strategies and flexible rate allocation techniques, and further discusses the major challenges and potential solutions for CPON. ©2025 The Author(s).

title: Harris Performance as Activation Function for Image Classification in Convolutional Neural Network and Transfer Learning Models
authors: Luther A. Villacruz, Maria Lyn Bernadette G. Mendoza, Robetson A. Laban
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Activation functions are important parameters of a deep neural network (DNN) which introduces non-linearity, complexity, and adaptability of the model for image classification. Convolutional neural networks (CNN) is a type of DNN are well-known for addressing problems related to image classification and since DNN are data-driven transfer learning (TL) is used to address the insufficient data by training well-known CNN architectures in a generic dataset to be applied for a task-specific CNN model. In this paper, we introduce Harris as an activation function determining its capability for image classification and determine its α-values in which high accuracy is obtained using a simple convolutional neural network (SCNN) and VGG-16 model trained and tested using the CIFAR-10 dataset and comparing its performance to ReLU. The results show that Harris provides a promising performance by exceeding the target accuracies for both training and testing set by ReLU at some of the α-values and using the F1-score it exceeds ReLU in the image classification for most of the CIFAR-10 classes.

title: Tunable Long Range OFDR Enabled by Ultrastable SiN ECTL
authors: N. K. Fontaine, D. A. S. Heim, D. Bose, M. Mazur, T. Huynh, T.-Y. Huang, R. Ryf, L. Dallachiesa, H. Chen, D. T. Neilson, K. W. Kim, D. Blumenthal
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: A novel packaged laser based on a SiN waveguide cavity is presented, which enables wide tunability (60 nm) while maintaining phase stability comparable with fixed frequency ultrastable sensing lasers. The laser enables long range full C-band OFDR characterization of a 280-km subsea span. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: A modified virtual sensor modeling method and its application in heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning system
authors: Delin Wang, Ke Zhang
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Realizing sensor redundancy is of great significance to ensure the normal operation of the heating, ventilation, and air-condition (HVAC) system. Developing a virtual sensor is an effective method to achieving sensor redundancy. Traditional virtual sensor models typically focus on feature extraction from uniformly sampled data. However, in actual HVAC system, the collected data may have irregular time intervals, posing challenges for conventional methods. To address this issue, this paper proposes a virtual sensor modeling method based on maximal information coefficient (MIC) and sample interval attention-based long short-term memory (SIA-LSTM). First of all, MIC is employed to identify process variables that exhibit a strong correlation with the target variable. Subsequently, SIA-LSTM introduced an attention mechanism to adaptively estimate varying sampling intervals is utilized to model the virtual sensors for supply and return water temperatures in the chiller unit of the HVAC system. Finally, the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method are validated and verified on an actual HVAC system.

title: The Composite Visual-Laser Navigation Method Applied in Indoor Poultry Farming Environments
authors: Jiafan Lu, Dongcheng Hu, Yitian Ye, Anqi Liu, Zixian Zhang, Xin Peng
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Indoor poultry farms rely on inspection robots to sustain precise environmental control, a factor essential for limiting rapid disease transmission and large-scale bird losses. Yet the challenging conditions inside these facilities—marked by harsh lighting contrasts and frequent water accumulation—introduce major obstacles. Conventional navigation strategies that depend on a single sensor often struggle in such settings, leading to problems like laser drift and errors in visual guide-line extraction. To address these issues, we introduce a new hybrid navigation approach that combines laser and vision sensing. This method dynamically calculates a fused yaw angle based on the real-time reliability of each sensing modality, thereby removing the need for physical navigation lines. Tests conducted in operational poultry houses show that our approach not only mitigates the fundamental weaknesses of single-sensor systems but also substantially improves navigation accuracy and overall efficiency. Consequently, it offers a promising pathway for enhancing inspection robot performance in complex indoor poultry farming environments.

title: Fault Diagnosis of Feed Pumps in Industrial Circulating Water Systems Based on Adversarial Domain Adaptive Networks
authors: Xuehui Lu, Jing Xu, Wenzheng Liu, Fachuan Gao, Jiasheng Li, Ping Ma
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The working state of water supply pumps in industrial circulating water systems is an important factor affecting the safe production of industrial processes, in order to timely and accurately identify the working state of water supply pumps, a deep reinforcement learning fault diagnosis method for water supply pumps incorporating adversarial domain-adaptive Dual Adversarial Competitive Networks (DANNs) is proposed. Firstly, Domain-Adversarial Neural Networks (DANN) is used to align the source and target domain feature mapping and reduce the distribution difference, then the feature network parameters are frozen and migrated to the Dueling Double DQN (D3QN) network to establish the fault diagnosis model of the water supply pump, and finally Finally, the strong perception and adaptive learning ability of the reinforcement learning algorithm is used to fine-tune the classifier parameters to improve the stability and cross-domain diagnosis performance of the model. The experimental results show that the proposed method not only has better performance in accuracy and stability than the traditional domain adaptation model and deep reinforcement learning model, but also can effectively identify the working state of the water supply pump.

title: Fine-Tuning Deep Convolutional Neural Networks for Melanoma Detection: A Ensemble Approach
authors: Anil Kumar, Kapil Shrivastava
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The accurate identification of skin lesions, especially for identifying melanoma and other malignant dermatological disorders, is essential for early diagnosis and efficient treatment planning. This article investigates how deep convolutional neural networks (DCNNs) can be used to automatically classify skin lesions. It does this by using tweaked versions of four well-known models: ResNet, DenseNet201, Inception V3 and a method that combines these designs. We first created a baseline CNN to establish a basic accuracy, subsequently fine-tuning the chosen DCNNs to enhance performance. By methodically adjusting the layer settings, we achieved significant improvements, leading to our ensemble model achieving a validation accuracy of 97.56%, which significantly outperformed individual models. The results show that fine-tuning can improve the accuracy and generalizability of DCNNs for classifying skin lesions. This shows that ensemble techniques with careful calibration can help doctors make better diagnoses in clinical settings.

title: Privacy-Focused Text Encryption for IoT Using Modified ChaCha and Homomorphic Paillier
authors: Mohammad Ubaidullah Bokhari, Syed Rayyan Ahmad, Shahnwaz Afzal, Rabiza Sohail Azmi, Arshil Noor, Basil Hanafi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: With the rapid expansion of IoT devices, protecting sensitive textual data in resource-constrained, low-power settings is increasingly essential. Traditional cryptographic methods, though secure, often overwhelm these systems and risk exposing data during computation. We present a hybrid encryption framework that blends the Paillier cryptosystem’s additive homomorphic properties for privacy-preserving data processing with a tailored ChaCha stream cipher, enhanced by nonlinear multiplication and a permutation layer to strengthen randomness, diffusion, and protection against cryptanalytic threats. This two-phase design provides secure computation and reliable data transport, crucial for real-time IoT applications. Systematic testing of encryption/decryption rates, throughput, and avalanche effect proves better performance compared to current solutions. Our solution presents a viable, scalable road for secure communication in areas such as e-health, electronic voting, and intelligent infrastructure, meeting the urgent call for lightweight security in the growing IoT environment.

title: A data-driven wind farm control method based on MPC and RL considering load safety
authors: Kangqiang Jia, Shanbi Wei, Wei Yang, Yi Chai
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Wind power efficiency is hindered by wake effects, especially at high wind speeds, increasing uncertainty and turbine loads. Traditional yaw control mitigates this but raises safety risks. To address this, we propose an MRL framework integrating Model Predictive Control (MPC) and Reinforcement Learning (RL) to enhance power generation, reduce loads, and ensure safety. FAST. Farm simulations confirm its effectiveness over RL alone.

title: Phishing URL Detection with GAN-Based Models and Machine Learning
authors: Dat Le Thanh, Hinh Nguyen Van, Tuyen Nguyen Ngoc, Trung Anh Do
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Online phishing attacks are becoming increasingly sophisticated, posing significant challenges to cybersecurity systems. Existing solutions, such as blacklist/whitelist-based URL filtering and traditional machine learning approaches, remain limited in their adaptability to new attack patterns. This study proposes a novel phishing domain detection method that integrates data augmentation using various Generative Adversarial Networks (Basic GAN, SeqGAN) with machine learning classifiers. Using GANs to generate synthetic phishing domain samples, our approach enhances the diversity and quality of training data, thereby improving the detection of previously unseen attack patterns. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an accuracy of 99.3%, outperforming conventional solutions. These results highlight the potential of GAN-based data augmentation to strengthen phishing detection systems significantly and offer a promising direction for future cybersecurity solutions.

title: Explainable AI Framework for Advertisement Recommendation Using SHAP and TabNet
authors: Ritu Rajal, Nishant Kumar, Sanjeev Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: In the online advertising industry, the potential to give personalized and targeted advertising is crucial in enhancing consumer interaction and conversion. Nevertheless, the recommendation systems based on deep learning are black boxes, which complicate their interpretability. This paper introduces an explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) system in which the TabNet deep learning algorithm will be incorporated with SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) as a means to provide an accurate and explainable ad recommendation. TabNet is applied to measure non-linear interactions between features in structured ad campaign data, whereas SHAP is applied to explain the output of the model in terms of individual input features to give coherent, comprehensive explanations. The presented system is trained and tested on real-world user advertisements dataset including user behavioural interactions and demographic features and sentiment-based TF-IDF features. SMOTE process is being used in training to balance data imbalance of conversion labels. On experimental performance, it shows good performance, with the AUC of 0.91 and Fl score of 0.79. SHAP-based analysis helps display the top characteristics of conversion, e.g., the length of engagement and sentiments indicators. Moreover, the framework provides the instance-level explanation, which allows any of the recommendations to be traced and interpreted. Such a level of predictive accuracy and explainability renders the model quite well-suited to deploy transparently and in an ethical manner in commercial systems used to target ads.

title: Disease Detection and Classification from Lung Images Using Deep Learning Methods
authors: Ipek Atik, Murat Kaan Akar
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Lung diseases are among the most important health issues that need to be addressed in the healthcare sector. Early detection of the disease and prompt treatment significantly reduce its progression. In the rapidly advancing field of healthcare, disease images play a crucial role in detecting lung diseases. In this study, YOLO models were used to analyse and accurately classify lung disease images. The study analysed lung disease images consisting of three classes—virus, bacteria, and normal images—in YOLO models to accurately and quickly detect the disease. In the experiments, YOLOv8 achieved 87.9%, YOLOv9 achieved 85%, YOLOv10 achieved 86.8%, YOLOv11 achieved 87.8%, and YOLOv12 achieved 86.1% average precision (mAP). In this study, YOLOv8 demonstrated the best performance compared to other models due to its ability to generalise object detection, thanks to its model architecture and feature extraction. This study makes significant contributions to deep learning-based medical imaging systems in terms of both accuracy and reliability.

title: UAV-Based Visual Contamination Detection and Intelligent Cleaning Strategy Optimization for Photovoltaic Panels
authors: Haijiang Tian, D. Ismail Saad, Tianshu Chen, Xiwei Yu, Bih Lii Chua, Houpin Yoong
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: An industrial park in China has adopted Building Integrated photovoltaic (BIPV) technology, integrating solar power generation products into steel structure workshops. The resulting pollution from photovoltaic panels has significantly reduced the power generation efficiency. Therefore, effective detection and cleaning strategies are imperative. In recent years, breakthroughs in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and artificial intelligence technologies have enabled UAVs to achieve precise pollution monitoring and formulate optimized cleaning strategies, providing new solutions for the cleaning of photovoltaic panels. This study explores the optimization of visual pollution detection and intelligent cleaning strategies based on unmanned aerial vehicles. Use UAVs to enter the photovoltaic panel array at a specific height and path to collect infrared video streams for color space conversion. Artificial intelligence is used to detect images to identify common defects in photovoltaic panels and guide cleaning robots to formulate effective cleaning strategies. In 2025, experimental flights were conducted using UAVs under various weather conditions, and the following conclusions were drawn. Firstly, the strategies of UAVs and cleaning robots depend on the weather, and the detection effect is best in clear and cloudy conditions. Secondly, a dynamic cleaning strategy must be adopted, that is, the degree of cleaning varies in different weather conditions. Thirdly, in future applications, all-weather sensor fusion and multi-robot collaboration must be employed to achieve a cleaning efficiency higher than 95%.

title: Real-Time Speech Emotion Recognition Using Deep Learning for Emotion Based Music Recommendation
authors: Grace Evelyn Wong, Rosalyn R Porle
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: Affective state is a key factor affecting the music preference and the user experience. Traditional music recommendation systems do not have the capability of emotional sense, and the recommendations may then be contradictory to the user who wants to listen to music in a certain mood. This paper introduces a real-time Speech Emotion Recognition (SER) system, which employs a hybrid model of a CNN and a BiLSTM to recognize the user's emotions from speech input. The model is trained on public available databases--CREMA-D, and RAVDESS--and Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC) features with 50 dimensions are used. The system is tailored for mobile implementation with TensorFlow Lite and packaged in a native Android app. Emotion recognition outcome plays emotion-based music according to a pre-stored play-list. The performance of the system is tested under different real-world scenarios ranging from noisy to silent conditions. User testing has shown that users can decern between positive, neutral and negative emotions. In addition, the mobile app possessed good usability and learned user satisfaction, which further implied that it had the possibility to be used to facilitate emotion efficiently using personalized music experiences.

title: Improvement of DVB-T Based Passive Radar Detection Using Multi-Frequency Diversity
authors: David Mata-Moya, Nerea Del-Rey-Maestre, Carlos Hernandez-Fernandez, Maria-Cortes Benito-Ortiz, Javier Rosado-Sanz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Signals and Systems (ICSigSys)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation and experimental validation of a multi-frequency passive radar system based on DVB-T signals in a Multiple-Input Single-Output configuration. The proposed system exploits different DVB-T (Digital Video Broadcasting-Terrestrial) channels (inputs) transmitted by a single Illuminator of Opportunity, applying decentralized fusion strategies using M-out-of-N binary integration rules to improve detection performance. Two integration rules (AND and OR) were evaluated under a fixed false alarm rate constraint. The system was tested using a passive radar demonstrator in a real-world scenario involving low-altitude drone detection. Results show that multi-frequency integration enhances detection capability. The proposed approach is validated as a robust, low-cost solution for real-time passive sensing in complex environments.

title: Performance Assessment of $800 \mathrm{G} / \lambda$ Filterless Optical Metroaccess Network with SOA-Based OADM Nodes
authors: S. Xia, R. Matsumoto, M. Rombouts, H. F. Santana, O. Raz, A. Rafel, N. Calabretta
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We assess an 800G/ <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> filterless metro-access network with cascaded SOA-based OADM nodes. Results at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$800 \mathrm{G} / \lambda$</tex> show error-free transmission through six cascaded nodes over 80 km fibre with 1-by-8 splitting to receiver pool, maintaining 5.5dB and 1.8dB OSNR margins with average OSNR penalty of 0.7 dB per node.

title: Automatic Modulation Classification using LSTMs with an Alternative Input Shape
authors: Alexander Gros, Aurélien Niébes, Véronique Moeyaert, Patrice Mégret
publish: 2025 IEEE Asia Pacific Conference on Wireless and Mobile (APWiMob)
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of input representation and architecture on the performance of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for Automatic Modulation Classification (AMC). Building on previous work, we reproduce and extend LSTM-based AMC models using the CSPB.ML.2018 dataset, introducing an alternative input shape that inverts the roles of time steps and features. This approach reduces training time by over 90% compared to conventional LSTMs and improves classification accuracy by up to 13.4% when using IQ inputs, particularly at low Signal-to-Noise Ratios (SNR). However, it requires longer input signal samples to match the performance of conventional models at high SNRs. We evaluate both cartesian (IQ) and polar input representations, demonstrating that IQ inputs consistently outperform polar inputs across all models. Our results highlight the trade-offs between computational efficiency, input length, and classification accuracy, offering insights for optimizing AMC systems in resource-constrained and real-time applications, such as cognitive radio and spectrum monitoring.

title: A Stacking Ensemble Approach for Breast Cancer Prediction with SMOTE-based Resampling and Feature Selection
authors: Archana Singh, Kuldeep Singh Kaswan, Rajani, Kritika Verma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Breast cancer stands as the most frequent form of female cancer which requires dependable diagnostic equipment to distinguish benign conditions from malignant ones. The early and accurate detection of conditions serves double purposes by aiding proper diagnosis and effective treatment methods. This paper presents an ensemble learning strategy based on stacking to forecast breast cancer outcomes using data from the Wisconsin Diagnostic Breast Cancer (WDBC) dataset. First the data undergoes two preprocessing stages that include SMOTE to remedy class unbalance and SelectKBest to select the top 20 features. StandardScaler is employed for normalization. The proposed model utilizes Logistic Regression as the meta-classifier in stacking while base classifiers include Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine, Decision Tree, Random Forest and Gradient Boosting. The developed model delivered superior performance through its 0.9737 accuracy rate along with 0.9722 precision, 0.9859 recall and 0.9790 F1-score as well as 0.9697 AUC-ROC. The experimental results indicate that the developed ensemble methodology provides highly effective automatic classification of breast cancer.

title: Enhancing Network Performance in Multimedia Video Streaming over SDN-VANET using Artificial Bee Colony Algorithms
authors: Kien Nguyen Khac, Ninh Bui Trung, Mai Dinh Thi Thai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This work proposes a UDP buffer size adaptation mechanism based on the Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) algorithm, where the novelty lies in a three-phase buffering strategy (stable, pre-handover, and post-handover). Instead of directly optimizing QoS or QoE metrics, the proposed method employs phase-based target buffer values (100 KB and 1000 KB) as the objective of the fitness function, allowing ABC to guide the buffer adjustment process in synchronization with handover dynamics. This approach enables timely buffer resizing to reduce packet loss during unstable phases while maximizing throughput and video stability in steady states. Experimental results using Mininet-WiFi show that ABC achieves significant improvements in delay, packet loss, PSNR, and SSIM compared to PSO and DE, particularly in high-mobility scenarios with frequent handovers.

title: UHF RFID Tag Antenna Performance Near Metallic Environments: A Comprehensive Characterization
authors: Hanen Shall, Emna Jaouadi, Sahbi Baccar, Moncef Kadi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive electromagnetic characterization of an RFID tag antenna when placed in proximity to metallic environments. The study investigates how key geometrical parameters mainly the tag-tometal gap, metal thickness and the overall size of the metallic structure are able to affect critical antenna performance metrics such as resonant frequency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$f_{r}$</tex>), bandwidth (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$B W$</tex>), gain and radiation efficiency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R E$</tex>). A printed dipole RFID tag antenna, optimized for UHF operation at 915 MHz, is modeled and analyzed using ANSYS-HFSS. Through a systematic parametric study, the results reveal that the metal structure is highly affecting the RFID tag antenna characteristics and that taking into account this environment from the first design phase is crucial for optimal performance. These findings not only provide valuable insights into the reliable deployment of RFID systems in metallic environments but also pave the way for the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) models to forecast the impact of metallic surroundings and predict best spatial alignment of the antenna. This predictive capability would greatly enhance the design process and enable optimized tag placement strategies in real-life RFID applications.

title: Fault Localization for Power Transformer ITSC based on Distribution Matching of Oil-Duct Magnetic by TD-PSO
authors: Bowen Wang, Jian Feng, Senxiang Lu, Danying Gai
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Inter-turn short circuit (ITSC) faults are among the most critical internal faults in power transformers, often causing severe equipment degradation and economic loss if not detected in time. However, traditional detection methods based on terminal electrical parameters lack sensitivity to early-stage or mild ITSCs. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel ITSC fault localization method based on abnormal leakage magnetic field tracing. An electromagnetic field coupling model is first established to analyze the spatial redistribution of leakage flux caused by shorted turns. The resulting magnetic anomaly is then formulated as an inverse problem, in which the fault location and severity are reconstructed by minimizing the discrepancy between simulated and observed flux distributions. A two-dimensional particle swarm optimization (TD-PSO) algorithm is introduced to solve this inverse problem, offering efficient convergence and high localization accuracy. Both simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an average localization error of 4.18% in simulation and 9 mm in experimental validation. Compared to conventional methods, it exhibits superior performance in sensitivity and robustness, especially under weak fault conditions. This study provides a physics-informed, optimization-driven framework for accurate and timely localization of ITSC faults, offering new insights for transformer condition monitoring and predictive maintenance.

title: Enhancing Automated Interactions via Hybrid Gesture Recognition
authors: Rohan Gupta, Sarabdeep Singh Bilkhu, Ranbir Khurana, Akshay Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Using gestures instead of voice control makes it easier to control domestic objects and improves the user experience, too. Gesture recognition as a channel of interaction with electronics is brought about in this paper by the proposition of a hybrid model toward increased accuracy and responsiveness. "Hybrid," in this case, means the combination of both hardware, e.g., MPU6050, and software, e.g., Python libraries. Hybrid systematics are discussed in this paper, wherein hardware parts are merged with relevant software commands to ultimately produce an efficient gesture recognition model. The model has been proven in this paper using the combination of OpenCV and MPU6050 to increase the level of accuracy. This enhances the overall interactions offered by the user while carrying out day-to-day activities with ease. Thus, this suggested model optimizes performance and improves accuracy.

title: A Novel Multi-Modal Deep Learning Framework for Cardiac Arrhythmia Detection Using ECG and PPG Signals
authors: Desh Deepak Gupta, Abhishek Singhal, Krishan Kant Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Cardiac arrhythmias are within the most common and severely impact cardiovascular morbidity, so timely and accurate diagnosis is needed. In order to detect arrhythmias, this paper proposes a brand-new multi-modal deep learning framework. Its process utilizes both PPG signals and ECG signals. PPG allows optical monitors that are simple for use as well as monitoring may be nearly continuously done. ECG gives precise electrical activity though. Attention mechanisms plus CNNs allow the model to capture spatiotemporal patterns within the two signals. What is detected then gets strengthened by fusion. Features are extracted by ECG as well as PPG-specific CNN branches plus inter-modal dependencies get integrated by a transformer-based fusion module then arrhythmia is diagnosed by one classification head. Ablation studies can show multi-modal fusion matters especially in detecting paroxysmal arrhythmias, where PPG complements ECG during motion. The real-time monitoring system is optimized and it is designed for being worn. The system's light weight makes body wear easier so monitoring in real time is possible. This paper advances the area of arrhythmia diagnosis since it consolidates information coming from ECG and PPG and since it incorporates Independent Component Analysis (ICA) so as to improve detection. Also, after consolidating of the ECG and PPG information, ICA diagnoses arrhythmia, and it can be applicable to the analysis for use in the clinic and for daily use. Enhancements might include edge-computing optimization and expansion. These enhancements may apply also to the rarer arrhythmia subtypes.

title: Design And Implementation of a Spatiotemporal GIS Database for Migrant Population Dynamics Management
authors: Hongkai Cao
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Strong technology platforms are needed to track, analyze and display data about migrants now and in previous years throughout areas and regions. The approach presented here is based on using specific techniques to construct and support a database using GIS for monitoring patterns in migrant population movements. The major approach is to organize the information in multiple layers supported by PostgreSQL and PostGIS, so the system can store and search for geospatial and temporal features. Spatiotemporal modelling is used to track migration over time based on temporal logic which supports analysing and forecasting movement. We use information from the government census, mobile networks and special surveys and feed this data to an automated ETL pipeline. The pipeline takes advantage of Python, along with GDAL/OGR spatial tools, for data cleanup, standardization and the creation of a single schema. Performance is improved by using R-tree for space and B-tree for time indexing methods for efficient access to a broad range of data. An animated web interface created using Leaflet.js and D3.js makes it possible to see changes in migration, population and geographic patterns. The data processing system is registered in city traffic scenarios to see how effectively it can supply timely, meaningful details for policy-makers and planners. The system is shown to assist in informed making decisions because of its accurate analysis of time and place. It gives institutions and governments a way to enhance resources for monitoring migrants and creating plans, all with the help of advanced GIS technologies.

title: Research on Longitudinal Upper and Lower Limit Speed Protection Curves for Superconducting Electrodynamic Suspension Train
authors: Shaowei Li, Linfeng Liu, Zhiqing Zhang, Wei Dong, Min Gu, Hao Ye, Zhihua Xiong
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: The superconducting electrodynamic suspension (SC-EDS) train exhibits significant advantages such as levitation and guidance self-stabilizing, large levitation gap, and high lift-to-drag ratio, indicating promising applications in high-speed and ultra-high-speed maglev rail transportation. This paper addresses the longitudinal upper and lower limit speed protection issues of the SC-EDS train, defining and proposing computational methods for upper and lower limit speed protection curves. Inspired by the safety protection strategies of wheel-rail and the electromagnetic suspension (EMS) train, and considering the two-stage braking process involving suspension and landing phases, this research establishes the upper-limit speed protection curves and the lower-limit speed protection curves. The methods for calculating these protection curves are elaborated, taking into account adverse conditions and equipment response delays. Algorithms and calculation examples for solving the curves are provided. The research outcomes offer theoretical foundations and technical support for the safe operation of the SC-EDS train.

title: Experimental Characterization of Stimulated Raman Scattering in Field-Deployed Coupled-Core Multi-Core Fibers
authors: G. Di Sciullo, D. A. Shaji, L. A. Zischler, R. S. Luís, R. Emmerich, M. Van Den Hout, C. Lasagni, P. Serena, A. Bononi, T. Hayashi, C. Schubert, C. Okonkwo, L. Palmieri, M. Shtaif, A. Marotta, A. Mecozzi, C. Antonelli
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We report the first experimental characterization of stimulated Raman scattering (SRS) in coupled-core multi-core fibers. The gain coefficient profile, measured in a deployed four-core fiber, is of similar magnitude to that observed in standard SMFs, consistent with the modeling of SRS with strong mode mixing.

title: Ensemble Learning with N-Gram Features for Enhanced Fault Diagnosis Through Maintenance Reports
authors: Nik Ahmad Danial Mohd Kamarolzaman, Nurul Adilla Mohd Subha, Nurul Hannah Mohd Yusof, Norikhwan Hamzah, Anita Ahmad, Noorhazirah Sunar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: This paper investigates the most effective machine learning algorithm for text-based classification of manufacturing maintenance reports. The study utilizes real-world maintenance data and explores NLP processing various n-gram-based TF-IDF tokenization techniques combined with ensemble machine learning (ML) approaches. Both stacking and voting ensemble methods are evaluated using base models including Logistic Regression (LR), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Random Forest (RF), Naive Bayes (NB), Gradient Boosting (GB), and Support Vector Machines (SVM). Model performance is evaluated using recall, F1 score, precision, and accuracy, with a particular emphasis on recall due to the imbalanced nature of the dataset. The results demonstrate that an ensemble model combining RF-SVM with unigram features achieves the best performance, attaining 86% accuracy and recall, a 83% percent F1 score, and 84% precision. These findings offer valuable guidance for users in selecting suitable ensemble methods based on the characteristics of their textual datasets for classification tasks in the manufacturing domain.
