title: Disturbance-Rejection-Based Adaptive RISE Control for an n-DOF Electro-Hydraulic Manipulators With Structural Nonlinearity
authors: Junjie Mi, Gang Shen, Jianyong Yao, Wenxiang Deng, Zhikai Yao, Xianglong Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article focuses on an n-degree-of-freedom (DOF) hydraulic manipulator operating in three-dimensional (3-D) space. Given that inaccurate modeling and disturbances pose difficulties for system control performance, a controller is designed based on the robust integral of sign error (RISE) approach with its parameters tuned using an adaptive method. A novel dual extended state observer (DESO) is employed to estimate and compensate for disturbances arising from both matched and mismatched uncertainties. Experiments are conducted on a multi-DOF experimental platform. The experimental findings demonstrate that the proposed controller effectively enhances joint tracking performance of the multi-DOF hydraulic manipulator. Specifically, on average, the control system's tracking accuracy for command signals is 47.02% higher than that achieved with RISE, 51.51% higher than that achieved with feedback linearization controller (FLC), and 69.66% higher than that achieved with proportional-integral (PI) control.

title: Compact and High-Efficiency Novel Wireless Power Transfer System for Reconfigurable Seat in Autonomous Vehicle Applications
authors: Donghoon Kim, Ye gu Kang, Chi-Hyung Ahn
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This article proposes a novel resonator structure for wireless power transfer (WPT) in autonomous vehicle seat applications. The proposed WPT system employs helical coils for both the transmitter and receiver (RX), achieving a high coupling coefficient exceeding 0.5 across a substantial RX movement range. To mitigate the complexity of the system due to RX movement, an <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$M$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-uniform resonator with unequal turn spacing was developed using a genetic algorithm based on theoretical analysis. While the RX was moving, the proposed <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$M$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-uniform resonator reduced the receiving-side voltage and current variations to 5.8% and 4.4%, respectively. This represents a significant improvement over the 34.1% and 37.0% observed in conventional coil designs with equal turn spacing. Additionally, the proposed system maintained a total system efficiency above 85% over the entire RX movement range, demonstrating its suitability for dynamic WPT applications without the need for RX position detection systems. In conclusion, the proposed resonator overcomes the tangling and reliability issues of traditional power cables, enabling flexible seat movement in future autonomous vehicles to optimize their interior space.

title: HARMONY: A Hardware-Aware Mapping and Optimizing Framework for Computing-In-Memory Accelerators
authors: Xinmo Li, Weidong Yang, Naifeng Jing, Qin Wang, Zhigang Mao, Weiguang Sheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: The increasing adoption of artificial intelligence has spurred the development of specialized deep neural network (DNN) accelerators. Among them, computing-in-memory (CIM) architectures are promising for their in-situ computation capability, which alleviates the computation and data movement bottlenecks of modern DNNs. However, the diversity of models and hardware designs makes it challenging to fully exploit CIM accelerators. Existing approaches often rely on manual mapping or provide limited automation, struggling to integrate general-purpose optimizations with CIM-specific features. In this work, we present HARMONY, a hardware-aware compilation framework for CIM accelerators. At its core is a hardware intermediate representation (IR) that unifies computational and memory abstractions. Based on this IR, HARMONY introduces an automatic mapping algorithm that identifies offloadable operators and constructs a hybrid software–hardware IR. This enables systematic integration of general-purpose and CIM-specific scheduling primitives within a unified search space, which is efficiently explored using reinforcement learning (RL). Extensive evaluations show that HARMONY supports a broader set of operators than existing CIM compilers and consistently delivers substantial performance and energy improvements across diverse DNN workloads. These results demonstrate that HARMONY provides both generality and efficiency, making it a practical compilation solution for CIM accelerators.

title: Towards a Practical Key Generation System for V2X Communications
authors: Hua Fu, Linning Peng, Junqing Zhang, Ming Liu, Xudong Chen, Aiqun Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The vehicle to everything (V2X) serves as a crucial foundation for future intelligent transportation systems. Security concerns within the V2X have garnered significant attention and key generation from wireless channels have emerged as a promising technique. However, applying key generation to V2X is quite challenging because the fast moving vehicles result in very small coherence time and impact channel measurements correlation. This paper designed a practical V2X key generation by enhancing channel state information (CSI) reciprocity and carried out extensive experimental evaluation. In particular, the designed key generation consists of channel probing, CSI preprocessing, CSI compensation and key establishment. In the channel probing, we deliberately reduced the time delay between uplink and downlink transmissions, to allow almost simultaneous measurements. We then carefully designed CSI preprocessing to remove hardware carrier leakage and eliminate noise effects. Furthermore, we devised CSI compensation by using interpolation or deep learning prediction to further improve the reciprocity. Finally, key establishment converted the measured CSI into binary sequences and reconcile on a common key via low-density parity-check (LDPC) code. We adopted universal software radio peripheral (USRP) X310 platforms for channel measurements and implemented the above algorithms. We carried out extensive experiments in real-road environments with various vehicle speeds. These carefully designed algorithms enabled our system working robustly even in high mobility scenarios, e.g., 40 km/h. Experimental results demonstrated common and random key can be generated with a key block error rate (BER) less than 0.1.

title: Navigation of Robotic Swarmalators with Dynamics and Constraints_supp1-3640404.mp4
authors: Steven Ceron
publish: N/A
abstract: Swarmalator studies have enabled self-organized collective behaviors that emerge from dual spatial and temporal coupling, without relying on external inputs. These behaviors arise solely from attractive and repulsive interactions modulated by a few global parameters. Here, we treat the swarmalator model as a planner and study how several of the collective behaviors change in terms of space-phase organization when the agents are robots with vehicle dynamics and constraints: including omnidirectional, unicycle, and bicycle dynamics. Furthermore, we use the control barrier function method to guarantee that the collective can navigate around objects, through cluttered environments, and transport objects in between obstacles by exploiting global and local control methods. This work brings us closer to realizing large groups of robotic swarmalators, of heterogeneous dynamics, that can enable shape formation, navigation, and object manipulation in cluttered environments.

title: Optimization Method for Multi-Sensor Detection Based on Improved Grey Wolf Algorithm and Virtual Force Strategy
authors: Shizhe Wang, Xu Chen, Weiyi Chen, Zongji Li, Yanze Pang
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: In marine environment investigation and target detection, the deployment scheme for multiple detection nodes directly determines the coverage and information acquisition effectiveness of the detection area. The existing research faces three problems: (1) the dilemma of the Pareto suboptimal trade-offs in multi-objective optimizations; (2) the insufficient convergence reliability of swarm intelligence algorithms; (3) physical modeling distortion in virtual force algorithms. To improve the coverage rate of detection area in multi-sensor systems, we propose an optimization method for the deployment strategy of multiple detection nodes based on improved grey wolf algorithm and virtual force strategy (namely IVF-CLGWO). Specifically, we propose a method to derive the minimum number of required sensors in the target area based on radius of the equivalent circle for sensor node sensing range, which transforms the multi-objective deployment optimization problem into a single objective one; Then, we improve the basic grey wolf optimization algorithm based on cosine convergence factor and Levy flight strategy (CLGWO) to improve the global search and local exploration capabilities of the algorithm; Finally, inspired by Coulomb’s law, we improve the virtual force algorithm (IVF) by optimizing the force equation of the sensor node and design an adaptive adjustment strategy for the maximum movement step size of the node. The numerical simulation results verified the reliability and stability of the proposed IVF-CLGWO algorithm, and combined with algorithm complexity analysis, sensitivity testing and ablation study, fully validated its comprehensive advantages. Compared with the benchmark method, in the fully-passive working mode, the optimal coverage rate of detection area increases by about 5% to 19.5%, and in the multi-base working mode, the optimal coverage rate of detection area increases by about 2% to 16.5%.

title: Frequency Stability Enhancement in Hybrid Thermal-Hydro Grids Using Structured Sliding Mode Control
authors: Phong Thanh Tran, Tuan Van Huynh, Dieu Ngoc Vo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper proposes an LFC method for hybrid thermal-hydro grids (HTHG) with parameter uncertainty. Second-order sliding mode control with double integrated sliding surfaces (DSSMC) increase HTHG frequency regulation, tie-line power management, and reliability. Asymptotic stability and dependability of HTHG are improved by this strategy, which also minimizes chattering in first order sliding mode control (SMC). The complete HTHG stabilization is examined employing Lyapunov's stability-based linear matrix inequality (LMI). A two-area thermal-hydropower system (TATHS) is used to test the LFC technique's efficacy. The suggested DSSMC scheme exhibits strong robustness in the face of parameter uncertainties and load disturbances (LDs) from the commercial, industrial, and residential sectors. Compared to alternative techniques with less uncertainty tolerance, it greatly improves HTHG overall reliability, tie-line power coordination, and frequency regulation. The outcomes by MATLAB/SIMULINK validate this method's potential as a reliable remedy for power system stability and LFC in HTHG settings.

title: Resource Allocation for Open Radio Access Networks Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Duc-Tien Nguyen, Trong-Tin Nguyen, Tai Hung Nguyen, Nguyen Huu Thanh, Quang-Trung Luu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to the resource allocation problem in Open Radio Access Networks (Open RAN), focusing on the coordination of independent xApps for efficient network slicing and physical resource block (PRB) allocation. The proposed framework targets enhanced mobile broadband (eMBB) services and aims to maximize the weighted throughput across user equipments (UEs) while ensuring resource constraints are met. Q-learning is employed as the decision-making mechanism for PRB assignment. Performance is evaluated through comparative analysis against an exact optimization method and a baseline greedy algorithm. Results show that the proposed approach achieves superior efficiency across varying scenarios, highlighting its effectiveness and potential for practical deployment in Open RAN environments.

title:
Enhanced Classification of CO and NO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Using Temperature-Modulated MOS Sensors and Machine Learning in an Electronic Nose System
authors: Tran Duc Giang, Ninh Thi Nhu Hoa, Pham Xuan Bac, Nguyen Ngoc Viet, Nguyen Viet Chien, Nguyen Van Hieu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This study presents the development of an intelligent gas sensing system based on a temperature-modulated metal oxide semiconductor (MOS) sensor array for accurate classification of carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen dioxide (NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), and their mixtures. The sensing module employs a MICS-4514 dual-gas sensor chip and a custom-designed circuit that dynamically controls the sensor’s heating cycle to capture rich, temperature-dependent response patterns. Sensor signals are processed using a sliding window technique to extract temporal features across multiple thermal stages. Among several machine learning algorithms evaluated, the Random Forest model achieved a classification accuracy of 99.96%. Compared to conventional fixed-temperature approaches, our temperature modulation technique significantly enhances selectivity and model accuracy without requiring additional sensor hardware. The proposed system demonstrates stable performance and high reliability, offering a compact and cost-effective solution for advanced gas discrimination applications.

title: A Hybrid 2D-3D Space Vector Modulation for Four-Phase Four-Leg Voltage Source Inverters
authors: Hiep Duy Do, Hieu T. Nguyen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Multiphase inverters are necessary for advanced multiphase motor control. This research develops a hybrid two and three-dimensional space vector pulse width modulation technique for a four-phase four-leg inverter, utilizing a specialized transformation matrix to facilitate the search for nearest vectors. The approach simplifies the determination of the spatial region containing the reference vector. Test results show low total harmonic distortion of currents and voltages compared to conventional pulse width modulation method making the technique suitable for applications in four-phase electric drives.

authors: Niyazi Ulas Dinc, Mustafa Yildirim, Ilker Oguz, Demetri Psaltis, Christophe Moser

We propose leveraging wave optics with distributed light modulation, enabling CMOS-compatible, low-voltage, nonblocking switching. This versatile approach allows miniaturization and easier scaling, overcoming traditional OCS limitations.

title: Next-Gen Shopping Experience: IoT-Based Smart Cart with Instant Billing
authors: Sachin Chawla, Sachin Raj, Hunny Chawla, Virender Singh, Keshav Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Modern retail solutions have been made possible by the quick development of technology, especially with the creation of IoT-based smart shopping carts. Through the automation of the billing process and the reduction of checkout counter wait times, these carts seek to improve the shopping experience. By providing functions like real-time inventory tracking, automatic payment, and route optimization within stores, these systems, which make use of technology like RFID, Bluetooth, and mobile applications, simplify the shopping experience. Smart shopping carts can also help with inventory control and offer insightful data about consumer behavior, which is advantageous to both consumers and merchants. This study examines many IoT-based smart shopping cart deployments, emphasizing how they have the potential to revolutionize the retail industry.

title: AI-Enabled Early Warning Systems for Underwater Missile Threats in Naval Defense
authors: Saravanan.M.S, Gajam Shekar, Amutharaj, S Nagakishore Bhavanam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: It is still difficult to find underwater missiles in navy defense since the sea’s acoustic environment complicates detection and modern threats are very hard to spot. An AI early warning system using deep learning has been presented to detect underwater missiles quickly and automatically from sonar data. We create a hybrid Convolutional Neural Network and Long-Short Term Memory (CNN-LSTM) model for the goal of identifying and following missile traces in noisy underwater conditions. We use readings from many distributed sonars to improve how effective our sonar detection systems are. When experiments are done using a dataset of underwater missile signatures, the system correctly identifies the signatures 96.5% of the time and keeps the false alarms below 1.8%. Compared to traditional signal processing, today’s methods can find signals farther away by about 25%. The new system allows for growth in autonomous defense underwater vehicles, helping to secure naval vessels from new risks.

title: Matlab–Unity Based Kinematic Simulation and Interactive Control Platform for Industrial Robot Arms
authors: Almila Duran, Tolga Erol, Ethem Kelekçi
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a virtual environment for the KUKA KR30 L-16 industrial robot arm, enabling real-time visualization and kinematic analysis before physical implementation. The mechanical model was designed in SolidWorks, exported as STL, and converted to FBX format in Blender. Coordinate frames were assigned to each joint, and forward kinematics was derived using the coordinate-frame composition method. Matlab was employed to compute the homogeneous transformation matrix, and the kinematic model was validated through motion and reachability tests in RoboDK as well as by comparing Unity-computed end-effector positions with Matlab results, showing millimeter-level agreement. The verified model was imported into Unity, where pivot points were assigned and an interactive interface with sliders, text fields, and input boxes was developed. Custom C# scripts enabled joint-level control, real-time end-effector computation, smooth homing motions, and free-scene camera navigation. Unlike previous studies focusing solely on Matlab-based simulation or Unity-based visualization, this work integrates both environments into a unified platform. The proposed approach provides a reproducible testbed for trajectory planning, motion control, and educational demonstrations, offering a safe, cost-effective, and extensible environment for industrial robotics research.

authors: Amir Shahin, Conor Coughlan, Mathias Berciano, Didit Yudistira, Shuchi Kaushik, Roger Loo, Hakim Kobbi, Patrick Carolan, Marta Agati, Dries Van Thourhout, Peter Verheyen, Maumita Chakrabarti, Yoojin Ban, Dimitrios Velenis, Filippo Ferraro, Joris Van Campenhout

title: Procedural Generation of Heritage Weaving Methods through Human–AI Collaboration
authors: Yixin Hong, Hongyang Zhang, Xu Zhu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: The weaving of bamboo and willow is the important part of traditional craft heritage, a complicated craft of wonders of manual work and cultural significance. The paper is a human–AI collaborative system to design weave pattern with interaction between human and AI through Procedural generation of the weave patterns by L-System modelling and Interactive Genetic Algorithms (IGAs) so that the design can be more authentic to their cultural use and adapted to the present product design. Such patterns that are applied in the constructions made of bamboo and willows also exploit the recursive structure and geometrical restrictions found in woven systems, which are codified in the logic rules of the L-System and used to produce systematically scalable and rule-based variants of patterns. At the same time, IGAs were also used to include live feedback of artisan weavers and designers on the pattern in order to continuously improve them on the basis of aesthetic, functional, and cultural requirements. The current weaving designs are used in various cultural products like furniture, lamps and decorations among other products and this way the continuity of heritage is maintained by embracing practical innovations. This framework will prove that adding algorithmic pattern generation to human aesthetics judgement is a viable direction to move heritage weaving towards through an enhanced cultural product design using digitally enhanced manufacturing processes.

title: Dominant Instability Mode Identification of Power System under Multi-Feature Fusion
authors: Man Li, Cong Wang, Hongli Zhang, Jiasheng Li, Fengjin Gong
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: In order to solve the problem of system failure and large-scale power outage caused by transient instability of power system, this paper proposes a dominant instability mode (DIM) identification model of power system based on Multi-feature Fusion (MFF). Firstly, the Laida criterion was used to preprocess the raw data to effectively identify and eliminate noise interference. Secondly, the residual bottleneck structure is introduced into the Deep Residual Memory Network (DRMN) to greatly reduce the computational complexity, and the bidirectional dependencies in the power system time series data are fully captured by combining bidirectional learning. In addition, the Tanh-Sigmoid hybrid activation function is introduced, and its nonlinear characteristics significantly enhance the expressive ability of the model. Finally, the cross-attention mechanism is used to dynamically allocate the weights of amplitude and phase angle features, which realizes the efficient fusion of multi-source features and the accurate capture of interactive information. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 99.18% in conventional tests and 95.50% under 5 dB noise conditions.. Compared with other models, the proposed model shows stronger effectiveness and anti-noise ability in the recognition of DIM in power system.

title: A Custom Meta Classifier Framework for Diabetic Retinopathy Detection Using Hybrid Deep Learning Approaches
authors: Km Meenakshi, Shakeeluddin, Abhishek Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy leads to many cases of preventable blindness in diabetic patients around the globe. It is very important to detect and classify Diabetic Retinopathy (DR) to provide fast and appropriate treatment. This works proposes a new framework called Custom Meta Classifier (CMC) by using various hybrid deep learning structures to increase accuracy in detecting and grading Diabetic Retinopathy (DR). We take an innovative method of using ResNet-50, Vision Transformer (ViT-B/16), and EfficientNet-B4 and merging their features by means of dynamic fusion and attention strategies. The proposed Custom Meta Classifier (CMC) makes use of adaptive weighting and cross-attention to make full use of each model’s special strengths. Evaluating APTOS 2019 with images that are 224×224 pixels uncovers that APTOS achieves 94.8% accuracy, 93.5% sensitivity, and 96.1% specificity. The meta-classifier consistently performs well with every severity of diabetic retinopathy.

title: Airflow Angle Estimation for Large Civil Aircraft under Non-Uniform Observability Condition
authors: Yiming Wan, Jiaoyang Kou, Lei Liu, Hongtao Liu, Yu Liu
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: This paper investigates the estimation of angle of attack (AOA) and angle of sideslip (AOS) using aircraft kinematics. The proposed estimator relies on an approximate linear time-varying kinematic model, and utilizes measurements from the GPS, inertial measurement unit, and pitot tube. Although the entire state vector is shown to be unobservable in the presence of a constant flight attitude, we perform a novel analysis on observability degree by evaluating the angle between the direction vector of each state variable and the observable subspace, and reveal that both AOA and AOS have a high observability degree as long as the airspeed is sufficiently large. To address the ill-conditioned problem associated with the above non-uniform observability condition, a reduced-order Schmidt-Kalman filter (SKF) based method is proposed to estimate only the strongly observable AOA and AOS in the state vector. The unobservable wind components are not explicitly estimated, but their influences are still considered for updating the covariance matrices and the filter gain. Using real cruise flight data of a large civil aircraft, the proposed SKF based method is demonstrated to have about 40% reduction in root mean square error in comparison with using the standard Kalman filter under the non-uniform observability condition.

authors: Seyed Navid Elyasi, Seyed Morteza Ahmadian, Jun Li, Paolo Monti, Rui Lin
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Communication noise from fiber-interconnected distributed quantum systems is quantified through monolithic processor simulations, with experimental results validating this approach as an effective method for evaluating the performance of distributed quantum algorithms. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Optimization of Rectangular Microstrip Patch Antenna Design Using Machine Learning: A Reverse Approach for S11 Parameter Prediction
authors: Durgesh Kumar Jha, Kanta Prasad Sharma, Anurag Shrivastava
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel method for the optimization of a microstrip patch antenna design based on machine learning (ML) methods. In this work, a machine learning based method for forward prediction and inverse design of microstrip patch antennas has been introduced, which focuses on the reflection coefficient (S11). A vast dataset generated through HFSS(High Frequency simulation software) simulations is used to train XGBoost regression models. The forward model estimates S11 from geometric parameters and frequency, and a reverse model along with numerical optimization predicts the design parameters required to meet a target S11. The forward model shows highly accurate result with minimal RMSE and accurately predicting S11 based on design inputs. The reverse model, although revealing good trends, proves to have limitations in precision. For example, the resultant predicted S11 was -11.81 dB for target of an S11 of -5 dB at 2.4 GHz, revealing an overestimation that demonstrates the non-uniqueness of the inverse problem. These results indicate that although machine learning is promising for antenna design automation, refinement in inverse modeling is required to achieve stable target attainment. This can be achieved through more robust model structures and improved optimization methods.

title: Single-Laser BiDi Coherent PON with Optical Injection Locking: Enabling 100G/200G Access Without High-Cost Lasers in ONU
authors: Haipeng Zhang, Zhensheng Jia, Luis Alberto Campos, Curtis Knittle
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate an optical injection locking (OIL)-based single-laser BiDi coherent PON, eliminating ECLs at ONUs for cost reduction. Optical filtering requirements for seed tone separation are relaxed, and laser frequency locking minimizes frequency offset. Experimental results confirm effective 100G/200G BiDi transmission over a 50 km link. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Low-Noise, Frequency-Agile Photonic Integrated Blue Laser for LiDAR and Underwater Communication
authors: Asger B. Gardner, Anat Siddharth, Mikael Reichler, Shivaprasad U. Hulyal, Alaina Attanasio, Xinru Ji, Sunil Bhave, Nicolas Volet, Simone Blanconi, Tobias J. Kippenberg
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Frequency-agile, low-noise blue lasers are important for atomic clocks, aerosol LiDAR, and underwater communications, but currently no chip-scale devices exist. We present a photonic integrated blue laser combining self-injection locking to a Si3N4 photonic integrated circuit with monolithically integrated AIN piezoactuators providing frequency agility. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Leveraging Conditional Diffusion-Policy for trajectory convergence in 6-DoF Robot Manipulation with Mutual Information Estimation Lower Bound*
authors: N. Nieto, G. De Los Ríos, Felix F. de J, A. Murra, L. A. Muñoz
publish: 2025 Latin American Robotics Symposium (LARS)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel regularization method to enhance trajectory generation for 6-Degrees of Freedom (DoF) robotic motion planning. The proposed approach integrates diffusion policies with conditional diffusion processes and a Mutual Information Neural Estimator (MINE) to improve trajectory-following accuracy. It generates 6-DoF action sequences from an initial noise distribution via a diffusion policy, refining them with a MINE. This enables learning of complex, nonlinear features in high-dimensional configuration spaces while optimizing the gradient field of an energy-based model for smooth and continuous motion trajectories. Experimental results demonstrate that this framework significantly enhances accuracy, allowing the use of smaller models without performance loss. These advancements create new opportunities for efficient and adaptive robotic control in real-world applications.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Integrated Backscatter Communication and User Localization
authors: Runzhe Yang, Amus Chee Yuen Goay, Yirui Deng, Deepak Mishra, Aruna Seneviratne
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) represent a critical technology for future wireless systems, enabling simultaneous environmental sensing and data transmission. In this paper, we experimentally demonstrate a novel integrated sensing and backscatter communication (ISABC) framework that uses a monostatic backscatter system for device-free indoor user localization. In contrast to most existing ISAC-related works in the literature, we consider energy harvesting backscattering tags as communication users, and our sensing application is non-intrusive, where we localise the target without tagging it. Specifically, we utilize Wireless Identification and Sensing Platform (WISP) tags and a machine learning model based on Support Vector Machines (SVM) to accurately estimate user positions within a defined sensing region. Through experiments conducted with off-the-shelf hardware, we systematically evaluate the influence of different numbers of tags, transmission power, and spatial resolution on localization accuracy and system through-put. Overall, our novel experimental demonstration indicates that the proposed ISABC framework achieves a localization accuracy that exceeds 90 % without a significant degradation in backscatter communication performance, highlighting its potential as a low-power and sustainable solution for next-generation Internet of Things (IoT) applications.

title: Asymmetric Retrodirective UHF RFID Tags: Design and Measurement Results
authors: Sebastian Böller, Thorben Grenter
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: This paper investigates retrodirective UHF RFID transponders and their potential to enhance wireless power transfer (WPT). Retrodirectivity is used to increase the communication range of an RFID system. An asymmetry in the transponder array is intended to support WPT by focusing the incoming power on one rectifier to maximize its efficiency. A commercially available UHF RFID tag IC compatible with EPC C1G2 was used for this study. Theoretical investigations show that both energy and communication range can be increased by a factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sqrt{2}$</tex> or about 41% through the use of two antennas in the transponder without reducing the transponder's read angle. Practically, a constructed C1G2-compatible transponder achieved an increase of approximately 15% in energy range and 19% in communication range. The presented technique is not limited to two antennas and can help to extend the range of RFID systems without modifications to the reader. This could especially be interesting for applications within the Ambient IoT (A-IoT) of 6G networks.

title: Channel Estimation for mmWave Massive MIMO Systems using Deep Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Shahryar Akbar, Farhan Khalid, Abdullah Hasan, Muhammad Shahzad Younis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Engineering and Technology (IICAIET)
abstract: As the requirements for ultra-reliable and high-throughput communication intensify in fifth generation (5G) and future wireless networks, accurate and scalable channel estimation remains crucial for optimal system performance. This paper proposes a deep learning-based approach for channel estimation in millimeter-wave (mmWave) massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems, utilizing a custom-designed convolutional neural network (CNN) trained on diverse synthetic datasets spanning a broad range of signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. Instead of relying on traditional handcrafted models and statistical assumptions, the proposed framework learns the underlying channel characteristics directly from data, enabling more adaptive and robust estimation. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves substantial reductions in normalized mean-square error (NMSE) compared to conventional estimators such as least squares (LS), and further exhibits improved performance over advanced methods, particularly across both low and high SNR regimes. Comprehensive evaluation and visualization underscore the robustness, adaptability, and practical potential of the proposed solution, highlighting the promise of deep learning to enhance or replace conventional channel estimation techniques in next-generation mobile communication systems.

title: How “Pay as You Grow” OXC Stacking Affects the Performance of Wavelength-Routing SDM/WDM Transparent Networks
authors: Thierry Zami, Ihtesham Khan, Jesse Simsarian, Mijail Szczerban, David Neilson, Roland Ryf
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: This study compares distinct approaches for gradual fiber activation to streamline operating expenditure as traffic grows in WDM transparent networks featuring a large bundle of fibers per link. We show how their effectiveness depends on the architecture of optical nodes. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: 8-Channel Monolithic InP Transmitter PIC Integrating DFB and MZM Arrays, Capable of Operating 106 GBd PAM4 at 85 °C
authors: A. Rundquist, J. Lavrencik, P. Abolghasem, M. Chagnon, S. Porto, P. Day, J. Anthony, C. Ozdemir, J. Patton, P. Gavrilovic, T. Frost, P. Turla, J. Macario, R. Safian, F. Sang, A. Diba, A. Meighan, M. Kuntz, R. Maher, V. Lal, M. Ziari, P. Evans
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: Data-centers require scalable link solutions, including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 200$</tex> Gbps. An 8-channel InP PIC with integrated lasers and modulators transmitted one representative channel 106 GBd PAM4 in a fully retimed module back-to-back with TDECQ <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.27 \text{dB}, R_{\text{LM }} 0.995$</tex>; and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$B E R<10^{-7}$</tex> over 0-15 km fiber.

title: A Study of Multilingual Approaches to Vietnamese Information Retrieval
authors: Nguyen Thi Bich Nguyen, Nguyen Thi Tuyet Hai, Nguyen Trung Hieu, Nguyen Thanh Tien
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: Natural language processing (NLP) applications have an extensive development in various languages. However, information retrieval (IR) for Vietnamese texts has not yet received adequate attention from the research community. In this study, we fine-tune high-quality multilingual embedding models to enhance the effectiveness of document retrieval. Additionally, we investigate several approaches to information retrieval in order to gain deeper insights into their performance and applicability.

title: MRI-Based Brain Tumor Classification with Deep Learning Methods
authors: Melike Kılıç, Seyit Metin Köroğlu, Duygu Işık, Savaş İzzetoğlu, Züleyha Akusta Dağdeviren
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: In this study, a custom Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model and EfficientNetB0 (a transfer learning model), were comparatively evaluated with Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) data to classify brain tumors. Brain tumors are of critical importance due to their profound impact on the central nervous system. Accurate and early diagnosis is an important factor that plays a valuable role in creating effective treatment strategies. The study addressed four types of brain tumors: pituitary, meningioma, glioma and no tumor. Initially, a custom CNN model was developed, yielding validation and test accuracies of 65% and 54%, respectively, which indicate limited classification performance. Subsequently, the EfficientNetB0 model was employed through a transfer learning approach, achieving substantially higher validation accuracy (0.96), test accuracy (0.97), and improved generalization capability. The findings clearly demonstrate that EfficientNetB0 surpasses the custom CNN model in brain tumor classification performance. These results indicate that EfficientNetB0 shows strong potential for a reliable and effective tool in supporting diagnostic decision-making for brain tumor assessment.

title: Nonstationary Process Monitoring Based on Analytic Stationary Subspace Analysis: A Space Perspective
authors: Long Gao, Donghua Zhou, Hongquan Ji
publish: 2025 CAA Symposium on Fault Detection, Supervision, and Safety for Technical Processes (SAFEPROCESS)
abstract: Stationary subspace analysis (SSA) is an effective tool for nonstationary process monitoring, by dividing process data into stationary and nonstationary components. However, only stationary components are used for nonstationary monitoring in most of SSA-based methods. Nonstationary components are difficult to monitor because anomalies can be easily masked by trend variations. In this paper, a nonstationary process monitoring method from a space perspective is proposed based on the analytic SSA (ASSA) method. Different from conventional methods, nonstationary components are monitored by constructing a principal angle-based statistic. The corresponding subspace of nonstationary components is invariant in the fault-free case. Motivated by this, anomalies can be monitored by comparing the variation between offline and online nonstationary subspaces. The advantages of the ASSA-based monitoring method are demonstrated on the Tennessee Eastman benchmark process.

title: Micro-transfer Printed Widely Tunable Membrane Laser on a SiN Platform
authors: Takuma Aihara, Yoshiho Maeda, Tatsurou Hiraki, Takuro Fujii, Koji Takeda, Tomonari Sato, Shinji Matsuo
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate an O-band, narro w-line width, widely tunable laser on a SiN platform using micro-transfer printing. A membrane InP-based semiconductor optical amplifier achieves 1.5-dB insertion loss to a SiN waveguide. The laser exhibits 34-nm tuning range, 3.4-kHz Lorentzian linewidth, and 11-mA threshold current at 45°C.

title: Distributing, Routing and Multiplexing O-Band Polarization-Entangled Photons With C-Band Classical Light Over an Operator's Metropolitan Fiber Network
authors: Thomas Rieser, Matheus Sena, Shane Andrewski, Niccolò Bigagli, Mael Flament, Ralf-Peter Braun, Michaela Ritter, Mehdi Namazi, Marc Geitz
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate O-band entanglement distribution over an operator's urban fiber network coexisting with classical C-band light. Our results confirm stable quantum performance under varying classical channel conditions and routing across multiple paths, highlighting the feasibility of real-world entanglement-based quantum networking deployments. ©2025 The Author(s)

title: Service Automation: Effects of Chatbot Implementation on Resource Efficiency and Business Performance in Bulgaria
authors: Ana Todorova, Irina Kostadinova, Svetlana Stefanova
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This paper examines the transformative impact of chatbots on enhancing operational efficiency and business performance within the Bulgarian economy. In the context of growing consumer expectations and challenges to traditional service models, such as limited resources and busy staff, digital assistants offer a strategic solution. By analysing specific case studies from different sectors in Bulgaria, the report demonstrates how chatbots effectively reduce response times, optimise operational costs and ensure 24/7 service availability. The results indicate that automating routine queries frees up human resources for more complex tasks, thereby increasing overall productivity. Advances in artificial intelligence and natural language processing continue to enhance the accuracy of these systems. The study provides evidence of the significant contribution of chatbots to business efficiency, offering valuable insights into digital transformation and future strategies for servicing the Bulgarian market.

title: Real-Time Energy Optimization in Smart Buildings Using Predictive Edge Intelligence
authors: Deepali V Patil, Shripad Joshi, Niranjani V, Nagendar Yamsani, Thella Preethi Priyanka, Vinod Kumar Shukla
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Secure Engineering Solutions (CISES)
abstract: The increasing adoption of smart energy systems has revealed the constraints of centralized cloud architectures, especially concerning real-time data manipulation, energy optimization, and system modularity. In the era of IoT-enabled devices, the necessity for decentralized, efficient solutions is paramount. This study presents an AI- enabled edge computing architecture to enhance smart energy systems through distributed processing, predictive modeling, and autonomous control. The research facilitates the implementation of machine learning models at the network edge, and successfully minimizes latency, increases energy efficiency, and improves scalability when compared to traditional cloud architectures. The comparative study produced improved performance across multiple metrics, including response time, power consumption, and hands-free processing. Furthermore, fundamental challenges have been investigated, such as limited edge device resources, device heterogeneity, and synchronization of data devices. A proof-of- concept implementation has successfully demonstrated the feasibility of the architecture, despite limitations in hardware and device integration. Based on this work, further research will include efforts to further the reliability and sustainability of smart energy systems through real-time control, coordinated mechanisms, and federated learning to enable robust smart energy ecosystems across multiple platforms.

title: Tunnel Diode I-V Measurement and Model Generation from Incomplete Data
authors: Brian Degnan, Francesco Amato, Gregory Durgin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on RFID Technology and Applications (RFID-TA)
abstract: The tunnel diode is a mature device that has recently received new attention for low-powered electronics due to its extraordinarily low zero-bias responsivity. One of the practical challenges with using these discrete devices is measuring the current-voltage (I-V) behavior due to selfoscillation. Although this oscillation may be damped through manual tuning at various biases, the tunnel diode I-V data is typically incomplete or poorly sampled. In this work, we discuss the nuances of picoammeters and testing tunnel diodes. Furthermore, measured data from a commercially available tunnel diode is presented with two methods to automatically create a SPICE model for the device when I-V data is incomplete.

title: Multi-Port Circularly Polarized Antenna for MIMO Communication
authors: Nguyen Tran, Thai Dinh Nguyen, Phuong Kim-Thi, Tu Le-Tuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: This paper presents an approach to design multi-port circularly polarized (CP) multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) antenna with wideband, high-gain, and compact characteristics. The proposed approach is a combination of dual-polarized CP radiating elements and hybrid couplers. The design concept is validated by using four dual-CP radiators and four hybrid couplers for 8-port MIMO array realization. Here, the use of hybrid couplers can excite both elements simultaneously, leading to high gain radiation. Besides, using dual-CP radiators helps to reduce the required radiating elements, resulting in a compact form factor. Simulations of the 8-port antenna with compact overall dimensions of 2.16λ×0.83λ×0.06λ demonstrate a wide operating bandwidth of 14.8% (5.0–5.8GHz). Across this band, the inter-port isolation is always better than 10 dB and the maximum gain of 9.0 dBi is achieved.

title: Dual Wavelength 200 Gbit/s NRZ-OOK Transmission Over 20 km with >30 dB Power Budget Enabled by Quantum-Dot SOAs
authors: Ahmed Galib Reza, Lakshmi Naravanan Venkatasubrarnani, Janina Rautert, Vladimir S. Mikhrin, Alexey Gubenko, Liam P. Barry
publish: 2025 European Conference on Optical Communications (ECOC)
abstract: We demonstrate 200 Gbit/s NRZ-OOK transmissions utilizing two wavelengths in the O-band with channel spacings of 0.7 and 1.1 nm. We achieve 30.1 dB power budget after 20 km at the HD-LOpe BER limit, employing a T-spaced FFE and InAs/GaAs quantum-dot SOA-based booster and pre-amplifiers.

title: Weather-Robust Semantic Segmentation via Unsupervised Augmentation: An End-To-End Approach for Multiple Adverse Conditions
authors: Duc-Hoc Tran, Van-Sang Doan, Thien Huynh-The
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Technologies for Communications (ATC)
abstract: The scarcity of high-quality labeled data significantly degrades the generalizability of deep learning models, particularly in scenarios with diverse and challenging imaging conditions, such as road scenes under heterogeneous environmental variability. This paper investigates key challenges in understanding the context of the road and proposes a hybrid data augmentation strategy to improve the robustness of semantic segmentation in adverse weather conditions, eliminating the dependency on additional annotated datasets. Experiments were conducted on the street dataset to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed data augmentation method. To further assess its efficacy, comparative experiments were performed using three semantic segmentation architectures: Attention-Unet, PSPNet, and DeepLabV3+. The results demonstrate improved performance compared to conventional augmentation methods across both real-world and synthetic datasets.

title: Uncertainties and Emerging Uses of Human-Ai Medical Diagnosis in Collaborative Clinical Practice
authors: António Correia, Benjamim Fonseca, Daniel Schneider, Ramon Chaves, Tommi Kärkkäinen
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: This paper discusses some recent developments in collaborative healthcare research considering settings where human clinicians collaborate through or interact with artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled systems to enhance clinical diagnosis, treatment procedures, and decision-making practices. Through a detailed examination of the potential gaps, implications, and challenges for health professionals and patients, this work explores typical AI-based collaborative clinical workflows and infrastructures that involve tasks such as patient data analysis, medical imaging, and event prediction. A brief synopsis of published research reveals inherent sociotechnical barriers concerning interoperability, data scarcity, bias amplification, trust, and transparency. It also highlights risks related to inadequate model and interface design, the oversimplification of clinical processes (e.g., lack of shared situational awareness), institutional misalignment (e.g., cultural norms and practices shaping how clinicians coordinate their efforts and make decisions based on AI recommendations), and commercial data manipulation that threatens patient care.

title: Adaptive Operation Planning and Intelligent Decision-Making System For Lunar Soil Drilling Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Rui Qiu, Guangcheng Ma, Hao Fu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Multidisciplinary Studies and Innovative Technologies (ISMSIT)
abstract: Autonomous systems play a critical role in the early planning stages of health management and prognostics to ensure reliable and efficient operation in space missions. Presently, there are several technical obstacles that might prevent the use of autonomous robotic drilling along with sampling on the moon. To ensure the successful and reliable operation of regolith sampling missions, it is necessary to study robotic self-adaptive drilling methods on the moon's surface. Previous work by the authors has connected ground drilling sample data with mechanical-soil interaction processes, investigated how lunar soil affects core drilling and load fluctuation states, and more. Afterwards, they offered a plausible assessment of the lunar soil sequence's condition during the drilling phase. The residual useful life (RUL) is predicted using the reliability-adaptive systems technique to avoid maintenance conflicts. In the proposed research, a lunar surface having many systems, such as one base and six rovers, is shown. The rovers drill into the moon's surface to bring back soil samples to Earth. While the lunar materials manufacturing facility is located within a level area, the rovers' duty is to collect dirt or rocks from areas surrounding small obstacles put on the edge of the flat surface. The best way to determine RUL is to monitor the drill's wear. When determining the drill failure rate, a lot of random variables are considered. Some examples of these include radiation, soil temperature relative to the rover, and soil density. Entire Assistance This study introduces a method for predicting drilling forces using machine learning. This study improves control settings and uses a novel method for real-time force forecasting to deliver intelligent lunar drilling that is both safe and efficient. Both the penetrating force and the spinning torque may be precisely predicted by the system. The study also reveals the spatial and temporal relationships between the different drilling state variables. The results of the case study demonstrate that (1) the proposed method of fusing spatiotemporal features has the potential to provide accurate real-time predictions (r = 0.903, mSE = 0.109).
